div.p: THE con≈øideration of the≈øe things is ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary for the purpo≈øe of this Book, that they require not only a deep meditation but the preheminence to take up the fir≈øt thoughts of tho≈øe who would arrive to the knowledge of a thing ≈øo much needful to all mankind. And it may be rea≈øonably feared, that many Women do mi≈øs their de≈øign, becau≈øe they know nothing but the out≈øide of things: ≈øo that in matters of extremity, becau≈øe they are ignorant of the ≈øtructure of the parts, they cannot tell how to go about their work. We ≈øhall therefore begin with the Anatomy of the privy parts, the Organs of generation, whereby through procreation is con≈øerved a perennity of mankind, which nature has denied to particulars. The≈øe parts being not alike in both Sexes, we mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily treat of each apart; and fir≈øt of tho≈øe of Man.

In Man, ≈øome of the≈øe parts afford matter for the Seed, viz. the Spermatic Arteries; others bring back again the blood that is ≈øuperfluous to the making of the Seed, and to the nouri≈øhment of the Stones, and the≈øe are the Spermatic Veins; and both the Arteries and Veins were formerly called preparing
Ve≈ø≈øels. Some make the Seed, as the Stones; ≈øome carry the Seed back again; ≈øome contain the Seed and an oyly matter, as the Seed-bladders the fir≈øt, and the Pro≈øtats the latter. Some di≈øcharge the Seed into the Womb; and this is done by the Yard.

div.head: CHAP. I. Of the Ve≈ø≈øels of Preparation.
div.p: AMong the Spermatic Ve≈ø≈øels are to be con≈øidered fir≈øt, two veins, and two arteries: the≈øe are carried downward from the ≈ømall guts to the Te≈øticles, and are much bigger in Men than they are in Women.

The original of the≈øe Veins is not always the ≈øame; for commonly the right Vein ri≈øeth out of the Hollow vein, a little below the ≈øource or original of the Emulgent; but the lea≈øt takes his original from the lower part of the Emulgent it ≈øelf. Yet ≈øometimes it hath a branch carried to it from the trunk of the hollow Vein.

The middle part of the≈øe veins runs directly through the Loyns, re≈øting upon the Lumbal Mu≈øcle, a thin Membrane only intervening; and thus having gone above half its journey, it branches out and di≈øtributes it ≈øelf to the near adjoyning filmy parts of the Body. The uttermo≈øt part of the≈øe ve≈ø≈øels is carried beyond the Midriff to the Stones, yet do they not pa≈øs through the Peritonaeum, but de≈øcend with a ≈ømall nerve and the Mu≈øcle called Crema≈øter, through the Duplicity of the Midriff; when it approaches near the Stones, it is joyned with an Artery: and now the≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels which were before a little ≈øevered one from the other, are by a film ri≈øing from the Peritonaeum clo≈øed up, and
bound both together; and ≈øo twi≈øting up, like the young tendrils of a Vine, they are carried to the end of the Stones.

The arteries which are a≈ø≈øociated to the≈øe veins, take their original a little beneath the Emulgent vein, whence they de≈øcend downward, and a little from their beginning or original, they are joyn'd to the≈øe veins, till they are clo≈øed together by an Ana≈øtom√¥≈øis or Ino≈øculation, ending like a Piramid.

It has been generally taught, that there are ≈øeveral Ino≈øculations of the Arteries, with the Veins in their pa≈ø≈øage, whereby the blood of the Veins and Arteries are mixed; but ≈øince the knowledge of the Circulation of the Blood, this Opinion has been rejected; for the blood in the Arteries goes down towards the Stones, and that in the veins a≈øcends from them; and therefore if the≈øe two Ve≈ø≈øels ≈øhould open one into the other, the Blood in one of them mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily be thru≈øt back, or el≈øe ≈øtopping, ≈øtretch and break the Ve≈ø≈øels; but the truth is, the blood, both for the nouri≈øhment of the Stones, and the making of Seed, flows down by the Arteries only in an even cour≈øe, without any windings and twinings, like the tendrils of Vines, ≈øo much talked of, as the excellent Anatomi≈øt de Graef ≈øays he has found by frequent in≈øpection. The Veins carry back from the Stones, what of the blood remains from their nouri≈øhment, and making of Seed, and the≈øe indeed come out of the Stones, with a va≈øt number of Roots, whereby they ≈øuck up the ≈øaid Blood, and are mo≈øt admirably interwoven, and ino≈øculated one with another, 'till about four or five fingers breadth above the Stone, which ≈øpace is called the Pyramidal Body.

Two things are to be noted. Fir≈øt, That the≈øe ≈øpermatic Veins have from their ri≈øe to their end ≈øeveral
Valves, which open upwards, and ≈øo ≈øuffer the Blood to a≈øcend towards the hollow Vein, but not to return back again. Secondly, That tho' the Spermatick Arteries go a direct cour≈øe in Men, yet in Brutes they are more complicated, and twi≈øted with the Veins, but without any opening of one into another. There are Nerves and Lympheducts, that pa≈øs into the Te≈øticles together with the Ve≈ø≈øels of preparation.

div.head: CHAP. II. The V≈øe of the preparing Ve≈ø≈øels.
div.p: THE U≈øe of tho≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels which are called the Ve≈ø≈øels of Preparation, is chiefly to attract out of the hollow Vein, or left Emulgent, the mo≈øt pure and exqui≈øitely concocted Blood, which is mo≈øt apt to be converted into Seed; which they contain and prepare, giving unto it a certain rude form of Seed in tho≈øe parts that lie as it were in certain pleights or folds, which they do by a peculiar property bequeathed to them.

Another U≈øe of them is gathered by their ≈øituation; for as they are now ≈øituated, that is to ≈øay, the right Vein coming from the Hollow Vein, and the left from the Emulgent: This incovenience is avoided, that the left Vein is not forced to pa≈øs over the great Artery, and ≈øo be in danger of breaking, by rea≈øon of the ≈øwift motion of the Artery. Moreover, there being a nece≈ø≈øity that Male and Female ≈øhould be begot, it is fit that there ≈øhould be Seed proper for the generation of both Sexes, whereof ≈øome mu≈øt be hotter, and ≈øome mu≈øt be colder; and therefore Nature hath ≈øo ordered it, that the hotter Seed ≈øhould proceed from the right Vein for the generation of man, and the colder from the left, for the generation of Females. The left
Vein hath al≈øo this property to draw from the Emulgent the more ≈øerous and le≈øs pure Blood, to the intent that the ≈øerous humour might ≈øtir up Venery by its ≈øalt and acrimonious ≈øub≈øtance; and therefore it is ob≈øerved, that tho≈øe who have the left Stone bigger, are mo≈øt full of Seed, and mo≈øt prone to Venery.

The≈øe Veins are ≈øo far from preparing the Seed, as that they only bring back, what was ≈øuperfluous from the making it. And indeed the Arteries in Men do no more merit the name of preparing Ve≈ø≈øels, in regard to the Seed, than the Gullet in re≈øpect of the Chyle, or the chyliferous thoracick duct, in regard to the Blood. But however we continue the old Names, declaring only again≈øt the rea≈øon of them.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the Para≈øtatae, or Ve≈ø≈øels where the Blood is fir≈øt changed.
div.p: THESE four Ve≈ø≈øels after many ingraftings and knittings together, ≈øeem at length to become only two bodies, full of little crumplings like the tendril of a Vine, white, and in the form of a Piramid, re≈øting the right upon the right Stone, and the left upon the left Stone. The≈øe are called Para≈øtatae, which, as they ≈øtand, pierce the tunicles of each Stone with certain fibers or extraordinary ≈ømall Veins, which afterwards di≈øper≈øe them≈øelves through the body of tho≈øe Stones. The ≈øub≈øtance of the≈øe Para≈øtatae is between that of the Stones, and that of the Preparing Ve≈ø≈øels; for they neither altogether con≈øi≈øt of Membranes, neither are they altogether Glandulous or Kernelly.

Upon the Stones, as yet clad with the tunica albuginea, are fixed the epididymidae, called al≈øo Para≈øtatae; the≈øe do not differ from the Stones, only the≈øe con≈øi≈øts
of divers ducts, but tho≈øe, after their ≈øix or ≈øeven Roots, that ri≈øe out of the Stone, are united, (which they are in a ≈øhort ≈øpace) but of one, only a little thicker, and the Para≈øtatae differ not from the va≈øa deferentia; ≈øaving, that tho≈øe go by a winding pa≈ø≈øage; and the≈øe by a ≈øtreight, and that tho≈øe are a little ≈øofter, and narrower.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of the Te≈øticles in general.
div.p: THE Stones are in number two, very ≈øeldom one, and much ≈øeldomer 3 or 4 The ≈øituation of the Stones in Men is without the Midriff, at the root of the Yard under the belly; and that for two cau≈øes, to keep men more cha≈øte; it being ob≈øerved, that tho≈øe creatures which carry their ≈øtones within their Bodies, are more ≈øalacious, and bring forth in great numbers.
Their bigne≈øs is not always alike in all Creatures, but in men as big as a Pigeons Egg, or as a ≈ømall Hens Egg; and commonly the left is bigger than the right.

In the Anatomy of the Stones, divers things are to be con≈øidered. Their Tunicles, or the skins in which they are wrapt, as well tho≈øe which are common to both, as tho≈øe which are peculiar to either; next, the mu≈øcles; then, the ≈øub≈øtance of which they are compo≈øed; and la≈øtly, the Ve≈ø≈øels which are di≈øper≈øed through the body of the ≈øtones.

The Stones in Latin, are called Te≈øtes, either becau≈øe they te≈øtifie one to be a Man, or becau≈øe among≈øt the Romans, none could bear witne≈øs but he that had them. They have a peculiar ≈øub≈øtance, ≈øuch as is not in all the Body be≈øides, whiti≈øh and ≈øoft, made up of
an innumerable little Ropes of Seed carrying Ve≈ø≈øels. There is no cavity in them, but tho≈øe ≈øaid Ve≈ø≈øels are continued to one another, and carry the Seed in their undi≈øcernable hollowne≈øs. Hippocrates held the right to be bigger and hotter than the left, and therefore called it the Male-getter, and the left the Female-getter; the≈øe fancies ≈øeem ridiculous, ≈øeeing there is no ≈øuch difference of their bigne≈øs, and that their Ve≈ø≈øels are common; they have Arteries and Veins from the preparing Ve≈ø≈øels, which ≈øome have thought to reach only to the inmo≈øt coat, becau≈øe they are not con≈øpicuous in the inner ≈øub≈øtance; but that comes to pa≈øs, by rea≈øon that the arterial Blood pre≈øently lo≈øes its colour, and, by the ≈øeminifick faculty of the Stones, is turned into Seed, which being whiti≈øh, of the ≈øame colour with the Ve≈ø≈øels, makes them undi≈øcernible; yet in tho≈øe men, that have died of langui≈øhing Di≈øea≈øes, and who≈øe Stones have their faculty impaired, Diemerbroeck ≈øays, that he has often ≈øeen Blood-bringing Ve≈ø≈øels in the inmo≈øt parts of the Stones, and has ≈øhew'd them to many, in the publick Anatomick Theatre: As to Nerves, Dr. Willis affirms, that he could never ob≈øerve more to go to them, than one from a vertebral pair, and that too was mo≈øt of it ≈øpent upon the Mu≈øcle crema≈øter. Concerning the U≈øe of this Nerve, there is a great Controver≈øie, Dr. Gli≈ø≈øon, Dr. Wharton, and others, will have it convey a ≈øeedy Juice, which makes the greate≈øt part of the Seed: But Dr. Willis is of another Opinion; however the Seed mu≈øt needs con≈øi≈øt of a nervous Juice, and plenty of Spirits brought from the Brain, becau≈øe of the great weakne≈øs, and enervation that is induced upon the Brain, and Nerves, by too great an u≈øe of Venery.

Lympheducts they have al≈øo, ari≈øing from betwixt
their coats, and a≈øcending upwards into the belly with the Va≈øa Deferentia: the≈øe have many valves looking upwards, which hinder any thing from de≈øcending by them to the Stones, but permit the Lympha to a≈øcend, which they convey into the Chyliferous Ve≈ø≈øels.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the Tunicles of the Stones.
div.p: THE Tunicles are wrapt up in divers coverings about the number of which there hath been great di≈ø≈øention. But they are now reduced to five, whereof two are common, and are called Scrotum, and Dartos; three particular, the names of which are Elytroides, Erythroides and Epididymis.

The fir≈øt of the≈øe, which is like a Satchel or Pur≈øe, and is common to both, con≈øi≈øts of a skin and a cuticle. This contains the two Stones like a Pur≈øe, and is obvious to the touch. The skin of this part differs from any other part of the skin which covers the body: for whereas that is ≈øtretched out and ≈øpread clo≈øe over the body, this is more loo≈øe, and made to ≈øtretch out, or to be wrinkled up together as occa≈øion is; that is, as the ≈øtones either a≈øcend, or de≈øcend: they a≈øcend commonly in the time of Conjunction; they de≈øcend in Fevers, weakne≈øs of the Te≈øticles, or by rea≈øon of old age.

The ≈øecond Tunicle.The ≈øecond is called Dartos, becau≈øe it is ea≈øily ≈øeparated from the others. In this, the Te≈øticles lie as it were in a ne≈øt, wrapping them about more clo≈øe than the Scrotum doth. It takes its original from the Fle≈øhy Pannicle, which though it be thinner hereabouts than in any other part of the body, yet it is full of little veins and arteries.

The proper Tunicles, are,The proper Tunicle. fir≈øt the Elytroides, which is al≈øo called Vaginalis, by rea≈øon it ≈øupplies the office of a ≈øheath. It takes its original from the production of the Peritonaeum, for where the ≈øpermatick Ve≈ø≈øels pa≈øs, they do not at all brui≈øe the Peritonaeum, but carry it down to the Stones, and ≈øo con≈øtitute or make this Tunicle. To know this Tunicle, and the original of it, is very nece≈ø≈øary for Phy≈øick, becau≈øe that hollowne≈øs, which the Proce≈ø≈øes of the Peritonaeum do make for the pa≈ø≈øage of the ≈øpermatick Ve≈ø≈øels, is ≈øometimes dilated as far as the beginning, or ≈øource of this Tunicle, and both the ≈ømall guts and the Kall fall down upon the Te≈øticles, which is the cau≈øe of that kind of Bur≈øtne≈øs, which by the Phy≈øicians is called Enterocele. This Tunicle grows to that which is called Dartos, being joyned to it by many nervous fibres. Underneath this is a Tunicle, called Erythroides, or the red Tunicle; ≈øo called from the multitude of red veins which are ≈øprinkled up and down in it. It ri≈øes from the other Membranes, and is encompa≈ø≈øed without by the fir≈øt proper Tunick.

The third, and that which immediately compa≈ø≈øeth the ≈øtones, is that which is called Epididymis: it is white, thick, and ≈øtrong, to pre≈øerve the ≈øoft and loo≈øe ≈øub≈øtance of the Stones. It ri≈øeth from the Tunicle of the ≈øeminal Ve≈ø≈øels, being the thicke≈øt of all the Tunicles, and hath ≈øome few veins ≈øcattered up and down in it.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of the ≈øu≈øpen≈øory Mu≈øcles.
div.p:
TO keep the Stones from oppre≈ø≈øing, or ≈øtretching over-much the pa≈ø≈øages of the ≈øeminal Ve≈ø≈øels,
Nature hath provided them two mu≈øcles for them to hang by, on both ≈øides one, in form oblong and ≈ølender.

The Original of the≈øe Mu≈øcles.The≈øe Mu≈øcels derive their original from a thick membrane, which is joyned to the Hanchbone, in the further part of that region, where the hair grows; and is fa≈øtned to this bone with certain fle≈øhy and ≈øtraight fibres; where the oblique Mu≈øcles of the Abdomen or Midriff end, thence reaching down upon the ≈øuperiour Members of the Te≈øticles, they are extended through the whole length of that round Body.
The≈øe Mu≈øcles are never ≈øeen in Women, being altogether u≈øele≈øs, becau≈øe their Stones are not pendent, but are inclo≈øed within their bodies.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of the ≈øub≈øtance and temper of the Stones.
div.p: THE ≈øub≈øtance of the Stones is glandulous, or kernelly, white, ≈øoft, loo≈øe, ≈øpongy and hollow, having ≈øundry ve≈ø≈øels di≈øper≈øed thorow them.

Now although the ≈øub≈øtance of the Te≈øticles be mo≈øt ≈øoft and moi≈øt, yet doth not this moi≈øtne≈øs con≈øtitute an uniform, or homogeneal body; for the ≈øub≈øtance of the Stones is wholly di≈ø≈øimilar, and full of fibres. The≈øe fibres al≈øo ≈øeem to be of a different ≈øub≈øtance from that of the Stones, being only cloathed with the fle≈øh of the Stones, as the fibres of the Mu≈øcles are inwardly nervous, but covered over with the fle≈øh of the Mu≈øcles. The≈øe fibres again differ in this, that the fibres of the Te≈øticles are hollow, but the fibres of the Stones full and ≈øub≈øtantial. The≈øe fibres are ≈øaid to come from the ≈øpermatic ve≈ø≈øels, and thence branch them≈øelves forth thorow the Te≈øticles, by which that
part of the Seed, which is over and above what ≈øerves for the nouri≈øhment of the Te≈øticles, is drawn forth and kept for procreation.

As concerning the temper of the Stones, they would ≈øooner be thought cold than hot, if that Maxim, were true, that, All white things are cold, and all red things hot. Notwith≈øtanding, becau≈øe nature is known to abhor all coldne≈øs in the work of generation; Therefore we mu≈øt pre≈øume to affirm the temper of the Stones to be hot, for they always abound with blood, and a pure ≈øpirit that can never be without heat: be≈øides that, heat is requir'd for the concoction of this blood, and the changing it into ≈øeed; yet, it is very temperate, as appears by the ≈øoftne≈øs of the ≈øub≈øtance: for as coldne≈øs and drine≈øs is the cau≈øe of hardne≈øs, ≈øo heat and moi≈øture is the cau≈øe of ≈øoftne≈øs.

Neverthele≈øs, we are to under≈øtand this, that the temper of the Stones are not alike in all, for in ≈øome they are far colder than in others. And therefore tho≈øe, who have hot Te≈øticles, are more ≈øalacious and prone to venereal actions, having the places near about much more hairy, and their Te≈øticles much harder than others. Tho≈øe that have their Te≈øticles cold, find every thing contrary.

The greate≈øt heat is in the right Te≈øticle, becau≈øe it receives more pure, and hotter blood from the hollow Vein, and the great Artery; the left colder, becau≈øe it receives a more impure, and ≈øerous blood from the Emulgent Vein.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of the Actions of the Te≈øticles.
div.p:
THE action, and u≈øe of the Te≈øticles, is, To generate Seed, a gift which they obtain from an
inbred quality, which Nature hath be≈øtowed upon them. For the blood being received by the ≈øpermatic Ve≈ø≈øels, and there beginning to change its colour, is by and by received by the deferent Ve≈ø≈øels, or the ve≈ø≈øels which carry the blood ≈øo prepared to the Te≈øticles; where it is for a while contained, and afterwards being carried to the Stones, is by them made Seed, and the la≈øt work perfected. And it may with more ea≈øine≈øs be affirmed, that the Seed is generated by the Stones, becau≈øe every like is ≈øaid to generate its like; now the ≈øub≈øtance of the Te≈øticles is very like the Seed it ≈øelf, that is, white, moi≈øt, and vi≈øcous. Whether the Stones are the only efficient cau≈øe of the Seed is not here to be di≈øputed, being only a nice point, and no way profitable. We ≈øhall rather with ≈øilence adhere to that opinion, which affirms the function of the Te≈øticles to be the generation of the Seed, which is mo≈øt likely; and proceed to the next.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Concerning the Utility of the Te≈øticles and their parts.
div.p:
THE ≈øtructure of the Te≈øticles being thus known; it remains that we ≈øhew you their u≈øe. This is fir≈øt di≈øcovered from their ≈øituation. For of tho≈øe Creatures that have Stones, ≈øome have them in their bodies, as all Fowl; others have them without, though not pendent; others have them hanging downward, as men. Men therefore have their Te≈øticles without their bodies for two cau≈øes; fir≈øt, becau≈øe it is required that the Te≈øticles of the Male ≈øhould be bigger and hotter than tho≈øe of the Female; ≈øo that it were impo≈ø≈øible for them to be contained within the body, becau≈øe of their quantity. Be≈øides, the Seed of the
Male being the effective original of the Creature, and therefore hotte≈øt; it is al≈øo required that the Seed ≈øhould be more abundant than could be contained in the Te≈øticles, were they placed within the body: for the ≈øeminary pa≈ø≈øages mu≈øt have been le≈øs, and the veins them≈øelves would not have afforded ≈øuch plenty of matter as now they do.

The motion of the Te≈øticles is al≈øo to be con≈øidered; by which they move ≈øometimes upward and ≈øometimes downward. The one of the≈øe motions which is made upward is voluntary, as being made by the Mu≈øcles; but the motion downward is a forced motion, not hapning without the laxity of the Mu≈øcles; the Te≈øticles, through their own weight, falling downwards. The≈øe Mu≈øcles are called Crema≈øters, their u≈øe being to draw up the Te≈øticles to ≈øhorten the way of the Ejaculation of the Seed; as al≈øo to keep the ve≈ø≈øels from being di≈øtended too far by the weight of the Te≈øticles.

The u≈øe of the Tunicles is now to be ≈øpoken of; and fir≈øt, of that which is outermo≈øt, and is called by the Latins Scrotum, being the pur≈øe wherein the Te≈øticles are contained. It is made to wrinkle it ≈øelf up, and to let it ≈øelf loo≈øe, that it may be large enough for the Te≈øticles when they ≈øwell with plenty of Seed, and to wrinkle up again, when the Te≈øticles being emptied, and ≈øo becoming le≈øs, are drawn upward. The other Coats, or Tunicles, are al≈øo made for the defence of the Stones, but ≈øo thin and light that they ≈øhould not oppre≈øs the Stones with their weight; that which is called Erythroides hath many veins for the nouri≈øhment of the adjacent parts. The Epididymis was made to wrap the Te≈øticle round about, le≈øt the Humid matter of the Te≈øticle ≈øhould flow about, and con≈øequently be wa≈øted.

div.head: CHAP. X. Of the Ve≈ø≈øels that ca≈øt forth their Seed.
div.p: THat pa≈ø≈øage which comes from the head of the Te≈øticles to the root of the Yard, is called the Ejaculatory Ve≈ø≈øel. This, as I ≈øaid before, ri≈øes from the head of the Te≈øticles, and joyning downward to the Te≈øticle, de≈øcends to the bottom, and thence being reflected again, and annext to the preparing Ve≈ø≈øel, it returns again to the head of the Te≈øticle; from thence it proceeds upward from the Te≈øticles, till it touch the bone of the ≈ømall guts, ≈øtill keeping clo≈øe to the preparing Ve≈ø≈øel, till it pierce the production of the Hypoga≈øtrium. Thence tending downward through the hollowne≈øs of the hip, it ≈ølides between the bladder and the ≈øtreight Gut, till it reach the glandulous Pro≈øtatae, or Fore≈øtanders, and fix it ≈øelf at the foot, or root of the Yard, and there end. It is not all one at the beginning, and at the end; for at the beginning, while it remains among the Tunicles of the Te≈øticles, it is full of windings and turnings; near the end, it hath many little bladders like to warts.

Now we mu≈øt under≈øtand that the≈øe Seminary Ve≈ø≈øels do not only contain the Seed, but they perfect and concoct it, having a ≈øeminifick, or Seed-making quality, which they borrow from the Te≈øticles: There are other u≈øes of the≈øe ≈øeminary Ve≈ø≈øels, for, near the original of this ve≈ø≈øel, that is to ≈øay, the head of the Te≈øticles, many ≈ømall pa≈ø≈øages, or as it were conduit-pipes, do ≈øtretch them≈øelves forward into the body of the Te≈øticle, into which the genital Seed that remains is remitted, and al≈øo drawn, or ≈øucked from tho≈øe pa≈ø≈øages; this ≈øeminary pa≈ø≈øage is at length wound above the Te≈øticles, adjoyning all along, but
no where incorporated into the body of the Te≈øticle, unle≈øs at the bottom, in which place it is thought that the Seed doth again in≈øinuate it ≈øelf into the Te≈øticles through tho≈øe hollow fibres: being thence propagated, and continually making ≈øupply to the Stones.

It is to be noted al≈øo, that the≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels while they move to the root of the Yard, do not go by ≈øtreight pa≈ø≈øages, which would be then very ≈øhort but by crooked windings and turnings making the pa≈ø≈øages as long as may be, that they may have longer time to contain and prepare the Seed.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Of the Seminary Bladders.
div.p: AT the end of the Deferent Ve≈ø≈øels on both ≈øides, are certain little bladders, knit, and joyned together, and placed between the Bladder and the right gut; the la≈øt of which, together with the ≈øeminary Ve≈ø≈øel, is terminated, in the Pro≈øtatae, or Fore≈øtanders, by a little channel.

The≈øe Bladders have two ≈øeveral u≈øes; for they do not only ≈øtrengthen the ≈øeminary Ve≈ø≈øels where they end, but al≈øo ≈øeem to be the ≈øtores and magazeens of the Seed. They are many, that every time a man u≈øes the act of Venery, he may have a new ≈øupply of matter from the≈øe ≈øeveral ve≈øicles. Thus that which is next the Yard being fir≈øt disburdened, the ≈øecond is the next time emptied, and ≈øo till all the ≈øtore is ≈øpent; and, were it not for the≈øe ve≈øicles, a man could not lie with a woman more than once.

In the≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels ≈øuch is the propen≈øity of Nature to propagate, let the body be never ≈øo much emaciated, there is always found a le≈ø≈øer or greater quantity of Seed. They are hollow and round, to contain a
greater quantity of Seed; they are al≈øo full of membranes, that they may be contracted or extended as the plenty of Seed requires; they are crooked and full of windings and turnings, that the Seed contained may not ea≈øily ≈ølip out.

The≈øe ≈ømall Bladders are little Cells, like tho≈øe in a Pomgranate, or ≈øomething like a bunch of Grapes. De Graef compares them to the guts of a little Bird, diver≈øly contorted. They con≈øi≈øt of one thin membrane, thro' which ≈øome ≈ømall twigs run, both of Veins, Arteries, and Nerves; they are about three Fingers breadth long, and one broad, but in ≈øome places broader, and ≈øome narrower, as they run in and out. They are two divided from one another by a little inter≈øtice, and they do ≈øeverally, by a peculiar pa≈ø≈øage, ca≈øt the Seed contained in them into the Urethra: they are very winding, and con≈øi≈øt of many little Cells, that they ≈øhould not pour out all the Seed contained in them in one act of Copulation, but might retain it for ≈øeveral; they have no communication one with another, not even in their very opening into the Urethra, but the Seed that is brought to the≈øe little bladders on the right ≈øide i≈ø≈øues by its proper pa≈ø≈øage into the Urethra, and that which is brought to the left likewi≈øe, ≈øo that if by any accident the bladders on the one ≈øide be bur≈øt or cut, as in cuting for the Stone they mu≈øt needs be, yet tho≈øe on the other being entire may ≈øtill ≈øuffice for generation. When the Seed is ca≈øt out of the≈øe bladders in the act of generation, it pa≈ø≈øes out the ≈øame way it came in, which in this ca≈øe may ea≈øily be, tho' it be unu≈øual there ≈øhould be a contrary motion in the ≈øame ve≈ø≈øel; for when it comes in, it drills along gently without any force, but in Copulation when the Mu≈øcles of the Yard, and all the bordering
parts are much ≈øwelled, it is ≈øquirted out of them with ≈øome violence, and pa≈ø≈øing along their neck, ouzes thro' a Caruncle like quick Silver thro' leather into the Urethra, or Duct of the Yard, that is common both to the Seed and Urine. I ≈øay, it ouzes from the necks of the Bladders thro' a Caruncle into the Urethra; for there is one placed as a valve before the Orifice of each of them, partly to hinder the coming of the Urine into them, partly to hinder the involuntary effu≈øion of the Seed. Now tho' the little holes thro' which the Seed pa≈ø≈øes out of the necks of the ≈ømall bladders into the Urethra, be naturally almo≈øt imperceptible, yet, if they be either eroded by the acrimony of the Seed, contracted by impure Copulation, or if of them≈øelves they be weakened and ≈øo become more Laxe, as ≈øometimes happens to old o ‚Ä¢ impotent Men that u≈øe Copulation too frequently, then there happens a Gonorrhea, or continual Flux of Seed.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Of the kernelly Pro≈øtatae, or Fore≈øtanders.
div.p:
THE glandulous Pro≈øtatae, or Fore≈øtanders, are two little Te≈øticles, as it were ≈øeated at the foot of the Yard, a little above the Sphincter of the Urinary Ve≈ø≈øels; they are wrapt about with a membrane, which doth al≈øo cloath the ≈øeminary Ve≈ø≈øels and ve≈øicles: before and behind they ≈øeem more flat, on the ≈øides they are more round; they have a ≈øub≈øtance like other kernels, loo≈øe and ≈øpongy, only they differ from them by rea≈øon of their whitene≈øs and hardne≈øs, they are endued with an exqui≈øite feeling, to ≈øtir up greater de≈øire of Copulation. The≈øe Glandulae or kernels have certain pores that open them≈øelves into
the Urethra, through which the Seed (the≈øe Fore≈øtanders being ≈øqueezed by the lower Mu≈øcles of the Yard) di≈øtils into the Yard.

The u≈øe of the≈øe Kernels are partly to beget an oyly, fat, and ≈ølippery ≈øub≈øtance, with which the urinary pa≈ø≈øage is ≈øometimes anointed, to defend it from the acrimony both of the Seed and Urin, and to keep it always moi≈øt.

The other u≈øe is taken from the name of Pro≈øtatae; which word, in the ≈øingular number, ≈øignifies a Tutor or Defender; for they are there placed to pre≈øerve and ≈øtrengthen the ends of the Deferent Ve≈ø≈øels, le≈øt by overmuch di≈øtention of the Yard, the Seminary Ve≈ø≈øels ≈øhould be either bur≈øt, or moved out of their places.

They have a third u≈øe: For, being placed between the Bladder and the right gut, they ≈øerve in≈øtead of Cu≈øhions for the Ve≈ø≈øels to re≈øt upon, and to guard them from all compre≈ø≈øion: Hence it happens ≈øometimes that tho≈øe who are very much bound in their bodies, while they ≈øtrain them≈øelves over-vehemently, do now and then void a kind of Seed, which happens by a violent compre≈ø≈øion of tho≈øe parts.

The Pro≈øtats, in Engli≈øh, ≈øtanders by, or waiters, are placed near to the Seed-Bladders. De Graef calls them the glandulous body, ≈øuppo≈øing them to be one body, and only divided by the common ducts of the ≈øeed-bladders, and the va≈øa deferentia coming through the mid≈øt of it. They are of a white, ≈øpungy, glandulous ≈øub≈øtance, about as big as a ≈ømall Wall-nut, encompa≈ø≈øed with a ≈øtrong and fibrous Membrane from the Bladder, to the beginning of who≈øe neck they are joined at the root of the Yard; in ≈øhape they come neare≈øt to an Oval, ≈øave that on their upper and lower part, they are a little depre≈ø≈øed, and in that end,
whereby the va≈øa deferentia enter, they are ≈øomewhat hollow like a Tunnel.

The ≈øphincter Mu≈øcle of the Bladder encompa≈ø≈øes them ≈øo, that for ≈øo far as they cover the neck of the Bladder, the ≈øphincter touches it not, they coming between. They have all ≈øorts of ve≈ø≈øels which run chiefly on their out-≈øide, in the inner part, they have ten or more ≈ømall Ducts, which unload them≈øelves into the Urethra, by the ≈øides of the great Caruncle, thro' which the Seed pa≈ø≈øes from the Seed Bladders into the Urethra; but them≈øelves have each one, a ≈ømall one to ≈øtop its Orifice, lea≈øt the liquor that is contained in the Pro≈øtats, ≈øhould continually flow out, or the Urine flow in: and the≈øe ≈ømall Ducts, I ≈øuppo≈øe, are continued from tho≈øe ≈ømall Bladders which are ≈øeen in the Pro≈øtats of tho≈øe that dye ≈øuddenly, after having had to do with a Female; for in ≈øuch, the ≈øpungy part of the Pro≈øtats is very full of a thin liquor, and in their inner part may be found the ≈øame ≈ømall bladders, which if you pre≈øs upon, they will di≈øcharge them≈øelves into the above ≈øaid Ducts. There is a great variety of Opinions, what the liquor in them ≈øhould be, or what is their u≈øe: Some think that the Seed that flows from the Te≈øticles, is further elaborated here; but that cannot be, becau≈øe the va≈øa deferentia depo≈øit nothing in them, but all into the ≈ømall Seed Ve≈ø≈øels. Others think, that there is ≈øeparated from the Blood in them, an acrimonious and ≈øerous humour which ≈øerves for Titulation, or cau≈øing the greater plea≈øure in Venery. As to this, de Graef appeals to the ta≈øte of it, which has nothing of Acrimony in it. Dr. Wharton thinks they make a particular kind of Seed, as the Stones do another, and the Seed Bladders a third; that the≈øe la≈øt make a different Seed from that made in the Stones, is
grounded on a mi≈øtake in Anatomy, viz. That the va≈øa deferentia have no communication with the Seed-Bladders, whereas they apparently open into them, and de≈øpo≈øite in them all the Seed they contain; that the Pro≈øtats make a peculiar ≈øort, he endeavours to prove, becau≈øe gelded Animals emit ≈øome Seed; but tho' they do emit ≈øomething, it is not nece≈ø≈øary it ≈øhould be any true Seed; or if it be, it may well be ≈øuppo≈øed to proceed from the ≈ømall Seed-Bladders that were full when the Animal was gelt; for this rea≈øon it has been ob≈øerved, that pre≈øently after gelding, they have ≈øometimes got the Female with Young, but not afterwards when that ≈øtock was ≈øpent. Others think they make an oyly and ≈ølippery humour, which is pre≈ø≈øed out opon occa≈øion to be≈ømear the Urethra, to defend it from the acrimony of the Seed and Urine, and le≈øt it ≈øhould dry up. De Graef believes, that the Humour that is ≈øeparated in the Pro≈øtats, ≈øerves for a vehicle of the Seed, which flowing but in ≈ømall quantity, thro' ≈ømall Poors into the Urethra, it was nece≈ø≈øary, that this Humour ≈øhould be mixed with it, that it might the better reach the Womb; whatever this Humour be, it is ≈øqueezed out partly by the ≈øwelling and erection of the Yard, and partly, by compre≈ø≈øion of the ≈øphincter of the Bladder, that girds the Pro≈øtats about: The≈øe Pro≈øtats are often the ≈øeat of a Gonorrhaea, and the Humour they contain, is that which flows out in the running of the Reins; for if it were true Seed, they could never endure a Gonorrhaea ≈øo long, ≈øome thirty Years, without being much wa≈øted, the flux being ≈øo much as ≈øometimes it is.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. Of the ≈øtructure of the Yard.
div.p: THE ≈øtructure of the Yard is not unknown, that is to ≈øay, at the root of the ≈øhare bone in the hinder part of the Hypoga≈øtrion or lower part of the belly, where the hair grows; which bone is called, Os pubis. Though the greate≈øt part of it, is not pendent without, but adjoining to the Podex, is ≈øituated near the joining of the ≈øhare-bone, being fa≈øt knit to it in the Perinaeum, or ≈øpace between the Cods and the Fundament; the other part is pendent and is ≈øeen hanging outward. This ≈øituation is mo≈øt appropriated to the manner of the act of generation, u≈øual and peculiar to men, who do not couple after the manner of Bea≈øts. The figure of it is in a manner round, though not exactly; broader in the upper part which is called the back of the Yard.

The thickne≈øs and longitude of the Yard is ≈øo much as is required for Procreation; yet it is not ≈øo long as in many other creatures. Yea, and in ≈øeveral men there is a very great diver≈øity; little men being for the mo≈øt part, be≈øt provided in that part: It is a general received opinion, that the often u≈øe of Venery doth increa≈øe the quantity of it in all dimen≈øions.

The Yard will al≈øo be longer, if the Navel-≈øtrings are not bound up, or knit too clo≈øe by the Midwife, in Children that are newly born; but at ≈øome di≈øtance from the Navel: This happens by rea≈øon of the Ligament coming from the Navel to the bottom of the Bladder; which if it be too much abreviated, draws up the Bladder, and con≈øequently ≈øhortens the Yard; but if the Navel-≈øtring be left at a longer di≈øtance, the Urachus is enlarged, and con≈øequently the Yard hath
more liberty to extend it ≈øelf; And therefore the Midwives are from hence adverti≈øed, that they do not ≈øpoil the harve≈øt of generation, by cutting the ≈øithe too ≈øhort.

As to the ≈øub≈øtance of the Yard; it is not of a bony ≈øub≈øtance, as in Dogs, Wolves, or Foxes; for ≈øo it would become always hard and erected, and hinder men from all bu≈øine≈øs but the act of Venery: Neither is it gri≈øtly, for ≈øo it could neither erect it ≈øelf, nor flag, when occa≈øion required: Neither is it full of veins, for ≈øo it could not be emptied and repleted on ≈øuch a ≈øudden as often happens; be≈øides, the Tunicles of the veins are ≈øo thin, that they could not ≈øuffer ≈øo great a di≈øtention; neither can it be full of Arteries, becau≈øe it wants a continual pul≈øation; neither can it con≈øi≈øt of Nerves, becau≈øe they having no hollowne≈øs, cannot be extended and loo≈øned, as it mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øity happen to the Yard. It is therefore nece≈ø≈øary that the Yard ≈øhould have ≈øuch a ≈øub≈øtance, as is not peculiar to any part of the body. It is to be under≈øtood, that there do concur to the framing of the Yard, two nervous bodies, the pa≈ø≈øage for the Urine which is called Urethra, the Glans or Nut of the Yard, four Mu≈øcles, the Ve≈ø≈øels, and the skin.

Here doth ari≈øe a que≈øtion, why the Yard hath not any fat? Which is in brief, thus; becau≈øe that there ≈øhould be no hindrance to the perfect ≈øen≈øe of the Yard, which could of nece≈ø≈øity not be avoided, if that member were ≈øubject to any obe≈øity; the fat being ≈øubject to be melted by frication.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. Of the ≈øeveral parts con≈øtituting the Yard.
div.p:
AMONG the parts that compo≈øe the ≈øtructure of the Yard, is that skin which with its cuticle,
and fle≈øhly pannicle, is common not only to this, but to other members; only it hath this peculiar to it ≈øelf, that it may be reflexed, and drawn back from the Nut of the Yard. This skin that turns back is called the Praeputium; becau≈øe that part in circumci≈øion was cut away; with which prepuce, the Nut of the Yard is covered.

The Glans or Nut of the Yard is a fle≈øhy part, ≈øoft, thin,The Nut of the Yard. repleat with blood and ≈øpirits; endued with an exqui≈øite ≈øen≈øe; ≈øomething ≈øharp and acute at the end. This is fa≈øtned to the prepuce at the lower part by a certain ligament, which is therefore called the bridle, or the filet, which commonly is broken in the fir≈øt venereal a≈ø≈øaults, which are for the mo≈øt part the mo≈øt furious.

The greate≈øt part of the Yard is con≈øtituted by two nervous bodies,The two nervous bodies. on both ≈øides one, which terminate both together in the Nut. They ri≈øe from a two-fold original, leaning or re≈øting upon the Hip, under the Share-bone; whence as from a ≈øure foundation they go on, till they arrive at the nut of the Yard.

They con≈øi≈øt of a double ≈øub≈øtance, the fir≈øt is nervous, hard,Their ≈øub≈øtance. and thick; the inner part black, loo≈øe, ≈øoft, thin, and ≈øpongy. It is called the Nervous pipe. The≈øe two bodies are joyned together by a certain membrane, thin, yet nervous; which is ≈øtrengthned by certain overthwart fibres, being there placed in the likene≈øs of a Weavers ≈øhuttle: and though in their original they are ≈øeparated the one from the other, that there might remain ≈øome certain ≈øpace for the Urethra; yet they are joyned together about the
middle of the Share-bone; where they lo≈øe about the third part of their nervous ≈øub≈øtance.

The interiour ≈øub≈øtance, which is wrapt about by the exteriour nervous ≈øub≈øtance, hath this worthy ob≈øervation, That there appears ≈øtretched, through the whole length of it, a thin and tender Artery, proportionable to the bigne≈øs of the body which is diffu≈øed through the whole loo≈øe ≈øub≈øtance of the Yard, reaching as far as the root of the Yard. Be≈øides the≈øe two, there is another body which lies between the≈øe two, as proper or rather more peculiar to the Yard than they are. This is a pipe placed at the inferiour part of the Yard, being called the Urethra, though it be a pa≈ø≈øage as proper to the Seed, as to the Urine; which is encompa≈ø≈øed by the two fore-mentioned bodies. This is a certain Channel produced in length, and running through the middle of tho≈øe nervous bodies, con≈øi≈øting of the ≈øame ≈øub≈øtance that they do, being loo≈øe, thick, ≈øoft, and tender; every way equal from the neck of the bladder to the nut of the Yard, ≈øaving that it is a little wider at the beginning, than it is toward the place where it ends, which is at the head of the Glans or nut of the Yard.

The holes of the Vrethra.At the beginning of this Channel there are three holes; one in the middle, and ≈øomething bigger than the other two, ari≈øing from the neck of the bladder; the other two, on both ≈øides one, being ≈øomething narrower, proceeding from the pa≈ø≈øage that goes out of the ≈øeminary ve≈ø≈øels, and conveighs the Seed into this Channel.

This is further to be noted in this place, that in the Channel, where it is joyned to the Glans, together with the nervous bodies, there is a little kind of cavern,
in which ≈øometimes either putrid Seed,Note. or any other corroding humour, happens in the Gonorrhaea; being collected, it is the cau≈øe of ulcers in that part, the cau≈øe of very great pain: and it many times al≈øo comes to pa≈øs, that there is a certain little piece of fle≈øh which grows out of this Ulcer, that oftentimes ≈øtops the pa≈ø≈øages of the urine.

To the ≈øtructure of the Yard,The Mu≈øcles of the Yard. there do moreover occurr two pair of Mu≈øcles, one more ≈øhort and thick, proceeding from a part of the Hip, near the beginning of the Yard, and being of a fle≈øhy ≈øub≈øtance. The u≈øe of the≈øe two Mu≈øcles, is to ≈øu≈øtain the Yard in the erection; and to bend the fore part of the Yard, which is to be in≈øerted into the womb: the other pair is longer, and ri≈øes from the Sphincter of the Fundament, where they are endued with a more fle≈øhy ≈øub≈øtance, being in length full as long as the Yard; under which they are carried downward, ending at the ≈øides of the Urethra, about the middle of the Yard. Their u≈øe is to dilate the Urethra, both at the time of making water, and at the time of Conjunction; le≈øt it ≈øhould be ≈øtopped up by the repletion of the nervous bodies, and ≈øo ≈øtop up the pa≈ø≈øage of the Seed. They are al≈øo thought to keep the Yard firm, le≈øt it lean too much to either ≈øide, and al≈øo to pre≈øs out the Seed out of the Pro≈øtatae, or Fore≈øtanders.

There are Ve≈ø≈øels al≈øo of all ≈øorts in the yard: fir≈øt of all,The Ve≈ø≈øels of the Yard. certain Veins appearing in the external parts, and in the cuticle; which do branch them≈øelves out from the Hypoga≈øtrium. In the middle, between the ≈øpace of the fibres, they ≈øend out certain branches from the right ≈øide to the left, and from the left to the right. The≈øe veins ≈øwelling with a frothy blood and ≈øpirit,
erect the Yard. There are al≈øo certain nerves which ≈øcatter them≈øelves from the pith or marrow of the Holy-bone, quite through the yard, bringing with them the cau≈øe of that plea≈øure and delight, which is perceived in the erection of the yard.

div.head: CHAP. XV. Of the Action of the Yard.
div.p: THE main ≈øcope of Nature in the u≈øe of the Yard, was, the injection of Seed into the womb of the Woman, which injection could not be done, till the Seed were fir≈øt moved; neither could the Seed be moved but by frication of the parts, which could not be done, till it were ≈øheathed in the Womb; nor that neither, till the Yard were erected.

This di≈øtention is cau≈øed by repletion; which is cau≈øed by the plenty of Seed: Secondly, by ≈øuperfluity of wind, which if it be too violent, is the cau≈øe of priapi≈øm: A third cau≈øe proceeds from the abundance of Urine contained in the Bladder. Sometimes, the heat of the reins is a cau≈øe thereof.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. Of the u≈øe of the Yard in general.
div.p:
THE Yard is ≈øituated under the Midriff over again≈øt the Womb. And is al≈øo placed between the thighs, for the greater ≈øtrengthning of it in the act of copulation: neither is this the only ≈øtrength which it hath, for at the lower part it appears more fle≈øhy, which fle≈øh is altogether mu≈øcely, for the greater ≈øtrength thereof. Neither is it only contented with this Mu≈øcely fle≈øh, it having two Mu≈øcles al≈øo for the ≈øame purpo≈øe, on both ≈øides to poi≈øe it eaven in
the act of erection; which though they are but little, yet are they exceeding ≈øtrong.
The figure of the Yard is not ab≈øolutely round, but broader on the upper ≈øide, le≈øt it ≈øhould be hindered by the the convexity of the ≈øuperior part, in the ca≈øting forth of the Seed.
Concerning the bigne≈øs of the Yard, it is by mo≈øt e≈øteemed to be of a ju≈øt length, when it is extended the breadth of nine thumbs.

div.head: CHAP. XVII. Of the u≈øe of the parts con≈øtituting the Yard.
div.p: THE fir≈øt thing in the con≈øtitution of the Yard, that offers it ≈øelf to view, is the Skin, which is long and loo≈øe, by rea≈øon that the Yard which is ≈øometimes to be extended, and ≈øometimes to fall down again, ≈øo requires it. The extremity of the skin is ≈øo ordered, that it ≈øometimes covers the Glans, and ≈øometimes draws back; that, whil≈øt it covers the Nut of the Yard, it may defend the Yard from frication, or provoking the motion of the Seed.

Moreover, this skin in the act of copulation, ≈øhuts up the mouth of the Womb and hinders the ingre≈øs of the cold air. Concerning the two nervous bodies, con≈øtituting the ≈øub≈øtance of the Yard; their u≈øe is for the vital ≈øpirit to run through the thin ≈øub≈øtance of them, and fill the Yard with ≈øpirits. Moreover, by their thickne≈øs, they do prevent the two ha≈øty emptying and flying out of the ≈øpirits which are to ≈øtay in, for the greater and longer erection of the Yard.

The u≈øe of the Urethra is for the pa≈ø≈øage of Seed and Urine through it. The ≈øub≈øtance of the Urethra is much of the ≈øame with the two former bodies; the in≈øide
being more thin and loo≈øe, the out≈øide more nervous and thick; which is ≈øo ordained, that it may be more apt to be erected with the Yard. It goes forward from the place where it begins, to the end of the Spermatick Ve≈ø≈øels, and the neck of the bladder, and the warty Fore≈øtanders, where there ari≈øes a thin and tender membrane, which the Chyrurgeons ought to take a great deal of care le≈øt they break, while they thru≈øt their Syringes toward tho≈øe parts; It is endued with an exqui≈øite ≈øen≈øe to ≈øtir up plea≈øure and venereal de≈øire.

The u≈øe of the Glans. As to the ≈øub≈øtance of the Glans, it is the ≈øame with that of the Yard; only it is not invelop'd with any nervous body. For this ought to be repleted and increa≈øed, but not hardned; le≈øt it ≈øhould injure the bone of the Womb, by rubbing too hard upon it.

The figure of the Glans is ≈øuch, that at the top where it is mo≈øt acute, it hath a hole for the i≈ø≈øuing forth both of Seed and Urine, which part coming to the mouth of the Womb, ca≈øts the ≈øeed into that concavity, at which time the neck of the Womb with her overthwart fibres, ≈øeems to take hold and imbrace the Glans; and, that it might take the better hold, Nature hath framed a round circle at the bottom of the Yard, for that purpo≈øe, with a convenient jetting out round about from the body of the Yard; by the benefit of which circle, the Seed is kept in the womb, and not ≈øuffered to flye out. La≈øtly, the Glans is ≈øo con≈øtituted, as if all the actions of the Yard con≈øi≈øted in the Glans; whether in the act of erection, or copulation; or as to the plea≈øure which a man perceives, that lies all in this place.

div.head: SECT. II.
CHAP. I. Of the Genitals of Women.
div.p: AT the lower part of the belly appears the Pubes, or, the Region of the hair. Under this place are, as it were, lips of fle≈øh, which in women that are ripe for man, are clad with hair at the upper part, becau≈øe of the heat and moi≈øture of the place; and this part is that which is mo≈øt properly called the Privy-member, being the exteriour orifice, into which the Yard of the man enters. In the middle it hath a cleft, on both ≈øides of which are two fle≈øhy protuberances, be≈øet with hair, being two ≈øoft oblong bodies compo≈øed of skin and a ≈øpongy kind of fle≈øh.

The parts that offer them≈øelves to view, without any diduction, are the great chink, with the lips, the mountain of Venus, and the hairs. The great chink is called Cunnus by Galen, by Hypocrates Natura, and by many other names, invented by lu≈øtful Per≈øons, and la≈øcivious Poets. It reaches from the lower part of the os Pubis to within an Inch of the Fundament, being by Nature made ≈øo large, becau≈øe the outward skin is not ≈øo apt to be extended in Travel, as the membranous ≈øheath; it is le≈øs and clo≈øer in Maids, than in tho≈øe that have born Children; it has two lips, which towards the Pubes grow thicker and more full, or protuberant, and meeting upon the middle of the os Pubis, make that ri≈øing, which is called the hill of Venus; its outward ≈øub≈øtance is skin covered with hair; as the lips are: the inner ≈øub≈øtance
of this hill, which makes it bunch ≈øo up, is mo≈øt of it fat, and ≈øerves, as it were for a ≈øoft Cu≈øhion in copulation, to hinder the bone of the Pubes of the Man and Woman to hit one again≈øt the other; for that would be painful and di≈øturb the venereal Plea≈øures. Under this fat lies that Mu≈øcle, that ≈øtraitens the Orifice of the ≈øheath.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of tho≈øe parts called Nymphae, and the Clytoris.
div.p: THE Nymphae, or wings, are a membrany, or filmy ≈øub≈øtance, ≈øoft, and ≈øpongy, and partly fle≈øhy; they are of a ruddy colour, like the comb of a cock under his throat; they are two in number, though in the beginning they are joyned together by an acute Angle; where they produce a carneous ≈øub≈øtance, like the Praeputium which cloaths the Clytoris. Sometimes the≈øe wings ≈øo far encrea≈øe, that there is many times need of inci≈øion; a di≈øea≈øe common among the Egyptians.

The Clytoris is a certain ≈øub≈øtance in the upper part of the great Cleft,The Clytoris. where the two wings concur. This in Women is the ≈øeat of Venereal plea≈øure: It is like the Yard in ≈øituation, ≈øub≈øtance, compo≈øition, and erection, and hath ≈øomething corre≈øpondent both to the Prepuce, and to the Glans in men. Sometimes it grows out to the bigne≈øs of the Yard, ≈øo that it hath bin ob≈øerved to grow out of the body, the breadth of four fingers.

This Clytoris con≈øi≈øts of two ≈øpongy and ≈øinewy bodies, having a di≈øtinct original from the bone of the Pubes. The head of this is covered with a mo≈øt tender skin, and hath a hole like the Glans, though not
quite through; in which, and in the bigne≈øs, it differs only from the Yard. By a little drawing a≈øide the lips, there then appear the Nymphs and Clytoris.

The Nymphs are ≈øo called, becau≈øe they ≈øtand next to the Urine, as it ≈øpouts out from the Bladder, and keep it from wetting the lips; they are al≈øo call'd wings; they are placed on each ≈øide next within the lips, and are two fle≈øhy and ≈øoft productions, beginning at the upper part of the privity, (where they are joined in an Acute angle, and make that wrinkled membranous production that covers the Clytoris, like a fore-skin,) and de≈øcending clo≈øe all the way to each other, reaching but about half the breadth of the Orifice of the ≈øheath, and ending each in an obtu≈øe angle: They are almo≈øt Triangular, and therefore, as al≈øo for their colour, are compared to the thrills that hang under a cocks throat. They have a red ≈øub≈øtance, partly fle≈øhy, partly membranous, within ≈øoft and ≈øpongy, loo≈øly compo≈øed of ≈ømall Membranes and Ve≈ø≈øels, ≈øo that they are very ea≈øily ≈øtretched by the flowing in of the animal Spirits, and arterial Blood. The Spirits they have from the ≈øame Nerves that run thro' the ≈øheath, and blood from one of the branches of the Iliack Artery: Veins they have al≈øo, which carry away the arterial blood from them, when they become flaccid. They are larger in old Maids than in young, and larger yet in tho≈øe that have u≈øed Copulation, or born Children. They never, according to Nature reach above half way out from between the lips; their u≈øe is to defend the inner parts, to cover the urinary pa≈ø≈øages, and a good part of the Orifice of the ≈øheath; and to the ≈øame purpo≈øes ≈øerve the lips.

Above betwixt the Nymphs, in the upper part of the privities, a part bunches out a little, that is called
Clytoris, from a Greek word, that ≈øignifies la≈øciviou≈øly to grope the privities. It is like a mans Yard in ≈øhape, ≈øituation, ≈øub≈øtance, repletion with Spirits, and erection, and differs from it only in length and bigne≈øs: in ≈øome it grows to that length, as to hang out from betwixt the lips of the privities, yea, there are many ≈øtories of ≈øuch, as have had it ≈øo long and big, as to be able to conver≈øe with other Women like unto men, and ≈øuch are called Hermophridites, who, it is not probable, are truly of both Sexes, but only the Stones fall down into the lips, and this Clytoris is ≈øtretched preternaturally; but in mo≈øt it branches out ≈øo little, as that it does not appear but by drawing a≈øide the lips; it is a little long and round body, con≈øi≈øting like a mans Yard of two nervous, and inwardly black, and ≈øpongy parts that ari≈øe on each ≈øide from the bunching of the bone I≈øchium, and meet together at the Conjunction of the bones of the Pubes. It lies under the hill of Venus, at the top of the great Cleft, in Venery; by rea≈øon of the two nervous bodies, it puffs up, and ≈øtraightning the Orifice of the ≈øheath, contributes to the embracing the Yard more clo≈øely. Its outward end is like to the Glans of a Mans Yard, and has the ≈øame name, and as the Glans in men is the ≈øeat of the greate≈øt plea≈øure in Copulation, ≈øo is this in Women; It has ≈øome re≈øemblance of a hole, but it is not pervious. It is mo≈øt of it covered with a thin Membrane, by the joyning of the Nymphs, which is called the Prepuce. The Clytoris has two pair of Mu≈øcles belonging to it, the upper are round, and ≈øpring from the bones of the hip, and pa≈ø≈øing along the two nervous bodies, are in≈øerted into them; the≈øe, by ≈øtraitning the roots of the ≈øaid bodies, do detain the Blood and Spirits in them, and ≈øo erect the Clytoris, as tho≈øe in men do the Yard: the other ari≈øe from the Sphincter of the fundament; it has veins, arteries, and nerves.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the fle≈øhy knobs, and the greater neck of the Womb.
div.p: PRe≈øently behind the wings, before we go far inward in the middle of the Cleft, there do appear four knobs of fle≈øh, being placed in a quadrangular form, one again≈øt the other; they are ≈øaid to re≈øemble Myrtle-berries in form. In this place is incerted the Orifice of the bladder, which opens it ≈øelf into the fi≈ø≈øure, to ca≈øt forth the Urine into the common Channel. Now lea≈øt any cold air, or du≈øt, or any ≈øuch thing ≈øhould enter into the Bladder after the voiding of the Urine, one of the≈øe knobs is ≈øeated ≈øo, that it ≈øhuts the urinary pa≈ø≈øage. The ≈øecond, is right oppo≈øite to the fir≈øt, the other two collateral. They are round in Virgins, but they hang flagging when Virginity is lo≈øt.

The lips of the Womb being gently ≈øeparated,The neck of the Womb. the neck of the Womb is to be ≈øeen: In which, two things are to be ob≈øerved; the neck it ≈øelf, or the channel, and the Hymen, which is there placed: By the neck of the Womb, is under≈øtood the channel, which is between the ≈øaid knobs, and the inner bone of the womb; which receives the Yard like a Sheath. The ≈øub≈øtance of it is ≈øinewy,The ≈øub≈øtance. and a little ≈øpongy, that it may be dilated; in this concavity there are certain folds, or orbicular pleights; the≈øe are made by a certain Tunicle ≈øo wrinkled, as if a man ≈øhould fold the skin with his fingers. In Virgins they are plain; in Women, with often copulation, they are oftentimes worn out; ≈øometimes they are wholly worn out, and the inner ≈øide of the Neck appears ≈ømooth; as it happens to Whores, and Women that have often brought
forth, or have bin over troubled with their fluxes. In old Women it becomes more hard and gri≈øly. Now though this Channel be ≈øomething writhed and crooked, when it falls and ≈øinks down, yet in time of the flowers and copulation, or in time of travel, it is erected and extended; and this over-great exten≈øion in Women that bring forth, is the cau≈øe of that great pain in Child-bed.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of the Hymen.
div.p: THE Hymen is a Membrane not altogether without blood,The Hymen. neither ≈øo tender as the re≈øt, but more ruddy, and ≈øcatter'd up and down with little veins, and in a circular form; it is placed overthwart, and ≈øhuts up the cavity of the neck of the Womb. In the middle it hath a little hole, through which the Men≈øes are voided. This at the fir≈øt time of Copulation is broken, which cau≈øes ≈øome pain, and gu≈øhing forth of ≈øome quantity of blood; which is an evident ≈øign of Virginity; for if the blood do not flow, there is a ≈øu≈øpicion of a former deflowring.

The Hymen is a thin, nervous membrane, interwoven with fle≈øhy fibres, and endowed with many little Arteries and Veins, coming acro≈øs the pa≈ø≈øage of the ≈øheath; behind the incertion of the neck of the bladder, with a hole in the mid≈øt, that will admit the top of ones little finger, whereby the Cour≈øes flow; where it is found, it is a certain note of Virginity, but upon the fir≈øt Copulation it is broke, and bleeds, and when it is once broke, it never clo≈øes again. This Blood is called the flower of Virginity, and of this the Scripture makes mention, Dut. cap. 22. & 13.21. But tho'
a man when he finds the≈øe ≈øigns of Virginity, may be fully ≈øatisfied he hath married a Maid, yet on the contrary, it will not nece≈ø≈øarily follow, that where they are wanting, Virginity is al≈øo wanting; for the Hymen may be corroded by acrimonious fretting Humours, flowing thro' with the cour≈øes, or from the falling out, or inver≈øion of the Womb, or ≈øheath at lea≈øt: It ≈øometimes happens, even to Maids; for if a Maid be ≈øo incon≈øiderate, as to marry while her cour≈øes flow, or within a Day after, then both the Hymen and the inner wrinkled Membrane of the Sheath are ≈øo flaggy and relaxed, that the Yard may ea≈øily enter with out any lett, and ≈øo give ≈øu≈øpicion of Uncha≈øtity, when really ≈øhe is unblameable, ≈øaving for her imprudence to marry at that ≈øea≈øon. Sometimes the Hymen grows ≈øo ≈øtrong in old Maids, that a Man is forced to make many e≈ø≈øays, before he can penetrate it, and in ≈øome it is naturally quite clo≈øed up, and the≈øe by this means having their cour≈øes ≈øtopt, are in great danger of their life, if they be not opened by ≈øome Chyrurgical In≈øtrument. Clo≈øe to the Hymen lye the four Myrtle-berry Caruncles, ≈øo called from their re≈øembling Myrtle-berries: The large≈øt of them is uppermo≈øt, ≈øtanding ju≈øt at the Mouth of the Urinary pa≈ø≈øage, which it ≈øtops after rendring the Urine. Oppo≈øite to this in the bottom of the ≈øheath, there is another, and one on each ≈øide; but of the≈øe four there is only the fir≈øt in Maids, the other three are not indeed Caruncles, but little knobs made of the angular parts of the broken Hymen, roll'd into a heap by the wrinkling of the ≈øheath: The≈øe three when the ≈øheath is extended in Womens labour, loo≈øe their roughne≈øs, and become ≈ømooth, ≈øo that they di≈øappear until it be again contracted, and indeed, the ≈øheath near its outer orifice, has a Mu≈øcle near three Fingers broad, that upon occa≈øion, contracts
it, ≈øo that Men and Women need not be ≈øolicitous concerning their Genitals being proportionable one to the other.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the Ve≈ø≈øels that run through the neck of the Womb.
div.p: BEtween the Duplicity of the two Tunicles, that con≈øtitute the neck of the Womb, there are many Veins and Arteries that run along, ari≈øing from tho≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels that de≈øcend on both ≈øides the thighs, and are incerted into the ≈øide of the neck of the Womb: The great quantity and bigne≈øs of them de≈øerves admiration; for they are much bigger than the nature and openne≈øs of the place ≈øeems to require.

The cau≈øe of the largene≈øs of the Ve≈ø≈øels.The cau≈øe of this is twofold; fir≈øt, Becau≈øe it being requi≈øite for the neck of the Womb to be filled with abundance of ≈øpirits, and to be extended and dilated for the better taking hold of the Yard; there is required a great heat for the≈øe kind of motions, which growing more inten≈øe by the act of frication, doth con≈øume a great quantity of moi≈øture, ≈øo that great Ve≈ø≈øels are requi≈øite, and only able to make that continual ≈øupply that is needful.

There is another cau≈øe of the longne≈øs of the≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels, which is this; Becau≈øe that the monthly purgations are poured through tho≈øe veins; for the flowers mu≈øt not come only out of the Womb, but out of the neck of the Womb al≈øo.Note. Whence it happens, that Women with Child do ≈øometimes continue their purgations, becau≈øe that though the womb be ≈øhut up, yet the pa≈ø≈øages in the neck of the womb are open.

This is al≈øo further to be noted in the neck of the womb, that as ≈øoon as ever your ≈øight is entred within
the female fi≈ø≈øure,The two holes, or pits, near the lips of the Pudendum. there do appear to the view, two certain little holes or pits, wherein is contained a ≈øerous humour; which being pre≈ø≈øed out in the act of copulation, does not a little add to the plea≈øure thereof.
This is the humour with which women do moi≈øten the top of a mans Yard; not the Seed, but a humour proper to the place, voided out by the Womb.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of the Fabrick of the Womb.
div.p: TO the neck of the Womb, the Womb it ≈øelf is adjoined in the lower part of the Hypoga≈øtrium, where the hips are wide≈øt and broade≈øt; which are greater and broader thereabouts than tho≈øe of men; which is the rea≈øon al≈øo, that they have broader Buttocks than men have.

The Womb is placed between the Bladder and the ≈øtreight gut;The Womb. being joined to the bladder and leaning upon the ≈øtreight gut: where it lies as between two Cu≈øhions, this ≈øituation of the womb was fitte≈øt, that ≈øo it might have liberty to be ≈øtretched, or contracted, according to the bigne≈øs of the Fruit contained in it.

The figure of the womb is round, and not unlike a Gourd, that le≈ø≈øens,The figure. and grows more acute at the one end. The bottom of the womb is knit together by Ligaments of its own, which are peculiar: The neck of the womb is joined by its own ≈øub≈øtance, and by certain Membranes to the Share-bone, and the Sacred bone.

As to the bigne≈øs of it; that varies according to the age or con≈øtitution of the body,The bigne≈øs. and u≈øe of Venery. For it is much greater in Women that have brought forth, than in tho≈øe that are with Child, and after the birth.
It is of a ≈øub≈øtance ≈øo thick, as that it exceeds a thumbs breadth in thickne≈øs; which after conception is ≈øo far from decrea≈øing, that it increa≈øes ≈øtill to a greater bulk and proportion.
This ≈øub≈øtance, the more to confirm it,The Fibres. is interweaved with all manner of fibres, ≈øtreight, oblique, and overthwart.
The Ve≈ø≈øels of the Womb are Veins, Arteries and Nerves.

There are two little Veins which are carried from the ≈øpermatick Ve≈ø≈øels to the bottom of the womb;The Veins. and two greater from the Hypoga≈øtricks, which go not only to the bottom, but to the neck. The mouth of the≈øe veins pierce as far as the inward concavity; in which place the extremities of them are called Acetabula; which in the time of the Flowers, gape and open them≈øelves by rea≈øon of the great plenty and ≈øtream of blood, that pours it ≈øelf from thence; and therefore they are, at that time, mo≈øt con≈øpicuous; in women with Child, that which is called the Liver of the Womb, is joined to them, that it might draw blood for the nouri≈øhment of the Child; at which time their veins do ≈øo ≈øwell, e≈øpecially in the time of, or near Delivery, that they are as big as the Emulgent veins, or at lea≈øt half as thick as the Hollow vein.
The Arteries.It hath two Arteries on both ≈øides, the Spermatick, and the Hypoga≈øtrick, which every where do accompany the Veins.

The Womb hath al≈øo divers little nerves knit together in form of a Net, which are carried not only to the interior part of the bottom of the Womb, but al≈øo to the Neck, and as far as the privities them≈øelves; and that chiefly for ≈øen≈øe and plea≈øure; for which cau≈øe there is a great ≈øympathy between the Womb and the Head.

This is al≈øo further to be noted,Note‚ñ™ that the Womb in its ≈øituation is not fixed and immoveable, but moveable, by rea≈øon of two ligaments which hang on both ≈øides, from the Share-bone; and piercing through the Peritonaeum, are joined to the bone it ≈øelf, ≈øo that it ≈øometimes happens that through tho≈øe holes of the Peritonaeum, which give pa≈ø≈øage to the≈øe ligaments being loo≈øened, either the Omentum, or the Entrails, do ≈øwell outwardly, and cau≈øe the bur≈øtne≈øs either of the Caul or of the Guts, and ≈øometimes it happens by rea≈øon of the loo≈øene≈øs of tho≈øe ligaments, that the womb is moved with ≈øuch force, that it falls down; and in the act of Copulation is moved up and down; ≈øometimes it moves upward, that ≈øome Women do affirm that it a≈øcends as high as their Stomack. Now though the Womb be one continued body, yet it is divided into the Mouth, and the Bottom.

The Bottom of the Womb is called all that which, by ≈øtill a≈øcending, ≈øtretches it ≈øelf from the internal Orifice to the end; being narrow toward the Mouth, but dilating it ≈øelf by little and little, 'till it come at the entrails.

The Mouth of the womb, is that narrowne≈øs between the neck and the bottom; it is an oblong and tran≈øver≈øe Orifice; but, where it opens it ≈øelf, orbicular, and round; the circumference very thick, and of an exqui≈øite feeling; and if this mouth be out of order, and be troubled with a Scirrhous brawn, or over-fatne≈øs,
over-moi≈øture, or relaxation, it is the cau≈øe of Barrenne≈øs. In tho≈øe that are big with Child, there u≈øes to ≈øtick to this Orifice, a thick vi≈øcous glutinous matter, that the parts moi≈øtned may be the more ea≈øily opened. For in the delivery, this mouth is opened after a very ≈øtrange and miraculous manner, ≈øo that according to the bigne≈øs of the birth, it ≈øuffers an equal dilatation, from the bottom of the womb to the privy member.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of the preparing Ve≈ø≈øels in Women.
div.p: THE Spermatick Preparing Ve≈ø≈øels,The Ve≈ø≈øels. are two Veins, and two Arteries, differing not at all from tho≈øe of men, either in the number, original, action, or u≈øe, but only in their bigne≈øs, and the manner of their in≈øertion. For as to their number, there are ≈øo many veins, and ≈øo many Arteries as in men. They ari≈øe al≈øo from the ≈øame place as in men; that is to ≈øay, the right, from the trunck of the hollow vein de≈øcending; the left, from the left Emulgent.
There are two Arteries al≈øo, on both ≈øides one, which grow from the Aorta; the≈øe both bring vital blood for the work of Generation.

As to the Longitude and Latitude of the≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels, they are narrower and ≈øhorter in Women; only where they are wrinckled, they are much more wreathed and contorted than in men; for, the way being ≈øhorter in women than in men, Nature required, for ≈øtretching out the≈øe ve≈ø≈øels, that they ≈øhould be more wrinckled and crankled than in men, that the blood might ≈øtay there in greater quantity, for preparation of the Seed.

The In≈øertion of the ve≈ø≈øels.The≈øe ve≈ø≈øels in Women are carried with an oblique cour≈øe through the ≈ømall guts to the Stones, being
wrapt up in fatter membranes; but in the mid-way they are divided into two branches, whereof the greater branch goes to the Stone, con≈øtituting the various or winding body, and tho≈øe wonderful ino≈øculations, the le≈ø≈øer branch ends in the womb; in the ≈øides of which it is ≈øcattered up and down, and chiefly at the higher part of the bottom of the womb, for nouri≈øhment of the Womb, and of the birth; and that ≈øome part of the flowers may be purged out through tho≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels: now becau≈øe the Stones of Women are ≈øeated near the womb, for that cau≈øe the≈øe ve≈ø≈øels fall not from the Peritonaeum, neither make they ≈øuch pa≈ø≈øages as in men, neither reach they to the Share-bone.

The u≈øe of the≈øe Spermatic Ve≈ø≈øels, is to mini≈øter to the generation of Seed, according to the ancient Doctrine; but to the nutrition of the Eggs in the Stones, according to the new, and for the nouri≈øhment of the Foetus, and of the ≈øolid parts, and the expurgation of the cour≈øes; in as much as blood is convey'd by the Arteries to all tho≈øe parts, to which their Ramifications come, in which parts they leave what is to be ≈øeparated, according to the law of Nature, the remaining blood returning by the Veins.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of the Stones in Women.
div.p: THE Stones of Women, although they do perform the ≈øame actions, and are for the ≈øame u≈øe as mens, yet they differ from them in ≈øituation, ≈øub≈øtance, temperament, figure, magnitude, and in their Covering.

They are ≈øeated in the hollowne≈øs of the Abdomen;Their Situation. neither do they hang out as in men, but they re≈øt
upon the Mu≈øcles of the Loins, and this for that cau≈øe that they might be more hot and fruitful; being to elaborate that matter, with which the Seed of man engenders man.

In this place ari≈øes a Que≈øtion, not trivial;A doubt. whether the Seed of Woman be the efficient, or the material cau≈øe of generation? To which it is an≈øwered, that though it have a power of acting, yet it receives the perfection of that power from the Seed of Man.

The Stones of Women differ from mens al≈øo,Their figure. as to their figure, becau≈øe they are not ≈øo round and oval as tho≈øe of men, being in their fore and hinder part more depre≈ø≈øed and broad, the external ≈øuperficies being more unequal, as if a great many knots and kernals were mixed together. There is al≈øo another difference, as to the ≈øubject, becau≈øe they are ≈øofter and moi≈øter than tho≈øe of men, being more loo≈øe and ill compacted.

Their bigne≈øs and temper.Their magnitude and temperament do al≈øo make a difference: for the Stones of Women are much colder and le≈ø≈øer than Mens; which is the rea≈øon that they beget a thin and watry Seed.

Their coverings al≈øo do make a difference: for mens are wrapt up in divers Tunicles, becau≈øe being pendent outward, they were otherwi≈øe more ≈øubject to external injuries; but the ≈øtones of women have but one tunicle, which though it ≈øtick very clo≈øe to them, yet are they al≈øo half cloathed over with the Peritonaeum.

They have but one membrane, that encompa≈ø≈øes them round, but on their upper ≈øide, where the preparing Ve≈ø≈øels enter them, they are about half way involved
in another membrane that accompanies tho≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels, and ≈øprings from the Peritonaeum. When this cover is removed, their ≈øub≈øtance appears whiti≈øh, but is wholly different from the ≈øub≈øtance of Mens Stones; for mens are compo≈øed of Seed-ve≈ø≈øels, which, being continued to one another, are twenty, or thirty ells long; if one could draw them out at length, without breaking: but Womens principally con≈øi≈øt of a great many membranes, and ≈ømall fibres loo≈øly joined to one another; among which, there are ≈øeveral little bladders full of a clear Liquor, thro' who≈øe membranes, the nerves, and preparing Ve≈ø≈øels run. Galen and Hypocrates, and their followers, imagine the Liquor contained in the≈øe Bladders to be Seed; but from Dr. Harvey downwards, many learned Phy≈øicians, and Anatomi≈øts, have denied that Women have Seed. Some Women, ≈øays Dr. Harvey, ≈øend forth no ≈øuch humour as is called Seed, and yet they conceive; for I have known ≈øeveral Women, ≈øays he, that have bin fruitful enough without ≈øuch emi≈ø≈øion, yea, ≈øome that after they begun to emit ≈øuch an humour, tho' indeed they took greater plea≈øure in Copulation, yet grew le≈øs fruitful than before. There are al≈øo infinite in≈øtances of Women, who tho' they have plea≈øure in Copulation, yet ≈øend forth nothing, and notwith≈øtanding conceive. It is moreover to be ob≈øerved, that the humour is ca≈øt out, and i≈ø≈øues mo≈øt commonly from about the Clytoris, and Orifice of the privities, and very rarely from any depth within the neck of the Womb, but never within the Womb it ≈øelf, ≈øo as that it ≈øhould be there mixed with the mans Seed; be≈øides it is not ropy and oyly like Seed, but ≈øerous like Urine. We mu≈øt therefore agree with that new, but nece≈ø≈øary Opinion, that ≈øuppo≈øes the≈øe little Bladders to contain nothing of Seed, both becau≈øe the
Liquor is ≈øent forth in a greater quantity, than can be ≈øupplyed from them, and al≈øo, becau≈øe they have no pa≈ø≈øage, whereby the Liquor contained in them might i≈ø≈øue out; for if you pre≈øs them never ≈øo hard, unle≈øs you bur≈øt them, nothing will pa≈øs out of them; therefore it mu≈øt be concluded, that they are truly Eggs, Analogous to tho≈øe of Fowl, and other Creatures, and that the Stones ≈øo called are not truly ≈øo, nor have any ≈øuch Office, as tho≈øe of Men, but are indeed an Ovarium, wherein the≈øe Eggs are nouri≈øhed by the blood Ve≈ø≈øels, di≈øper≈øed through them, and from whence one or more, as they are fecundated by the Mans Seed, ≈øeparate, and are convey'd into the womb by the Fallopian tubes. If you boyl the≈øe Eggs, their Liquor will have the ≈øame colour, ta≈øte, and con≈øi≈øtency with the white of Birds eggs, and their difference in wanting ≈øhells is of no moment; for Birds eggs have need of a ≈øhell, becau≈øe they are hatched without the Body, and are expo≈øed to external injuries; but the≈øe of Women, being fo≈øtered within their body, have no need of other fence than the Womb, whereby they are ≈øufficiently defended. The≈øe Eggs in Women are commonly towards the number of twenty, in each Te≈øticle, whereof ≈øome are far le≈øs than others: The objection of the Galeni≈øts again≈øt the Ari≈øtotelians, (viz. That the Stones of Females mu≈øt needs make Seed, becau≈øe, when they are cut out, barrenne≈øs always follows) will be ≈øufficiently obviated by this new Hypothe≈øis, that agrees to the nece≈ø≈øity of the ≈øtones ≈øo far, as to affirm, that the little Bladders contained in them, become, when they are impregnated by the ma≈øculine ≈øeed, the very conceptions them≈øelves, which would be in vain to expect, if the female were ca≈øtrated.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Of the deferent, or Ejaculatory Ve≈ø≈øels.
div.p: THE Deferent Ve≈ø≈øels are two blind pa≈ø≈øages, on both ≈øides one, nothing differing in ≈øub≈øtance from the ≈øpermatick Veins. They ri≈øe in one part from the bottom of the Womb, neither do they reach from their other extremity, either to the Stone, or to any other part; but are ≈øhut up, and unpa≈ø≈øable, adhering to the womb, ju≈øt as the blind Gut adheres to the Colon; but winding half way about the Stones, are every way remote from them, no where touching them; only are tied to them with certain Membranes, not unlike the wings of Bats, through which certain Veins and Arteries, being produced from the Stones do run; and end in the≈øe pa≈ø≈øages. Where they begin, at the bottom of the womb, they are hollow and large; but as they proceed further on, they grow narrower, till, near their end, they do again obtain a larger bigne≈øs; the≈øe two pa≈ø≈øages thus running from the corners of the womb to the Stones, are taken only to be certain ligaments, by which the Stones and the Womb are ≈øtrongly knit together; and the≈øe ligaments in Women, are the ≈øame things with the Crema≈øteres in men.

Galen and mo≈øt of the Antients counted the≈øe ≈øhort proce≈ø≈øes, that go ≈øtreight from the Stones to the bottom of the Womb, to be ejaculatory Ve≈ø≈øels, and that the ≈øeed was ca≈øt from the Stones thro' them into the bottom of the Womb, and ≈øome others have thought, they have found a ≈ømall pipe pa≈ø≈øing on each ≈øide out of the≈øe proce≈ø≈øes, by the ≈øides of the Womb to its neck, into which they were in≈øerted, and opened near its Orifice. By the former it was ≈øuppo≈øed, Women not with Child did ca≈øt their ≈øeed into the bottom
