of the Womb, and by the≈øe latter, ≈øuch as were already impregnated; for that if it ≈øhould have i≈ø≈øued into the bottom of the womb, where the conception was, it would have corrupted, to the great prejudice of the Faetus. But many accurate Anatomi≈øts have not bin able to find the lea≈øt foot-≈øtep of the≈øe latter ducts; and as for the former, ≈øeeing they have not any cavity, and therefore can have nothing of ≈øeed in them, we mu≈øt conclude, that they are only ligaments of the ≈øtones to keep them in their place; and this may be proved farther, by ob≈øerving that they come not into the inner cavity of the womb, but are knit only to its outward Coat, and there are only two holes in the bottom of the womb, that admit a probe, and tho≈øe lead to the fallopian tubes, and not to the≈øe ligaments.

Seeing therefore, that tho≈øe which have bin accounted ejaculatory Ve≈ø≈øels, either are not to be found at all, or are found unfit for ≈øuch an Office, and having withal rejected the Opinion of Womens having ≈øeed, and affirm'd, that that which makes the Conception, is one of tho≈øe little bladders in the ≈øtones, dropping from thence, and conveyed into the womb, we mu≈øt enquire by what way they can pa≈øs; for if the above≈øaid ligaments reputed deferent Ve≈ø≈øels, have no pa≈ø≈øage, whereby the ≈øeed, if there were any might pa≈øs, much le≈øs cou'd one of the≈øe bladders be conveyed that way; and therefore, for deferent Ve≈ø≈øels, we a≈ø≈øign tho≈øe pa≈ø≈øages, that are called the fallopian tubes, they are very ≈ølender, and narrow pa≈ø≈øages, nervous and white, ari≈øing from the ≈øides of the womb, and at a little di≈øtance from it, they become larger, and twi≈øt like the tendrel of a Vine, 'till near their end, where cea≈øing their winding, they grow very large, and ≈øeem membranous and fle≈øhy, which end is very much torn and jaggy, like the edge of rent Cloaths, and has
a large hole, which always lies clo≈øed, becau≈øe tho≈øe jags fall together; but yet being opened they are like the outmo≈øt orifice of a bra≈øs Trumpet The≈øe tubes are the ≈øame in Women, that the horns of the womb are in other Creatures, for they an≈øwer to tho≈øe, both in ≈øituation, connection, amplitude, perforation, likene≈øs, and al≈øo office: For as other Creatures always conceive in the Horns, ≈øo it has been ≈øometimes ob≈øerved, that a Conception has in a Woman bin contained in one of the tubes, which mu≈øt have happened, when the Egg, being received out of the ≈øtone into it, has been ≈øtopt in its pa≈ø≈øage to the womb, either from its own bigne≈øs, or ≈øome ob≈øtruction in the tube. The ≈øub≈øtance of the tubes is not nervous, as Fallopius affirms, but membranous; for they con≈øi≈øt of two membranes, the outer and inner; the inner ≈øprings from, or at lea≈øt is common with that, which covers the inner ≈øub≈øtance of the womb: But whereas it is ≈ømooth in the womb, it is very wrinkled in the tubes, the outer is common with the outmo≈øt of the womb, and this is ≈ømooth.

The capacity of the≈øe pa≈ø≈øages varies very much, for in the beginning, as it goes out of the womb, it only admits a bri≈øtle; but in his progre≈øs, where it is mo≈øt capacious, it will receive ones little finger, but in the extremity, where it is jagged, it is but about a quarter ≈øo wide, their length al≈øo is very uncertain, for they ≈øometimes increa≈øe from four or five, to eight or nine fingers breadth long. Their u≈øe is in a fruitful Copulation to grant a pa≈ø≈øage to the finer part of the man's Seed, or of a ≈øeminal fume towards the ≈øtones, to bedew the Eggs contained in them, which Eggs, one or more being thereby ripened, and dropping off from the ≈øtone, are received by the extremity of the tubes, and carried along their inner cavity to the womb.

Two objections may be made again≈øt this u≈øe: Fir≈øt, That the end of the tube not ≈øticking clo≈øe to the ≈øtone, when one of the Eggs drops from the ≈øtone, it would more probably fall into the cavity of the belly than light ju≈øt pat in the mouth of the tube. Secondly, when it is received by it, its pa≈ø≈øage is ≈øo narnow, that it is hard to imagin how it can pa≈øs by it: But as to the fir≈øt, the ≈øame objection may lye again≈øt the u≈øe of the oviduct in Hens; for in them it does not join quite clo≈øe to the Ovarium, and yet it is certain, that the rudiments of the Eggs do all pa≈øs by them to the womb. Moreover it is probable, that when all the other parts of the Genitals are turgid in the act of Copulation, the≈øe tubes al≈øo may be in ≈øome mea≈øure erected, and extend their open mouth to the ≈øtones, to impregnate the Eggs with the ≈øeminal fume thro' their pa≈ø≈øage, and if any one be ripened, and ≈øeparate, to receive it afterwards by its orifice. As to the ≈øecond objection again≈øt the narrowne≈øs of the≈øe tubes, he that con≈øiders the ≈øtraightne≈øs of the inner orifice of the womb, both in maids and in women with Child, yet ob≈øerves to dilate ≈øo much upon occa≈øion, as to grant a pa≈ø≈øage to the Child out of the womb, cannot wonder that to ≈øerve a nece≈ø≈øary end of Nature, the ≈ømall pa≈ø≈øages of the tubes ≈øhould be ≈øo far ≈øtretched, as to make way for an Egg, ≈øeeing its proportion to their pa≈ø≈øage, is much le≈øs, than of the Child to the u≈øual largene≈øs of the ≈øaid orifice.

div.head: CHAP. X. Of the Actions and U≈øes of the Genital parts in Women.
div.p:
IN the privie part, are ≈øeen the Pubes, the mountains of Venus, the two lips, the orifice under which the two wings lye hid, the little knobs of fle≈øh, re≈øembling
Myrtle-berries, the pa≈ø≈øages of the Urine, and the Clytoris.

As for the Pubes, and the Mountains of Venus, they ≈øerve for this u≈øe, that the great Orifice might be the better ≈øhut, and to avoid compre≈ø≈øion in copulation; for which cau≈øe they are be≈øet with hair, and are covered with a hard kind of fat; the great Orifice receives the Yard, and gives pa≈ø≈øage to the Ur ‚Ä¢ ne and the birth. The u≈øe of the≈øe Wings, or knobs of fle≈øh like myrtle-berries, are for the defence of the internal parts, ≈øhutting the Orifice of the neck le≈øt cold air, du≈øt, or any other annoyances ≈øhould hurt it, from without; and while they ≈øwell up, they cau≈øe titillation and de≈øire in tho≈øe parts. La≈øtly, the pa≈ø≈øages of the Urine being ≈øhut up by the knobs of fle≈øh, re≈øembling myrtle-berries, hinders the unvoluntary pa≈ø≈øage of the Urine.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Of the Action of the Clytoris.
div.p: THE action of the Clytoris is like that of the Yard, which is erection; which erection is for the motion, and attraction of the Seed.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Of the action and u≈øe of the Neck of the Womb.
div.p:
THE action of the neck of the Womb, is the ≈øame with that of the Yard, that is to ≈øay, Erection, which is occa≈øioned divers ways. Fir≈øt, all this pa≈ø≈øage is erected, and made ≈øtreight, for the better conveyance of the Yard to the Womb, Then, while the whole pa≈ø≈øage is erected, it is repleted with
≈øpirit and vital blood, whereby it becomes narrower for the more ≈øtreight embracing of the Yard.

The cau≈øes of this erection are; fir≈øt, becau≈øe if the womb were not erected, the Yard could not have a convenient pa≈ø≈øage into the womb; ≈øecondly it would hinder convenient affrication, without which the Seed could not be drawn forth. La≈øtly, it hinders any hurt, or damage which might be done by the violent force of the Yard.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. Of the u≈øes of the ve≈ø≈øels running through the neck of the Womb.
div.p: FIRST, it is required that there ≈øhould be a concurrence of divers Veins and Arteries, for the nouri≈øhment of that part; and though that part it ≈øelf, being full of Membranes, does not require much nouri≈øhment, yet by rea≈øon that it is to ≈øuffer Erection, that could not be done but by blood and ≈øpirits, which are contained in the≈øe ve≈ø≈øels: Be≈øides, although the ≈øub≈øtance of this part be of a cold temperament, being notwith≈øtanding ≈øtill heated by the act of Copulation, that heat would ≈øoon con≈øume a ≈ølender nouri≈øhment; which nature hath ≈øupplied, by the concour≈øe of the≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels. Another cau≈øe of the plenty of the≈øe veins, is nouri≈øhment of the Birth, and the exclu≈øion of flowers.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. Of the actions of the Womb.
div.p: THE fir≈øt u≈øe of the Womb is to attract the Seed by a familiar ≈øympathy, ju≈øt as the Second u≈øe is to retain it, which is properly called Conception.
The third is to cheri≈øh the Seed thus attracted, to alter it, and change into the Birth, by rai≈øing up that power which before lay ≈øleeping in the Seed, and to reduce it from power into act.

The fourth action of the Womb is to ≈øend forth the birth at the time prefixed; the apt time of expul≈øion, is, when the expul≈øive faculty begins to be affected with ≈øome ≈øen≈øe of trouble, that is, when the Birth afflicts and oppre≈ø≈øes the Womb with its own weight.

Be≈øides the≈øe u≈øes, it hath the≈øe moreover; To nouri≈øh the Birth, and to dilate it ≈øelf, which it doth by the help of Veins and Arteries, which do fill more and more with matter, as nature requires.

The chiefe≈øt action of the Womb,The proper actions of the Womb. and mo≈øt proper to it, is, the retention of the Seed; without which, nothing of other actions could be performed for the Generation of man.

div.head: CHAP. XV. Of the Utility of the Womb.
div.p: FIRST, it is the mo≈øt fit place for Copulation, as being in a place furthe≈øt removed from the ≈øen≈øes; near which it were not fit to be, by rea≈øon of the inconveniencies which would nece≈ø≈øarily ari≈øe.
It is mo≈øt fit to receive the Birth, as being hollow; in which concavity the birth may increa≈øe to its full proportion every way.

It is mo≈øt fit for the exclu≈øion of the Birth, as being placed downward, whereby the birth might help it ≈øelf with its own weight; and al≈øo by rea≈øon of the Mu≈øcles of the Abdomen, which ≈øerve for compre≈ø≈øion, and do help the endeavours of the mother.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. Of the Utility of the preparing Ve≈ø≈øels in Women.
div.p: THE Utilities of the≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels are taken from their Original, and from their In≈øertion, the right Vein ri≈øing from the Hollow; and the left from the Emulgent, as in men; that the more hot and purer blood might come from the right vein, for the procreation of Males; and the more ≈øerous and watry blood from the Emulgent, for the generation of Women.

The Ve≈ø≈øels al≈øo in women are ≈øhorter than in men, becau≈øe the way is not ≈øo far to the Stones; which brevity of the Ve≈ø≈øels is lengthned out by the many turnings and windings with which tho≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels are endued. In the middle way, tho≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels divide them≈øelves like a Fork, the greater part going to the Stones, carrying the matter for Seed; the le≈ø≈øer is carried to the womb, where it ≈øcatters it ≈øelf all along the ≈øides of it, for the nutrition of the Womb.
As for the Arteries, they afford the blood which is more full of ≈øpirits to perfect the Seed.

div.head: CHAP. XVII. Of the Utility of the Stones.
div.p:
THE u≈øe of the Stones in Women, is the ≈øame as in men; that is to ≈øay, to prepare the Seed, and to make it fit for procreation. They are ≈øeated within, that they ≈øhould not want a continual heat, to cheri≈øh them; for the matter of Seed being colder in women than in men, it requires a greater heat, which it would of nece≈ø≈øity want, were the Stones placed outward, like tho≈øe of men; and for that cau≈øe are they
covered only with one Tunicle, that the heat of tho≈øe parts may more ea≈øily pa≈øs to them. And therefore the Stones of women are ≈øofter than tho≈øe of men becau≈øe they ≈øhould not perfect ≈øo ≈øub≈øtantial a Seed; and that the heat of the adjacent parts ≈øhould not be wholly taken up in the cheri≈øhing of them.

Their figure is not exactly round,Their figure. but depre≈ø≈øed, that the little Meanders of the veins di≈øper≈øed through the Membrane, from the Stones to the deferent Ve≈ø≈øels, might have more room to be incerted for the attraction of the Seed, out of the whole ≈øub≈øtance of the Stones. The inequality and ruggedne≈øs of them makes for the longer ≈øtay of the Seed in tho≈øe crooked and winding Ve≈ø≈øels.

div.head: SECT. III.
CHAP. I. Of the ≈øigns of Conception.
div.p: HAving thus ≈øhewed you the Anatomy and U≈øe of the parts,Signs of Conception. it will be requi≈øite to di≈øcour≈øe of the Conception it ≈øelf, which is the main and chief end of the≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels: And fir≈øt of the ≈øigns of Conception.
The ≈øigns of Conception on the Mothers ≈øide, are certain and apparent; fir≈øt, if after ≈øhe hath had the company of her Husband, ≈øhe hath received more content than ordinary.

Pains in the head, giddine≈øs, dimne≈øs of the eyes; all the≈øe concurring together, portend conception; the apples of the eyes decrea≈øe, the eyes them≈øelves ≈øwell, and become of a dark colour, the veins of the eyes
wax red, and ≈øwell with blood, the eyes ≈øink, the eyebrows grow loo≈øe, various colours appear in the eyes, little red pimples ri≈øe in the face, the veins between the No≈øe and the Eyes ≈øwell with blood, and are ≈øeen more plain; the vein under the tongue looks greeni≈øh, the neck is hot, the back bone cold, the veins and arteries ≈øwell, and the pul≈øes are ob≈øerved more ea≈øily; the veins in the brea≈øt fir≈øt look of a black colour, but afterward turn yellowi≈øh, the Teats look red; if ≈øhe drink cold drink, ≈øhe feels the cold in her brea≈øt, ≈øhe loaths her meat and drink, ≈øhe hath divers longings, but her natural appetite is de≈øtroyed: Continual vomitings follow, and weakne≈øs of the ≈øtomach, ≈øour belches worms about her Navel, faintne≈øs of the loyns, the lower part of her belly ≈øwelling, inward griping of the body, the retention of the Seed 7 days after the act of copulation: After which act there is a cold and trembling which ≈øeizes the external members; the attractive force of the womb increa≈øes; the womb dries up. It is al≈øo a certain ≈øign of conception, if the Midwife touching with her finger the interiour neck of the womb, ≈øhall find it exactly clo≈øed, ≈øo that the point of a needle will not go between: The womb waxeth round and ≈øwells, the flowers cea≈øe to flow (for the Veins through which they come down, carry the blood to the nouri≈øhment of the birth;) the thighs ≈øwell with ≈øome pain, the whole body grows weak, and the face waxes pale; the Excrements proceed ≈ølower out of the body: The Urine is white, a little cloud ≈øwimming at the top, and many atoms appear in the Urine. div.head: CHAP. V. Of fal≈øe Conception.
div.p:
WOmen do oftentimes deceive them≈øelves concerning their Conception;Fal≈øe Conception. for they do many times believe them≈øelves to be big with Child, when it is nothing el≈øe but either the Retention of their flowers, which do not fall down according to their accu≈øtomed Periods of

div.head: CHAP. VI. How Women with Child ought to govern them≈øelves.
div.p: IN the fir≈øt place, ≈øhe ought to chu≈øe a temperate and whole≈øome air, neither too hot nor too cold, nor in a watry and damp place, nor too ≈øubject to fogs and winds, e≈øpecially the South-wind, which is a great enemy to Women with Child, cau≈øing oft-times abortion in them. Take of blanched Almonds number 12, of the four greater cold Seeds, each one dram and an half, of the Seeds of Lettice, and white Poppies, each half a dram, beat them in a marble Mortar, and pour on them a ≈øufficient quantity of barly Water, make an emul≈øion for two Do≈øes; add an Ounce of Syrrup of Violets and half a dram of Sal Prunella. That her brea≈øts, after her delivery, may not grow big, and ≈øwell overmuch,Precepts concerning the brea≈øts. as al≈øo to avoid the danger of too much blood, which being converted into Milk, may chance to curd and breed ≈øome di≈øea≈øe in the brea≈øt: Therefore as ≈øoon as ≈øhe perceives her ≈øelf with child, let her carry about her neck, a ≈ømall neck-lace of Gold, though ≈øome do more e≈øteem of a neck-lace of ≈øteel, or a little ingot of Steel, to hang between the two brea≈øts: You may al≈øo foment the brea≈øts a quarter of an hour every morning, with the di≈øtilled waters of Sage, Periwinckle, or ground-Ivy, making them fir≈øt luke-warm: When the third or fourth month of her time is come, and that ≈øhe perceives the Infant to begin to ≈øwell, and to grow big,Concerning the belly. ≈øhe may ≈øwathe it with a linnen ≈øwathe-band, which ≈øhe may anoint with ≈øome convenient Pomatum; this keeps the Belly ≈ømooth, and from wrinckles, and from hanging down like a Tripe.

div.head: She may u≈øe this Liniment, or Pomatum.
div.p: Take the Gall of a Kid, and of a Sow, of each 3 ounces, Capon-grea≈øe and Goo≈øe-grea≈øe of each an ounce, and a half; cut the≈øe into little pieces, and melt them in an earthen di≈øh, putting thereto as much water as will ≈øuffice to keep them from burning; then ≈øtrain it through a linnen cloath, and afterwards having wa≈øhed it in fair water, until it be very white, add to it of the marrow of a red Deer, about an ounce; then wa≈øh it again in Ro≈øe-water, or ≈øome other water of a good ≈øcent, and anoint the ≈øwathe-band therewith.

div.head: Take this one more Liniment.

If the Woman all her time do complain that ≈øhe feels little or no motion of the Child, let her carry upon her Navel this following Quilt, which will give ≈øtrength to the Infant.

Take Powder of Ro≈øes, red Corral, Gilliflowers, of each three ounces and an half; Seed of Angelica, two drams; Ma≈øtick, a dram and an half, Ambergreece two grains, Musk one grain; put all the≈øe in a bag of fine linnen, and quilt them together for the u≈øe afore≈øaid. Thus much is to be ob≈øerved by women with Child that are in health, and have no other di≈øea≈øes hanging upon them: but of the other di≈øea≈øes incident to women with Child, we ≈øhall take a time hereafter to Treat.

The Womb-cake, otherwi≈øe called the Womb-liver, is much like the Spleen, it has abundance of Fibres; and ≈ømall ve≈ø≈øels, it is two fingers breadth, thin near the edges, and thick in the middle. And when the Child is ready for Birth, it is a quarter of a Yard over: It is ≈ømooth and ≈øomewhat hollowi≈øh on the ≈øide next the Child, and is joined to the Chorion, but is very unequal on that ≈øide next the Womb, and has many Bunchings out, by which it ≈øticks fa≈øt to the Womb. When there are Twins, there are two Womb-Cakes, either di≈øtinct in Shape, or ≈øeperated by a Membrane one from the other, and a particular rope of umbilical Ve≈ø≈øels is in≈øerted into each from each Child; it at fir≈øt appears like a woolly Sub≈øtance on the out≈øide of the outward Membrane, that encompa≈ø≈øes the Child about the
ninth week; and a red fle≈øhy ≈øoft ≈øub≈øtance grows upon it in a ≈øhort time, that is unequal, and in little knobs, and thereby pre≈øently ≈øticks to the Womb, and is very vi≈øible about the thirteenth Week; till this time the Child is increa≈øed and nouri≈øhed wholly by the appo≈øition of the Chry≈øtaline or Albugineous Liquor, wherein it ≈øwims loo≈øe in the inner Membrane call'd Amnios, having no umbilical Ve≈ø≈øels formed, whereby to receive any thing from the Womb-cake: But when it grows bigger, and begins to need more Nouri≈øhment, the extremities of the umbilical Ve≈ø≈øels begin to grow out of the Navel by little and little, and are extended towards the Womb-cake, that they may draw a more nouri≈øhing juice out of it. It has Arteries, Veins Nerves, and Lympheducts, ≈øome from the Womb, and ≈øome from the Chorion. But tho' they are very large and vi≈øible in the Womb, yet they ≈øend but very ≈ømall Capillaries to the Womb-cake. Tho≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels that come from the Chorion are Arteries and Veins, and perhaps the Lympheducts, the Arteries and Veins that come from the Womb, Spring from the Hypoga≈øtricks, and from that Branch of the Spermaticks, that is in≈øerted into the bottom of the Womb, the Umbilical Ve≈ø≈øels of the Child come from the Chorion. The Womb-cake for the fir≈øt Month ≈øticks very fa≈øt to the Womb, but when the Child is come to Maturity, it ea≈øily ≈øeperates from the Womb, and falls from it like ripe fruit from a Tree, and after the Birth makes part of the Secundine. Next to the Womb-cake follow the two Membranes in which the Child is wrapt, the outer is called Chorion, the inner Amnios, and when the Child is perfectly formed, there is a third betwixt the other two called Allantois. The Chorion is ≈øomewhat thick, ≈ømooth on the in≈øide, but ≈øomething unequal or rough; and in that part of it, that ≈øticks to the Womb-cake, and thereby to the womb, there are
many Ve≈ø≈øels which ri≈øe from the Womb-cake it ≈øelf, and the Umbilical Ve≈ø≈øels. Twins are both encompa≈ø≈øed in one Chorion, but each a particular Amnios, it covers the Egg originally, and when the Egg is carried to the Womb, and becomes a Conception, this membrane ≈øucks up the moi≈øture that abounds in the womb at that time; for while the Conception is loo≈øe in the Womb, it is increa≈øed in the ≈øame manner, as an Egg in a Hen, which while it is in the knot, it is only a Yolk, and when it drops off from thence, and falls thro' the Infundibulum, it is not at all altered, but when it comes into the Cells of the Proce≈øs of the Womb, it begins to gather white, tho' it adhere to no part of the Womb, nor has any Umbilical Ve≈ø≈øels but as Eggs of Fi≈øhes and Frogs do without procure to them≈øelves whites out of the Water, or as Beans, Pea≈øe, and other Pul≈øe, and bread Corn, being ≈øteep'd in Moi≈øture, ≈øwell and ≈øo acquire Nouri≈øhment from the Bud that is ≈øpringing out of them. In like manner, does a whiti≈øh Moi≈øture flow out of the Wrinkles of the Womb, whence the Yolk gathers its white, and concocts it by its vegetative and innate heat: And indeed, the Liquor that abounds in the Wrinkles of the Womb, ta≈øts like the white; and in this manner, the Yolk falling by Degrees, is encompa≈ø≈øed with a white, till at la≈øt, the outmo≈øt Womb having got Skins and a Shell, is brought to perfection: Even ≈øo the Chorion ≈øucks up the albugineous Liquor that from the fir≈øt Conception increa≈øes daily in it, and ≈øweats thro' the Amnios, wherein the Embrio-≈øwims, till the Umbilical Ve≈ø≈øels and the Womb-cake are formed, from and thro' which, the Child may receive Nouri≈øhment. That Membrane that immediately contains the Child is called Amnios; it is joined to the Chorion only where the Umbilical Ve≈ø≈øels pa≈øs thro' them both into the Womb-cake, it is ≈øoft, ≈ømooth, very thin and tran≈øparent, and loo≈øely inve≈øts the Child, the ≈øhape of it is ≈øomewhat oval; it has Ve≈ø≈øels from the ≈øame Origins, as the Chorion. The Membrane call'd Allantoides is the third that encompa≈ø≈øes the whole Child; it is very probable that this as well as the other two was originally in the Egg, yet it does not appear, till after the formation of the Umbilical Ve≈ø≈øels and Womb-cake, and 'till the Albugineous Liquor cea≈øes to be ≈øuckt up by the Chorion out of the Womb: but as ≈øoon as the Child begins to be nouri≈øhed by the Umbilical Ve≈ø≈øels, and the Urachus is pa≈ø≈øable, then this Membrane begins pre≈øently to appear. is very thin, ≈ømooth, ≈øoft, and yet den≈øe, it may be di≈øtingui≈øhed from the Chorion and Amnios, becau≈øe they have a great many Ve≈ø≈øels di≈øper≈øed thro' them, but this has neither Vein nor Artery that is vi≈øible. After opening the Membranes that encompa≈øs the Child, the Navel-≈øtring appears, which is membranous, wreathed, and unequal, ari≈øing from the Navel, and reaching to the Womb-cake; it is about half an ell long, and a finger thick. The Urachus is the fourth Umbilical Ve≈ø≈øel, which is a ≈ømall membranous, round pipe, endued with a very ≈øtraight Cavity,
it ri≈øes from the bottom of the Bladder up to the Navel, out of which it pa≈ø≈øes along within the common Cover, and opens into the allantoides; the≈øe four Ve≈ø≈øels have one common Cover, which keeps each of them from touching the other, which is called funiculus, it is membranous, round and hollow, and con≈øi≈øts of a double Coat, it has ≈øeveral knots upon it here and there, whereby the Midwives gue≈øs how many Children more the Mother ≈øhall have; but this is vain and ≈øuper≈øtitious. There have been great di≈øputes among Phy≈øicians, with what, and by what way the Child is nouri≈øhed, ≈øome ≈øay by blood alone received by the umbilical Vein, others by chile alone conveyed in by the mouth; but indeed, according to the different degrees of perfection, that an Egg pa≈ø≈øes from a Conception to a Child fit for the Birth, it is nouri≈øhed differently; for as ≈øoon as an Egg is ripened, and falls into the womb, it immediately ≈øucks up thro' its outward membranes ≈øome of that albugonious liquor, wherewith at this time the internal ≈øuperficies of the womb is much moi≈øtened; and therefore as ≈øoon as the fir≈øt liniaments of the Child begin to the drawn out of that Humour contained in the Amnios, they are immediately increa≈øed by the appo≈øition of the ≈øaid liquor ≈øtrained out of the chorion thro' the amnios into its cavity; but when the parts of the Child begin to be a little more perfect, and the chorion is ≈øo den≈øe, that not any more of the ≈øaid liquor is ≈øuckt up by it, the umbillical Ve≈ø≈øels begin to be formed, and to extend to the ≈øide of the amnios, which
they penetrate, and both the Vein and the Arteries pa≈øs al≈øo through the allantois and Chorion, and are implanted into the Womb-cake, that at this time, fir≈øt gathering upon the Chorion, joins it to the womb, and now the hypoga≈øtrick and ≈øpermatick Arteries, that before carried the nutritious juice into the cavity of the womb, open by their orifices into the Womb-cake, where either by ≈øtraining through it, or by fermenting, they put off the ≈øaid juice, which is ≈øuckt up by the umbilical Vein, and carried by it, fir≈øt to the Liver, afterwards to the Heart of the Child, where the thin ≈øpirituous part of it is converted into blood, but the thick and earthy part going down by the aorta enters the umbilical Arteries, and by tho≈øe branches of them, that run through the amnios, is di≈øcharged into the cavity of it. Some perhaps may ridicule this pa≈ø≈øage of the nutritious juice, becau≈øe it is ≈øuppo≈øed, according to this account to chu≈øe its way, as if it were a rea≈øonable Creature, but they may as well expo≈øe the pa≈ø≈øage of the Chyle from the common duct to the Womb-cake, when the Child is in the Womb, for how ≈øhould the Chyle know, or the milky Ve≈ø≈øels by which it pa≈ø≈øes, that there is any Child in the Womb, that the one ≈øhould offer to go that way, and the other give it way to go thither at that time; whereas the pa≈ø≈øage is ≈øhut at other times; and yet this, they that laugh at this pa≈ø≈øage of the nutritious juice, allow; and how comes the Chyle to turn its cour≈øe pre≈øently after the Child is born, and in≈øtead of going down to the womb, ri≈øe up to the brea≈øts. What rea≈øon can be given for the≈øe and many other things in nature? We are therefore forced to confe≈øs, that there are many things in nature, that are only known to Almighty God, the maker of all things. There is al≈øo another objection again≈øt this opinion, becau≈øe it allows none of the Mothers blood to be received
by the Child thro' the Umbilical Vein, but only nutritious juice, and how ≈øhould it come to pa≈øs that the blood ≈øhould be bred in the Child, ≈øeeing it has blood before the Liver, or Heart, or any other part that a≈ø≈øi≈øts in the making blood, are in a condition to officiate. It is indeed very ≈øtrange, how blood ≈øhould be made ≈øo ≈øoon, but that it is made out of the Nutritious Juice, without the mixture of any from the Mother, is manife≈øt by Dr. Harvey's curious Ob≈øervations concerning the order of the generation of the parts in a Chicken, which from fir≈øt to la≈øt receives nothing from the head; (≈øays he) there appears at the very fir≈øt a red leaping Speck, a beating Bladder, and Fibres drawn from thence containing blood in them; and as far as one can di≈øcern by in≈øpection, blood is made before the leaping Speck is formed, and the ≈øame has vital heat, before it is ≈øtir'd by the Pul≈øe: And as the beating begins in the blood, and from it, ≈øo at la≈øt, at the point of Death it ends in it. And becau≈øe the beating Bladders, and the ≈øanguinous Fibres that are made from it, and are ≈øeen fir≈øt of all, it ≈øeems as if the blood were before its Receptacles. This Worthy Author, in his Treati≈øe of the generation of Animals, owns it is a Paradox, that blood ≈øhould be made, and moved, and have vital Spirit before any Organs for making blood or of motion have a being; and that the Body ≈øhould be nouri≈øhed and increa≈øed before the Stomach and Bowels the Organs of Concoction are framed. But neither of the≈øe are ≈øtranger, than that there ≈øhould be Sen≈øe and Motion before there is a Brain. And yet he ≈øays in his 57th Exercitation, that the Faetus moves, contracts, and ≈øtretches out it ≈øelf, when there is nothing to be ≈øeen for a Brain but clear water. Now if all the≈øe wonderful and unaccountable things do undoubtedly come to pa≈øs in an Egg, by the warmth of the Hen
only, why ≈øhould we count it a wonderful thing, that nutritious Juice impregnated with the vital Spirits of the arterial blood wherewith it circulates thro' the Mother's Heart, ≈øhould be turned into blood in a Child, comforted with the friendly warmth of the Womb, tho' the Mother ≈øends no humour to it under the form of Blood, and tho' it ≈øelf as yet has no perfect Organs to make Blood.

The thicker nutritious juice being put off in the Amnios, by the umbilical Arteries, the Child ≈øucks in ≈øome of it, as ≈øoon as the Mouth, Stomach, and the like are perfectly formed, which going down into the Stomach and Guts, is received by the milky Veins, as in grown people. Diemerbrock proves that the Child is nouri≈øhed this way, by the following Rea≈øons; fir≈øt, becau≈øe the Stomach of the Child is never empty, but has a milky whiti≈øh liquor in it, and in the mouth of the Child, there is al≈øo ≈øuch an humour. 2dly. Becau≈øe there are Excrements in the guts, and the Child voids them by ≈øtool, as ≈øoon as it is born, and certainly the≈øe are Excrements of ≈øome nouri≈øhment taken in by the Mouth. 3dly. Had not the Stomach been accu≈øtomed to perform Concoction in the Womb, it would not pre≈øently after the Birth perform the ≈øame. 4thly. Becau≈øe the Infant pre≈øently after it is born, knows how to ≈øuck the Brea≈øt, which it cannot be thought it could ≈øo readily do, if it had taken nothing by ≈øuction, while it was in the Womb. 5thly. Becau≈øe many Children vomit up a milky nouri≈øhment, as ≈øoon as they are born, before they have ≈øuckt any Brea≈øt, or taken any thing by the Mouth, which therefore mu≈øt needs be received into the Stomach.

Some ≈øay by way of Objection to what has bin before ≈øet down, if the Child be not nouri≈øhed by the Mothers blood, why ≈øhould her Cour≈øes be ≈øtopt, all or mo≈øt of the time ≈øhe goes with Child? to which may be an≈øwer ‚Ä¢ d,
that it is for the ≈øame rea≈øon, that Nur≈øes that give ≈øuck commonly want them al≈øo, for as in Nur≈øes, the Chyle pa≈ø≈øes in a great proportion to the Brea≈øts, whereby the Blood being defrauded of its due, and wonted ≈øhare, does not increa≈øe to that Degree, as to need to be le≈ø≈øened by the flowing of the Cour≈øes, ≈øo there is ≈øo great a quantity of the nutritious Juice, in women with Child that pa≈ø≈øes to the Womb-cake, by the Hypoga≈øtrick and Spermatick Arteries, for the Nouri≈øhment of the Child, that the Cour≈øes ≈øtop after the fir≈øt or ≈øecond Month, if the Woman be not very ≈øanguine.

The Child is nouri≈øhed three ≈øeveral ways, by one and the ≈øame humour, fir≈øt by appo≈øition, whil≈øt it is yet an imperfect Embryo, before the Umbilical Ve≈ø≈øels are framed: But when the Umbilical Ve≈ø≈øels are perfected, then it receives the ≈øame Liquor by the Umbilical Vein, the mo≈øt ≈øpirituous and thin part whereof, it changes into blood, and ≈øends the thicker part, by the Umbilical Artery into the Amnios, which the Child ≈øucks in at its Mouth, and being concocted again in the Stomach, is received out of the Guts by the mill ‚Ä¢ y Veins, as after the Birth.

The parts of a Child in the Womb differ very much from tho≈øe in a grown per≈øon. All the parts are le≈øs the bones are ≈øofter, and many of them gri≈øly and flexible; the head is proportionably bigger than the re≈øt of the Body, the Crown is not covered with Bone, but with a membrane, the Bone of the fore-head and under jaw is divided, the Bone of the hinder part of the Head is di≈øtingui≈øhed into three, four, or five Bones; the Brain and Nerves are ≈øofter than in grown per≈øons, the Bones that ≈øerve for hearing are very hard and big, the Brea≈øts ≈øwell, and out of them, in Children new born, whether Boy or Girl a ≈øerous milk flows forth, ≈øometimes of its own accord, ≈øometimes with a light pre≈ø≈øure.
The ≈øpinous proce≈ø≈øes of the Vertebrae of the Back are wanting; the Heart is very big, and its Ears large; there are two unions of the greater Ve≈ø≈øels that are not to be ≈øeen in grown per≈øons, namely, Fir≈øt the Oval Hole, whereby there is a pa≈ø≈øage open out of the hollow Vein into the Vein of the Lungs, ju≈øt as each of them are opening, the fir≈øt into the right ventricle, and the latter into the left Ventricle of the Heart; and this hole ju≈øt as it opens into the Vein of the Lungs has a Valve, that hinders any thing from returning out of the ≈øaid Vein into the hole. Secondly, the Arterial Channel, which two fingers breadth from the Ba≈øis of the Heart joins the Artery of the Lungs to the Aorta, it has a pretty large cavity, and a≈øcends a little obliquely from the ≈øaid Artery to the Aorta, into which it carries the Blood that was driven into the Artery of the Lungs out of the right Ventricle of the Heart, ≈øo that it never comes into the left Ventricle, as the Blood that is ≈øent out of the left Ventricle into the Aorta, never came to the right, but immediatly pa≈øt into it out of the hollow Vein by the Oval hole, ≈øo that the Blood does not pa≈øs thro' both the ventricles as it does after the Child is born. The Lungs will ≈øink before the Child is born, whereas if the Child be but born, and takes only half a dozen of breaths, they become ≈øpungy and light, that they will ≈øwim; and by this may be known whether tho≈øe Children that are murdered by Wenches, and which they commonly affirm they are ≈øtill-born, were really ≈øo or no; for if they were ≈øtill born, the Lungs will ≈øink, but if alive, ≈øo as to breath never ≈øo little a while, they will ≈øwim. The Umbilical Ve≈ø≈øels go out of the Belly, the Stomach is narrower, but pretty full of a whiti≈øh Liquor; the Caul can ≈øcarce be ≈øeen, being ≈øomewhat like a Spiders web, the Guts are ≈øeven times longer than the Body; in the
≈ømall Guts, the Excrements are flegmatick and yellow, but ≈øomewhat hard and blacki≈øh, ≈øometimes greeni≈øh in the thick Gut, the blind Gut is larger than u≈øual, and often fill'd with Excrements; the Liver is very large and has a pa≈ø≈øage more than in grown People, called the Veiny Channel, it carries the greate≈øt part of what is brought by the umbilical Vein, directly and in a full ≈øtream into the hollow Vein above the Liver; but as ≈øoon as the Child is born, this Channel clo≈øes pre≈øently, ≈øo do the Urachus, and the two umbilical Arteries, the ≈øpleen is ≈ømall, the Gall Bladder is full of Yellow or Green Choler, the Sweet-bread is very large and White, the Kidneys are big, and unequal, and ≈øeem, as if they were compounded of many Glaudules, the Ureteres are wide, and the Bladder is ≈øtretch'd with Urine.

div.head: SECT. IV. Of the formation of the Child in the Womb.
CHAP. I. Of the mixture of the Seed of both Sexes, as al≈øo of its ≈øub≈øtance and form.
div.p: AFTER that the Womb, which is the Genital Member of the Female Sex hath received the Seed of the Man, ≈øhe commixes al≈øo her own Seed, ≈øo that there is now but one mixture made of the Seed of both Sexes.

Now of the next matter, of the birth; There is a difference among the Learned, which being unnece≈ø≈øary
The natural forme of a child lying in ye womb.
for this place we ≈øhall let go, and ≈øtick clo≈øe to them, who affirm, that the ≈øeed of both Sexes, being confu≈øed in the Womb, doth make up the fir≈øt matter of the Birth; ≈øo that if there were not a mixture of both Seeds, it were impo≈ø≈øible that any generation could be. Yet though there be of nece≈ø≈øity a confu≈øion of both Seeds, we deny not but that their qualities are different, for the Seed of a man exceeds the Seed of a Woman, both in thickne≈øs and heat, which is more cold and moi≈øt, and therefore more watry. Yet though they differ thus in quality, it is not to be denied, but that the Seed of the Woman gives a mutual a≈ø≈øi≈øtance to the Seed of the Man, in the work of generation.

But it being unque≈øtionable, that the men≈øtruous Blood is the matter of the Womans Seed, therefore that ye may know the Original of it, it is to be under≈øtood that the Men≈øtruous blood is nothing el≈øe but an Excrement of the third concoction, gathered together every Month, and purged out. Which Purgation being duly made, the Woman is then in perfect health of body; but if they come not down according to their accu≈øtomed times, and ≈øea≈øons, or do not come down at all, the Woman neither can conceive nor engender.

Thus the Seeds of both Sexes meeting in the Womb, and there mixing together, they are pre≈øently enclo≈øed in a little Tunicle, begot by the heat of the Womb, and are there as it were coagulated and curdled together.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the three Tunicles which the birth is wrapt in, in the the Womb.
div.p:
FIRST, out of the extreme ≈øuperficies of the Seed, by rea≈øon of the more watry moi≈øture of the womans Seed, a thin Membrane is generated, which by
rea≈øon of its moi≈øt quality is dilated farther, being at fir≈øt tran≈øparent; but, after the Birth comes forth, folded up together, and is called the Secundine.

But of the ≈øuperfluous moi≈øture of the≈øe two Tunicles, are begot two other Tunicles, which defend the Infant from being clogged with any ≈øuperfluities, as from the Flowers retained after Conception, which ≈øerve neither for the nouri≈øhment, nor for the increa≈øe of the Infant. Yet are they retained 'till the very time of the Birth: At which time they are either let out by the hand of the Midwife; or el≈øe bur≈øting the Secondine wherein they are contained, they flow out of them≈øelves.

The ≈øecond Tunicle is that which was anciently called Allantoides, wrapping about all the interiour parts, frrom the Navel downwards; this is full of folds and wrinckles; in which the Urine, Sweat, and other ≈øharp Humours that di≈øtill from the Infant, almo≈øt grown to maturity, are contained and kept to the time of Delivery.

By this ≈øecond Tunicle, therefore the Infant is delivered, and defended from tho≈øe humours, le≈øt they ≈øhould either corrode, and hurt the tender skin of the Infant, or el≈øe any way defile and foul the Infant.
The third Tunicle, within all the≈øe, compa≈ø≈øes the whole Birth round about, defending it from all ≈øharp exteriour humours, being very ≈øoft and tender.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the true generation of the parts, and the increa≈øe of them, according to the ≈øeveral days and ≈øea≈øons.
div.p:
AFTER the Womb hath received the Genital Seed, and by its heat hath ≈øhut them both up, curdled and coagulated together, from the fir≈øt to the ≈øeventh day are generated many fibres, bred by a hot
motion, in which not long after, the Liver with its chief Organs is fir≈øt formed. Through which Organs the vital ≈øpirit being ≈øent to the Seed, within the tenth day forms, and di≈øtingui≈øhes the chiefe≈øt members. This Spirit is let in through certain Veins of the Secondine, through which the Blood flows in and out, of which the Navel is generated. At the ≈øame time, in the clotted Seed there do appear three white lumps, not unlike curdled Milk, out of which ari≈øe the Liver, the Brain, and the Heart.
Pre≈øently after this, a Vein is directed through the Navel, to ≈øuch the thicker ≈øort of the Blood that remains in the Seed, for the nouri≈øhment of the parts. This Vein is two-forked.

In the other branch of this Vein is a certain blood collected,The Liver framed. out of which the Liver is fir≈øt framed; for the Liver is nothing but a certain ma≈øs of Blood, or Blood coagulated, and hardned to a ≈øub≈øtance: And here you may ≈øee what a company of Veins it hath, which ≈øerve both for the expul≈øive, and attractive faculty. In the other Branch are generated tho≈øe Textures of Veins, with a dilatation of other Veins, as al≈øo of the Spleen, and the Guts in the lower part of the Belly; by and by all the Veins like branches gathering into one Trunk, toward the upper part of the Liver, meet all in the Concave or hollow Vein. This Trunk ≈øends other branches of Veins, to con≈øtitute the Diaphragme, others it ≈øends into the upper part of the back-bone, ≈øeated about the Diaphragme, as al≈øo the lower parts, as far as the Thighs.
Afterwards the Heart with its Veins, directed from the Navel to that part of the Seed, and carried as far as the Back-bone, is formed.

The≈øe Veins ≈øuck the hotte≈øt,The Heart formed. and mo≈øt ≈øubtil part of the Blood, out of which the
heart is generated in the membrane of the heart, otherwi≈øe called the Pericardium, being by nature thick and fle≈øhy, according as the heat of the Members requires. Now the hollow vein extending it ≈øelf and piercing the interior part of the right ≈øide of the heart, carries blood thither for the nouri≈øhment of the heart: From the ≈øame branch of this vein, in the ≈øame part of the heart ari≈øes another vein called by ≈øome the ≈øtill vein, becau≈øe it beats not with ≈øo quick a Pul≈øe as the others do, ordained to ≈øend the mo≈øt purely concocted blood in the heart to the lungs, being encompa≈ø≈øed with two Tunicles like Arteries, But in the concavity of the left part of the heart ari≈øes a great beating vein, called the Aorta, diffu≈øing the vital ≈øpirit from the heart into all the beating veins in the body.

Under the ≈øaid vein called the Aorta, in the concavity of the heart, there is another vein called the veiny Artery, which was therefore framed to carry the cool air from the lungs to temper the great heat of the heart.

Now there being many veins, which running from the concavity of the heart, are in≈øerted into the lungs, therefore by the≈øe veins the lungs are al≈øo framed; for the vein which proceeds from the right concavity, produces a mo≈øt ≈øubtile blood, which is turned into the ≈øub≈øtance of the lungs. By the great veins of the heart and liver the hollow vein, and the Aorta is the whole brea≈øt generated, and after that the arms, and legs in order.

Within the fore≈øaid time, is generated the la≈øt and chiefe≈øt part of this ≈øub≈øtance, that is to ≈øay, Brain, in the third little skin of this ma≈øs: For the whole ma≈øs of the Seed being repleat with vital ≈øpirits, that vital ≈øpirit contracts a great part of the Genital moi≈øture into one certain hollowne≈øs, where the Brain is formed; outwardly it is covered with a certain covering, which being baked and dried by the heat, is reduced into a bone, and ≈øo is the Skull made.

Now the Brain is ≈øo formed as to conceive, retain, and change the nature of all the vital ≈øpirits, whence are the beginings of Rea≈øon, and of all the Sen≈øes; for, as out of the Liver ari≈øe the Veins, out of the Heart ari≈øe the Arteries, ≈øo out of the Brain ari≈øe the Nerves of a more ≈øoft and gentle nature, yet not hollow like Veins, but ≈øollid. The≈øe are the cheife≈øt in≈øtruments of all the Sen≈øes and by which all the motion of the Sen≈øes are made by the vital Spirit.

After the Nerves, is generated by the Brain, al≈øo the pith of the back-bone, which cannot be called Marrow: For the Marrow is a ≈øuperfluous ≈øub≈øtance begot out of the Blood, de≈øtined for the moi≈øtening, and for the ≈øtrengthening of the bones: but the brain and pith of the back-bone take their beginning from the Seed, being not de≈øtined for the nouri≈øhing, or ≈øtrengthning of the members but to con≈øtitute certain private and particular parts of the body, for the motion and u≈øe the Sen≈øes, that all the other. Nerves may take their begining thence; for from the pith of the back-bone, do ari≈øe many Nerves, by which the body obtains both ≈øen≈øe and motion.

Here is al≈øo to be noted, that out of the Seed it ≈øelf are generated gri≈øtles, bones, tunicles, for the Veins of the Liver, the arteries of the heart, the brain with its Nerves: be≈øides, the tunicles and pannicles, and the other coverings which the Infant is wrapt in. Now of the proper blood of the Birth, the fle≈øh is formed; and whatever parts are of a fle≈øhy ≈øub≈øtance; as the heart, the liver, the lights, Then are all the≈øe nouri≈øhed by the men≈øtrous blood, which is attracted through the veins of the Navel. This is all di≈øtinctly done from the conception unto the eighteenth day of the fir≈øt month, in all which time it is called Seed. After which it receives the name of Birth.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of the nouri≈øhment of the Birth in the Womb.
div.p: WHil≈øt the Birth remains in the Womb, it is cheri≈øhed up with blood attracted through the Navel, which is the rea≈øon that the flowers do cea≈øe alwayes in Women, as ≈øoon as they have conceived.

Now this blood, pre≈øently after conception, is di≈øtingui≈øhed into three parts; the pure≈øt of it drawn by the Child for the nouri≈øhment of it ≈øelf; the ≈øecond, which is le≈øs pure and thin, the Womb forces upwards to the brea≈øt, where it is turned into milk. The third and mo≈øt impure part of the blood remains in the Matrix, and comes away with the Secondines, both in the Birth, and after the Birth,

Now the Infant being thus formed and perfected in the womb for the fir≈øt month ≈øends forth its Urine thro' the pa≈ø≈øages of the navel; but in the la≈øt month that pa≈ø≈øage being ≈øhut up through the privy-members; yet notwith≈øtanding, while the child is in the Womb, he voids nothing out at the Fundament, becau≈øe he hath taken no nouri≈øhment in at the Mouth. After the forty fifth day it receives life, and is then called an Infant.

Now, though the Infant hath by this time obtained ≈øen≈øe, yet doth he not move: He mo≈øt commonly moves in twice the time that he was formed, and in thrice the ≈øpace after he began his motion, he ha≈øtens into the world; as for example, if the infant were formed in forty five days, it will move in ninety, and be born the ninth month after that.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the condition of the Infant in the Womb, in the ≈øixth, ≈øeventh, and eighth month.
div.p: AFter the third and fourth month, the Infant is nouri≈øhed with more plenty of nouri≈øhment, until the time of delivery approach. Now you mu≈øt ob≈øerve that a child born in the ≈øixth month cannot live, by rea≈øon that it is not come to its ju≈øt perfection; but if it be born in the ≈øeventh month, it will very ea≈øily live, becau≈øe it is come to its full perfection. Now the rea≈øon why tho≈øe that are born in the eighth month do not live, when as tho≈øe that are born in the ≈øeventh do, is plain; for in the ≈øeventh month the Infant ≈øtirs it ≈øelf to come forth; ≈øo that if it have ≈øo much ≈øtrength it ea≈øily performs its de≈øire; if not, it remains in the womb, till it have gathered two months more ≈øtrength. After this motion of the ≈øeventh month, if it be not able to come forth, it changes it ≈øelf into another part of the womb, by which motion it is ≈øo weakened, that if it ≈øhould be born in the eighth month, it were impo≈ø≈øible that it ≈øhould live, for it is weakened by a double motion; not only that of the ≈øeventh month, but al≈øo by that motion whereby it ≈øtrives to go forth in the eighth month.

div.head: SECT. V.
CHAP. I. Of the ≈øituation of the Child in the Womb.
div.p:
COncerning the ≈øituation of the Child in the womb, it may be con≈øidered either generally, or ≈øpecially;
≈øpecially, either as it concerns the Male, or the Female.
The Male is commonly ≈øituated in the right ≈øide of the Womb the Female in the left.

The general ≈øituation of the Child, either Male, or Female, in the Womb, is always the ≈øame which hath been ob≈øerved and ≈øeen to be in this po≈øture, when the Infant lies with his Back and his Buttocks leaning again≈øt the Back of the Mother, the Head inclined, and touching his Brea≈øt with his Chin; re≈øting his two Hands upon his Knees; his Navel and his No≈øe between his two Knees, with his two Eyes upon his two Thumbs, his Legs folded backward, and touching his Buttocks with each Leg.
This Figure is the mo≈øt natural, as being lea≈øt ≈øubject to ≈øuffer any accident, being le≈øs inconvenient, and le≈øs trouble≈øome to the Mother.
The mo≈øt natural form for the Child to come into the World, is when the Head comes forward, the Hands being ≈øtretched upon the Hips.

The things which are the Cau≈øes of a Womans delivery, are three; fir≈øt, the want of re≈øpiration and Air for the Infant. The ≈øecond is the want of nouri≈øhment, of which, when the Infant finds a defect in his Mothers Womb he is forced to ≈øeek it in another place. The third is the narrowne≈øs of the place where the Infant lies, ≈øo that he is forced to ≈øeek room other where, which makes him to break the Membranes, wherein he was contained, pre≈ø≈øing and con≈øtraining the Mother by the ≈øharpne≈øs of tho≈øe Waters, to do her duty for his relea≈øe. Now as ≈øome ≈øay, there are three ways or manners of Childrens coming upon the Earth; Fir≈øt, when the Head comes foremo≈øt, and then the Woman is ea≈øily delivered: The ≈øecond, when it comes forth a-cro≈øs, or one ≈øide, or the Feet foremo≈øt, and then the Woman
≈øuffers much, and either they both die, or one of them, As for tho≈øe Births which are unnatural, we ≈øhall in another place treat of them, and their remedies. In this combate, the Infant and the Mother ≈øuffer very much, by rea≈øon that Woman is a Creature delicate and timerous, and not patient of much labour: or, becau≈øe women great with Child live a lazy and ≈øloathful life; and be≈øides that, many times they eat bad victuals, which encrea≈øes Humours and ≈øuperfluous Excrements, which quantity of Humours makes the Woman to breath ≈øhort, which is a thing very trouble≈øome to the Infant; for a Woman that will expel the Birth quick, ought to keep her breath in, as much as ≈øhe can. The third Rea≈øon of the pain in Womens Travail, is by rea≈øon that the Head of a Child is bigger, being compared to the Members, than the Head of any other Creature, which makes a greater opening and dilaceration.

But the Women that ≈øuffer mo≈øt pain, are they who were not delivered before, having not been accu≈øtomed to the ≈øufferance of that labour; as al≈øo elderly Women, by rea≈øon that the Bone of the Pubes, the Bone of the Hip, and the Os Sacrum, are not ≈øo ea≈øily ≈øeparated, the
‚Ä¢ igaments being more ≈øtrong and hard.
Now in the contention which the Child makes to i≈ø≈øue forth, the Head comes fir≈øt, by rea≈øon of the weight, being more heavy than the other Members.
