div.head: SECT. IV.
CHAP. I. Of Midwives.
div.p: ALthough in the≈øe days there are many unskilful Women that take upon them the knowledge of Midwifry, barely upon the priviledge of their age: Yet there are many things which ought to be ob≈øerved in a Midwife, that they are utterly wanting of. Let us therefore con≈øider of the things required in a Midwife, in relation both to her Per≈øon, and her manners: As for her Age, ≈øhe ought to be neither too young, nor too old,Her Age. in a good habit of Body, and not ≈øubject to Di≈øea≈øes, nor mi≈ø≈øhapen in any parts of her Body, peculiar in her Habits, and in her Per≈øon; her Hands mu≈øt be ≈ømall. with her Nails pared clo≈øe, without any Rings upon them, in the time of her Duty, nor Bracelets upon her Wri≈øts; ≈øhe mu≈øt be chearful, plea≈øant, ≈øtrong, laborious, and u≈øed to travel; it being required that ≈øhe ≈øhould be ≈øtirring at all Hours, and abiding a long time together with her Patient.
For her Manners, ≈øhe ought to be Courteous, Sober, Cha≈øte; not repining,Her Manners. Cholerick, Arrogant, or Covetous, nor apt to talk of what ≈øhe ≈øees in the Hou≈øes where ≈øhe hath to do.
Her Spirit.For her Spirit; ≈øhe ought to be prudent, wary, and cunning, oft-times to u≈øe fair and flattering words.

She ought moreover to know, that God hath given to all things their Beginnings, their Increa≈øings, their E≈øtate of Perfection, and Declination: Therefore the ≈øaid Midwife, nor any of her a≈ø≈øi≈øtants, mu≈øt not do any thing ra≈øhly, for to precipitate or ha≈øten Nature.

div.head: CHAP. II. What ought to be ob≈øerved, when the Woman is near the time of her lying down.
div.p: Of Women near the time of their lying down.THE Hour of the Womans lying down approaching, the Woman with Child ought to prepare her ≈øelf in this manner; ≈øhe mu≈øt pre≈øently call her Midwife and A≈ø≈øi≈øtants to her, it being requi≈øite to have them rather ≈øooner than later.

Her Bed.She ought to prepare a little Bed, or Couch, of a moderate heighth, as well for the covenience of the Midwife, as for the ea≈øe of her ≈øelf, and others that ≈øhall be about her to a≈ø≈øi≈øt her in her Travel: This mu≈øt be ≈øituated in a place convenient for the People to pa≈øs up and down, near the fire, and far from Doors: It will be requi≈øite for her to have change of Linnen, as al≈øo a little Cricket for her to re≈øt her feet on, having more force when her Feet are bowed.

In the time of Travel what to do.When ≈øhe finds her Pains growing, it will be nece≈ø≈øary for her to walk lei≈øurely up and down the Chamber, afterwards ≈øhe may lye down warm, and then ri≈øe and walk again, expecting the coming down of her Waters, and the opening of the Womb. For to keep her ≈øelf long a-bed, is very trouble≈øome: Though when ≈øhe is
a-bed notwith≈øtanding that ≈øhe hath ≈øome certain pains ≈øometimes, yet ≈øhe may lie and re≈øt her ≈øelf, and now and then take a nap: By which means, both the Mother and the Infant do with greater ≈øtrength endure their ≈øucceeding hard≈øhip; be≈øides that, her waters do come down better. If her Travel be long, ≈øhe may take ≈øome broth, or the yolk of a porched Egg, with ≈øome bread, or a cup of wine, or di≈øtilled water; yet ≈øhe mu≈øt have a care le≈øt ≈øhe over-charge her ≈øelf either with meat or drink.

It is certain, that all women are not delivered alike; for ≈øome lie in their bed, others ≈øit in a chair, being ≈øupported and held up by others, or el≈øe re≈øting upon the ≈øide of the bed or chair; others upon their knees, being upheld under their arms; but the be≈øt and ≈øafe≈øt is to lie in their beds; and for her good and convenient delivery, let the Midwife and others ob≈øerve what follows.

Fir≈øt, the woman that is in travel, ought to be laid upon her back,Certain Rules. her head being lifted up a little higher with a pillow, having al≈øo a pillow under her reins to ≈øu≈øtain her back; under her buttocks ≈øhe mu≈øt have a larger pillow, to rai≈øe them a little, and that her rump may be elevated; for a woman that lies low in tho≈øe parts, can never be well delivered, for the avoiding of which, this ≈øituation is very convenient. Her thighs and knees mu≈øt be a good way ≈øeparated the one from the other, with her legs bowed, and drawn up towards her buttocks, the ≈øoles of her feet, and her heels, being fixed upon a board, laid thwart the bed for that purpo≈øe.

Secondly, to ≈øome women they do u≈øe a ≈øwath-band four double; this ≈øwath-band mu≈øt be a foot broad or more; which being put under her reins, is to be held
up ≈øtreight, by two per≈øons ≈øtanding on each ≈øide ju≈øt at the time of her pains, both of them, at the ≈øame in≈øtant, heaving up both ends, with an exact evene≈øs; for otherwi≈øe it does more harm than good. It is al≈øo requi≈øite, that two of her friends ≈øhould hold the upper part of her ≈øhoulders, that ≈øhe may be able to force out the Birth with more advantage; And it will not be ami≈øs, for ≈øome of her friends to pre≈øs the upper parts of her belly, ≈øo to thru≈øt down the Infant, by little and little. Such a ≈øoft compre≈ø≈øion, will much facilitate the travel, and give ea≈øe to the womans pains.

Thirdly, as for the woman her ≈øelf, ≈øhe mu≈øt be of a good heart, and force her ≈øelf by ≈øtriving as much as po≈ø≈øibly ≈øhe can; ≈øtopping her mouth, and keeping her breath, as if ≈øhe were doing the ordinary deeds of nature.
As for the Cholick, if it ≈øeize Women in Travail, you may read the Remedies in the following Chapter.

div.head: CHAP. III. How to expel the Cholick from Women in Child-bed.
div.p: THere are ≈øome women, who at the ≈øame in≈øtant that they are in travel, are taken with fits of the Cholick; which is often cau≈øed by the crudities and indige≈øtions of the ≈øtomach, which do torment women ≈øo extremely, that it exceeds the pain of their Travel; and while this pain la≈øts, a woman advances nothing toward the end of her Travel: the pain of Travel being hardly to be di≈øtingui≈øhed from it.

For her ea≈øe therefore, the woman ought to take the≈øe Remedies; two ounces of oyl of ≈øweet Almonds, with an ounce of Cinnamon water, or el≈øe ≈øome wind di≈øpelling Cly≈øter, and if the fir≈øt time ≈øuffice not, you may re-iterate it; and ≈øometimes fomentations, that are
proper for the di≈øpelling of wind, are very nece≈ø≈øary for this purpo≈øe.

div.head: CHAP. IV. How the Midwife may know when the pains of Travel do ≈øeize upon a woman.
div.p: WHen the Woman begins to cry out, and hath ≈øent for her Widwife; the fir≈øt thing that the Midwife is to ask, is, when ≈øhe did conceive? 2. Then is ≈øhe to look diligently upon the belly of the Woman and to mark it well; for if ≈øhe do behold the upper parts of the belly ≈øunk and hollow, and the lower parts of the belly full and big, ≈øhe may then conclude that the Child is fallen down. 3. She ought then to ask her ≈øome que≈øtions concerning her pains; for if they be quick and ≈øtrong, begining at the Reins, and ≈øliding down all along the belly, without ending at the Navel, but ≈øtill falling down upon the groins, and inwardly at the bottom of the belly, below which is the interiour neck of the womb; the≈øe are certain ≈øigns that the woman begins to be in Labour. 4. But for more certainty, the Midwife may put up her hand, being anointed fir≈øt with fre≈øh butter, and if ≈øhe perceive the inner neck of the womb to dilate it ≈øelf, 'tis a certain ≈øign that the pains of Child-bed are upon the woman, or if ≈øhe perceive any thing to pu≈øh forwards her travel is al≈øo undoubtable.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the falling down of the waters, a good while before the woman travels.
div.p:
THere are ≈øome women, who have their waters come from them, a long time before their travel, ≈øometimes
twelve days, ≈øometimes eight Days, ≈øometimes ≈øix and ≈øometimes four; though the ordinary time be not above three Hours before her travel; they remaining for the mo≈øt part not above twenty four Hours. This is cau≈øed by ≈øome Ruptures of the Membranes, where, from the beginning of the formation of the Child, the Humour is contained, rather than by the abundance of Humours; and therefore though a Woman that hath abundance, and that the Membranes containing them, are ≈øo ≈øtrong, that they will not break ≈øuddenly, though the Woman ≈øhall not travel 'till they break, yet the Midwife ought not to break them, but rather hold the Voman over a Ve≈ø≈øel of warm Water and al≈øo u≈øe ≈øome ≈øoftning Liniment, to ≈øoften the, Membranes, that ≈øo the Mother ≈øtraining, the Head or other Member of the Child, may break them more ea≈øily.

But for tho≈øe Women that have the≈øe evacuations ≈øo long before they travel, they mu≈øt refrain going into the Air, for fear of injuring them≈øelves, the pa≈ø≈øages being open; for though the Air cannot hinder the Child from coming forth, by rea≈øon of its weight, yet oftentimes getting within the Secondine, it not only ≈øtreightens the Ve≈ø≈øels, and Mouths of the Veins, that are at the bottom of the Womb, but al≈øo cau≈øes ≈øeveral Convul≈øions, to the great danger of the Woman: But it is an ea≈øie thing to remedy the≈øe accidents, by keeping clo≈øe in her Chamber, having al≈øo a ≈øpecial regard to di≈øtingui≈øh, whether they be the Waters of the Birth, or any Hydropick humour of the Matrix.

div.head: CHAP. VI. What the Midwife ought to do in time of Travel.
div.p:
THE Midwife ≈øeeing the Birth come naturally, the Pains now coming thicker and thicker, the
Womb al≈øo opening to be deliver'd of its Burden, and the endeavours of the Child being ≈øeen to come forth; the Midwife mu≈øt now encourage her Patient, admoni≈øhing her to ≈øhut her Mouth, and to hold her breath, and to ≈øtrain and endeavour with her lower parts: Neither ought the Midwife to be too ha≈øty, either to widen or force the pa≈ø≈øage of the Infant, or to break the Membranes, but to ≈øtay 'till the Membranes do bur≈øt of their own accord.

And here is to be noted the ignorance of ≈øome Women, who for ha≈øte to be gone to other Women do tear the Membranes with their Nails, to the danger both of the Woman and of the Child, which then remains dry, without that moi≈øture which makes the pa≈ø≈øage ≈ølippery; which mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øity augment the pain of the Woman.

When the Head comes forth of the Womb, the Midwife mu≈øt take it gently between her two Hands, and then when her Pains encrea≈øe, ≈ølipping down her Hands under the Arm-holes, gently drawing forth the Infant, yet ≈øtaying her Hand always, but when the Pains come upon the Woman: This mu≈øt be done with a very delicate and tender Hand, le≈øt the Child, by any rude or har≈øh handling, ≈øhould receive any deformed ≈øhape of Body.

When the Child is come into the World, which is commonly with his Face downward, it mu≈øt be ≈øuddenly turned upon his back, le≈øt it ≈øhould be ≈øtifled for want of Air. Then let her cut the Navel-≈øtring, leaving the length of four Fingers, tying it with a ≈øilk Thread as near the Belly as may be: Which done, the Child if it be well, may be laid a≈øide, only care mu≈øt be had, that the Head and the Stomach be well covered, and that nothing come upon his Face.

div.head: CHAP. VII. How to draw forth the Secondines.
div.p: THE Child being thus drawn forth, and in ≈øafety, the Midwife mu≈øt now apply her ≈øelf to the drawing out of the Secondines, which mu≈øt be done by wagging and ≈øtirring them up and down, and then gently drawing them forth, cau≈øing the Woman to take Salt in both her Hands, and to ≈øhut them clo≈øe, and then to blow in them whereby you ≈øhall know whether they be broken or no: It may be done al≈øo by cau≈øing her to put one Finger in her Mouth, to provoke a de≈øire of vomiting, or el≈øe by ≈øtirring, as when ≈øhe is doing the ordinary deeds of Nature, or as Nature it ≈øelf con≈øtrained her to do, before the Head of the Child was come forth. All this mu≈øt be done ≈øpeedily; yet if this be not ≈øufficient, ≈øhe may take the Yolk of an Egg raw, or ≈øhe may take a ≈ømall draught of raw Elder-water, or you may cau≈øe her to ≈ømell to a piece of A≈ø≈øa Foetida. If ≈øhe be troubled with Wind-Cholicks, or have taken Cold, which oftentimes doth breed Wind, which is a great hindrance to the coming forth of the Secondines; the Midwife ought to chafe the Womans Belly with her Hand, which doth not only break the wind, but cau≈øes the Secondine to come down. If this fails, the Midwife may with her Hand dilate the Orifice of the womb drawing it forth gently and by Degrees.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. What may be given to a Woman in Travel.
div.p: IN the fir≈øt place, hot and violent Remedies are to be avoided, but in ca≈øes of great nece≈ø≈øity; for it many times happens that they are the cau≈øe of dangerous ‚Ä¢ eavers.

Two other things are al≈øo very dangerous to a Woman in Travel, too much repletion, and too much emptine≈øs; for the Stomach of a Woman with Child doth not dige≈øt her meat in ≈øo ≈øhort a time as Women that are not with Child do; Therefore the Midwife ought to inform her ≈øelf how long it was ≈øince ≈øhe eat, and in what quantity; and if it were long ≈øince ≈øhe did eat, and that ≈øhe grow feeble, they may give in the intermi≈ø≈øions of her Pains ≈øome warm cheri≈øhing and Cordial Broths, or the Yolk of a poached Egg: If her Travel endure long, then to ≈øtrengthen her and comfort her, ≈øhe may take a draught of Cinnamon-water, not exceeding an ounce, or at twice, a dram of the Confection of Alkermes; di≈ø≈øolved into two ≈øpoonfuls of Claret-Wine, and not more than one of the≈øe three things. For if they take two much, as is before ≈øaid, it cau≈øes Fevers, and Heats in the whole Body, of which follow many inconveniencies, for it ≈øtops the Purgations, of which many ≈øtrange Di≈øea≈øes en≈øue.

div.head: CHAP. IX. How to put the Womb again in its place.
div.p: SOME Women newly brought to Bed, are many times afflicted with greater Pains than tho≈øe of their Travel, by rea≈øon that the womb is not well put into its place, or if it have, the Swathe-band being loo≈øe, it is apt to roul upwards in the Belly. This happens to Women that are not well purged after their Delivery; for remedy hereof, having put the Matrix right into its place, rowl up two linnen Swathes pretty hard, bringing them al≈øo round the Hips; then take whites of Eggs, beaten, and a dram of Pepper in Powder, which being ≈øpread upon Tow, is to be applied warm to the Navel; then let the Belly be well ≈øwathed. This is the only remedy to ea≈øe the Pain.

div.head: CHAP. X. Again≈øt the extreme lo≈øs of blood, which happens to women immediately after their delivery.
div.p:
THere are many women which immediately after their Delivery do ≈øuffer great lo≈øs of blood, which proceeds from a great plentitude or fulne≈øs; or by rea≈øon that in their travel they took too many hot and corro≈øive medecines; or, by ≈øtraining them≈øelves too hard over-heated the blood, ≈øo that after Travel, it runs from them in great quantity. To remedy this, the woman ought to take a ≈ømall quantity of wine, in a ≈øpoon; and if the weakne≈øs be much, let her mix half a dram of Alkermes, with a draught of wine, and take care that ≈øhe be well ≈øwaithed upward; for that pre≈ø≈øes down and ≈øtreightens the ve≈ø≈øels, and hinders the violent flux: Give her al≈øo the yolk of an Egg to take, for that recalls the natural heat to the ≈øtomach, which was di≈øper≈øed through the whole. It would be nece≈ø≈øary al≈øo, to ≈øpread along the reins of the woman and all along the back-bone, by rea≈øon of the hollow vein, a napkin dipt in Oxicrate, or Water mingled with Vinegar. You may al≈øo lay upon each groin, a Skein of raw Silk, moi≈øtned in cold Water, Take al≈øo of that well tempered Earth, of which they make the Floor of an Oven, and ≈øteep it in ≈øtrong Vinegar, then ≈øpread it upon a linnen Cloath, and lay it upon the Reins; this moderates the heat of the Blood, and ≈øtops the violent flux of it: Great care mu≈øt be al≈øo had, that all the while the blood comes from her, ≈øhe do not ≈øleep, for many times they are taken away in that weakne≈øs, when the people think they do but take their Re≈øt: But when you ≈øee this great Flux moderated, you may take away the a≈øtringent Medicines by little and little, ≈øo that the Blood may cea≈øe
running by degrees, le≈øt any blood ≈øhould be retained that may chance to do mi≈øchief.

div.head: CHAP. XI. What is to be done to a woman pre≈øently after her Delivery.
div.p: PRe≈øently after a woman is delivered, if ≈øhe have had a ≈øore Travel, they ought to ca≈øt her into the skin of a Sheep flead alive, and put about her Reins as hot as may be; upon her Belly al≈øo lay the Skin of a Hare flead alive, having cut the Throat of it afterwards, and rubbed the Skin with the Blood, which is to be clapt as warm as may be to her Belly.
This clo≈øes up the dilatations made by the Birth, and cha≈øes from tho≈øe parts the ill and melancholy Blood. The≈øe remedies are to be kept on two hours in Winter, and one hour in Summer.

After this ≈øwathe the Woman with a Napkin about a quarter of a yard large, having before chafed the belly with Oyl of St. John's-wort. Then rai≈øe up the Matrix with a linnen Cloath many times folded; then with a little pillow about a quarter of a yard long cover her Flanks, then u≈øe the Swathe, beginning a little above the Hanches, yet rather higher than lower, winding it pretty tite, Lay al≈øo warm Cloaths upon the nipples, letting alone tho≈øe remedies which are proper for the driving back of the Milk, which are not ≈øo ≈øoon to be applied, for the body is now all in a commotion, and there is neither vein nor artery which doth not beat: Wherefore tho≈øe Remedies that cha≈øe away the Milk, being all di≈ø≈øolving, therefore it is not proper to put ≈øuch Medicines upon the Brea≈øt during that commotion, for fear that tho≈øe medecines ≈øhould make a ≈øtop of any thing hurtful in tho≈øe parts, and
therefore it is better to give ten or twelve hours for the Blood to ≈øettle in; as al≈øo for that which was ca≈øt upon the Lungs by the agitation of Travel, to di≈øtil down again into its place.

You may al≈øo make a re≈øtrictive of the white and yellow of an Egg beaten together, with an Ounce af Oyl of St. John's-wort, and an ounce of Oyl of Ro≈øes, an ounce of Ro≈øe-water, and an ounce of Plantain-water, beat all the≈øe together very well; in this you may dip a linnen cloath folded double, and apply it without warming of it to the Brea≈øts: This comforts and ea≈øes the pains of that part.
She mu≈øt not ≈øleep pre≈øently; but a matter of four hours after her delivery, you may give her ≈øome nouri≈øhing Broth, or Caudle, and then if ≈øhe will, ≈øhe may ≈øleep.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Of women that have a great deal of Blood, and purge not, neither in their travel nor after.
div.p:
SOme women have great Superfluity of Blood, and yet purge not at all, neither in their Travel, nor afterwards; to which, if remedies be not applied, the Women do run great Hazards and Dangers in their lying in, great Suffocations of the Matrix, and continual Feavers; this may be remedied, being fir≈øt informed of their natural di≈øpo≈øition before they were with Child; knowing that when they had their purgations, they had them in great quantity, and for a good while together, as al≈øo when they came, being a gro≈øs and thick Blood; and therefore ≈øeeing that now they do not purge in great quantity, and that they have divers unquietne≈ø≈øes, weakne≈ø≈øes of the Stomach, and pains of the head; wherefore you may give her in the Morning a little Syrup of Maiden-hair, and Hy≈øop-water
mingled together, and Syrup of Wormwood, with White-wine; in their broths you may boyl Jacines and opening Herbs, keeping the belly ≈øoluble with Cly≈øters; ≈øhe mu≈øt eat no ≈øolid Meat, ≈øhe mu≈øt be well chafed from the Groins down to the very Ankle-bone, always ≈øtrokeing and carrying the hand down-ward; Blood-letting al≈øo in the Foot in the morning is not ami≈øs; as al≈øo fome Fumigation that clean≈øes the Matrix, and draws down the Blood: Yet care mu≈øt be had, that the≈øe la≈øt Remedies be not u≈øed before the Matrix be put into its place, for fear that the≈øe remedies ≈øhould draw it down too low, but about eight or ten Days after the Matrix was put into its place. For clean≈øing the Matrix, you may u≈øe this Receipt.

Take Pellitory, Sanicle, Camomile, Melilot, Greenbalm, Red-balm, white Mullein, Mallows, Mar≈øhmallow, Betony, Margeram, Nipp, March-violets, Mugwort; take of each a like quantity, and cut them ≈ømall, and let them boyl in a new pot, with three pints of good White-wine; let the Woman take the fume of this Receipt three times in a day; if ≈øhe have any gro≈øs Blood in the Matrix, it will undoubtedly bring it down: You may al≈øo chafe the Womans Belly with Oyl of Violets, this helps the Purgations being once di≈ø≈øolved. The rea≈øon why this thick Blood ≈øtays in the≈øe parts, is, becau≈øe the Woman having it before ≈øhe was with Child, the heat of the Womb, when ≈øhe is with Child redoubling thickens it more, ≈øo that when ≈øhe comes to lie down, it cannot flow; ≈øo that it is to be taken away as much as may be with the afore≈øaid means; Mollyfying Fomentations are al≈øo proper for this purpo≈øe, while the woman ≈øits over the fumigation.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. For tho≈øe who have but a little blood.
div.p: THo≈øe Women that have but little blood, ought not to lie in their beds as tho≈øe who have a great deal. They ought to take good nouri≈øhment in a little quantity: As Eggs well boyld in the ≈øhell in a Morning: The juyce of Mutton and Veal, ≈øqueezed out, and Mutton broth; and all the≈øe being mingled together, nouri≈øh very much, and make very good blood; as al≈øo Pigeons, Partridge, Mutton, Quaile, and ≈øuch other meats good for the ≈øtomach.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. What is to be done to the Infant.
div.p: THE Midwife having tied up the Navel-≈øtring, as is before ≈øaid, ≈øhe ought next to clean≈øe the Infant, not only in the face, but al≈øo over the whole body; anointing the groins, hips, buttocks, thighs and joynts with Oyl of ≈øweet Almonds, or fre≈øh Butter; this makes the skin more firm, and ≈øhuts up the pores of the skin, ≈øo that the exterior air cannot come to hurt it; and be≈øides this, it ≈øtrengthens all the parts of the body.
It would not be ami≈øs to make a bath, or decoction of Ro≈øes and Sage in Wine, and with that to wa≈øh the Infant every morning

After the Infant is thus well anointed, and after that well dried and wrapped up, you may give to the Infant a little Sack and Sugar in a ≈øpoon, or el≈øe the quantity of a Pea≈øe bigne≈øs of Mithridate or Treacle di≈ø≈øolved in Wine, with a little Carduus-Water.

div.head: CHAP. XV. How to Govern Women in Child-bed.
div.p:
THere is great difference in the governing Women in Child-bed; for ≈øhe that thinks to order an ordinary labouring, or Country-woman, like a per≈øon of quality, kills her, and ≈øhe that thinks to govern a per≈øon of quality like an ordinary Country-woman, does the ≈øame to her. For the Stomach and Con≈øtitution of the one is tender and weak, and the Con≈øtitution and Stomach of the other ≈øtrong and lu≈øty; which will not be ≈øatisfied with ordinary Viands: For if you give to one of the≈øe ≈øtrong Stomachs pre≈øently after their delivery, any ≈øtrong Broth, or Eggs, or a draught of Milk, they are like Mills that always grind, and empty as fa≈øt as they pour in; and that that gives one Woman a fever, keeps another from it; and therefore Women in Child-bed are to be governed by their ≈øeveral Con≈øtitutions. As for Women that are delicate, and have been accu≈øtomed to live delicately, greater care mu≈øt be taken of them, giving them meats that breed good nouri≈øhment, and do not clog the ≈øtomach, forbearing al≈øo to give her tho≈øe meats to which ≈øhe has too great a di≈ølike, agreeing to her humour, provided, that the meat which ≈øhe loves be not hurtful; and giving her for the fir≈øt eight days of her lying in, boyled meats rather than ro≈øted, as gellies, &c. the juice of Veal, or Capon, but not Mutton, it being too feveri≈øh: giving her to drink Barly-water, or el≈øe water boyled, wherein is boyled a dram of Cinnamon to every pint, and two ounces of Sugar di≈ø≈øolved; or if ≈øhe do not love Sugar, Coriander-≈øeed water; if ≈øhe drink wine, let it be two thirds of water to one third of wine, giving her in the morning white-wine, and in
the afternoon Claret, taking care of eating any thing that may breed any crudities: She may al≈øo take at the di≈øcretion of tho≈øe about her, Almond-milk now and then. There are ≈øome women that cannot be kept from ≈øleeping, and others that cannot ≈øleep at all. It will not be ami≈øs to give to tho≈øe that cannot ≈øleep, French barley-water; the way to make it well, is to let it boyl well, and to take the broth without ≈øtraining it; neither ought it to be taken after the eight days are pa≈øt, by rea≈øon that it nouri≈øhes exceedingly, and does not a little ob≈øtruct the Liver.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. Of the Bathings that a Woman is to u≈øe for the fir≈øt eight days of her lying in.
div.p: TAke a good handful of old or new Chervil, and boyl it in a ≈øufficient quantity of water, then taking it from the fire, add to it a ≈øpoonful of Honey of Ro≈øes; this draws down the Purgations, clean≈øes and heals the part. The herb it ≈øelf may ≈øerve for a fomentation, to take away any inflammation. There are ≈øome that u≈øe milk to the purpo≈øe afore≈øaid, affirming that it is a great a≈ø≈øwager of the pain; but that having been proved by others, hath been ob≈øerved rather to engender filth, than to be any way a clearer, by rea≈øon that the ≈øharp humour cau≈øeth it to curdle.

div.head: CHAP. XVII. How a Midwife ought to govern her ≈øelf, in ca≈øe a Woman be to be Delivered of two Children.
div.p:
TAE Travel of a Woman bringing forth two Infants is more tedious, and it many times happens that one of the Children comes forth very well,
and the other comes forth very hardly; and this is certain, that that which comes forth fir≈øt, is always the ≈øtronge≈øt having the power to go before the other, and to break the membranes that enveloped it. And ofttimes while the fir≈øt is born, the other remains behind, wrapt in ≈øuch membranes as the former was, ≈øo that it remains a good ≈øpace behind the other, ≈øometimes two hours, and yet it hath been very well born. Now knowing, that that which came fir≈øt was the ≈øtronge≈øt, it would not be ami≈øs to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the other in coming forth, by breaking the Membranes that contain the waters; and, if that fail, by giving ≈øtrong Cly≈øters to excite the pain; which were it not many times done, the Child would never be able to endure the pain of coming into the World, by rea≈øon of its extraordinary weakne≈øs; which is ≈øo great ≈øometimes, that the bone of the Forehead is divided, and ≈øeparated down to the no≈øe; although the Infant being born, it joyns together again, and the Infant does very well: Which if it happen, you mu≈øt have a great care to bind ≈øome kind of ≈øoft pillow upon the place, that the air may not enter in. If the ≈øecond Child come forth ill, you mu≈øt not delay to break the Membranes, and to draw the Infant gently out by the feet: For (having u≈øed all its endeavours to come forth) to keep it there, or to prolong the Travel any longer, is more dangerous than profitable; ≈øometimes two come ≈øo ≈øuddenly the one after the other, that there ≈øeems to be but one Delivery of both, there being but a little Membrane that ≈øeparates them; In this ca≈øe, holding the fir≈øt, you mu≈øt cut the Navel-≈øtring, and bind it about, and tye it about the Hip, while they draw forth the other Infant, which by a longer ≈øtay would be much weakned.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII. Of the danger that a Woman hath, to purge her ≈øelf for the fir≈øt days of her Lying in.
div.p: IT is an ordinary thing for Women that lye in, by rea≈øon of their bed to lo≈øe the benefit of their bellies, which hinders the evacuation of their Milk, which cau≈øes Fevers, by ≈øending gro≈øs vapours to the head; yet can they not be freed by any Purgation taken in at the mouth; but it would be much to the purpo≈øe to take pertinent Cly≈øters which hinder the fore≈øaid evils cau≈øing their brea≈øts to become full, and to become, ≈øtiff, taking them as occa≈øion requires, once in two or three days. There are ≈øome unskilful women, that not under≈øtanding the ill con≈øequences which may follow, do give Sena to Women in the fir≈øt days of their lying in; of which ≈øome have been very ill, and others have died. For Nature being now weakned by the Travel, and while it is labouring to re≈øtore the body to its former E≈øtate, is not to be di≈øturbed with violent Purgations. And therefore Cly≈øters are always mo≈øt proper: Neither are laxative broths, nor the broth of prunes, nor baked apples fa≈øting; for the≈øe do engender wind, but rather ≈øome good Suppo≈øitories would be more u≈øeful.

div.head: CHAP. XIX. Of the ≈øecond wa≈øhing for Women.
div.p: THE ≈øecond wa≈øhing for Women ought to be with Province Ro≈øes, put into little bags, and boiled in water and wine, of each a like proportion; and this is to be done for the ≈øecond eight days.

div.head: CHAP. XX. What is to be done to Infants as ≈øoon as they are born.
div.p: IT is an approved Maxim, that as ≈øoon as a Child is born, you ought to give it a ≈øpoonful of pure wine; for that a≈ø≈øi≈øts and helps the Child to regain its ≈øpirits Another advantage is this; that the wine cuts the flegm which the Child has in its throat; be≈øides, the ≈øpirit of the wine ri≈øing up to the head, comforts and ≈øtrengthens it; and it hinders al≈øo from the Epilep≈øie, which proceeds from the debility of the brain.

This being done, and the Mother fully delivered, you mu≈øt tye the Navel-vein with a ≈øilk well twi≈øted, and many times doubled, and if there be any blood in the vein, you mu≈øt be ≈øure to empty it, for fear, if it ≈øhould be left, it ≈øhould turn into corruption; then it mu≈øt be well dried with powder of rotten wood: You mu≈øt tye it two fingers breadth from the belly, and leave it long, three fingers breadths above the tying place; and if it be fat, you mu≈øt clo≈øe it over and above, that the vein may be well clo≈øed, then wind the ≈øtring twice about it, knitting as many knots. But if the Child be come afore its time, you need not tye it ≈øo ≈øtrong, for fear of cutting it with the ≈øilk; but if the Navel-vein be full of water and wind, you ought then, having tied it one time, and wrapt a linnen cloth about the end of it, which is ≈øtill to be held upward, to uncover it again, about half an hour after, and then to tye it and wrap it about again, ≈øtill keeping the end up; for fear, that if the vein were not fully clo≈øed, there might be ≈øome danger in the bleeding.
Some people give to the Infant Treacle di≈ø≈øolved in Wine; but this mu≈øt be done warily in a very ≈ømall quantity, and that not commonly neither.

The Infant mu≈øt be wa≈øhed with water and wine luke-warm, to clean≈øe it; afterwards wa≈øh the face, as al≈øo chafe the throat, the arms and hands, with Oyl of Walnuts, drawn without fire, which ≈øome ≈øay will keep them from Sun-burning, then put one hand upon the bone of the Fore-head, and another upon the bone called the Coronal bone, and ≈øoftly clo≈øe up the gap which was made during the time of travel, clo≈øing al≈øo the Sutures one again≈øt another exactly; then gently put your finger under the tongue, to ≈øee if the Infant have the ≈øtring or no; and if it have, it may be clipt away with the point of a pair of ≈øharp Cizzers, without danger. There are ≈øome that think they can ≈øhape the head and no≈øe of a Child as if it were of Wax, But let ≈øuch take notice that have flat no≈øed Children, rather to let the no≈øe alone, than by ≈øqueezing and clo≈øing it too much to render the no≈øe ob≈øtructed; for that compre≈ø≈øing the Gri≈øtles of the no≈øe, renders the Child liable either to ≈øpeak alway in the no≈øe, or to lo≈øe his ≈ømelling. There are ≈øome Children that are born with their no≈øes awry; for the help of which, you may with your finger moi≈øtned in fair water, gently ≈øtroke the no≈øe, but lay no ≈øtre≈øs upon it. That happens by rea≈øon that the no≈øe of the Child lights upon ≈øome bone of the Mother as it was coming into the World.

div.head: CHAP. XXI. Of the la≈øt wa≈øhing for Women.
div.p: THE la≈øt wa≈øhing for Women, is to be for four days, with Province Ro≈øes boyled in Wine and Myrrh-water.

div.head: CHAP. XXII. Of an A≈øtringent for Women, when they ≈øhall have occa≈øion.
div.p: TAke Galls, Cypre≈øs-nuts, and Pomgranate-flowers, Roch-Allome, of each two ounces, Province Ro≈øes, four ounces, Knot-gra≈øs a good handful; the rind of Ca≈ø≈øia, the rind of Pomegranates, Scarlet berries, of each three ounces, the nature or Sperm of a Whale, one ounce, Ro≈øe-water, Myrrh-water, and Burnet-water, of each an ounce and a half, Wine and water of a Smiths forge, of each four ounces and a half, then make two little bags about a quarter of a Yard long, and half a quarter of a Yard broad, then boil all the≈øe in the fore≈øaid water in a new Pot, u≈øing the bags one after another, as occa≈øion ≈øerveth.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII. To make Cere-cloaths for Women.
div.p: TAke white Wax, half a pound, the ≈øperm of a Whale, and Venice-Turpentine, well wa≈øhed in Ro≈øe-water, and Plaintain-water, of each an ounce and a half, then melt all the≈øe together, then mingle with them an ounce of Venice white Lead, then order your Cloath as you plea≈øe, making ≈øome for the Belly, and ≈øome for the nipples, having fir≈øt rubbed it over with Oyl of Acorns or the ≈øperm of a Whale.

div.head: CHAP. XXIV. To clean≈øe a Woman before ≈øhe ri≈øes.
div.p:
TAke bitter Almonds and peel them, make thereof a Pa≈øte with the Powder of Orris, and the yolk
of Eggs, and put it in a little bag of Tammy, and temper within the bag, with black Wine luke-warm, and afterwards u≈øe it upon the places where the ≈øear-cloaths had been laid, then wa≈øh the places with black Wine mingled with Orange flower.

div.head: CHAP. XXV. How a Woman lying in of her fir≈øt Child, may avoid the gripings of her belly.
div.p: THere are ≈øome women lying in of their fir≈øt Child who are troubled much with gripings in the belly, and the≈øe Women commonly endure Pains when their Terms come down, by rea≈øon of the ≈ømalne≈øs of the Veins which conveigh the blood into the Matrix; ≈øuch women have Gripings in their bellies, when they lie in of their fir≈øt Child, which other women are not troubled with, by rea≈øon that they have larger Ve≈ø≈øels yet although they have them not in their fir≈øt lying in, it would not be ami≈øs to u≈øe ≈øome proper remedies, that ≈øo they may be never troubled with them; which if they receive not at their fir≈øt lying in, they will be uncapable of receiving them ever after; for though they may take remedies afterwards to le≈ø≈øen the pain, yet they can never cure it wholly.

Now that which is ordinarily done to women is, as ≈øoon as ever they are brought to bed, to give them two Ounces of Oyl of ≈øweet Almonds drawn without fire, with two ounces of Syrup of Maiden-hair; 'tis true, this is good to make her purgations part away, but not to remedy the griping.

Some there are that do take two drops of the blood which comes out of the Navel ≈øtring of the Infant, and give it mingled to the Woman in the fore≈øaid Syrups,
though there is much fault to be found with this, by rea≈øon of the na≈øtine≈øs of it.

Others do boil a white Chicken, in the which they do put two ounces of Sugar, a dram of ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ne ‚Ä¢ Cinamon, half a Nutmed grated two or three Dates, five or ≈øix Cloves; the Fowl being boiled, you may put into it a ≈ømall quantity of Claret, then boyl it altogether again letting it boil till the Fowl be well ≈øoaked, then ≈øtrain it, and give it to the Woman as ≈øoon as ≈øhe is laid down; for want of a white Hen you may take a Pigeon, or a red Partridge for want of either: Only take heed to give her this if ≈øhe be feveri≈øh, becau≈øe it is ≈øomething hot.
The Seed of Savory taken in warm broth is very good, and it is al≈øo very good for tho≈øe that have the Cholick.

div.head: The Queen of France, her Receipt.
div.p: Take a dram of the root of the great Comfrey, one of the kernels of Peaches, Nutmegs, of each two ≈øcruples, yellow Amber half a dram, Amber-greece half a ≈øcruple, mingle all the≈øe together, and give to the woman as ≈øoon as ≈øhe is laid down, the quantity of a dram mingled in White-wine, or, if the Woman be feveri≈øh, in ≈øome good warm broth.

div.head: CHAP. XXVI. Certain precepts concerning the delay and difficulty of bringing forth.
div.p:
BEing now come to talk of the impediments of the Birth, you may know that the Birth is hindered by a two-fold manner, the one natural, the other not natural; of the unnatural we ≈øhall treat in its place; for the natural take the≈øe following directions: But in
the fir≈øt place let the Midwife be very skilful that ≈øhe may decline, as much as in her lies, all the Impediments that may be avoided.

If the Birth be hindered by the drine≈øs and ≈øtreightnes of the neck of the Womb, take a little beaten Hellebore or Pepper, and blow it into the no≈øtrils of the Mother. Her Mouth mu≈øt be held clo≈øe, her Breath, kept in, and ≈øneezing mu≈øt be provoked as much as may be, whereby the Spirits being forced to the lower parts, may be the more available to force down the Child. You may al≈øo give her Shepherds pur≈øe dried in a little Broth, or Wine; al≈øo a little quantity of Honey mingled with twice as much luke-warm water, and given her, will not be unprofitable. The milk al≈øo of another Woman mixt with Maiden-hair, and applyed warm to the Navel. She may take al≈øo Oyl of Laurel in Wine, or warm Broth; two Grains of Pepper being taken inwardly, do not only force out the Birth, but al≈øo drive out the Secondines.
This is al≈øo an excellent remedy again≈øt a difficult Travail.
Take Trochi≈øchs of Myrrhe one dram, grains of Saffron ten, Cinnamon one Scruple, mingle all this with two ounces of Penny-royal-water, and give it the Woman to drink.

Let her drink it warm, and let her go to her Bed for an hour, till ≈øhe finds the Operation of the drink moving her to her Labour. If this profit and that the Infant coming with his head foremo≈øt ≈øtick in the Womb, you may u≈øe the≈øe pills, of which ≈øhe may take ≈øeven and then re≈øt.

Take Gum Bdellium, Myrrh, Savin-≈øeed, Liquid Storax, Agaric, of each half a ≈øcruple, Diagridium ≈øix grains, mingle all the≈øe with Ca≈ø≈øia extracted, as much as ≈øuffices, and make up Pills about the bigne≈øs of a Pea.

You may al≈øo u≈øe a pe≈ø≈øary, as long, and as thick as your finger, of pure wool, which mu≈øt be covered over with ≈øilk, and dipt in the juice of Rue, where Scamony hath been di≈ø≈øolved, and ≈øo u≈øed. If the≈øe things prove without effect, ≈øhe may u≈øe this en≈øuing Bath above her Belly.

Take of the Root and Herb, Mar≈øh-Mallows ≈øix handfuls, Mallows, Camomile, Melilot, Par≈øley, of each four handfuls, Line-≈øeed, and Seed of Fenugreek, of each two pound, Lavender, and Laurel Leaves, of each two handfuls.

Let all the≈øe things be boyled together in Water, wherein the Woman is to ≈øit, or el≈øe to have tho≈øe parts well wet and moi≈øtned with Spunges, which being done, and the Woman well dried with warm Cloaths, let her be brought to the Bed, and anointed with this Ointment.

Take Oyl of ≈øweet Almonds, Hens Fat, Oyl of Lillies, Mu≈øcilage of Mar≈øh-mallows of each half an Ounce, Mingle all the≈øe with as much wax as is ≈øufficient, and make an Oyntment: This being done, give her this little Do≈øe.

Take two Yolks of Eggs and boil them in old Wine, then mix with them the≈øe Spices, Cinamon half an Ounce, rind of Ca≈ø≈øia, 2 drams; or you may leave out the Ca≈ø≈øia, and in≈øtead thereof put in the more Cinamon, Saffron half a Scruple, Savine, Betony, Venus-hair, Dittany, Fenugreek, Lawrel-berries, Mint, of each one dram: The bone of the Heart of a Hart, Pearls prepared, mingle all the≈øe with Sugar, and make a thick Pouder and give it.
If the Secondine come before the Child, and hinder the Egre≈øs of the Child, is to be cut off, and this following Pe≈ø≈øary to be put up.

Take Mar≈øh-mallows with the Roots two handfuls, Mother-wort one handful, Rue one ounce and an half,
Fenugreek, Line-≈øeed, of each an ounce, ten Figs; make of the≈øe a decoction, with as much water as is ≈øufficient, and when you have ≈øtrained it, add this to it, Oyl of Lillies, Oyl of Lin≈øeed, of each two Ounces, Musk one grain: In this decoction, let the pe≈ø≈øary be dipt, and put up; ≈øhe may afterwards u≈øe this Electuary.

Take Myrrh, Ca≈øtor, ≈øweet ≈ømelling Flag, of each two drams, Cinamon one ounce, Saffron half a Scruple, Mace, Savin, of each a Scruple, clarified Honey half a pound: You may al≈øo make an Electuary with the water of Thyme, and Mother-wort, wherein have been boiled Fenugreek, Lin≈øeed, grains of Juniper, of each one ≈øpoonful.
Now, after that the Woman hath been weakned with the≈øe Impediments, you may give her in Broth, Species Laetificans; or Manus Chri≈øti, or Diamargariton.

div.head: CHAP. XXVII. How the Secondines are to be ha≈øtned out.
div.p:
THE Secondines, after that the Infant is born, may be many ways hindred; fir≈øt by the debility, or weakne≈øs of the Matrix, which happens by the frequent motion and endeavouring of the Infant, as al≈øo by rea≈øon of the difficulty of the Birth, or by rea≈øon that the womb doth not continue di≈øtended, or becau≈øe it is many times ≈øtreightned, by which the womb is ≈øo weakned, that by its own force it is not able to expel the Secondines: Be≈øides, the Secondines may inwardly ≈øtick clo≈øe to the womb, which happens many times through the abundance of ≈øuperfluous Humours that are retained in the Matrix, by rea≈øon of which glutinous Humours, the Secondines ≈øtick to the Matrix. The≈øe are no way el≈øe to be pulled away, but by the Hand of the Midwife. Thirdly, the Secondines are hard to come
away, if all the waters come away with the Infant, for then the Secondines, being left without moi≈øture, cannot come away by rea≈øon of the drine≈øs of the womb; be≈øides that, the Matrix and the Neck of the womb are rougher by rea≈øon of the drine≈øs thereof, for the≈øe waters render the way ≈ølippery and ea≈øie, both for the Infant, and for the Secondines; which being ≈ølipped away, the womb is to be anointed with Juices and Oils. Fourthly, when the Mouth of the Matrix, by rea≈øon of the pains of Child-bearing, ≈øwells, as often happens, unle≈øs there be a provident care taken to prevent it. Fifthly, when the Neck of the Matrix is ≈øtreighter and more clo≈øe, and for that rea≈øon fat Women travel with much more difficulty: Therefore when the Secondines do make any extraordinary ≈øtay, the Midwife is to u≈øe all her endeavour to make way for them; for that retention cau≈øes ≈øuffocation, and divers other Evils; for being long detained, they putrifie and cau≈øe an evil ≈ømell, which a≈øcending up to the Heart, Liver, Stomach, Diaphragme, and ≈øo to the Brain, cau≈øe pains in the Head and Lungs, ≈øhortne≈øs of Breath, Faintne≈øs, cold Sweats; ≈øo that there is great danger; and al≈øo Apoplexies and Epilep≈øies, are not a little to be feared. Now in all the time of their ≈øtay, the Women are to be refre≈øhed with convenient Food, to add ≈øtrength to them, giving them ≈øometimes the Yolks of Eggs boiled in old wine with Sugar, and ≈øprinkled over with Saffron and Cinamon, or ≈øome Broth made of Capon or Hen, ≈øea≈øoned with Cinamon and Saffron: It may not be ami≈øs to make certain Perfumes for the Woman to receive up into her womb, made of Saffron, Ca≈øtor, Myrrh, and Cinamon, of each the quantity of a Bean, and care mu≈øt be had that the Fume pa≈øs no further than the Matrix, and this may be done till the Fume of the≈øe Spices ≈øhall cea≈øe. After this a little ≈øneezig Powder is to be put into
to her No≈øtrils, compo≈øed of Hellebore, or ≈øuch like; the Woman ≈øhutting her Mouth hard, and keeping her Breath: If the≈øe things prevail not, give her this following Potion.

Take Trochi≈øch of Myrrh, ten grains of Saffron, one Scruple of Cinamon, Penny Royal waters two ounces; make of this one draught and give her; after ≈øhe hath taken this, and re≈øted a little while, let a Pe≈ø≈øary of Hellebore and Opoponax wrapt up in pure wool, be thru≈øt up into the neck of the womb. This will certainly bring down the Secondines, for it is of ≈øo great vertue, that it is efficacious in expelling the Child which is dead, together with the Secondines.

Take Mallows, Hollihock, Wormwood, Mugwort, Calamint, Origanum, each one handful, make a Bath, and let her ≈øit therein up to the Navel, and ≈øtroke ever downwards with her Hands, and give her inwardly Myrrh a Scruple, Cinamon poudered in Nutmeg-water or wine, or drink Calamint, or Penny-Royal in wine.

Neither will it be ami≈øs to anoint the Matrix with the Ointment called Ba≈øilicon; if this doth nothing avail toward the bringing down of the Secondines, and that the Woman is in great danger of her life, then with the Con≈øent of her Husband and Kindred, give her ≈øeven of the following Pills, which being taken, let her lie ≈øtill 'till the vertue of them do provoke new Pains; for they are of ≈øo great Vertue, that they al≈øo do expel the dead Child, together with the Secondines; yet herein it will not be ami≈øs to con≈øult the skilful Phy≈øician.

div.head: The Pills are the≈øe.
div.p:
Take of Ca≈øtor, Myrrh, Liquid Storax, of each a ≈øcruple; the bark of Cinamon, or Ca≈ø≈øia, and Birthwort, of each half a ≈øcruple; Agaric half an ounce, Diagridium 6 grains, Saffron, Siler of the Mountain, Savin,
of each 3 gr. Thebaic Opium, A≈ø≈øa faetida, of each one gr. mingle all the≈øe with as much extracted Ca≈ø≈øia as is ≈øufficient, and make of them certain Pills as big as pea≈øe, and give them to the Woman in a ≈ømall quantity of Penny-Royal water. It may be al≈øo expedient to apply this en≈øuing Plai≈øter.

Take one part of Coloquintida boiled in water, and as much of the juice of Rue, with the≈øe mingle Line≈øeed, Fenugreek, Barly meal, of each a ≈øpoonful, let them all boil together, and the Plai≈øter made of the≈øe mu≈øt be laid upon all that part, from the Navel to the Privities.

div.head: CHAP. XXVIII. Of ca≈øes of Extremity; and fir≈øt, what is to be done to a Woman, who in her Travail is accompanied with a flux of blood, and with Convul≈øions.
div.p:
IN the fir≈øt place, great care mu≈øt be had, as to the ≈øituation of the Woman: The Woman in this ca≈øe mu≈øt be laid cro≈øs her Bed, where ≈øhe mu≈øt be held by ≈øome one that hath ≈øtrength, that ≈øhe may not ≈ølide, or move her ≈øelf in the operations of the Chirurgion. Her thighs mu≈øt be held hard and wide abroad, with her legs bent backwards towards her Hips, and her Head leaning upon a Bol≈øter; the reins of her Back and her Crupper being a little elevated, with certain pillows put underneath her Thighs; be≈øides this, ≈øhe mu≈øt be well cover'd with linnen Cloaths laid upon her ≈øtomach, Belly, and Thighs, to defend her from the cold and wind: Being thus ≈øituated, the Chyrurgion ought to put up his Hand, being fir≈øt well opened within the neck of the womb, to remove all tho≈øe clots of blood, which may lie there to ob≈øtru≈øt the pa≈ø≈øages of the blood. He may then try if the interiour neck of the womb be
≈øufficiently dilated, that he may put in his hand, and move the Infant, if it be needful, which mu≈øt be done as gently, and with as little violence as may be: He mu≈øt anoint it on all parts with ≈øweet-butter, or good Pomatum, and ≈øo opening it by little and little, he may put his hand quite in; and if the waters are not yet come down, he may without any difficulty let them forth; and then at the ≈øame in≈øtant, if the Infant comes with the head forwards he ≈øhall gently turn it. to find out the feet, and when he hath found one of them, he ≈øhall gently draw it forth, and immediately tye a riband about it, with a knot hanging downward, then let him put it in again, ≈øuffering part of the riband to hang out, that he may more ea≈øily be able to find out the other foot; which he ≈øhall quickly do, by thru≈øting up his hand along the thigh of the Infant; when he hath found it, he ≈øhall take the other foot, and draw them both together at an even length, giving the woman now and then ≈øome lei≈øure to breath, but urging her ≈øtill to ≈øtrain her ≈øelf, when ≈øhe feels the pains coming on her: Then ≈øhall the Chirurgion or Midwife take a fine linnen cloth, and wrap about the thighs of the Child, le≈øt by taking it naked, his fingers ≈øhould ≈ølip; in that manner drawing it forth, 'till it appear all come forth, ob≈øerving ≈øtill that the Belly and the Face be ≈øtill kept downward.

Now if the woman hath a flux of blood, and that the neck of the Matrix be open, the Chirurgion ought to con≈øider, whether the Infant or the Secondines come forth fir≈øt of all, for it oftentimes happens that the Secondines pa≈ø≈øing toward the mouth of the Matrix, do ≈øo ≈øtop and ob≈øtruct it, that they do not give leave for the Child, or the Waters to come forth; ≈øo that ≈øome perceiving that ≈øoftne≈øs, are pre≈øently of opinion that the mouth of the Womb is not open. But this the
Midwife or Chirurgion may ea≈øily di≈øcern, by thru≈øting up the middle finger as high as may be, and feeling therewith the circumference of the neck of the Womb, by which they will ≈øoon perceive whether the Womb be dilated or no, and whether it be the Secondines that pre≈øent them≈øelves. Now when it is found to be the Secondines, and that they cannot ea≈øily come forth, the Midwife may with her two fingers widen the pa≈ø≈øage, that ≈øhe may have thereby the liberty to put up her hand, and ≈øeek for the Infant. Now if the Secondines be not placed in the middle, they mu≈øt be turned a little, as quickly as may be, that you may more conveniently ≈øeek for the feet of the Infant, to draw it forth as we have ≈øaid.
In ≈øuch a ca≈øe as this, all care mu≈øt be had that nothing be broken, and that every thing be brought out whole, for ≈øo though the woman ≈øhould die, the Midwife or Chirurgion would be blamele≈øs.

If the Secondines come fir≈øt, the be≈øt way is to deliver the Woman with all the expedition that may be, by rea≈øon of the great fluxes of blood that will follow, by rea≈øon that the veins are opened: But here are two things to be con≈øidered; the fir≈øt is, whether the Secondines are much, or little come forth; if they are but little advanced, they mu≈øt be put back with care and diligence; and if the head of the Child appear fir≈øt, it mu≈øt be guided directly toward the neck of the Womb, as in the mo≈øt natural birth; but if there appear any difficulty in the birth, by rea≈øon of the weakne≈øs, either of the Child, or of the Mother, then the mo≈øt convenient way will be to ≈øeek for the Feet, as we have ≈øaid before.

Another thing to be ob≈øerved is, that if the Secondines be ≈øo far advanced, that they cannot be put back, and that the Child follow it clo≈øe, then are the Secondines
to be pulled away with all the care and expedition that can be, and to be laid a≈øide without cutting the Entrail that ≈øticks to them, for by that you may be guided to the Infant, which whether it be alive or dead,Of the Child dead in the Mothers Belly. is to be pulled out by the feet with as much care and quickne≈øs as may be; though it is not to be done but in ca≈øe of great nece≈ø≈øity, for otherwi≈øe the Secondines ought to come la≈øt.
If the Child be dead in the Womb of the Mother, the Woman is then to be ≈øituated in the ≈øame po≈øture, as when ≈øhe is troubled with a flux of blood.

If it pre≈øent it ≈øelf dead, with the head foremo≈øt, and that there is little or no hope that the woman may be delivered without a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, and that her ≈øtrength begins to fail her, the mo≈øt certain and ≈øafe way is to put up the hand: For the Chirurgion mu≈øt then ≈ølide up his left hand being hollowed, as when a Man ≈øtrives to hold water in it, cau≈øing it to ≈ølide in the neck of the Womb, along the lower part thereof toward the feet, and that between the head of the Infant, and the neck of the Matrix: And having thus opened the Womb with his left hand, he ≈øhall with his right put up his hook above his left hand, between the head of the Child, and the flat of his hand, and fix in in the bone of the temple, toward the ear, or el≈øe in the hollow of the eye, or in the Occipital bone, keeping his left hand ≈øtill in its place; after this, gently moving and ≈øtirring the head with his left hand, with his right hand holding the hook well fixed, he ≈øhall draw the Child forth by degrees, exhorting the Woman all the while to force and ≈øtrain her ≈øelf with all her power, and then is the be≈øt time to draw forth the Child, when the pains ≈øhall ≈øeize her; now if it happen that he lo≈øe his hold in one place, the danger is nothing, for he
hath the liberty to fix his In≈øtrument better in another place. The head being thus drawn forth, he mu≈øt with all ≈øpeed that may be, ≈ølip his hands down the Child's arm-holes, to draw forth his ≈øhoulders, and the re≈øt of his body: In the mean while it will be requi≈øite to give the Woman a ≈ømall draught of wine, or a to≈øt ≈øopt in wine of Hipocras.

If, after the≈øe Medicines following adhibited,Another way. the Child make no ha≈øte into the World, but lies unmoved in the Womb, then you may proceed to In≈øtruments after another manner. Fir≈øt of all, as ≈øoon as the Woman is brought to bed, let her take this following potion hot, and ab≈øtain from all other meat, and remain quiet for the ≈øpace of an hour or two, 'till ≈øhe feel the power and efficacy of the Medicine.

Take ≈øeven cut Figs, Fenugreek, Motherwort-≈øeed, and Rue, of each two drams, water of Peny-royal and Motherwort, of each ≈øix ounces, boil all the≈øe to the con≈øumption of half, ≈øtrain them; and to the ≈øtraining add Trochi≈øchs of Myrrh one dram, three grains of Saffron, Sugar as much as is ≈øufficient; make one draught of this, and ≈øpice it with a little Cinamon.

After ≈øhe hath re≈øted a little upon this, let her again return to her travel, at what time certain perfumes mu≈øt be made ready of Trochi≈øchs, compo≈øed of the≈øe following Spices to be ca≈øt on the coals, and ≈øo u≈øed, as that the perfume may only come to the Matrix, and no further.
Take Ca≈øtor, Sulphur, Galbanum, Opoponax, Pigeons-dung, A≈ø≈øa-faetida, of each half a dram, mingle all the≈øe with the juyce of Rue, and make a Trochi≈øch of them in the form of a Filberd.
If the≈øe produce no effect, you may u≈øe this following Emplai≈øter.

Take Galbanum an ounce and a half, Coloquintida without the grains two drams, the juyces of Rue and Motherwort, new wax, as much of each as is ≈øufficient, of each make a plai≈øter. Let this be ≈øpread upon a cloth to reach from the Navil to the Privities, and in breadth to both the ≈øides, which ≈øhe may keep on for the ≈øpace of an hour or two. A Pe≈ø≈øary may be al≈øo convenient, made of Wool, and clo≈øed over with ≈øilk, and then moi≈øtned in the following Decoction.

Take of round Birth-wort brought from France, Savin, and Coloquintida, with Grains, Staves-acre, black Ellebore, of each half a dram, brui≈øe the≈øe together, and make a Pe≈ø≈øary, with as much of the juyce of Rue as is ≈øufficient.

But now if all the≈øe things avail not, and that the Midwife is not able to dilate the pa≈ø≈øage for the Infant, then you mu≈øt have recour≈øe to the Chirurgion; to which purpo≈øe, ≈øhe is to be placed in a ≈øeat, ≈øo that ≈øhe may turn her crupper as much from the back of the Chair as may be; drawn up her legs as clo≈øe as ≈øhe can, but ≈øpreading her Hips abroad as much as may be. Or el≈øe if it ≈øeem more commodious, ≈øhe may be laid upon the Bed, with her head downwards, her buttocks rai≈øed, and her thighs drawn up as much as can be: then you may go to work, either with your ≈øpeculum matricis, or his Apertory; ≈øo that the womb being ≈øufficiently widened by the help of the≈øe In≈øtruments, the birth may be drawn out by the hands of the Chirurgion, together with the Secondines, if po≈ø≈øible may be. The womb mu≈øt then be wa≈øhed and anointed, the woman then mu≈øt be laid in her bed, and well comforted with ≈øpices, as al≈øo with ≈øome comfortable meat and drink. This cour≈øe mu≈øt be taken with all dead Infants, and al≈øo with Moles and Secondines, which are hindred in their coming forth naturally.

If by the≈øe In≈øtruments the Womb cannot be ≈øufficiently widened for the egre≈øs of the Infants, there are yet other In≈øtruments, by which the Womb may be widened without damage to the Mother, and the Birth be brought forth, ≈øuch as are Drakes-bill, and the long Pincers, by which the Womb is not only widened, but the Birth taken hold of by them for the more forcible drawing it forth.

If there be any ≈øwelling, or inflammation, or concrete blood, gathered together in the preputium of the Matrix, under the skin, tho≈øe tumours either before or after the Birth, where the matter appears thinne≈øt and ripe≈øt, the Midwife may cut with a pen-knife and ≈øqueeze out the matter; anointing it afterwards often with a pe≈ø≈øary dipt in Oil of Ro≈øes, until it be whole.

If it happen that the Child be ≈øwollen in the Womb in any part of it, by rea≈øon of Wind or any watry Humour, yet if it be alive, ≈øuch means are to be u≈øed, as may be lea≈øt to the detriment of the Child and of the Mother; but if it be dead, in whatever part tho≈øe humours be, either in the brea≈øt, arms, or legs, the Midwife may then put up her hand, and with a little knife for that purpo≈øe, cut the ≈øwollen part, that by letting out of the Wind or humour, the Child may grow le≈øs and be brought forth with le≈øs difficulty.

Many times it happens that the Child comes into the World with the feet foremo≈øt; and the hands dilating them≈øelves from the hips. In this ca≈øe the Midwife ought to be well furni≈øhed with Oyntments, helping the egre≈øs of the Infant, by anointing and ≈øtroaking it, le≈øt it be carried backward. Having al≈øo a great care to take hold of both the arms of the Infant, and keep them clo≈øe to the hips, that the Child may come forth after its own manner. If by rea≈øon of this deduction of
the Arms, from the ≈øides of the Infant, and the narrowne≈øs of the Matrix, it ≈øo happen that the Child cannot make a total egre≈øs, the womb of the Woman, and the Infant it ≈øelf, are to be well anointed, ≈øneezing Powders being admini≈øtred to the Woman, to help her endeavours; the womb is al≈øo to be pre≈ø≈øed hard with both hands, that the Child make no retirement back, but may ≈øtill move forward.

It happens ≈øometime that the Child comes forward with its feet, with the Arms not clo≈øe to its ≈øides, but extended above its head; which when it comes to pa≈øs, the Midwife is by no means to receive this Birth, unle≈øs the Child be very ≈ømall, and the Matrix ≈øo wide, that it may afford an ea≈øie pa≈ø≈øage to the Child; yet may ≈øhe not then receive it, till ≈øhe hath well anointed both the Child and the Matrix. But it would be much more ≈øafe and convenient, for both the Child and the Mother, to put back the Child into the Womb and bring it to its natural form, which may be done in this manner. The woman mu≈øt lie on her back upon her bed, with her head downward, and her buttocks a little elevated, which being done, the Midwife ≈øhall gently compre≈øs the belly of the Woman toward the Midriff, thereby to put back the Infant into the Womb. But above all, things let her take care that ≈øhe turn the Face of the Child toward the back of the Mother, rai≈øing up the thighs and buttocks of the Child, toward the navel of the Mother, to bring the Child to a more legitimate and natural production.

If the Child happen to come forth but with one Foot, the Arm being extended along the ≈øides, with the other Foot turned backward, the Woman is in≈øtantly to be brought to her bed, and laid in the ≈øame po≈øture as we have before told you, and then is the other foot which came forth fir≈øt to be put back into the Womb; which being done, let the woman rock her ≈øelf from one
≈øide of the bed to the other, (lying alwaies with her head low, and her Buttocks rai≈øed) 'till ≈øhe apprehend the Child to be turned, upon which ≈øhe may immediately expect her pains with all the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance that may be given; and in the mean while to be comforted as much as may be with Cordial Potions, and whol≈øome Medicines.

Many times it happens that the Child lies athwart, and falls upon his ≈øide, which when it comes to pa≈øs, the Mother is not to be urged to her labour, neither is the Birth to be expected after that manner, for it is impo≈ø≈øible that the Child ≈øhould be ≈øo born without ≈øome conver≈øion; and therefore the Midwife is to do all ≈øhe can to reduce it to a more natural form of Birth, by moving the Buttocks, and ≈øteering the Head to the pa≈ø≈øage; if this ≈øucceed not, let her try by often rocking the Woman to and fro, to bring the Child to its natural form of being born.

If it happen that the Child ha≈øten to the Birth, with the Legs and Arms di≈øtorted, the Midwife ought not to ha≈øten the Woman, but immediately ca≈øt her on her Bed, where ≈øhe may direct the Woman to roul her ≈øelf to and fro; or el≈øe ≈øhe may gently ≈øtroke the womb of the Woman as ≈øhe lies, 'till ≈øhe have reduced the Infant to a better po≈øture; If this profit not, the Midwife mu≈øt take the Legs and clo≈øe them together, then if ≈øhe can, ≈øhe mu≈øt get her Hand about the Arms of the Child, and in the ≈øafe≈øt way ≈øhe can, direct it to its coming forth; though it be the ≈øafe≈øt way to turn the Infant in the Womb, and by that means compo≈øe it to the natural Birth.

If the Infant come into the World with both knees forward, with the Hands hanging down upon the Thighs. The Midwife may then put up both the Knees upward, 'till the Feet happen to come forward, and then with her left Hand let her take hold of the
Feet, and keep her right Hand about the ≈øides of the Child, and in that po≈øture endeavour the Birth of the Child; but if that ≈øucceed not, let the Woman as is ≈øaid before, be brought to her Bed, and there wallow from ≈øide to ≈øide, 'till ≈øhe have moved the Child into a better po≈øture.

But when it happens that the Child ha≈øtens forwards, with one Arm extended upon the Thigh, and the other ≈øtretched over the Head, the Feet being ≈øtretched out at length in the Womb, the Midwife may by no means receive the Child in this po≈øture, but mu≈øt lay the Patient upon the Bed, as we have ≈øaid before; then mu≈øt the Womans Belly be gently pre≈ø≈øed backward, that the Infant may retire into the Womb, and if it give not backward of its own accord, the Midwife may with her Hand gently thru≈øt back the Shoulder, and bring the Arm that was ≈øtretched back to its right place.

The mo≈øt dangerous of all tho≈øe that we have ≈øpoken of is this, and therefore the Midwife mu≈øt take care to put back the Infant in this ca≈øe into the Womb: Fir≈øt of all therefore anoint well her Hands, as al≈øo the Womb of the Woman, then, if ≈øhe can, let her thru≈øt in her Hand near the Arms of the Infant, and ≈øo move the Shoulders that the Infant may fall back into the womb; and then to bring it to the natural form, let her thru≈øt up her other Hand, and reduce the Arms of the Infant to the ≈øides of it; If this ≈øucceed not, the Woman mu≈øt be laid on her Bed, and after a little re≈øt, ≈øhe mu≈øt be ordered as before we have ≈øaid: If this avail not, ≈øhe mu≈øt be brought back to her Seat, as we have before rehear≈øed; then mu≈øt her womb, by the help of tho≈øe Women that a≈ø≈øi≈øt her be gently pre≈øt downward, and on both ≈øides, while the Midwife having anointed the Matrix, and both the Arms of the Infant, joins them as clo≈øe together as ≈øhe can, and in that manner receives
the Infant. And there is the le≈øs danger in this form, if the Midwife be diligent, and the Child ≈ølender.

If the Infant thru≈øt it ≈øelf forwards with the buttocks formo≈øt, the Midwife mu≈øt put up her Hand well anointed, and ≈øo by heaving up and putting back the Buttocks ≈øtrive to turn the Head to the Pa≈ø≈øage. Yet overmuch ha≈øte mu≈øt not be made, le≈øt the Infant ≈øhould fall back into ≈øome wor≈øe Po≈øture; and therefore if it cannot be turned by putting up the Hand, the Woman mu≈øt be brought to her Bed, and ordered as we have often ≈øaid before; comfortable things being conveniently mini≈øtred to her.

If the Child come forward with the neck bowed, and the ≈øhoulders forward, with the Hands and Feet ≈øtretched upwards; in this ca≈øe the Midwife mu≈øt carefully move the ≈øhoulders backward that ≈øhe may be able to bring the Head forwards, which may be ea≈øily done, for the ≈øhoulders being removed, the Head will ≈øoon appear formo≈øt, yet if this ≈øuffice not, the Woman mu≈øt be laid on her back upon the Bed, and ordered according to the former Precepts.

When the Infant thru≈øts forth the Hands and Feet formo≈øt care mu≈øt be had to avoid the danger of this mi≈øhapen po≈øture, and therefore the Midwife mu≈øt ≈øtrive by removing the Feet, to lay hold on the Head, and, as much as in her lies, to direct it to the pa≈ø≈øage; the Hands are al≈øo to be removed, unle≈øs of their own accord they fall down to the ≈øides. If by this means it cannot be done, the former Precepts of converting the Child are to be ob≈øerved.

Sometimes it happens that the Child ≈øtrives to force its pa≈ø≈øage in this po≈øture which is very dangerous. Fir≈øt of all therefore let the Midwife anoint her Hands well, and the Womb of the Woman; which being done, let her put up her Hand, and ≈øeek for the Arms of the
Child, which when ≈øhe hath found, let her hold them fa≈øt, till ≈øhe hath hold of the Head al≈øo, which ≈øhe mu≈øt with all her skill endeavour to bring formo≈øt, then let her remove the Hands of the Infant, and fix them upon the ≈øides of the Infant. Yet if this do not avail, it will be the ≈øafe≈øt way to lay the Woman on her Bed, and to proceed according to the former Precepts, to try if by that delay ≈øhe may have the more advantage to proceed as before

The ≈øame method which is to be ob≈øerved in ≈øingle Birth, is al≈øo to be ob≈øerved in ca≈øe of Twins or of tripple Birth; for as the ≈øingle Birth hath but one natural way, and many unnatural Forms, ≈øo is it with the Birth of many Children; and therefore when it happens that Twins appear, coming into the World according to the natural form, the Midwife mu≈øt ob≈øerve to receive that fir≈øt which is neare≈øt the pa≈ø≈øage; yet be ≈øure not to let go the other, le≈øt it ≈øhould fall back into the womb, and tumble into ≈øome other form, but the one being born, immediately to receive the other; this Birth is the more ea≈øie in the natural form, becau≈øe the fir≈øt Child widens the pa≈ø≈øage for the latter, but in unnatural Births there is mo≈øt difficulty in the pa≈ø≈øage of the ≈øecond Child: Care mu≈øt be al≈øo had in the birth of Twins, that the Secondine be naturally brought forth, le≈øt the womb being deliver'd of its Burthen, ≈øhould fall, and the Secondine by that means be delayed to the damage of the Woman in Child-bed.

If there be Twins in the Womb, and one of them endeavour to come forth with the Head formo≈øt, and the other with the Feet: Fir≈øt of all the Midwife mu≈øt con≈øider, which of the two the Woman may be delivered of with mo≈øt expedition; if the Head of the one be le≈øs forward than the Feet of the ≈øecond, it will be mo≈øt convenient to draw that forth by the Feet, turning
the head of the other a little to the other ≈øide; and that being delivered, ≈øhe mu≈øt pre≈øenty lay hold of the Head of that which is within, and direct it ju≈øt to the pa≈ø≈øage of the Womb; which may be done with more ea≈øe, by rea≈øon of the gap which the formo≈øt hath made.

If it happen, in drawing forth the fir≈øt by the feet, that the other change its ≈øituation, the Midwife may then draw forth the other by the Feet as ≈øhe did the fir≈øt; and if the head of the fir≈øt be more forward, then ≈øhe mu≈øt put back the Feet of the fir≈øt, and receive that which comes with the head formo≈øt.

If both of them pre≈øs together to the pa≈ø≈øage of the Womb, the Midwife mu≈øt take great care; and therefore ≈øhe mu≈øt put up her hand to ≈øee which of them is mo≈øt forward, as al≈øo to try whether it be not ≈øome mon≈øtrous Conception, as two heads upon one body, or two bodies joined in one, either at the ≈øhoulders, or at the ≈øides, which may be known, if ≈øhe put up her hand gently between the two heads as high as ≈øhe can; and if ≈øhe find that they are twins, ≈øhe may gently put the one to one ≈øide, to make way for the pa≈ø≈øage of the other, which is mo≈øt advanced; which mu≈øt be directed ju≈øt to the orifice of the Womb, having a great care that ≈øhe do not change the ≈øituation of the ≈øecond; and as ≈øhe feels the pains of the Mother coming on her, ≈øhe mu≈øt by all means bring forward the Child ≈øhe would receive, ≈øtill keeping the other back, with two or three fingers of the left hand: and thus having delivered the fir≈øt, if the ≈øecond be not well ≈øituated, ≈øhe mu≈øt bring the head to „Äà‚óä„Äâ neck of the Womb, where it will find the pa≈ø≈øage „Äà‚óä„Äâ to it, by the delivery of the fir≈øt.

Now le≈øt the fir≈øt Child ≈øhould be in danger of its life, you mu≈øt take it from the Mother, and carefully tie up the Navel-≈øtring, as is formerly mentioned, and al≈øo bind again with a large and long fillet, that part of the
Navel which is fa≈øt to the Secondines, that they may be more ea≈øily found, Then the ≈øecond Child being born the Midwife mu≈øt ≈øee if there be not two Secondines, for by rea≈øon of the ≈øhortne≈øs of the ligature, it may have hapned to retire back again, to the damage of the Woman; and therefore the Secondines mu≈øt be ha≈øtened forth as ≈øoon as may be, le≈øt the Womb ≈øhould clo≈øe.

If the two Infants have but one body, the better way is to turn the head upwards, and to draw it forth by the Feet, than by the head: Taking care when you come to the Hips, to draw it forth as quick as may be.

The ≈øecond form of unnatural Birth is very dangerous, and therefore requires the greater care of the Midwife. Fir≈øt, therefore let her well anoint the Womb of the Woman that the pa≈ø≈øage may be more ≈ølippery; which being done, let her take hold of the hands of one of the Infants, and keeping them clo≈øe to the ≈øides, direct the head to the orifice of the Womb; that being born, let her proceed in the ≈øame manner toward the other. If ≈øhe cannot come to take hold of either of the Infants Arms, ≈øhe mu≈øt bring the Woman again to her Bed, and try by the afore≈øaid Agitation of her body, if the Infants may be brought to a more convenient form of delivery.
