div.p: IN the fir≈øt place you may lay the skin of a Hare, or Sheep, for the ≈øpace of four or five hours; which being taken away, you may then anoint it with this following Oyntment, and then lay a linnen Towel all over her belly and hips, which mu≈øt be continued on for the fir≈øt ≈øeven days, looking after it, and turning every Morning.

div.head: The Oyntment may be this.
div.p: Take the Oyl of ≈øweet-Almonds, Camomile, and St. John's wort, each one ounce and a half, Sperma ceti two Ounces, Goats fat one Ounce, Oyl of Miriles half an Ounce, melt all the≈øe, and make an Oyntment to anoint the Belly: Now before the Cerecloth be put on, you mu≈øt apply a little Plai≈øter of Galbanum, about the bigne≈øs of 2 or 3 fingers to the Navel, in the middle of which may be put two or three grains of Civet, yet ≈øo as that the Woman may not perceive the ≈øent of it. The Cerecloth may be this.

Take White Wax four ounces, Pomatum without Musk, Calfs-grea≈øe, of each one ounce, Sperma ceti an ounce and a half, Oyl of St. John's-wort, and Sweet Almonds, of each one ounce; Venice-Turpentine wa≈øhed in Pellitory-water half an ounce; melt the≈øe in Balneo Mariae, and ≈øpread them upon a cloath about the bigne≈øs of the belly, and when it is cool apply it.

The next care is to be had of the Brea≈øts, upon the≈øe ≈øome put round Cerecloth made thus; Take ≈øix ounces of new Wax, Oyl of Myrtle, Ro≈øes and Honey of Narbon, of each two ounces; melt the≈øe altogether, and make a Cerecloth, let them have holes in the middle for the Nipples to go through.

div.head: This Oyntment is al≈øo very good to keep the Milk from clotting.
div.p: Take Oyntment of Populeon one ounce, Galen's refrigerating Oyntment half an ounce, Oyl of Ro≈øes ≈øix drams, Vinegar a ≈ømall quantity; melt them together and make an Oyntment.

div.head: This fomentation is al≈øo much commended.
div.p:
Take Fennel, Par≈øly, Mallows, Mar≈øh-mallows, of each a ≈ømall handful, Laurel and Camomile-flowers, of each half a handful, boyl the≈øe according to Art, and make a Fomentation for the Nipples. After this Fomentation,
anoint them with Oleum Ro≈øatum, Omphacium, and then apply this following Plai≈øter.

Take Venice-Turpentine four ounces, well wa≈øhed in ≈øtrong wine, and Ro≈øe-water, adding to it two whole Eggs, and a ≈øcruple of Saffron, with as much wax as is ≈øufficient; ≈øpread this upon a linnen cloath, and apply it. As for the lower parts, for the three fir≈øt days they are to be fomented with a certain fomentation of Milk, wherein hath been boiled a few Ro≈øes, ≈øome Chervil, and a little Plantain. From the next day to the eighth day, you may u≈øe this bath; Wine and water, of each half a pint; red Ro≈øes and flowers of St. John's wort, of each two handfuls; Agrimony one handful, mak of this a decoction; after bathing once, or twice, lay this following Oyntment along the lips of the Privities upon a linnen cloth.
Take Oyl of St. John's wort 2 ounces, Sperma ceti an ounce and a half, a little white wax, mix all the≈øe together, melt them, and make an Oyntment.
After the eight days are pa≈øt, you may lay upon her belly this following Plai≈øter.

Take Oyl of St. John's wort, Camomile, and Anni≈øeeds, of each one ounce, Oyl of Ma≈øtick an ounce and a half, Oyl of Mirtles ≈øix drams, Sperma ceti two ounces, the fat of the Reins of a Goat an ounce and a half, Deers ≈øuet one ounce; of this make an Oyntment to anoint the belly of the woman in Child-bed, and then apply this following Plai≈øter.

Take Oyl of Myrtles, and St. Johns-wort, of each an ounce and a half, Oyl of Nip one ounce, Venice-Turpentine, wa≈øhed in water of Motherwort, four ounces; melt all the≈øe together, and put them upon a Hempen cloath, that may cover all the belly, and let her wear it the ≈øpace of eight days.
The≈øe fifteen days being pa≈øt, for the ≈øpace of eight days more, you may lay upon her belly and her hips this following Plai≈øter.

Take Oyl of Ma≈øtick, Myrtles, Ja≈ømine, and Quinces, of each an ounce and a half, Oyl of Acorns two ounces, Sperma ceti one ounce, Venice-Turpentine wa≈øhed in Plantain-water, half an ounce; wax ≈øix ounces, melt all the≈øe together, adding powder of Ma≈øtick, and ≈øeal'd earth, of each half an ounce, Florentine Orrice one ounce, ≈øpread all the≈øe upon a hempen cloath, and lay it upon her belly, to be kept there for the ≈øpace of eight or ten days; for the lower parts, this Fomentation may be needful.

Take Leaves of Plantain, Mullein, Knot-gra≈øs, and Hor≈øe-tail, of each one handful, Cypre≈øs-leaves a handful and a half; of the rind of Pomgranates, Cypre≈øs-Nuts, and Pomgranate-flowers, of each half an ounce; red Ro≈øes, Camomile and Melilot, of each a handful; Roch-allum two ounces, Sweet ≈ømelling-Flag and Florentine-Orrice, of each three drams, Gilliflowers one dram; make of the≈øe two bags, and boyl them in like quantities of ≈øowre wine, and Smith's water, for the exteriour mouth of the neck of the Womb.

div.head: Of the choice of a good Nur≈øe.
div.p:
THE choice of a good Nur≈øe is very important, and therefore you mu≈øt fir≈øt look upon her a≈øpect, and ≈øee whether her ≈øight be no way imperfect, as whether ≈øhe be ≈øquint-eyed, or have a down-ca≈øt look; you mu≈øt have a ≈øpecial care that ≈øhe be not red haired, for their Milk is extreamly hot; ≈øee moreover, whether her teeth be ≈øound and white, and well ≈øet; know whether ≈øhe come of Parents that have been troubled with the Con≈øumption; and if ≈øhe have not, nor be con≈øumptive her ≈øelf, you may judge of her
≈øtomach, and whether ≈øhe be ≈øubject to Catarrhs; you mu≈øt al≈øo take heed that ≈øhe ≈øend no ≈øtinking-breath, either from her mouth, or no≈øtrils, for that corrupts the Lungs of the Infant. Enquire whether neither ≈øhe, nor any of her kindred have been troubled with Lepro≈øie, by rea≈øon that it is very contagious, or with the Falling-Sickne≈øs. And therefore tho≈øe Women that either cannot or will not nur≈øe their own Children, mu≈øt make u≈øe of ≈øuch women as are mo≈øt fit to the humour they would have the Child to be of: For the Nur≈øe is now to be the ≈øecond Mother of the Child, from whom the Infant draws all her Conditions, be they good, be they bad; and it is often ≈øeen, that Children do partake more of the Conditions of the Nur≈øe, than the Mother, and therefore care mu≈øt be taken that the Nur≈øe be good conditioned, good teeth, brown hair, of a healthy generation; that neither ≈øhe nor her Husband have had the French Di≈øea≈øe; that ≈øhe be not peevi≈øh nor cholerick, that ≈øhe have Milk in abundance, and a good fle≈øhy brea≈øt, that her brea≈øt be not over-fle≈øhy, that ≈øhe be not over fat; and, above all, that ≈øhe be not of too amorous a humour, and de≈øirous to be with her Husband, for that is perfect venom to the milk.

div.head: What is to be done in the extream pains of the Child.
div.p:
IF a Child have extream throws pre≈øently after it be born, you mu≈øt rub it with Pellitory and fre≈øh butter, or Spinage, or el≈øe with Hogs-greace, and apply it upon the Navel, having fir≈øt a great care that it be not too hot. Or el≈øe make a little cake of Eggs, and Oyl of Nuts, and apply it in the very ≈øame place; if this avail not, give it a little Cly≈øter of Milk, the yolk of
an Egg, and a little Sugar; this ea≈øeth the pain of the Inte≈øtines.

div.head: What is to be done with tho≈øe Children that are troubled with Flegm.
div.p: THere are ≈øome Children born of ill-con≈øtitution'd Women, or el≈øe of Women that have not u≈øed good nouri≈øhment in the time of their being with Child, who are very full of flegm, the≈øe you mu≈øt lay upon one ≈øide, and ≈øomtimes upon the other; for if you lay them upon their backs, you may perchance choak them; you mu≈øt be ≈øure to keep their bellies ≈øoluble, cau≈øing them to void that blood kept in the Entrails from the time of their being in the womb, by giving it a little Suppo≈øitory of black Sope well rubbed in fre≈øh butter, to take away the Acrimony of it; then give it a ≈øpoonful of Syrup of Violets, this cau≈øes the flegm to pa≈øs down. If you perceive that the Infant hath not much heat, you may mix with it half the quantity of Oyl of ≈øweet Almonds, and half of the ≈øyrup of Violets, and continue it, ≈øtroaking the ≈øtomach an ‚Ä¢ the belly of the Infant with fre≈øh butter, every time tha ‚Ä¢ they undre≈øs him.

div.head: That which ought to be done to Children that have their Cods full of wind.
div.p: WHen Infants have their Cods full, ye mu≈øt examine whether it be with wind, or water; if it be with water, by rubbing and chafing the skin with fre≈øh butter, the waters will ≈øweat out; if it be wind, the Children mu≈øt be ≈øtirred, and ≈øwung gently, mingling in their drink the decoction of Ani≈øeeds.

div.head: How to take away the Canker from the mouths of Infants.
div.p:
THere have been known certain Children which have ben nouri≈øhed with cold milk, which hath been thick, and in great quantity, which a few days after its birth, hath heated the mouth of the Infant in ≈øuch a fa≈øhion, that it cau≈øed a white Canker, which pre≈øently po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed the tongue, palate, the gums, the throat, and all the mouth, whereupon it was taken with a Fever, and it could no longer ≈øuck, all the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance that could be was ≈øtill applied, and when no other Medicine did avail, there was found one, a particular remedy, which was half a handful of Sage, a handful of Chervil brui≈øed a little, and boyled in a ≈øufficient quantity of water, about a dozen ≈øeethings, to which you mu≈øt add a ≈øpoonful of Vinegar; when you have ≈øtrained it, you mu≈øt put to it an ounce of Honey of Ro≈øes, then you mu≈øt have a little hooked ≈øtick, with a little piece of Scarlet tied at the end, then putting the water in a Sawcer, dip the end of the ≈øtick where the Scarlet is tied, and then rub the place affected gently, and you ≈øhall find the Canker „Äà‚óä„Äâ a ‚Ä¢
≈øwage by little and little.

div.head: What is to be done to Children who≈øe Inte≈øtines are falle ‚Ä¢ .
div.p:
THERE are a great many Infants, who≈øe great gut falls; which is a thing very ea≈øily remedied at the beginning, and therefore you mu≈øt put it up again: Fir≈øt, lay the Child with the Head lowermo≈øt, then you mu≈øt have a thick Cu≈øhion, ≈øoaked in Smiths Water, then you mu≈øt have an emplai≈øter made of the Roots of great Comfrey ≈øcraped, and put upon it as an Ointment; then looking to it every day, taking care
that it cry but little, and never unbind him, but as he lyes, le≈øt the Gut tumble down again, and ≈øo the Cure be delayed; as the Child grows big, the Hole le≈ø≈øens, and the Inte≈øtine grows big. This is an experienced way.

div.head: To make an Oyntment to ≈øtrengthen the Thighs and legs of the Child, and make him go.
div.p: TAKE Sage, Marjoram, Dwarf-Elder, brui≈øe them a good while together, 'till you have beaten out a good deal of Juyce, then put it into a Gla≈øs Vial, 'till it be full, and ≈øtop up the Hole with pa≈øte, and round the ≈øides al≈øo of the ≈øaid Pa≈øte; put it then in an Oven, to bake as long as a good big Loaf, then draw it forth, and ≈øuffer it to cool, then break the Pa≈øte which is round the Vial; break the Bottle, and keep up that which is within, which you ≈øhall find turned to an Oyntment: And when you would u≈øe it, you mu≈øt add to it ≈øome of the Marrow of the Hoof of an Ox, melting it altogether, and when ye have ≈øo done, you mu≈øt rub the hinder part of the legs, and thighs of the Child. This hath been done to a Child, whom a famous Phy≈øician, after 3 Years having in hand, gave over, ≈øaying, that it would never go.

div.head: Of the relaxations of the Matrix, and the cau≈øe.
div.p:
THere are many cau≈øes of the relaxation of the Matrix, the one proceeding from great Fluxes, which fall down upon the ligaments thereof, cau≈øing them to wax loo≈øe; Others come to this Di≈øea≈øe by ≈øome falls, others by rea≈øon of carrying in their womb too great Burdens, others by ≈øtraining them≈øelves in travail before their time, and becau≈øe the Orifice of the Womb is not open; ≈øometimes, and very often by rea≈øon of the Midwifes, who putting up their Hands into the
Womb, tear down they know not what, which is oftentimes a part of the Matrix, to the bottom of which the Secondines adhere, drawing down part of the womb, which they take to be the Secondines; which is oftentimes brought al≈øo to a wor≈øe condition, when the unskilful Women force her to the Remedies, for bringing down the Secondines; as holding Bay ≈øalt in her Hand, ≈øtreining to Vomit, and the like. For remedy whereof, all the≈øe telaxations of the Matrix, are by the ≈øame Remedies, except tho≈øe which are occa≈øion'd by ≈øtrong Fluxes, for in this ca≈øe other Remedies are not ≈øufficient, being that you are to take away the cau≈øe of tho≈øe defluxions, before you can proceed to the Cure of the relaxation. Among the re≈øt, I will relate one that hath been found very profitable and experienced, which is this a≈øtringent. Take Gall-nuts, Cypre≈øs nuts, and Pomgranate Flowers, Roche-Alum, of each two Ounces, Province Ro≈øes four ounces, Knot-gra≈øs a good big handful, the Rind of Ca≈ø≈øia, the Rind of Pomegranates, Scarlet Grains, of each three Ounces, the nature of a Whale one ounce; Mirrh-water, Ro≈øe-water, and Sloe-water, an ounce and a half, thick Wine, and Smiths-water, of each four ounces and a half; then make two little bags of a quarter of a Yard long, cau≈øing them to boil in the afore≈øaid waters, in a new pot, u≈øing one after another as you have occa≈øion, letting it lie upon the Bone of the Pubes, pa≈ø≈øing in between the Hips, chafing her often, and holding her Head and her Reins low, u≈øing in the Morning ≈øometimes a little Ma≈øtick in an Egg, or ≈øometimes Plantain Seed: If the Di≈øea≈øe be not too old, it may be cured by this means; but if it be of a long ≈øtanding, you mu≈øt make a pe≈ø≈øary half round, and half Oval, of great thick Cork, pierced through in the middle; tye a little Pack-thred to the end, then cover it over with white Wax, that
it may do no hurt, and to make it more thick, this mu≈øt be dipped in Oyl of Olives to make it enter, and it mu≈øt be ≈øtraight, that it may not ea≈øily fall out; and if it be too little, to have another bigger, and when the Woman goes to do her nece≈ø≈øary occa≈øions, ≈øhe mu≈øt hold it in, le≈øt ≈øhe ≈øhould force it out; the Hole is made, that the Vapours of the womb may have a vent, and to give way for her purgations to flow, neither mu≈øt it be taken away 'till after the Purgations are pa≈ø≈øed, the thickne≈øs cau≈øes the Matrix to mount up as long, as it is very thick, for the Ligaments being clo≈øe do then retire. If they be Women that bear Children, the Midwife ought not to ≈øuffer them to force them≈øelves, but as Nature con≈øtrains her, having her own hand ready after the throw, to put back the Matrix with her finger, and when ≈øhe is brought to bed, lay her low with her head and with her reins, rai≈øing her up with pillows put under her hips; and for Women that are troubled with this Di≈øea≈øe, they ought not to lace them≈øelves over hard, for that thr ‚Ä¢ ≈øts down the Matrix, and makes the Woman pouch bellied, and hinders the Infant from being well ≈øituated in her Body, cau≈øing her to carry the Child all upon her Hips, and makes her Belly as deformed as her Wa≈øte is hand≈øome.

div.head: Of a di≈øea≈øe that happens by rea≈øon of the fall of the Matrix.
div.p:
THere is ≈øometimes a relaxation of the Membrane, that covers the rectum Inte≈øtinum, when the head of the Child, at the begining of the Travel falls downward, and draws it low; oftentimes it comes by rea≈øon of Women with Child lacing them≈øelves, which cau≈øes ≈øuch a conflux of wind to the≈øe parts, that it ≈øeems to the Woman to be the head of the Child, in≈øomuch
that ≈øhe is hardly able to ≈øtand upright, neither can ≈øhe go. For remedy hereof, you mu≈øt keep the woman ≈øoluble, giving her Ani≈øe, and Coriander ≈øeeds to di≈ø≈øipate the winds. You mu≈øt take Sage, Agrimony, Motherworth, Balm, white Wormwood, Margerom, a little Rue, and a little Thyme, and Camomile and having picked all the above written Herbs, you mu≈øt cut them very ≈ømall, and having well mingled them, put them into a maple platter, and then put hot Cinders upon them, and upon tho≈øe another handful of Herbs, covering the platter with a clo≈øe cloth, that the woman may receive the ≈ømoak; this is a remedy which hath been much approved and experimented.

div.head: To remedy the fall of the Fundament in Infants:
div.p: TAke of the green ≈øhrub whereof they make ‚Ä¢ rooms, and cut, it ≈ømall, and lay it upon the Coals, and ≈øet the Child over the ≈ømoak thereof, and it will certainly cure it.

div.head: Of the di≈øea≈øes of Women, and fir≈øt of the inflammation of the brea≈øt.
div.p:
THe Inflammation of the Brea≈øts is a hard ≈øwelling together with a beating pain, redne≈øs, and ≈øhooting. The chief cau≈øe of this is the abundance of blood, drawn up together in that place, though there be ≈øometime other cau≈øes al≈øo, as the ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion of the cour≈øes, the Haemorrhoids, or a blow received upon the Brea≈øts. The ≈øigns of it are ea≈øie to be known, that is to ≈øay, a certain redne≈øs and burning heat, oft-times joined with a Fever. For the cure of this, there are four ≈øorts of remedies; Fir≈øt, the order of diet, which mu≈øt be comforting and moi≈øtning, as Broth of Pullets, where Endive, Borage, Lettice, and Pur≈ølain may be boyled al≈øo; ≈øhe may drink the Juyce of Pomgranates, or Barley
water, with Anni≈øeeds boyled in it: the u≈øe of Wine, and all ≈øorts of Spices are very dangerous, and if the Woman go not freely to the ≈øtool, there is nothing better than a Lenitive Cly≈øte ‚Ä¢
; ≈øhe may ≈øleep much, and mu≈øt not di≈øturb her ≈øelf with any pa≈ø≈øion. The next way of Remedy is by diverting the humours, which is done by frictions, letting blood in the foot, ≈øcarrification of the legs, or veficatories applied to tho≈øe places, e≈øpecially if the flowers are ≈øtopped, or ready to come down; if not, it will be expedient to open a vein in the arm.

You may al≈øo prepare the humour to void it out of the place affected, by opening either the middle vein, or the Ba≈øilic, or the Vena Saphena, which may be done two or three times, as occa≈øion ≈øerves; after blood-letting, purge, but let this be done with gentle Medicines; ≈øuch are Ca≈ø≈øia, Manna, Tamarind, Syrup of Ro≈øes or Violets Solutive, having a little before u≈øed certain Syrups which may a≈ø≈øwage and temper the humours.

Take ≈øyrup of Ro≈øes and Pur≈ølain, of each one ounce, Endive‚ñ™ water and Plantain-water, of each an ounce, give this to the Patient, neither will it be ami≈øs to give her Syrup of Succory, or Endive, or ≈øuch like; for the≈øe Syrups have a cooling and refre≈øhing faculty, e≈øpecially being mingled with Plantain or Endive-water, or ≈øuch like, or the decoction of the ≈øaid Herbs; now when the humour is thus prepared you may give her ≈øome gentle Purges. As for Example, take of the pulp of Ca≈ø≈øia, and Tamarinds, of each ≈øix drams; of this make a little Bolus with ≈øome Sugar, and give it to the Patient; or with this Potion.

Take of the Leaves of Italian Orach three drams, of Ani≈øeed one ≈øcruple, infu≈øe the≈øe into four ounces of the fore≈øaid waters. Into this being ≈øtrained, infu≈øe an
ounce of Ca≈ø≈øia, and into the ≈øtreining of this, di≈ø≈øolve an ounce of Solutive Syrup of Ro≈øes, of this make a Potion and give it. The fourth way of cure con≈øi≈øts in Topicks, ≈øuch as may drive back and repre≈øs the humour, though care mu≈øt be had that they be not over-≈øtrong, le≈øt you thereby do cool the heart too much, and thereupon drive the humour upon the heart it ≈øelf. And therefore temperate Medicines are chiefly to be cho≈øen, and ≈øuch e≈øpecially as are to dige≈øt and di≈ø≈øolve the humour: Wherefore it ≈øhall not be ami≈øs to apply a linnen cloth dipt in white ≈øtrong vinegar, and a little cold water, which mu≈øt be applied to the Brea≈øts, and often changed. Or el≈øe you may dip linnen cloaths al≈øo in a decoction of Camomile-flowers, and Violet-flowers, with a ≈ømall quantity of Oyl of Ro≈øes, and a drop of vinegar or two; or you may u≈øe this Fomentation. Take of the juyce of Night-≈øhade and Oyl of Ro≈øes, of each an ounce and a half; of the decoction of Fenugreek, Camomile, and Line-≈øeed, two ounces, vinegar one ounce.
This Medicine you may u≈øe by dipping a ≈øpunge therein, and ≈øo wa≈øhing and fomenting the Brea≈øt therewith.

div.head: CHAP. XXX. Of Swellings from Milk.
div.p:
MILK is certainly the occa≈øion of many tumours of divers kinds; if the ferment of the Brea≈øt be over-active and vigorous, it ≈øeparates Milk with too great Violence, cau≈øing thereby an over-fermentation of the parts, which u≈øually occa≈øions an Inflammation; if the Serum be hot or partake much of blood, otherwi≈øe it rai≈øes a flegmatic Swelling; or if the matter be di≈øpo≈øed to coagulation, the Kings-evil; and the≈øe are
the mo≈øt frequent ≈øpecies of Swellings commonly ≈øuppo≈øed to ari≈øe from milk. Any of the≈øe three may degenerate into a Scirrhus, and that Scirrhus into a Cancer. The ≈øigns are vi≈øible; if the fir≈øt happen, there are all the Symptoms of an Inflammation, namely Heat, Redne≈øs, Ten≈øion, pul≈øation, and the like. If the ≈øecond, large Di≈øten≈øion with pain, but no heat: If the Kings-evil, then hard Kernels are ea≈øily felt. Swellings made by the over eagerne≈øs of the milky Ferment go ea≈øily off, if no other Symptom attend them; ≈øucking and drawing the brea≈øts commonly di≈øcharges the Milk as fa≈øt as it can be made, and then all the danger is over. But if the fermentation occa≈øion any di≈øorder in the Blood, the Patient is more or le≈øs endangered, according to the quality of the ≈øwelling produced, namely an inflammation occa≈øions a Fever. Flegmatick ≈øwellings are apt to grow Ulcerous, and ≈øometimes turn to the King's Evil, or a Scirrhus, and require a long time for their Cure. Abundance of Milk cau≈øes inflammations, and apo≈øtumations, and the like, and therefore the Woman ought to u≈øe a ≈ølender diet, and it ought to be of ≈øuch a quality as may le≈øs di≈øpo≈øe the Humours to ferment. Panadoes, Barly grewel, and ≈øuch like cooling and moi≈øtening Spoon-meat ought to be u≈øed; Chicken Broth is the highe≈øt Dyet whil≈øt the Humour is fermenting; the Medicines proper to dimini≈øh the Milk, are Lettice, Pur≈ølain, Endive, Succory, Smallage and the like; the Milk is u≈øually drawn out of the Brea≈øts by the Infant's ≈øucking; but if the Child be ≈øo weak it cannot ≈øuck, or not ≈øufficiently, the Milk mu≈øt be di≈øcharged by Whelps ≈øucking, or the Mother may draw her own Brea≈øts her ≈øelf by an In≈øtrument ≈øold for that purpo≈øe. The ≈øwelling made by the Milk is re≈øtrained by the application of Night-≈øhade, Lettice, Plantain, Vine tops, Bramble-buds, Hor≈øe-tail,
and the like, or Oyl of Ro≈øes, Myrtles with Vinegar and the like. The Tumour may be di≈øcu≈ø≈øed by the application of Mints, Cat-mints, Rue; the Seeds of Fenugreek, Cumin, Fennel, and the like; or dry'd up by applying Cloaths dipt in Lime-water, or in a ≈øolution of Sacharum Saturni made in Frogs Spawn-water, during which time fine Towe ≈øprinkl'd with Ceru≈øs, may be applied to the Arm-pits. When the Swelling is very painful, a Catapla≈øm made of the Meals of Barly, Beans and Lentils boiled in Oxymel, is proper; at the ≈øame time Towe dipt in Oxycrat may be applied under the Arms: If the Inflammation be gone too far towards Suppuration, it mu≈øt be promoted with Suppuratives, and opened by Inci≈øion or cau≈øtick. When the Swelling is hard and not inflamed, apply the following Cerate.

Take of the tops of Worm-wood powdered, two drams, of the Seeds of Lentils, Fenugreek, and Fennel, each an ounce; of the juice of Henbane and Hemlock, each three ounces, of ointment of Mar≈øhmallows two ounces, of Ducks and Goo≈øe grea≈øe, each one ounce, of Deers Suet two ounces, of liquid Storax half an ounce; with a ≈øufficient quantity of Wax make a Cerat. Hemlock boil'd in Wine, and beaten up with Hogs lard, re≈øolves the hardne≈øs in the Brea≈øts; but if it be applyed alone, it ≈øtirs up Heat, and occa≈øions Ulcers in the skin. Green Mints or Chick-weed are common applications, and of good u≈øe, either alone, or mixed with other Medicines in all the hard Swellings of the Brea≈øts occa≈øioned by Milk. All Plai≈øters applyed to the Brea≈øts, ought to have a hole ≈ønipt in them for the Nipples, le≈øt they be fretted by them, e≈øpecially that the Milk may be drawn forth while the Medicines lye on.

A young Woman after Child-birth was afflicted with a ≈øwelling in her Brea≈øts, one was called, that per≈øwaded
her Relations it was a Cancer, and treated her accordingly, but her Brea≈øts growing more painful, and much danger being apprehended from ≈øuch a Di≈øea≈øe, a Phy≈øician was advi≈øed with; but he being wary in giving his judgment in Surgery, where there might happen any di≈øpute, de≈øired that a Surgeon might be fetched; upon their view, the Brea≈øt appeared big, and inflamed; it was apo≈øtumated, and the matter perfectly dige≈øted, and the skin thin and ready to break. The Surgeon propo≈øed the applying of a Pulte≈øs of white-Bread and Milk, a≈ø≈øuring them before Morning, they ≈øhould find a Porringer full of matter di≈øcharged; they did ≈øo, and the ≈øwelling broke, and was cured by the u≈øe of Ba≈øilicon without any more trouble; and indeed when the matter is well ≈øuppurated, and a convenient opening made for di≈øcharge, the≈øe Tumours generally heal of them≈øelves, if the Habit of the Body be good; but where it is otherwi≈øe, or the management ill, the Cure is many times very trouble≈øome.

A Young Gentlewoman after Child-bed, being indi≈øpo≈øed in her Health, her left Brea≈øt became di≈øea≈øed and ≈øwell'd, and after ≈øome days by ill management, growing more painful and ≈øwelled, one was called in who endeavoured ≈øuppuration, and after ≈øome time opened it; but the fluxion increa≈øed, and other obce≈ø≈øes were rai≈øed, and from the ≈øeveral Apo≈øtumations, ≈øinous Ulcers were afterwards made, and ≈øo the work became difficult; the ab≈øce≈øs begun deep in the body of the Glands, and thro' length of time, corrupted them, and rendred the ≈øwelling hard, and the Tents ≈øtopping in the matter between dre≈ø≈øings, had occa≈øioned a large di≈øcharge: The method of Cure con≈øi≈øted in the enlarging of that Orifice, where the matter ≈øeemed to be detained, and then to proceed with deter≈øives and the like; a cau≈øtick was applied to the part round about the Orifice,
≈øtoping the hole with Lint. by which means in a ≈øhort time, a clear way was made for the matter, as the E≈øchar ≈øeparated, a Fungus thru≈øt forth, which was ≈øprinkled with red Precipitat, and the E≈øchar was dre≈ø≈øed with Ba≈øilicon, and the other openings with Diapompholigos, and the Cerate of Mar≈øh-mallows over all: After a more full-≈øeparation of the E≈øchar, ob≈øerving the Fungus to ri≈øe more large, a Stupe was applied, wrung out of a decoction of the tops of Worm wood, Rue Mint, the Flowers of red Ro≈øes and Balau≈øtines made in Wine and Water, and Chalcanthum was applyed upon the Fungus, and pledgets of the Ointment of Tutty over the Ulcerated parts. The ≈øecond day after the Dre≈ø≈øings were took off, and the E≈øchar was found to be made by the Catheretick, which was thru≈øt off, and it was dre≈ø≈øed again with the ≈øame, and the u≈øe of the E≈øcharoticks was continued; during the≈øe applicationss a Plai≈øter of Bole was applied over the Brea≈øt to re≈øtrain the fluxion, yet notwith≈øtanding the fungus encrea≈øed, and rai≈øed the ≈øwelling between that and the other Orifices, and therefore a large Cau≈øtick was applied upon the ≈øwelling, which laid ≈øome of the Orifices into this, the E≈øchar was divided, and dre≈ø≈øed up with lenients, and the Fungus was cover'd with e≈øcharoticks, wherever it began to thru≈øt out, by which it was kept down: But after the ≈øeparation of this latter E≈øchar, the Fingus appeared great, and the way of extirpating it by E≈øcharoticks being ≈ølow, the Surgeon thru≈øt his Finger under it, and at once broke it, and pulled it out in pieces, and then filled up the place with Par ‚Ä¢ cel≈øus's mundificative upon Pledgits ≈øprinkled with red Precipitat, and the fore≈øaid Plai≈øter being applied over the whole Brea≈øt, it was bound up. The ≈øecond day after it was opened again, and by this method often repeated, the remainder of the Fungus
was ≈øubdued, and a firm ba≈øis rai≈øed, on which to incarn with an addition of powders of the roots of orris, myrrh, and Sarcacoll to the fore-mentioned Mundificative, and Agripa's Cerate was applied over the brea≈øt and in a few days it was cicatrized with a ≈ømooth Cicatrix, the lips falling in by the benefit of Nature, which was a≈ø≈øi≈øted the while by traumatick decoctions, and the like. When one of the Brea≈øts has been Cured, it happens often that the other ≈øwells from the abundance of Milk, and grows hard and apo≈øtuntats; ≈øometimes both Brea≈øts are thus di≈øea≈øed at one time. A Gentlewoman had both her Brea≈øts ≈øwelled a long time, and afterwards they apo≈øtumated by rea≈øon of the pain; ≈øeveral ab≈øce≈ø≈øes were made, and the matter di≈øcharged by ≈øuch openings. In proce≈øs of time the Ulcers became ≈øinuous, and callous, with hardne≈øs of the glands; the Cure was begun by Fomentations, and di≈øcu≈ø≈øing and re≈øolving Pulte≈ø≈øes made of the roots and leaves of Mar≈øh-mallows, henbane, the tops of hemlock, mint, rue, the flowers of elder, the ≈øeeds of fenugreek, flax, and the like, and with the meal of lentiles, barly, hogs-lard, ducks and goo≈øe grea≈øe, and the like; and dilating the orifices, and clean≈øing with paracel≈øu≈øes mundificative, red precipitat and allom; while the Surgeon was endeavouring by the methods above≈øaid, new troubles aro≈øe within, which forced him to lay ≈øuch places open by cau≈øtick, as might be≈øt ≈øerve for the di≈øcharge of matter, after ≈øeparation of the E≈øchar, he again clean≈øed and healed them.

div.head: Of windy Tumours in the Brea≈øts.
div.p:
THE flatuous Tumour of the Brea≈øts is cau≈øed by a thick vapour, which ri≈øes from the men≈øtrual blood which is retained‚ñ™ or corrupted in the Matrix.
The cau≈øes of which are; fir≈øt, the ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion of the flowers; or when the flowers are not di≈øcharged into their proper place, and in their proper time; as al≈øo from the corruption of the humours, by which are ingendered divers bad fumes and vapours; for, this being received into the Brea≈øts, cau≈øes a di≈øtention much like a true ≈øwelling. The ≈øign by which it is known, is the pain which it brings along with it, which is ≈øharp and prickling, cau≈øing a di≈øtention of the part. The heart is not a little out of order, by rea≈øon of the windine≈ø≈øes which lye ≈øo near it; and commonly the left Brea≈øt is mow ≈øwoln, communicating its pain to the arm, ≈øhoulder, and ribs of the ≈øame ≈øide. And the ≈øigns differ from tho≈øe of a Cancer; for in this di≈øtemper the Brea≈øt is white and ≈øhining, by rea≈øon of the di≈øtention; and if you touch it, it ≈øounds like a drum. And if you pre≈øs it with your hands, you will find that it is ≈øwelled in all parts alike, and not in one more than another. This is Cured fir≈øt by a good order of diet, taking little victuals, whereby crudities may be avoided that do afford matter to the ob≈øtructions, and increa≈øe windine≈øs: For which cau≈øe ≈øhe mu≈øt al≈øo drink little, and that, water boyled with Cinamon, Ani≈øeed, and rind of Citrons. The next remedy is by u≈øing things which are good to provoke the Cour≈øes, (among which u≈øe this Receit, ≈øtrain Celandine ≈øtampt into po≈ø≈øet-ale, and drink it four days before the new-moon, and four days after.) And it will not be ami≈øs to let blood three or four times in the year, about the time that the Cour≈øes ought to begin. For by this means you may provoke the flowers, and hinder the increa≈øe either of a Scirrhus, or of a Cancer; to which purpo≈øe, baths and frictions are not a little to be u≈øed. In the next place, you mu≈øt prepare the humours that foment this windine≈øs
both in the Matrix and in the Veins, and that by Syrups which do expell flegm and melancholly; after which you mu≈øt purge your Patient; for which purpo≈øe you may u≈øe this gentle Apozem. Take of the root of Tamarinds, Cypre≈øs, Buglo≈øs, of each an ounce and a half; flowers of Borage, Epithymum, Sena, of each half a handful, flowers of Balm one handful, Rai≈øins one ounce, Prunes in number twelve, boyl them in a ≈øufficient quantity of water, and then in a pint of the water di≈ø≈øolve four ounces of the ≈øyrup of Violets; make of this an Apozem clarified according to Art, and ≈øweeten it with a ≈øufficient quantity of Sugar, giving four or five ounces at a time. In the next place, you may u≈øe Topicks to attenuate and re≈øolve; to which purpo≈øe you may bathe or foment the Brea≈øt with a Sponge dipt in Lye, and then lay upon it a linnen cloth, dipt and moy≈øtned in Aqua-vitae, and dryed in the ≈øhade, or el≈øe dipt in fre≈øh butter that hath boyled a good while, or in oyl of Lillies, or in oyl both of the root and ≈øeed of Angelica; or you may foment the Brea≈øt with this Decoction. Take wheat-bran two handfuls, leaves of Dill and Melilot, of each half a handful; Ani≈øeed, Fennel, and Cumin≈øeed, of each two drams, Camomile-flowers one handful; boyl all the≈øe in a ≈øufficient quantity of water and white-wine, and let them boyl to the con≈øumption of the third part. In this decoction you may wet a ≈øponge, and wa≈øh or foment the Brea≈øt therewith. After you have fomented the part, you may put this Oyntment upon the part affected: Take oyl of Lillies and Elder, of each an ounce and a half, of the be≈øt Bal≈øom half an ounce, powder of burnt-lead unwa≈øht, Ani≈øeed one dram, and as much wax as is ≈øufficient.

div.head: Of the watry Tumour of the Brea≈øt.
div.p:
THE watry tumour is ingendered by a thick and watry flegm gathered together in great abundance in the Brea≈øt and parts adjoyning, and it happens many times that this watry and flegmy ≈øub≈øtance is not always gathered to one particular place, but al≈øo diffu≈øed through all the parts of the Brea≈øt, which cau≈øes a general ≈øwelling in that part. This ≈øwelling (that we may define it) is a loo≈øe and ≈øoft tumour without much pain, yielding to the touch and pre≈ø≈øing of the fingers, ≈øo that the hole which is made by the pre≈ø≈øing of the fingers remains a pretty while after; yet it ≈øoon becomes painful, if there be any Acrimony joyned with it; or if there be any di≈øtention by rea≈øon of the pre≈øs of Vapours to that part. This oftentimes happens by rea≈øon of the ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion of the Cour≈øes; ≈øometimes it is occa≈øioned by rea≈øon of a clear and watry flegm, which di≈øcharges it ≈øelf upon the≈øe parts. This ≈øwelling is ea≈øily di≈øtingui≈øhed from other ≈øwellings, by rea≈øon of the loo≈øene≈øs and ≈øoftne≈øs thereof, and by the pain, which is always le≈øs than in other ≈øwellings: and in this kind of tumour the pain a≈øcends up to the arms and ≈øhoulders, and the whole Brea≈øt is altogether ≈øwoln and rai≈øed; and this pain comes at certain times, chiefly when the Flowers ought to come down, which being once come down, the pain dimini≈øhes, by rea≈øon that the Woman is then throughly Purged. Yet notwith≈øtanding, there doth remain ≈øome certain kind of ≈øwelling, which happens not in the windy tumours, by rea≈øon that the purgations of the Flowers do totally di≈ø≈øipate the matter of tho≈øe ≈øwellings. The≈øe flegmy tumours do ea≈øily turn into Cancers, and are therefore to be diligently looked after.
As to the Cure of the≈øe tumours, there is required fir≈øt an orderly Diet, which mu≈øt be drying, her Bread mu≈øt be well baked and levened, dryed Rai≈øins, parched Almonds, A≈øparagus, ro≈øted Fle≈øh, and ≈ømall Birds. Before meat ≈øhe may take a little Honey of Ro≈øes upon a wafer-cake. For her drink, let it be the decoction of Ani≈øeeds, China-roots, Sa≈ø≈øafras, and Sar≈øaparil. If the retention of the Flowers be the cau≈øe of this evil, let her then u≈øe rather boyled than ro≈øted meats, and then let her boyl them with Sage, Bettony and Hy≈øop. All meats made of Milk are dangerous, as al≈øo ≈øleep after dinner, and unleavened bread.

You may in the next place, u≈øe things to divert the humour, as Frictions, and Baths. If her Flowers are ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, let a vein be opened in the Feet. Next after you have prepared the humour by the u≈øe of Syrups, as tho≈øe of Mint, Wormwood, Hy≈øop, Liquori≈øh, Maidenhair, Hony of Ro≈øes, with Fennel-water, water of Hy≈øop, Marjoram, Ro≈øemary, Betony, Mint, then may you u≈øe ≈øome Purges with tho≈øe Pills, call'd Sine quibus, Agarick Pills, and Cochy Pills. If the Patient be ≈øtrong, and not to be worked upon by weak Phy≈øick, you may then add two or three grains of Diagridium, or of Troches of Alhandal; the≈øe Pills are to be u≈øed for eight days, half a dram at a time. Another way may be by Topicks, to attenuate and re≈øolve; for which purpo≈øe the Fomentations ≈øpecified in the foregoing Chapters, may be very fitly u≈øed, being prepared with Vine-a≈øhes, or Figtree-a≈øhes, whereto a little Vinegar may be put; though the u≈øe of things that drive back the humour are not here to be u≈øed; you may al≈øo rub and chafe the Brea≈øt with this Oyntment. Take of Oyl of ≈øweet-almonds, Oyl of Line-≈øeed, of each one ounce, Ganders-grea≈øe of each half an ounce, a little Diachylon in≈øtead of Wax; a plai≈øter of
great Diachylon would not be ami≈øs in this Di≈øea≈øe; if the Woman feel any pain, or heat in her Brea≈øts, let her anoint them with Oyl of Ro≈øes, a little burnt-lead, and a little white wax, or with a little Oleum Omphacinum, and Oyl of ≈øweet almonds tempered together in a Mortar. In the di≈øper≈øing and re≈øolving of the humour, you may u≈øe baths of Alum and Sulphur prepared with the decoction of Hy≈øop, Mint, and Sage, and after that ≈øuch Oyntments as are mo≈øt approved for the ≈øame purpo≈øe, always taking heed of too boy≈øterous Remedies. If you would ≈øuppurate, or mature the ≈øwelling, you mu≈øt u≈øe ≈øuch Remedies as we have de≈øcribed in the following and foregoing Chapters; the ≈øtronge≈øt of which you may here apply, becau≈øe the matter is more ob≈øtinate and tenacious, mingling with them, for that purpo≈øe, other more effective Remedies, as are the roots of Mallows, Mar≈øh-mallows, Lillies, Figs, goo≈øe-grea≈øe, and the like; when the ≈øore is opened, you mu≈øt tend it after the ≈øame manner, as is before rehear≈øed. There are other Remedies, either to be taken inwardly, or to be outwardly applied, which ≈øerve to fortifie and comfort the Stomach, as to take every morning a ≈øpoonful of Con≈øerve of Ro≈øemary, pre≈øerved Orange, or Trochi≈øques of Aromaticum Ro≈øatum, Diagalanga, or Diacuminum.

div.head: Of the Kernels in the Brea≈øts.
div.p:
THE Kernels of the Brea≈øt are little round Bodies ≈øoft and thin like a ≈øponge, which ≈øometimes grow hard by rea≈øon of the phlegmy humour which is ≈øometimes purely ≈øo, and ≈øometimes is mingled with other ≈øharp and acrimonious humours: But ≈øometimes it comes to pa≈øs, that not only the kernels of the Brea≈øt are ≈øwollen, but al≈øo that there do grow others which ought not to be there, which may not unfitly be termed
a kind of Kings-evil, being a ≈øwelling which proceeds of thick flegm, or el≈øe of a thick mattry blood hardned under the skin; they are cau≈øed many times by the detention of the flowers, the blood oftentimes mounting up into the Brea≈øt.

The Cure of the≈øe is undertaken two ways; by ≈øoftning the hard tumour, and preventing the Cancer; and then al≈øo a ≈øtrict diet is to be ob≈øerved, which mu≈øt be moderately attenuating, and by keeping them≈øelves warm, which is perform'd by moderate exerci≈øe before meals, as al≈øo by u≈øing ≈øulphury baths; but full diet, ea≈øe, idlene≈øs, and meats of hard dige≈øtion are very dangerous; and indeed in all re≈øpects be≈øides, the cure is the ≈øame as is ≈øet down in the foregoing Chapter. but if the kernel be ≈øwelled up with a ≈øharp tumour, tho≈øe topicks are to be u≈øed that are pre≈øcribed al≈øo in the foregoing Chapter, only in ca≈øe the fluxion remain any time, you may mingle tho≈øe things which do a little more refre≈øh; ≈øuch are oil of Ro≈øes, and oil of Violets; when the flux of humours cea≈øes, you may then add oyl of Camomile, and Lillies, and other ≈øuch like things, to di≈ø≈øolve and di≈ø≈øipate the humour. If you find that this kernel is become a kind of Kings-evil, you mu≈øt then u≈øe ≈øtronger Medicines; adding to the forementioned purgation, a dram and a half of the root of Mechoacan, or three drams of Diaturbith. For topicks you may u≈øe ≈øuch as do ≈øoften and di≈øpel, but ≈øuch as are ≈øtronger than the≈øe, we have expre≈ø≈øed in the former Chapter. You mu≈øt at length, when all other ways do fail, u≈øe the operation of the hand to take away the root of the di≈øea≈øe; but this is not to be done, 'till you have u≈øed all other means to ≈øoften and di≈øpell the humour, which may perhaps be done by the u≈øe of Diachylon, or by a plai≈øter of melilot, to
which you may add half an ounce of Ammoniach, an ounce of Oly of Lillies, and an ounce and an half of the root of Flower-deluce of Florence. Neither may this following Plai≈øter be ami≈øs: Take of the roots of Mar≈øh-mallows two ounces, boil them and ≈øtrain them, and add to that Oyl of Lillies, Ganders-grea≈øe, of each an ounce, burnt Lead, and roots of Orrice, of each an ounce and an half; mingle all the≈øe together, and make of them an Emplai≈øter: If this avail not, the operation of the Hand mu≈øt be u≈øed, in which the skill of the Surgeon mu≈øt be very able, and ready.

div.head: Of the Scirrhus of the Brea≈øts.
div.p:
THE Scirrhus of the Brea≈øts is a hard ≈øwelling without pain: Of this there are two kinds, the one ingendred of a Melancholy, and produced by a feculent and gro≈øs blood, or el≈øe from a thick Flegm; now this exqui≈øite Scirrhus is without pain, in which it differs from the other: The other is not ≈øo exqui≈øite an hardne≈øs, perhaps becau≈øe it is not yet come to its full maturity, or el≈øe becau≈øe it hath certain other humours mixt with it. This exqui≈øite kind of Scirrhus is ingendred, either becau≈øe the Spleen is ob≈øtructed, and cannot purge away the melancholy Blood, which for that rea≈øon abounding in the Body, di≈øcharges and empties it ≈øelf upon the Brea≈øts; or by rea≈øon of the ≈øupre≈ø≈øion of the Cour≈øes, which cau≈øes the feculent and gro≈øs humour to di≈øgorge it ≈øelf upon the Brea≈øt, gathering together in the Veins and Fle≈øh of the ≈øame. Many times the ignorance of the Surgeon is the cau≈øe of it, when they apply an unrea≈øonable company of refrigerating Medicines to the inflammations of the Brea≈øt, or too many re≈øolving and heating Medicines to it, in ca≈øe the Brea≈øts be over-hard. This Scirrhus is known by its hardne≈øs without pain, from the unevenne≈øs of
the Body, and the colour of the part either inclining to black or brown. Now though the cure of the≈øe hardne≈ø≈øes be ≈øomething difficult, yet is there great hopes that they may be overcome; which is to be done two ways, by mollifying diligently that which is hard, and by taking that away which remains hard and knotty in the Brea≈øt. And fir≈øt of all, care is to be had to keep good order of diet; to which purpo≈øe ≈øhe mu≈øt u≈øe Wheaten bread, rear Eggs, Pullets Capons, Partridge, Veal and Mutton, which mu≈øt be boiled with Spinage. Buglo≈øs and Borage; ≈øhe mu≈øt ab≈øtain from Beef, Veni≈øon, Hares-fle≈øh and Brawn, from Pea≈øe and Beans, and unlevened Bread, from all Salt and Smoaked Meats; as al≈øo from all things that have a ≈øharp biting quality; al≈øo ≈øhe mu≈øt ab≈øtain from all care and ≈øadne≈øs, immoderate exerci≈øe and going in the Winds. If the monthly Cour≈øes be ≈øtopt, you mu≈øt ≈øeek to provoke them gently, which may be done by letting Blood in the Foot, or to let blood with Hor≈øe-leeches: In the next place, it will not be ami≈øs to purge well with Sena, and Rheubarb, to which you may add Catholicon, or Triphera Per≈øica, if you find that the Di≈øea≈øe needs a more ≈øtrong purgation. Between every purge it will not be ami≈øs to take good Cordial and Comfortable things, as Confection of Alkermes, Tria≈øantalon, Electuarium de gemmis, con≈øerve of the Roots of Borage, Con≈øerve of Orange-flowers. You may after all this u≈øe Topicks, that is to ≈øay, ≈øuch Medicines as heat and dry moderately, being hot in the ≈øecond degree, and dry in the fir≈øt; ≈øuch are Sheeps grea≈øe, e≈øpecially that grea≈øie ≈øub≈øtance that grows upon the flank of a Sheep; Wax, Oyl of ≈øweet Almonds, Oyl of Camomile, Oyl of Dill, Capons-grea≈øe, Goo≈øe-grea≈øe, Hogs-grea≈øe, Bears-grea≈øe, &c. Veal-marrow, Deers-marrow, Emul≈øions of Mallows, Lillies, and other things of more
force: As liquid-pitch. Liquid Storax, Galbanum, Cummin-≈øeed, Rue-≈øeed, Broom-flowers, and Dill-≈øeed. If this ≈øwelling come of a hard Flegm, which is known becau≈øe it yields not ≈øo much to the touch as the other; you mu≈øt u≈øe the ≈øame Topicks to this, as to the watry tumour before rehear≈øed. If melancholy be the cau≈øe of it, you may u≈øe a Fomentation of the leaves of Mallows, and Mar≈øh-mallows, of each a handful and a half, of Fenugreek and Line≈øeed, of each two drams, Cucumbers, Bears-foot, of each two ounces; boil them in as much water as is ≈øufficient, and Foment the brea≈øt with this twice or thrice a day After that, take this Oyntment: Take of the root of Mallows one ounce, when it is boiled and brui≈øed, take it out, and add to it Sheeps grea≈øe, and Capons-grea≈øe of each two ounces, and with a little Wax make an Ointment: This you may u≈øe for ≈øome few days, after which you may, if need require, u≈øe this Ointment: Take Hy≈øop-leaves, Dill-leaves, and Thyme-leaves, of each half a handful; roots of Mallows, and Fenugreek-≈øeed, of each half an ounce, boil them in as much Wine and Vinegar as is ≈øufficient, 'till half be boiled away; then take of the afore≈øaid Vinegar, Goo≈øe-grea≈øe, Ducks-grea≈øe, and the marrow of the leg of a Hart, of each two ounces, boil it to the Con≈øumption of half the Vinegar: You may add to this two drams of Diachylon, and make it into the form of a Plai≈øter: You may al≈øo u≈øe for this purpo≈øe plai≈øters of Melilot, or Oxycroceum. At length, if all remedies fail, the operation of the hand mu≈øt be the la≈øt ≈øuccour, which we leave to the Surgeon.

In the Cure of a Scirrhus three intentions are required, the fir≈øt is the regulation of Diet, and manner of living; the ≈øecond is the preparing and evacuating the antecedent or peccant Humour, the third is the application of external Medicines; in order to the fir≈øt, the Air
ought to be clear and temperately hot and moi≈øt, their Food ≈øuch as may breed good blood, as new laid Eggs, Chicken Pullets, Mutton, Veal, Lamb, Kid, and the≈øe boyled with Spinage, Borrage, Endive Succory, Lettice, Sorrel, and the like, their Bread ought to be of good Wheat, and well baked, their Drink a well boi ‚Ä¢
ed ≈ømall Ale, or ≈ømall white Wine, Rheni≈øh or the like, their exerci≈øe and ≈øleep mu≈øt be moderate, their minds mu≈øt be chearful‚ñ™ and their bodies ≈øoluble by Gli≈øters, or otherwi≈øe. The ≈øecond intention is the evacuation of the Humour, which abounds in the Body, whether flegm, or Melancholy be the cau≈øe of the Scirrhus or whether it proceeds from ob≈øtructions of the Cour≈øes, or a ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion of the Hemorrhoids; if from any of the≈øe cau≈øes blood abounds, and be feculent, bleeding is allowed, but if Bloud do not abound, forbear bleeding, and proceed in preparing and evacuating the humours; the Antients u≈øed for preparatives the Syrrups of the juice of Borrage, Buglo≈øs, of Hops, of Apples, and the Bizantine Syrup, and the like, and al≈øo the de≈øtill'd waters of the ≈øame Plants or Whey The following are al≈øo u≈øed, Gerion's decoction of Senna, the decoction of Dodder of Time, al≈øo the decoctions of Ca≈ø≈øia, Tamarinds and the like, with the purging Syrup of Apples. The≈øe Humours being tough, require frequent purging, but the Purges mu≈øt not be ≈øtrong. After evacuations, you mu≈øt endeavour revul≈øion to contrary parts by Frictions, Cupping, I≈ø≈øues, and the like; for ob≈øtructions of the Hemorrhoid, Leeches may be applyed; and in a ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion of the Cour≈øes, a Vein may be opened in the Leg or Arm. The third intention is performed in treating the Humour it ≈øelf, in doing which, the≈øe directions are to be followed: Fir≈øt, you mu≈øt not u≈øe repe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ents, for cold and tough Humours, whereof the≈øe Swellings con≈øi≈øt, cannot return
back as hot humours, but do increa≈øe thereby. In the next place you ought to be cautious in the u≈øe of Emollients alone; for thereby they are frequently exa≈øperated, and end in Cancers. You ought al≈øo to forbear the u≈øe of ≈øtrong Di≈øcutients, le≈øt thereby you re≈øolve the ≈øerous thin humours, and convert the thicker part into a more ≈øolid ≈øub≈øtance; therefore you are to con≈øider well the habit of the body, and whether the Scirrhus be old or new. As to the habit of the Body, young People, and ≈øuch as live effeminately mu≈øt be treated with milder re≈øolvents than tho≈øe who live a laborious life. So al≈øo a new Scirrhus, whil≈øt it is increa≈øing, requires milder applications than the confirmed and inveterate one, the milder re≈øolvents are fre≈øh Butter, Hens-grea≈øe, oyl of ≈øweet Almonds and Lillies, Ducks and Goo≈øe-grea≈øe, the Suet of a Calf, a Goat, Cow, old Lard, the roots of Mar≈øh-mallows, Lillies, and the like; the ≈øtronger are the roots of wild Cucumber, Briony, Solamons ≈øeal, Orris, Shippitch, Liquid-pitch, Turpentine, Galbanum, Ammoniacum, Bdellium, Opoponax, and the like. Vinegar, by rea≈øon of its penetrative quality, is properly mixed with other Medicines to di≈ø≈øolve thick humours. For Fomentations u≈øe the following

Take of the roots of Mar≈øh-mallows and Lillies, each four ounces, of the roots of wild Cucumber two ounces, of the tops of Hemlock two handfuls, of the tops of Marjoram one handful, of the flowers of Melilot and Elder, each one Pugil, of the ≈øeeds of Flax, Fenugreek and Mar≈øh-mallows each one ounce, boyl them in a ≈øufficient quantity of Fountain-water, to the ≈øtrained liquor add a little Vinegar.
In ≈øoft Bodies when the Scirrhous is new.

Take of the roots of Mar≈øh-mallows half a pound, of the roots of Lillies three ounces, of the ≈øeeds of Flax
and Fenugreek each one ounce, boyl them in Broth made of the feet and head of a Sheep, then beat them and pulp them thro' a Sive, and add to them of the oyl of Camomile and Lillies each two ounces, of Oe≈øypus one ounce and an half, of ≈øimple Diachylon Plai≈øter di≈ø≈øolved in oyl of Lillies three ounces, with a ≈øufficient quantity of white wax make a Cerate.

In dry bodies, where the Scirrhous is more confirmed, a fume of Vinegar, or of Spirit of Wine ≈øprinkled upon a hot ≈øtone, are of excellent u≈øe for re≈øolving the≈øe tumours; afterwards you mu≈øt chafe the part, and apply the following.

Take of Galbanum, Ammoniacum, and Bdellium di≈ø≈øolved in Vinegar, and of liquid Storax, each one ounce, of great Diachylon two ounces, of oyl of Lillies, and Goo≈øe grea≈øe, each one ounce; of the cerate of Oe≈øypus two ounces, melt them all together, and with white wax make a ≈øoft Cerate.
If by the u≈øe of the≈øe Medicines, the Scirrhus tend to ≈øuppuration, it mu≈øt be treated accordingly; but be careful you be not deceived, and the ≈øuppuration prove fal≈øe, and end in a Cancer.

A Gentlewoman of a full body having been long di≈øea≈øed by an immoderate flux of the Cour≈øes, and ≈øubject to a Cough, and ≈øhortne≈øs of breath, and the like, at length recovered her Health by the pre≈øcriptions of her Phy≈øician, and enjoyed it the ≈øpace of a year, but was afterwards ≈øeiz'd with a ≈øtraitne≈øs and pain in her right Brea≈øt, which encrea≈øed much with inflamation. At fir≈øt ≈øight it ≈øeemed to be a confirmed Cancer fixed to the ribs. but upon more mature deliberation, and handling of it, the Surgeon found the Di≈øea≈øe was in the skin, and that the Glands and Mu≈øculous fle≈øh underneath were not hard, or otherwi≈øe affected, than as they were bound in by the inten≈øe
hardne≈øs of the skin, which kept them immoveable; from that unea≈øine≈øs an Eri≈øypelas was rai≈øed, which over≈øpread the skin of the Brea≈øt, and parts about with great heat. The Surgeon ≈øuppo≈øed the hardne≈øs proceeded from a concretion of the nutritious juices, he applied over the parts affected, Galen's Cerate, to repre≈øs the heat, and ≈øupplied her with Medicines to dre≈øs her ≈øelf, that ≈øhe might according to her de≈øire, return to her hou≈øe in the Country, where ≈øhe was let blood, and purged with Manna, and Cream of Tartar, di≈ø≈øolved in Whey; and ≈øhe was afterwards purged with Ep≈øom waters. But after all, growing more indi≈øpo≈øed, ≈øhe returned to London at which time her Brea≈øt was inflamed, and excoriated and ≈øeveral hard Tubercles were upon the skin, that gleeted much; the Scirrhus was al≈øo ≈øpread up that ≈øide of the neck by the Ma≈øtoide Mu≈øcle, to the bone of the ≈øhoulder, and Scapula, and ≈øo under that arm-pit, and down that ≈øide; ≈øome of the excoriations were dre≈ø≈øed with Vigo's Oyntment of Tutty, and others with Pledgets dipt in this following Lotion.
