Thus the Inflamation remitted, and the Excoriations were heal'd in ≈øome places, and checkt in others.
Many inward Remedies were al≈øo pre≈øcribed, viz. Emul≈øions, Cordials, and the like, according to the accidents which hapened; but the Scirrhus ≈øtill ≈øpreading, over-ran the other Brea≈øt, and ≈øide of the neck, and in a few weeks made her neck ≈øtiff and immoveable, and by rea≈øon of the compre≈ø≈øion which was made in the arm-pit, and about the ≈øhoulder, there was a ≈øtagnation of the humours, and the arm ≈øwell'd to the fingers ends. The arm was fomented with a decoction of the leaves and roots of Mar≈øh mallows, of the leaves of Violets, Plantain, Night-≈øhade, Willow, Ducks-meat, of the flowers of Camomile and Melilot, of the ≈øeeds of Flax and Fenugreek, and Embrocations, Cerates, Emollients and Re≈øolvents were u≈øed to ≈øuccour the parts; but all this while ≈øhe was afflicted, either with the Collick, a Loo≈øene≈øs or Vomiting, Mercurius dulcis was al≈øo u≈øed inwardly to carry off the matter, and Mercurial Oyntments outwardly, and the Surgeon would have Salivated her, if ≈øhe would have permitted. The Scirrhus ≈øeized on both ≈øides of her neck, her ≈øhoulders, arms, brea≈øts, and ≈øides, and began to invade the skin of her loins and hips, yet ≈øhe was not ≈øick or pained, but eat her dinner well; ≈øhe at length grew weary of Medicine, and with patience endured the remaining accidents of her di≈øea≈øe, 'till it kill ‚Ä¢ d her. She was ≈øeiz'd with this Scirrhus in May, and died the Augu≈øt following.

div.head: Of the Cancer in the Brea≈øt.
div.p:
THE Cancer is a venomous tumour, hard, and very much ≈øwelled, hot, and durable, more exa≈øperated oftentimes by remedies than a≈ø≈øwaged. The Cancer proceeds from a feculent and gro≈øs humour, which being gathered together in the ≈øpleen, is cha≈øed away from thence after it grows too hot; which when
Nature cannot void, it mo≈øt commonly in Women empties it ≈øelf upon the Brea≈øts, by rea≈øon of their cavernous and ≈øpongy nature: the matter of it is a hot melancholy blood, and it is known by the crooked windings, and retored veins that are about it, ≈øtretching out long roots a good way from it, being ≈øometimes blacki≈øh, and ≈øometimes inclined to black and blue‚ñ™ It is ≈øoft to ≈øee to, but it is very hard to the touch, extending the pain as far as the ≈øhoulders. It will ≈øometimes remain for two years together, no bigger than a Bean; afterwards it grows to be as big as a Nut, then to the bigne≈øs of an Egg; and after that increa≈øing to a larger ≈øize. When the skin breaks, there i≈ø≈øues out a great deal of pe≈øtilent matter, thin, and blacki≈øh, and having a very bad ≈ømell. The Ulcer it it ≈øelf is very unequal, the lips and orifice thereof being ≈øwell'd with hardne≈øs, and inverted; a light Fever po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth the body, and often ≈øwoonings. And many times the pe≈øtilency of the humour having corroded a Vein, there i≈ø≈øues out a great deal of blood. If the Cancer be ulcerated, or in any inward part of the body, no Medicine can prevail; for remedies do more exa≈øperate than help it. To burn it with Iron is pe≈øtilent, and if it be cut with a Pen knife, it returns again as ≈øoon as it is but skin ‚Ä¢ d over. But if it be an exulcerated Cancer (which is ea≈øily known) and ari≈øes from a more ≈øharp matter, for then the fle≈øh is corrupted, ≈øending forth a very noy≈øom matter, being very irk≈øom to the ≈øight, and accompanied with a gentle Fever, and ≈øwooning, and i≈ø≈øuing out of blood;) The cure of this is to be done by drying and refrigerating Medicines, or by inci≈øion to the quick, and expre≈ø≈øion of the corrupted blood afterwards; after which the wound mu≈øt be well clean≈øed; For which purpo≈øe the powder which is called Hartman's ble≈ø≈øed Powder,
is very prevalent. The diet mu≈øt be of meats that moi≈øten and refrigerate; blood letting al≈øo is profitable, as al≈øo preparation of the Humour, with the juyce of ≈øweet ≈ømelling Apples, and extract of Ellebore, and often purgation with Lapis Lazuli pills; and particularly if the Cancer be not ulcerated, you may apply this Ointment. Take Litharge one ounce, beat it in a marble Mortar with a leaden Pe≈øtle, incorporating into it two ounces of Ro≈øe-water and Oil of Ro≈øes. In ca≈øe the pain be great, u≈øe this remedy, Take white Poppy≈øeed one ounce, Oil of Ro≈øes four ounces, Henbane ≈øeed and Opium, of each a dram and a half; Gumme Arabick half an ounce, a little Wax, of which you may make an ointment. If the Cancer be already ulcerated, take this water: Take of the juyces of Night-≈øhade, Hou≈øleek, Sorrel, Scabious, Honey-≈øucles, Mullein, Figwo ‚Ä¢ t, Dropwort, Plantain, Toads flax, Agrimony, of each half a pound, juice of green Olives one pint, the Fle≈øh of Frogs, and River-Crabs, of each a pound and a half, the whites of ≈øix Eggs, Alum three ounces; Camphire one dram; let all the≈øe be di≈øtilled in a leaden Limbeck, and with the di≈øtilled water foment the part affected. Take al≈øo Allum as much as a Nut, Honey two penniworth, red Wine a pint, ≈øeeth them together 'till the fifth part be ≈øpent, ≈øtrein it through a cloth, and wa≈øh the Cancer therewith.

A Woman having a pain in her Brea≈øt, advi≈øed with a Surgeon, who felt one of the Glands ≈øwell'd; he advi≈øed her to forbear handling it, and to forbear lacing her ≈øelf too ≈øtrait It lay ≈øome Years quiet; but then the death of her Husband happening, and one affliction following another, and the Cour≈øes ≈øtopping, the humours ‚Ä¢ omented in this Gland, and afterwards the brea≈øt ≈øwell'd, and ≈øeem ‚Ä¢ d to apo≈øtumate. Some a≈ø≈øured her, it was a ≈øimple apo≈øthumation, and requir'd dige≈øtives,
and ≈øhe was per≈øwaded to follow their advice, 'till ≈øhe became extreamly pained. It was without inflammation, but ≈øwell'd very big, and ≈øeem'd to be full of matter; it was not without hard tubercles, and other ≈øymptoms to ≈øhew it would end in a Cancer, when≈øoever it ≈øhould break; therefore a skilful Surgeon refu≈øed to open it, but advi≈øed the be≈øt he could to give her ea≈øe, and promi≈øed to come to her, if after it brake ≈øhe would ≈øend for him. Some Months after ≈øhe ≈øent for him, and ≈øhew'd him a great quantity of curdled matter newly bur≈øt forth; the Brea≈øt was lank, but very hard Glands lay within, and in the circumference of the tumour, there were ≈øome tubercles that required to be eradicated; to which purpo≈øe, he de≈øign'd to have ≈ølit open the ab≈øce≈øs, and to have pull'd away the Cancerated Glands, but ≈øhe would not permit him ≈øo much as to enlarge the orifice; upon which con≈øideration he left her, and ≈øhe died within half a year after.

div.head: Of the greatne≈øs of the Brea≈øts.
div.p:
THE greatne≈øs of the Brea≈øts is very un≈øightly, the cau≈øe of their greatne≈øs is often handling of them, ≈øtore of windy Vapours, and retention of the monthly Cour≈øes; The cure of them is not to be neglected, becau≈øe the le≈ø≈øer the Brea≈øts be, the le≈øs ≈øubject they are to be cancered; they are cured by diet fir≈øt, wherein the u≈øe of a≈øtringent meats is to be recommended, ≈øo that they be not windy by repercu≈ø≈øion of the humours and blood which flow to that part, ≈øuch are the juyce of Hemlock, and the anointing of the place with Partridge Eggs: Or you may u≈øe this following Catapla≈øm; Take of the juyce of Hemlock, three ounces, of white lead, Acacia, and Frankincen≈øe, of each three drams, of Vinegar one ounce, mingle all the≈øe together, to which you may add powder of Spunge, burnt Alum, burnt
Lead, bole Armoniack, and of the≈øe with a ≈øufficient quantity of Wax and oyl of Myrtle, make a very profitable Ointment. Thirdly, by the di≈øcu≈ø≈øion of that which is gathered together in that part; for which purpo≈øe you may make an Ointment in this manner; take of the mud or lome, found in molis Ton≈øorum, two ounces; Oil of Myrtle one ounce, Vinegar half an ounce; or thus, take of the ≈øame lome and Bole Armoniack, of each an ounce, white Lead two drams, Oil of Ma≈øtick two ounces and a half, of the Emul≈øion of Henbane≈øeed one dram and a half, anoint the Brea≈øt with this, and then upon that put a linnen cloath dipt in the deco ‚Ä¢ tion of Oke-apples. Fourthly, by compre≈ø≈øion of the part, which is done by u≈øing a kind of plate of Lead upon the Brea≈øt anointed within ≈øide with Oil of Henbane-≈øeed.

div.head: Of the defect, abundance, and coagulation of the Milk.
div.p:
THE defect of Milk ari≈øes from a double cau≈øe; for either it is a defect in the blood, which is dried up by rea≈øon of ≈øome hot maladies of the body, either through intemperancy of the Liver through fa≈øting, or too much evacuation. If the deficiency of milk come from the≈øe cau≈øes, it may be increa≈øed again, either by prepared Cry≈øtal; The leaves al≈øo, root and ≈øeed of Fennel do avail much in this particular, and the powder of Earth-Worms prepared and drunk in Wine, as al≈øo the Electuary called Electuarium Zacuthi. There is another cau≈øe which proceeds from the Lactifying quality, which is many times ≈øo weak, that it can neither attract nor concoct the Blood, by rea≈øon of ≈øome outward refrigerating, and a≈øtringent qualities, or by rea≈øon of ≈øome other Di≈øea≈øes. The Cure of which being looked after in their re≈øpective places, much conduceth to the re≈øtoring of that defect. The redundance
of milk proceeds from too great a plenty of blood, and a ≈øtrong lactifying quality. In the cure of which the increa≈øe of blood is to be impeded, which is done by drying up that humour, and diver≈øion; to which blood-letting conduceth much: Medicines al≈øo that drive it back are to be put upon the Brea≈øts towards the Arms; to which purpo≈øe Hemlock boiled in Chervil-water and Vinegar avails.

Curdling of the milk is when the thinner part of the milk exhales, and the more gro≈øs and heavy part ≈øtays behind, which many times is the cau≈øe of tumours, kernels, and Apo≈øthumes. In this ca≈øe the Infant is not to ≈øuck the part affected; though that Brea≈øt is al≈øo to be ≈øuckt for fear, le≈øt the milk which is newly generated, ≈øhould be curdled and knotted by that which is there already; and ≈øo that part of the coagulated milk may be hindred from putrifying. To the di≈ø≈øolving of the Milk it much conduceth to wa≈øh the Brea≈øt with Water, Wine, and Vinegar mixt together; as al≈øo a Fomentation made of the decoction of Mar≈øh-mallows, Fenugreek, and Melilote, and then anointing them with a liniment of Oil of Ro≈øes, Oil of ≈øweet Almonds, juice of Par≈øley and Vinegar, wherein let the Gall of a Hare be fir≈øt di≈ø≈øolved. Hemlock water in this ca≈øe al≈øo is not a little commended.

div.head: Of the Di≈øea≈øes of the neck of the Womb, and fir≈øt of the Di≈øea≈øe called Tentigo.
div.p:
TENTIGO is a Di≈øea≈øe in Women, when the Clitoris increa≈øes to an over great mea≈øure; the ≈øubject of this Di≈øea≈øe is the Clytoris, or nervous piece of fle≈øh, which the lips or wings of the privities do embrace, and which ≈øuffers erection in the act of Venery: The ≈øigns of it are evident, for it hangs below the orifice of the Privities as big as the neck of a Goo≈øe:
The cau≈øes hereof are a great concour≈øe of Humours, or nutriment, by rea≈øon of the laxity of it, which happens by often handling. The Cure is performed by the diminution of the blood, and drawing out of the other humours. A ≈ølender and refrigerating diet is al≈øo nece≈ø≈øary, and ≈øuch things as have a di≈øcu≈ø≈øive faculty, as the leaves of Ma≈øtick-tree, and the leaves of Olive-tree. In the next place, by taking away the excre≈øcence, to which purpo≈øe gentle Cau≈øticks may be fir≈øt applied, as Allum, and the Aegyptiack Ointment, and that Lie whereof Sope is made, being boiled with Roman Vitriol, to which at la≈øt you may add ≈øome Opium, and form the compo≈øition into Trochi≈øques, which being afterwards made into a powder, is to be ≈øprinkled upon the fle≈øhy excre≈øcence: At length the fle≈øh is to be out away, either by binding hard, or by ≈øection; care being taken that you avoid an inflammation.

There is another Di≈øea≈øe, which is called Cauda, which is a carnous ≈øub≈øtance proceeding from the mouth of the Womb, which ≈øometimes fills up the privy parts, and ≈øometimes thru≈øts it ≈øelf outwards like a tail. The Cure of this is the ≈øame with the former; only if it come to Section, it may be done either with a Hor≈øe-hair, or a ≈øilken thread wound about it, being fir≈øt dipt in Sublimat water; or el≈øe with a Knife.

div.head: Of the narrowne≈øs of the neck of the Womb.
div.p:
THIS narrowne≈øs is either of the Womb it ≈øelf, or of the Orifice of the Womb; the ≈øigns are the ≈øtoppage of the Cour≈øes, followed with a depre≈ø≈øing and weighty pain. The cau≈øe is partly natural from the Nativity, and partly varies according to the differences of the Di≈øea≈øe: The difference is in this, it hapning ≈øometimes that this ≈øtreightne≈øs con≈øi≈øts in the exterior orifice, whereby neither the Flowers have free
pa≈ø≈øage, neither can ≈øhe enjoy coition, or conceive with Child, becau≈øe ≈øhe cannot receive either the Man or the Seed. Sometimes the narrowne≈øs is in the interior orifice of the Womb, into which the flowing retires back again, to the ab≈øolute hindrance of Conception; ≈øometimes it is occa≈øioned by way of compre≈ø≈øion, when the Caul being fatter than ordinary, lies upon the neck of the Womb. Sometimes the ≈øplaying of the thighs ≈øtone in the Bladder, or ≈øome tumour in the ≈øtraight gut. Sometimes it happens by the clinging of other parts together which happens either from the Birth, and then either the Fle≈øh which appears red, and is ≈øoft to the touch, intercepts the pa≈ø≈øage; or el≈øe the Membrane which ≈øeems, white feels hard being touched. In the Cure of this, the u≈øe of moi≈øt Fomentations is very prevalent, and an in≈øection is to be made perpendicularly; great care being taken for fear of hurting the neck of the Bladder. The Humour is next to be provoked forth, and a Tent dipt in ≈øome ≈øuppurating Plai≈øter is to be put up; the next day it is to be wa≈øhed with water and Honey, and cicatrizing Plai≈øters to be applied; if it come after the Birth, it is either occa≈øion ‚Ä¢ d by an Ulcer, and then either the ≈øides of the neck cling together, in which ca≈øe either inci≈øion, or cauterization is to be u≈øed; or el≈øe there is a brawny ≈øub≈øtance which is to be cut away with a Penknife; or el≈øe ≈øome ≈øpongy and luxuriant fle≈øh, in which ca≈øe drying and d ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ cu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ng Medicines ‚Ä¢ re to be u≈øed, as Birthwort, Frankincen≈ø ‚Ä¢ Myrrh, and Ma≈øtick, afterwards you may apply things to eat it away; and la≈øt of all to cut it away by inci≈øion.

div.head: Of Wheals, Condyloma's of the Womb, and of the Hemorrhoids.
div.p: THE Wheals of the Womb are certain ri≈øings in the neck of the womb, which by their acrimony excite both pain and itching. The ≈øigns of them are an itching pain, and full of ≈øcurf from that part, for the better ≈øearching of which, the In≈øtrument called ≈øpeculum Matricis is to be u≈øed. The Cau≈øes of this are, certain cholerick, ≈øharp, and adu≈øt humours, and thick. Among the preparing Medicines, Syrup of Fumitory is much commended, and Chichory with a decoction of Lupines. Topicks al≈øo are u≈øeful that di≈øcu≈øs and mitigate the humour, as Baths, and in≈øe≈ø≈øions, and the wa≈øhing of the place with Wine and Nitre, which is often to be u≈øed. The≈øe Wheals are divided into gentle, and venemous, which are ≈øaid to be contagious; they are to be wa≈øhed in a water thus made. Take of Aloes the quantity of a Pea; of the flower of bra≈øs the quantity of half a Pea, powder the≈øe, and mingle them in an ounce of white-wine, Plantain-water, and Ro≈øe-water, of each an ounce, which is to be kept in a gla≈øs ve≈ø≈øel.

Condyloma's are certain ≈øwelling wrinckles in the neck of the Womb, with pain and heat. There is no need to tell the ≈øigns of the≈øe, for they are apparent to the eye; the wrinkles are like tho≈øe which appear in the hand when you clo≈øe the fir≈øt; but are much bigger when the cour≈øes flow: they are cau≈øed by adu≈øt and thick humours; ≈øome of the≈øe are with an inflamation, which have more pain and heat, and the ≈øwelling is hard: In the cure of which, you mu≈øt u≈øe in≈øe≈ø≈øions, and fomentations that ea≈øe pain; ≈øometimes they come
without any inflammation, which if they be new come are to be dried up; if they be old, they are fir≈øt to be ≈øoftned afterwards to be dige≈øted and dried up; for which purpo≈øe you may u≈øe powder of Egg-≈øhels burnt, or this Oyntment: Take of the Trochi≈øques of Steel one dram powdered, mixt with a little Oyl of Ro≈øes and Wax, with half an ounce of the juyce of Mullein; if this profit not, the Warts are to be ≈øhaved away with a knife, and an a≈øtringent powder laid upon them.

Hemorrhoids of the Womb are little protuberancies like tho≈øe of the Fundament, produced in the neck of the Womb, through the abundance of feculent blood; the ≈øubject is the neck of the Womb, for where the Veins end, there do grow the≈øe extuberancies, ju≈øt as in the Hemorrhoids.
The ≈øigns are evident, and ea≈øily ≈øeen by the help of the Speculum Matricis: The women who are thus affected look pale, and are troubled with a wearine≈øs.

The cau≈øe is a feculent blood, which flowing to the≈øe Veins before its ≈øea≈øon, and ≈øetling there, grows thicker, ≈øo that it cannot pierce the orifice of the Veins. They are cured by a revul≈øion of the humour; Fir≈øt, by letting blood in the Arm. Secondly, by drawing it to another part, as by letting blood in the heel. Sometimes the≈øe Hemorrhoids are very painful, and are di≈øtingui≈øhed from that men≈øtruous effluxion, by the pain which they bring: they are cured by mittigating and a≈ø≈øwaging in ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ions, ‚Ä¢ s al≈øo by Opiates carefully applied. Others are without pain, to which the fore≈øaid remedies may be applied

Others are open, and do ≈øometim ‚Ä¢ s run moderately (and then Nature is to be ‚Ä¢ et alon ‚Ä¢ ) or violent ‚Ä¢ y, ≈øo that thereby the ≈øtrength of the per≈øon is impaired, in
which ca≈øe a Vein mu≈øt be opened in the arm, two or three times, purgation is al≈øo to be u≈øed by Myrobolans, Tamarind, and Rheubarb; and at length you mu≈øt apply tho≈øe things which cea≈øe the blood.

Others are termed blind, out of which there i≈ø≈øues no blood; they are cured by blood-letting; the part is to be al≈øo ≈øoftned and fomented with things that ≈øoften and open the orifices of the Veins, and di≈øpel the humour; ≈øuch are an Oyntment made of the pith of Coloquintida, and Oyl of ≈øweet Almonds, or the juyce of Capers mixt with Aloes; neither is the applying of Hor≈øeleaches ami≈øs.

The Cure of the≈øe Excre≈øcences at their fir≈øt budding forth, may be attempted by drying and a≈øtringent Medicines, as with the tops of Brambles and Hor≈øe-tail, with the Leaves and Berries of Myrtles and Sumach, with the rind of Pomgranats, Balau≈øtins, ≈øcales of Bra≈øs, wa≈øh'd Lime, Allom, and the like, made into fomentations, or powder'd and mixed with Oyntments, and applied upon Tow. If the≈øe do not check their growth, you may cut them off with a Knife, or Scizers, and con≈øume the remaining roots by E≈øcharoticks, or actual Cautery, and then proceed in the cure by dige≈øtion, and Epuloticks accordingly. To prevent their growing again, Authors commend the a≈øhes of Vine and Bean-≈øtalks mix'd with Vinegar, to apply upon the part.
The Cure of Chaps or Fi≈ø≈øures con≈øi≈øts in removing the Callo≈øity, and Cicatrizing them ≈ømooth; if moi≈øture abound, things that are dry mu≈øt be u≈øed. To which purpo≈øe,

Take of the flowers of Red-Ro≈øes, of Myrtle-Berries, of the tops of Brambles, each one handful; of the roots of Tormentil and Bi≈øtort, each one ounce; of Allom one dram, boyl them in a pint and an half
of Steel-water; towards the end of boyling, add four ounces of red wine, wherewith foment the part, then apply what follows.

Take of Litharge and Ceru≈øe, each three drams, of Sarcocoal, Ma≈øtick, and Frankincen≈øe, each one Scruple, of Sealed-earth two Scruples, of Oyl of Ro≈øes four ounces, of Wax a ≈øufficient quantity, mingle them over the fire, then beat them in a leaden Mortar for u≈øe.
If dryne≈øs be the fault, you mu≈øt dre≈øs them with Medicines that are moi≈øtening; as,
Take of Calves fat, of Ducks and Hens-grea≈øe, each two drams, of Litharge of Gold one dram, mingle them in a leaden Mortar, according to art.

The material cau≈øe of all the≈øe ≈øorts of Excre≈øcences, is flegmatic or gro≈øs clammy blood thru≈øt forth, by the ≈øtrength of the expul≈øive faculty, out of the Pores of the skin, and dry'd up into the≈øe forms in which you ≈øee them. All the≈øe ≈øpecies of Excre≈øcences, are for the mo≈øt part Symptoms of the French Pox.

div.head: Of the Ulcers of the neck of the Womb.
div.p: THE ≈øigns of the≈øe Ulcers is a pain, and perpetual twinging, which increa≈øes, if any thing that hath an ab≈øter≈øive quality be ca≈øt in; the i≈ø≈øuing out of putrid humours, and matter with blood, if the Ulcer be great, or the Flowers come down; often making water, and the water hot; as al≈øo a pain in the fore-part of the head toward the roots of the eyes; as al≈øo ≈øome kind of gentle Fever.

The Cure of this is hard, becau≈øe of its being in a place of ≈øo exqui≈øite ≈øen≈øe, and moi≈øt, and having ≈øuch a ≈øympathy with other parts of the Body: For the ea≈øing of the pain, Chalybeated milk is very much conducing; and to the drying of them up, drying baths
are the be≈øt and mo≈øt prevalent remedy. The≈øe differ much, coming either from external cau≈øes, as ra≈øh Phy≈øick, hard labours, and violent coiture; or from internal cau≈øes, as the corruption of the Secondines, the Cour≈øes retained, and the Urine flux, a virulent Gonorrhea the Pox, inflammations turned into Apo≈øtems, humors flowing from other parts of the body, and there ≈øetling; all which mu≈øt be duly con≈øidered in the Cure. Others are in the outward part, and may be ea≈øily come at with Medicines; others deep, and mu≈øt be come at only with injection; for which purpo≈øe, u≈øe this following.

Take whites of four Eggs, beat them well, and put to them an equal quantity of Ro≈øe water, and Plantain-water, as much in quantity as they come to, C ‚Ä¢ mphire, Ceru≈øe, Litharge of Gold, and Bole-Armoni ‚Ä¢ ck of each a like quantity, green Copperas, half as much as of any of them, beat all to powder, mix it, and ≈øtrain it through a cloth, and make your injection 'till the part infected be whole; and if there be any pain, ≈øometimes inject a little new warm milk.

Others are more gentle, with a little ≈øtinking matter flowing from them. For the cure of which, gentle ab≈øter≈øives are profitable, as Honey of Ro≈øes with Barly-water, Whey with Sugar, and the decoction of Lentiles: after the≈øe, gentle a≈øtringents mu≈øt be applied. Others are ≈øordid, with much matter ≈ølowing from them: In which ca≈øe ≈øtronger Medicines mu≈øt be applied. Others do eat into the Fle≈øh, having a coloured, green, and ≈øtinking matter flowing from them. For the clean≈øing of which, Aloes and Wormwood are very much commended, or the fore≈øaid injection.

There are another ≈øort of Ulcers, little and long, which eat the skin of the neck of the Womb; they are known by the pain and blood which they produce immediately
after congre≈ø≈øion; they are ≈øeen al≈øo by looking into the neck of the Womb, being much like chilblains that come upon the hands in Winter time. They are cau≈øed divers ways, either by a difficult Lying in, or by a violent coiture, and cured by an a≈øtringent Cly≈øter: or they are produced by ≈øome Inflammation, or Flux of ≈øharp humours; Purgations are here needful, before Topicks be applied, among which is much commended the grea≈øe that fries out of wooden ladles, much u≈øed in Kitchens being held to the fire; as al≈øo the Oyntment called Pomatum

The Cure of the Ulcer mu≈øt be perform ‚Ä¢ d by ≈øtopping the defluction of acrid humours, and by clean≈øing and conglutinating the Ulcer. And fir≈øt, if the body be Plethorick, or if the Ulcer be accompanied with an inflammation, a vein mu≈øt be open'd in the arm, and bleeding mu≈øt be repeated as often as there is danger of a new Fluxion, e≈øpecially at the time of the Cour≈øes, to le≈ø≈øen them, which are wont to increa≈øe the matter of the Ulcer, and to promote the Flux of other humors to the Womb. Purging is al≈øo very nece≈ø≈øary to clean≈øe the body from ill humors, but it ought to con≈øi≈øt of gentle Catharticks, as of Sena, Rhubarb, Tamarinds, Myrobalans, and the like; it mu≈øt be often repeated, that the vitious humors may be diverted; and this is of ≈øo great moment that a Noble Matron was cur'd of an Ulcer of the Womb, by taking every day five ounces of a decoction of Sena, dodder of Thyme, red Ro≈øes. Indian Myrobalans ≈øweetned with Sugar, and by injecting a clean≈øing decoction into the Womb.

If the Sick vomits ea≈øily, a Vomit is mo≈øt u≈øeful; for it m ‚Ä¢ kes a revul≈øion of the humors from the Womb, and the days the ≈øick does not purge, a vulnerarary decoction
mu≈øt be u≈øed a long while, made in the following manner.

Take of the leaves of Agrimony, Knot-gra≈øs, Burnet and Plaintain, each half an handful, of the roots of China three drams, of Coriander-≈øeed one dram, of Rai≈øins half an ounce, of red Sanders one Scruple, boyl them in Chicken Broth, ≈øtrain it, let the ≈øick take of it Morning and Evening.

If the Fever be violent, and if a great quantity of Sanies be evacuated, Whey is very proper, half a pint or more being taken in a morning with a little honey of Ro≈øes. If the Body begins to w ‚Ä¢ ≈øte, and there is a Hectick Fever, A≈ø≈øes milk mu≈øt be taken with Sugar of Ro≈øes for a whole Month, Sudor ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ks may al≈øo do good to dry the Ulcer; and to drive the ≈øerous humour towards the habit of the body, if the ‚Ä¢ e be no inflammation or hot intemperies, Turpen ‚Ä¢ ine wa≈øhed in ≈øome proper water for the Womb, as in Mugwort, or Feverfew-water, or in ≈øome water proper for the Ulcer, taken with Sugar of Ro≈øes by intervals, clean≈øes and heals the Ulcer, Pills of Bdellium taken dayly, or every other day, are al≈øo very good.

Take of Bdellium three drams, of Myrrh and Frankincen≈øe, each one dram, of Sarc ‚Ä¢ coal, Amber, S ‚Ä¢ orax, and Myrobalans call'd Chebule, each one dr ‚Ä¢ m, of red Coral two Scruples, with Syrup of Poppi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , make a ma≈øs for Pills, to which, when the pain is violent, may be added a little Opium. Troches of Al ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
kengy with Opium may be al≈øo u≈øed, when the pain is violent. The following powder is al≈øo very e ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ectual to dry the Ulcer.

Take of Acatia, and Hypoci≈øtis, each one dram, of Dragons-blood, white Starch, the roots of Pl ‚Ä¢ ntai ‚Ä¢ , and of round Birthwort, each half a dram, of Bole Armoniack one dram, of Ma≈øtich and Sarcacoal, each half
a dram of the≈øe make a fine Powder. The Do≈øe is one dram in Plantain ‚Ä¢ or Ro≈øe-water, or in ≈øome Chalybe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Water.

To clean≈øe, heal, and dry the Ulcer, various In ‚Ä¢ ections are prepared; but they mu≈øt not be u≈øed 'till the inflammation is taken off‚ñ™ and 'till the pain is e ‚Ä¢ ≈øed‚ñ™ and therefore upon account of the inflammation and acrimony, Emul≈øions of the cold ≈øeeds, the whey of Goats Milk, or the Milk it ≈øelf, or mixed with the juyce of Plantain, or Shepherd's-Pur≈øe, may be injected fir≈øt If nece≈ø≈øity requires, a decoction of Poppy heads, and tops of Mallows may be injected. Some Practitioners ≈øay, the Sick may be much relieved by injecting frequently warm water.

The hot intemperies, and the pain being quieted, at lea≈øt dimini≈øh'd, ≈øuch things mu≈øt be u≈øed as clean≈øe, beginning with the gentle, as Whey with Sugar, a d ‚Ä¢ coction of B ‚Ä¢ rly with Sugar, or hony of Ro≈øes; but ≈øimple Hydr ‚Ä¢ mel clean≈øes more. A decoction will be a little ≈øtronger made with Barly, Lentils, Beans not excorticated, of the leaves of Smallage, Plantain, and Pellitory a little hony of Ro≈øes may be added. When the Ulcer is very ≈øordid, the following decoction may be u≈øed.

Take of the roots of Gentian, Rhaponticum, Zedoary, and round Birthwort, each one ounce, of white Wine three pints, boyl them to the con≈øumption of a third part; in the ≈øtrain'd Liquor di≈ø≈øolve half a pound of Sugar, and keep it for u≈øe.
If the Ulcer be very faetid, a little Aegyptiac Oyntment may be added to the decoction; when the Ulcer is well clean≈øed, you mu≈øt u≈øe ≈øuch things as dry and con≈øolidate.

Take of the Roots of Comfry, and Bi≈øtort, each one ounce, of the leaves of Plantain, Hor≈øe-tail, Shepherds-pur≈øe,
Sanicle, Mou≈øe-ear, Milfoil, each one handful, of red Ro≈øes half an handful; boil them in a mea≈øure of Water for an injection. The following ≈øarcotic powder may be added to it.
Take of the Roots of Orris, Birthwort, and Comfry, each half an Ounce, of Myrrh one ounce, of Aloes three drams, make a Powder, whereof let half an ounce be mingled with every injection.

Take of Turpentine wa≈øhed in Plantain-water, two Drams, di≈ø≈øolve it with Honey and the Yolk of an Egg, and mingle it with the injection. This is very effectual, and is more ≈øo, if the Sarcotic Powder be al≈øo added.
Fumes mu≈øt be u≈øed for deep Ulcers, for they penetrate to the bottom of the Womb, and dry the Ulcers.
Take of Frankincen≈øe, Myrrh, Ma≈øtick, Gum of Juniper, Labdanum, each one ounce, with a ≈øufficient quantity of Turpentine, make troches for a fume.

When the Ulcer is very ob≈øtinate, Cinnabar mu≈øt be added, which is of excellent u≈øe. The Bath-waters have cured ≈øome Women, when all other Medicines have bin ineffectual. After you have ≈øufficiently clean≈øed the Ulcer, you mu≈øt apply a drying and cicatrizing Ointment. Take of Tutty wa≈øhed half an ounce, and of Litharge, Ceru≈øe, and Sarcacoal, each two drams, of Oyl and Wax a ≈øufficient quantity, make an Ointment. Sometimes the Ulcer penetrates the right gut, and ≈øometimes the bladder, which may be known by the matter evacuated by tho≈øe parts; if it flow by the right gut, lenitive, clean≈øing, and drying Gli≈øters mu≈øt be injected; but if it flow from the Bladder, gentle and cooling diureticks mu≈øt be u≈øed, as an emul≈øion of the greater cold Seeds, Turpentine, and the like. If the Ulcer turn to a Fi≈øtula, which chiefly happens, when it is opened outwardly towards the Hip, tho' it may happen in the
womb it ≈øelf, or in the neck of it. In this ca≈øe we mu≈øt con≈øider, whether it be be≈øt to leave the accu≈øtomed pa≈ø≈øage untouched, thro' which nature endeavours to evacuate various Excrements, or to undertake the ‚Ä¢ ure of it: But if that be thought mo≈øt proper for the ≈øick, a Cure that is call'd palliative, mu≈øt be in≈øtituted by purges frequently-repeated, and by ≈øweatlng twice a Year, and by clean≈øing and ≈øtrengthening injections, and by applying over a plai≈øter of Diapalma, or the like; but if there be any hopes of a Cure, the ≈øame Remedies mu≈øt be u≈øed, which are proper for other Fi≈øtula's. If the Ulcer be occa≈øion'd by the French Pox, it cannot be cured without an univer≈øal Cure; in performing which, the fumes of Cinnabar receiv'd thro' a Tunnel into the womb, are peculiarly proper. Al≈øo the anointing the inner parts of the womb with a Mercurial Ointment

In all Ulcers of the womb if there be a trouble≈øome itching about the neck, as it frequently happens, by rea≈øon of a defluxion of an acid and Salt Humour to the part, a pe≈ø≈øary mu≈øt be made to qualifie it, dipt in the ointment of Elecampane with Mercury, or in Aegyptiacum di≈ø≈øolved in Sea or Allom-water, or in fre≈øh Butter, wherein Quick-Silver has been extingui≈øhed, to which mu≈øt be added Sulphur.

div.head: Of the Di≈øea≈øes of the Womb. Of the Womb being out of temper.
div.p:
THE intemperance of the Womb is when it hath lo≈øt its natural temper, and is affected with a preternatural intemperancy ari≈øing both from inward and outward cau≈øes. The one of the≈øe is hot, and is known by the womans pronene≈øs to Venery, by the ≈ømall Flux of the Monthly Cour≈øes, by their adu≈øtne≈øs, ≈øharpne≈øs, inordinate, and difficult Flux. (Hence in proce≈øs of time they are very Hypochondriack) by early growing of
the hairs about the Privities, by redne≈øs of the Face, and drine≈øs of the lips, and frequent pains of the head, and abundance of cholerick humours in the Body; it ari≈øeth either at fir≈øt from the Birth, which cau≈øes Women to be Virago's, and to be barren; or after their Nativity, from outward cau≈øes, as the u≈øe of hot things, overmuch Venery, and ≈øuch Medicines as bring the heat and blood to the Womb. The cure con≈øi≈øts in a contrary diet, and cooling Medicines, both internal and external, which are to be applyed to the back and ≈øides; which mu≈øt be very moderate, that the heat which is nece≈ø≈øary for Conception may not be weakened, and the cold and membranous ≈øub≈øtance of the womb come to any harm; or le≈øt the Ve≈ø≈øels which ≈øerve for the carrying away of the Cour≈øes ≈øhould be thickned, and the Nerves of the back and ≈øides be any way mi≈øchieved.

The next way of cure is performed by evacuating Medicines, namely, Rheubarb and ≈øolutive Syrup of Ro≈øes, Manna al≈øo profiteth much; the flower of Vitriol of Venus and Mars, taken from three grains to ≈øix, and put in any proper Syrup, purges the Womb.

There is another intemperancy which comes of cold, which is known by a le≈ø≈øer pronene≈øs to Venery, and little plea≈øure taken in it, a ≈øetling in the Cour≈øes, with a ≈ølimy and flegmy matter mixed, and an inordinate flowing of them by rea≈øon of the plenty of Humours collected in the Womb, which cau≈øes ob≈øtructions, by rea≈øon of abundance of windy vapours in the Womb, crudities and watrine≈øs of the Seed, which cau≈øes it to flow without any plea≈øure, a pale colour in the Face: It ari≈øes from cau≈øes contrary to the former, it is cured by contrary diet, by hot Medicines applyed to the womb, among which the roots of Birthwort, Clove-Gilliflowers, Angelica, and Eringo's, are very much
commended. The leaves al≈øo of Mercury, Balm, Dittany, Penny-royal, Sage, Ro≈øemary, Mugwort, flowers of Centaury, Marigolds, Sage, Ro≈øemary, Borage; and ≈øundry ≈øpices, as Nutmegs, Cubebs, Saffron and Cinamon. The≈øe kind of Compounds are al≈øo very u≈øeful, as Oyl of Mace, Oyl of Amber, Oyl of Myrrh, and of Cinamon.

There is another intemperancy of the womb, which comes of moi≈øture, and is joined mo≈øt commonly with the cold intemperancy: it is known by the plenty of the Cour≈øes, and by the thinne≈øs and watrine≈øs of them; as al≈øo the moi≈øtne≈øs of the Privities, by rea≈øon of the moi≈øtne≈øs of the Excrements; no plea≈øure in the act of Venery, and pronene≈øs to abortion, by rea≈øon of the growth of the Birth. It hath the ≈øame original with the frigid intemperancy, and happens mo≈øt commonly to Women, who are lazy and ≈øedentary: It is cured with the ≈øame Medicines as the former; only this may be added, that a fume may be made of the ≈øhavings of Ivory: And the decoction of Sage, being received into tho≈øe parts before ≈øupper, is very much commended. Baths of Sulphur do al≈øo profit much.

There is another di≈øtemper of the Womb, which is dry, which is di≈øcerned by the want of Seed, and the defect of the Cour≈øes, by ≈ølowne≈øs to Venery, drine≈øs of the Mouth of the Womb, by a blacki≈øh colour of the lower lip, which is always chopt. It ≈øometimes ari≈øes from the very Nativity, which cau≈øes a dry and lean con≈øtitution of Body; ≈øometime through age, and then Women cea≈øe to bring Children; ≈øometimes from inflammations and ≈øuch like Di≈øea≈øes; ≈øometimes from a defect of blood, which ought to moi≈øten the parts; which happens either through a narrowne≈øs and ob≈øtruction of the Veins, or el≈øe becau≈øe it being voided out at the neck of the Womb, cannot pierce to the bottom.
The cure of this is performed fir≈øt by a contrary diet, where you mu≈øt al≈øo avoid much labour, watching, hunger, and ≈øadne≈øs. Secondly, by the u≈øe of moi≈øtning things, among≈øt which are mo≈øt commended, Borage, Buglo≈øs, Mercury, Mallows, Violets. Among outward means, Baths of ≈øweet water, and unctions with Oyl of ≈øweet Almonds, Oyl of white Lillies, Hens-grea≈øe, and the marrow of Calves legs. The cure is the more hard, if the drine≈øs have been of any long continuance.

There is another which is a compound di≈øtemper, which is mo≈øt often cold and moi≈øt, which is di≈øcerned by comparing the ≈øigns of the ≈øimple di≈øtemperatures together. div.head: Of the narrowne≈øs of the Ve≈ø≈øels of the Womb.
div.p: THE ≈øigns of the narrowne≈øs of the ve≈ø≈øels of the Womb, are partly the retention of the Flowers ≈øo that they cannot flow, as al≈øo the hindrance of conception, by rea≈øon that the pa≈ø≈øage of the blood is intercepted.
The cau≈øes are partly external, as from a≈øtringent baths and medicines, which is known from the relation of the party affected; it is cured more ea≈øily by moi≈øtning and mollifying Medicines.

The other cau≈øes are internal, as from Fle≈øh, or Membrane, clinging to the orifice of the Womb, or by a clo≈øing up of the orifices of the veins, by rea≈øon of ≈øome violent extraction of the Secondines, which is commonly incurable; the only cure which may be tryed is by mollifying applications. Another cau≈øe is deduced from ob≈øtruction, which ari≈øes from certain thick vi≈øcous and copious humours flowing from other parts of the Body, the heat of tho≈øe places not being able to attenuate them; or el≈øe gather together in the Womb it ≈øelf, by rea≈øon of the weakne≈øs of the heat of that part; it is di≈øcerned by the ≈øame ≈øigns as the cold Di≈øtemper, there being al≈øo a ≈ølimy matter which now and then comes down from the Womb: It is cured as other ob≈øtructions, by ≈øharp and bitter Medicines, and ≈øteel-wine, as al≈øo baths made with opening and mollifying things.

Sometime ‚Ä¢ this narrowne≈øs ari≈øes from a compre≈ø≈øion of the parts, occa≈øioned either by ≈øome ≈øwelling or Schirrus, either within or without the Womb; if this be, there do appear manife≈øt ≈øigns of ≈øwelling: It is an evil for the mo≈øt part incurable; many times it is occa≈øioned by an over-fatne≈øs of tho≈øe parts, which is plain to the ≈øen≈øe.

div.head: Of the puffing up of the Womb.
div.p:
THE puffing up of the Womb is a windy ≈øwelling of that part, occa≈øioned from cold, flegmy and flatulent matter, which is increa≈øed through the defect of natural heat in the Womb. This is called the windy Mole, it giving hopes of a conception. The ≈øigns of this, are a di≈øtention of the Womb not far from the Midriff, which is now increa≈øed, now dimini≈øhed; ≈øometimes extending it ≈øelf to the Navel, ≈øometimes to the Loins and Diaphragm. It differs
from the Drop≈øie, partly becau≈øe the ≈øwelling is not ≈øo great, and the party affected is not much troubled with thir≈øt, by the increa≈øing and dimini≈øhing of the tumor; and by the upper part not being ≈øo lean.

It is di≈øtingui≈øh'd from the Drop≈øie of the Womb by the fore apprehen≈øion of the cau≈øes that beget tho≈øe windy vapors, by the ≈øound, and le≈øs pondero≈øity, as as al≈øo by a feeling of an exten≈øive and pricking pain in the womb, and parts adjoyning. It is al≈øo di≈øtingui≈øhed from the inflammation of the inte≈øtines, becau≈øe here is no great pain, neither is the Patient hard bound; yet the Flowers are ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, and the feet and hollow of the eyes do ≈øwell, and the colour of the body is changed, the woman draws her breath ≈øhort and is ≈øad, and when ≈øhe awakes is fain to lift up her head to take breath. It differs from a Mole, becau≈øe there is not that heavine≈øs and pondero≈øity in the womb; be≈øides the woman doth not feel the burden of her womb tumble from one ≈øide to the other: It is di≈øtingui≈øhed from conception by the ≈øound, and by the increa≈øing and decrea≈øing of the ≈øwelling, and by the deadne≈øs of the motion, not unlike that of a dead Infant: for if the Midriff be violently compre≈ø≈øed, the wind being then compelled to the part adjoyning, there is a kind of palpitating motion perceived through all the Midriff.

The matter of this di≈øtemper is generated either in the Womb it ≈øelf, or by rea≈øon of the ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion of the Cour≈øes, or by the interception of due purgation after delivery. Many times it comes through the veins and ≈øeminal ve≈ø≈øels. Now the weakne≈øs of the heat proceeds ≈øometimes from the external air, ≈øometimes from hard Delivery, from the ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion of the Cour≈øes, from abortion, &c. The Cure is performed after the ≈øame way that other Cures are managed: among tho≈øe
things that purge, Species Hierae, and Diaphaenicon, with Ca≈øtor, are mo≈øt commended; for Fumes, Nutmeg is counted the be≈øt; for Potions, Nutmegs brui≈øed and boyled with the roots of Mather, and drunk in ≈øix ounces of wine, and two drams of Sugar. Sometimes this wind gets into the cavity of the Womb, and then the neck and orifice of the Womb is clo≈øed, ≈øo that nothing can go forth, when the woman is moved, or when the Midriff is pre≈ø≈øed down with her hand, and then a kind of noi≈øe and ≈øound is perceived. Sometimes the wind gets into the tunicles of the Womb, and then the mouth of the Womb may be open: by rea≈øon of the ≈øhutting up of the windy vapours in a narrow place, there goes a noi≈øe forth, and the pain grows greater, and extends farther. This is more hard and difficult to be cured than that which is in the concavity of the Womb.

div.head: Of the inflammation of the Womb.
div.p: THE inflammation of the Womb is a ≈øwelling of the ≈øame through the putrefaction of blood which is fallen down into its ≈øub≈øtance, having many ≈øymptoms, and now tending to a Scirrhus, now towards an Apo≈øtem.

The ≈øigns are various; there is a ≈øwelling in the Womb with heat and pain, and a retraction of the Womb to the more inward parts; the neck of the Womb appears red, with little veins ≈øcattered up and down in it, like the web of a Spider. There is ≈øometimes a difficulty of breathing, with ≈øome kind of Pleuri≈øie, becau≈øe the interior tunicle of the Womb being extended, which ri≈øes from, and is joyned to the Peritonaeum; th ‚Ä¢ parts al≈øo to which that coheres, are ≈øtretched.

The excrements of the belly and bladder are detained by rea≈øon of the heat and drine≈øs of the belly, and the compre≈ø≈øion of the pa≈ø≈øages. Sometimes the whole body of the belly ≈øeems empty, or filled with water, and the Navel hangs forward, and the mouth of the womb is made very ≈ølender and clo≈øe; and upon a ≈øudden few depraved cour≈øes come down: then happens a burning Fever by rea≈øon of the great ≈øympathy with the womb and the heart, occa≈øioned through the Arteries and great Ve≈ø≈øels. There is a pain in the brea≈øts, with a ≈øwelling in them, by rea≈øon of the con≈øent and agreement between the groyns, the hips, the ≈øeptum tran≈øver≈øum claviculare, and the forepart of the head, which is extended to the roots of the eyes; as al≈øo from vapours which ri≈øe from the putrified blood to the head, through the Arteries that run along through the neck, pa≈ø≈øing by both parts of the infundibulum into the fore part of the head.
The cau≈øe of this con≈øi≈øts in the blood, which is ≈øometimes with Choler, and ≈øometimes with Melancholy.

The Cure is difficult, if the blood in that part be wholly putrified; for that cau≈øeth a ≈øordid humor which con≈øumes the Patient with a continual Fever. If it be an Eri≈øypelas, or St. Anthonies fire, there is no cure at all, becau≈øe the Birth dies by rea≈øon of the exce≈ø≈øive heat which cau≈øes abortion to follow, which kills the Woman; if it turn to a gangrene, it is deadly: it is cured as other inflammations, which may be ob≈øerved in the following Chapters. Only ob≈øerve that for revul≈øion you mu≈øt not let blood in the veins of the thighs, for that draws down the blood to the womb; but in the arm, the blood flowing from the Liver, and the parts adjoyning. For deriving of the matter, you may cut a vein in the ham, unle≈øs the Woman be with
Child, for that will cau≈øe abortion: Refrigerating and moi≈øtning Topicks, without any binding faculty, may be well applied; to which purpo≈øe the decoction of wild Thyme, prepared with Chalybeat water, and outwardly applied with a ≈øponge, is an excellent Remedy.

The≈øe inflammations ≈øometimes affect the whole womb, and ≈øometimes either ≈øide of the Womb, which cau≈øes the heat to de≈øcend into the Hip, becau≈øe of the ligaments of the Womb which are carred thither; the thigh is difficultly moved, and the groins are inflamed; ≈øometimes the inflammation po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth the po≈øterior part, which cau≈øes the belly to be bound, and a pain in the loins and back-bone; ≈øometimes it po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth the forepart, which becau≈øe it coheres to the bladder, the Urine is ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, or made very difficultly; and the pain is extended above the Privities: Semetimes it po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øes the bottom of the Womb, which cau≈øes ≈øuch a pain in the lower part of the Belly, that it is hardly to be touched, and the pain extends to the Navel.

There is another inflammation which degenerates into a Scirrhus, whereall the ≈øymptoms are not ≈øo dangerous, yet there is a great heavine≈øs perceived in the parts adjoyning. This evil is diuturnal, and commonly ends in the Drop≈øie; ≈øometimes it turns to an Apo≈øtem, ≈øwelling 'till it break: In this ca≈øe, the body is troubled with a ≈øhivering, e≈øpecially towards the Evening; when the Apo≈øtem is broken, ≈øometimes it empties it ≈øelf into the concavity of the Womb, wherein there is le≈øs danger; and ≈øometimes in other parts of the Body; which cau≈øes ≈øometimes a ≈øtoppage in the Urine, and ≈øometimes in the Belly, with a ≈øwelling of the hairy parts, and the feeling of ≈øomething floating up and down.

div.head: Of the Schirrus of the Womb.
div.p: THE Schirrus of the Womb is a hard ≈øwelling of the ≈øaid part without pain, begot by ≈øome thick earthly and feculent Humour; the ≈øigns, be≈øides others that are general, are the≈øe in particular: The Flowers at the beginning are either wholly ≈øtopt, or flow very ≈øparingly, the evil increa≈øing, there is a great flux of blood by intervals, the mouths of the Veins being opened more than ordinary, or becau≈øe the Womb is not able to receive, or to retain its wonted proportion of blood: It is di≈øtingui≈øh'd from the Mole, becau≈øe in that di≈øtemper the Flowers, if they flow, flow inordinately; the Brea≈øts ≈øwell with Milk, which in the Schirrus grow very lank.

The cau≈øe of this is a gro≈øs feculent humour, being a thick blood, ≈øometimes Flegmy, ≈øometimes melancholy, which happens to tho≈øe who decline in their age; or to tho≈øe who have been troubled with a ≈øqueami≈øh and naughty ≈øtomach: Often it ari≈øes from an ill cured Inflammation, through the u≈øe of Medicines that cool too much.

The Cure is difficult, either becau≈øe having been dried for a long time they cannot be ≈øoftned, or becau≈øe the natural heat in tho≈øe places where the Schirrus is, is for the mo≈øt part extinct; and then becau≈øe while the humour is mollifying, if it have conceived any putrefaction, it ea≈øily turns to the Cancer: For the cure, it is the ≈øame as of the Brea≈øts.

It differs either as being in, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing the ≈øub≈øtance of the Womb, which cau≈øes the Womb to lean downward upon the Hip, and Back, and there begets pain; ≈øometimes po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing the neck of the Womb, which is di≈øcerned by touching it, and is cured more ea≈øily than the former: If it be in the upper part of the

div.head: Of the Drop≈øie of the Womb.
div.p: THE Drop≈øie of the Womb is a di≈øtemper from water collected in the Womb, either by ≈øome fault in the part it ≈øelf, or in the parts adjoining. The ≈øigns of this are a loo≈øe ≈øwelling at the bottom of the belly, extending it ≈øelf according to the proportion of the Womb; the fewne≈øs and naughtine≈øs of the Cour≈øes; a moi≈øtne≈øs, and ≈ølenderne≈øs of the neck of the Womb, ≈øoftne≈øs of the Brea≈øt, want of Milk, a ≈øhivering in the Body, and ≈øometimes a Fever: It differs from an inflammation by the ≈øymptoms above related; and from an inflation, in the defect of ≈øound and di≈øtention; from a Mole, becau≈øe in this there is a greater weight perceived at the bottom of the belly, and the Brea≈øts at the time of delivery are not without milk. It differs from Conception, becau≈øe in the Drop≈øie the ≈øwelling is ju≈øt according to the form of the Womb; but in Conception it is always ≈øharper. In Women with Child the Flowers do not flow; but in this Di≈øea≈øe there flows ≈øuch a certain bloody vitious humour, without any order, which cea≈øes quickly. The cau≈øe of this is a water gathered there through ≈øome defect of the Liver or Spleen, or through ≈øome weakne≈øs in the Womb; by rea≈øon whereof it is not able to concoct or expel the Excrements; or through a too immoderate defluxion of the Cour≈øes, which oppre≈ø≈øeth the natural heat; or through a ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion of them, which ≈øuffocates the heat.

The cure is to be performed by the eduction of the water, and ≈øtrengthening of the Womb; for which purpo≈øe the u≈øe of Antimonial Pills is not a little to be commended. Her diet mu≈øt be of meats that breed good Juice; ≈øhe mu≈øt drink little, ≈øhe mu≈øt u≈øe in≈øtead of drink, a Pti≈øan or Barly-broth, made with Sa≈ø≈øafras, or Sar≈øaparilla, if her Cour≈øes be ≈øtopt, you may let her blood in the foot; if the repletion be great, then to let her blood in the arm will not be ami≈øs. The u≈øe of Cly≈øters is not ami≈øs, and Fomentations are al≈øo very nece≈ø≈øary, made with the decoction of Broom, wild Cucumbers, Flowers of Camomile, Melilot, with Origan, Cumin, Fenel, Ani≈øeed, of which you may make ≈øeveral injections. Ointments al≈øo may be u≈øeful, made of Oil of Lillies, or Oil of Dill: Then may you apply upon the Belly this Plai≈øter: Take of the emplai≈øter of Laurel berries two Ounces; Oil of Camomile and Melilot, two ounces and a half; Pigeons dung and Goats dung, of each half an ounce; mix them altogether, and make a Plai≈øter, adding thereto a little Venice Turpentine.

div.head: Of the falling of the Womb.
div.p: THE falling of the Womb is the falling of it down below the Abdomen or Midriff, proceeding from a loo≈øene≈øs of the Ligamants.

The general ≈øigns of this, are a pain in the loins, and hairy parts, and of the Os ≈øacrum, or holy Bone, to which the Womb is fa≈øtned; at the beginning the pain is not very great, nor after long continuance, by rea≈øon of u≈øe: The weight thereof being only trouble≈øome, which is an impediment to the Patient in going‚ñ™ The particular ≈øigns do vary according as the fall is greater or le≈øs; for in the one the Womb de≈øcends to the middle of the Hips and lower; in the latter there
is perceived the di≈øtention of the skin, and as it were the weight of a good big Egg about the Privities.

The Cure of this is difficult, if there be the greater falling of the Womb, if the Woman be in Age, if a Fever, Convul≈øion, or other ≈øymptoms happen; if that be in women with Child, it is deadly; and ≈øometimes it is corrupted by the ambient Air, and turns into a Gangrene. The Cure con≈øi≈øts in the re-putting of it into its own place, where you mu≈øt ob≈øerve, fir≈øt to ≈øtop the inflammation, if there be any; or if there be any ≈øwelling cau≈øed by the cold Air, you mu≈øt foment the part fir≈øt with decoction of Mallows, Mar≈øh-mallows, Flowers of Camomile, and Lawrel Berries: If there be any wind or excrement in the Gut, you mu≈øt u≈øe Cly≈øters fir≈øt; it is al≈øo to be fomented and anointed with agglutinating and a≈øtringent, or binding Medicines, there is a Fumigation to be made of the skin of a ≈øalt Eel dried, and poudered. When it is to be put into its place, the woman mu≈øt be laid with her Belly upwards; then mu≈øt the Midwife, or other Party employed, with a linnen Cloth dipt in Oyl of Ro≈øes, a little warmed, gently thru≈øt up the part affected which is fallen, as gently as may be, turning a little. Now to keep it up, the woman mu≈øt be kept lying on her back, with her thighs ≈øtretched out, and one laid upon another acro≈øs; the Belly mu≈øt not be too much bound, le≈øt in the ejection of the excrement, the Womb ≈øhould be again precipitated, neither mu≈øt it be loo≈øe, le≈øt the Membranes binding the Womb ≈øhould be unloo≈øed: Then mu≈øt you u≈øe agglutinating Medicines, Pe≈ø≈øaries, Fomentations, and Injections; yet great care mu≈øt be had, le≈øt you ≈øuppre≈øs the Cour≈øes. Of this there be ≈øome differences, either by rea≈øon of the loo≈øene≈øs of the Ligaments which are four, which is di≈øcerned in that it is generated by degrees, and with le≈øs pain: It ari≈øes

div.head: Of the a≈øcent of the Matrix, as al≈øo of the Wounds and Ulcers of the ≈øame.
div.p: SOme have thought that it is po≈ø≈øible for the Womb to a≈øcend up to the Stomach, which opinion is altogether fal≈øe; for fir≈øt it is tyed ≈øo fa≈øt with four Ligaments, that it is impo≈ø≈øible for it to move to the upper parts: Be≈øides, ≈øuppo≈øe it had a natural motion by the Fibres, yet the Womb being ≈øo firmly annexed to the right gut, and to the Privities, it would nece≈ø≈øarily follow that tho≈øe parts ≈øhould be al≈øo ≈øtretched. div.head: Of the pain of the Womb.
div.p:
THere is no need to give other ≈øigns of this than the complaint of the Woman; it affects both women that are free, and women that are with Child: It happens ≈øometimes from corroding humors, e≈øpecially cau≈øed by Ulcers, or vitious Flowers‚ñ™ The cure whereof is referred to the≈øe heads; ≈øometimes it happens from a di≈øtention cau≈øed either by ≈øome curdled blood ≈øticking in the cavity of the Womb, and then there is a copious Flux of blood out of the Womb, and the pain is fixed chiefly about the orifice of the Womb; the right Gut and the Bladder being affected by rea≈øon of the continual de≈øire of expelling forth the humor. It is cured by things that di≈øcu≈øs the wind; to which purpo≈øe it may not be ami≈øs to u≈øe a Cly≈øter made of Malm≈øey and Oyl of Nuts, of each three ounces, of Aqua vitae one ounce, of Oyl of Juniper and di≈øtilled Rue of each two drams, and applied warm; or a mixture of ≈øpirit of wine and ≈øpirit of Nitre, of each half a dram or two ≈øcruples, exhibited in the ≈øpirit of Wine, Sperma ceti, with Oyl of ≈øweet Almonds, or a Plai≈øter of Caranna and Tachamahacca applied to the Navel. Sometimes it is occa≈øioned by the retention and corruption of the ≈øeed. For the Cure, look the Chapter of the ≈øuffocation of the Matrix.

div.head: Of the Suppre≈ø≈øion of the Flowers.
div.p: THE ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion of the Flowers is the retention of the men≈øtrual blood, either by rea≈øon of the narrowne≈øs of the ve≈ø≈øels, or through ≈øome corruption of the blood. The ≈øigns are evident from the relation of the Woman: Yet if they are loth to confe≈øs, it may be di≈øcerned by this; for in Virgins the ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed blood wanders up and down the Veins, and begets ob≈øtructions, changing the colour of the Body, and cau≈øing Fevers. In Women, becau≈øe the blood is carried down to the Womb, where it begets many di≈øea≈øes, it is di≈øtingui≈øhed from retention after Conception, becau≈øe women with Child find no alteration of affections of the mind, and retain the native colour of their bodies; and in the third month they ≈øhall perceive the motion and ≈øituation of the Infant; and la≈øtly, the mouth of the womb is clo≈øed up.

The Cau≈øes of this di≈øtemper are the narrowne≈øs of the Veins, and the vitiou≈øne≈øs of the blood. The Cure of this mu≈øt be ha≈øtened, becau≈øe this ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion if it ≈øtay long begets many more di≈øea≈øes, as Fevers, Drop≈øies, Vomiting of blood, and the like: The Cure is hard if it be of any continuance, and if it ≈øtay beyond the ≈øixth month, it is almo≈øt incurable; e≈øpecially if it happen through any perver≈øion of the neck of the Womb; for then the woman is troubled with often ≈øwooning, and vomiting of blood, and a pain ≈øeizes the parts of the Belly, the Back, and the Backbone, which is attended with a Fever, and the excrements of the Belly and Bladder are ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed; a wearine≈øs po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øes the whole Body, becau≈øe of the diffu≈øion of the retained blood through the whole body, and e≈øpecially the hips and thighs, becau≈øe of the ≈øympathy of tho≈øe parts with the veins of the Womb. In the fir≈øt place, the letting of blood is commended; for the blood which every month ≈øtays in the body, and ≈øticks in the Veins, is to be provoked downward to the Womb; and therefore a vein is to be opened in the heel, for ≈øo the plenty of blood is dimini≈øhed, and the motion of the blood is made toward the Womb; if nece≈ø≈øity requires that it ≈øhould be done more than once, one day a vein mu≈øt be opened in one thigh, and another day in the other; and that which is opened for evacuation mu≈øt be fir≈øt opened, that which is opened in the ham, or heel, mu≈øt be done after Purgation, three, or four, or five days before the time that the accu≈øtomed evacuations of the Woman ought to come down. Cupping-gla≈ø≈øes al≈øo are to be applied fir≈øt to the more remote places, as to the thighs; and then to the nearer parts, as to the hips: Ligatures, or bindings and frictions, at the time of the coming down of the Flowers, after Purgation of the whole body, are
not to be omitted. In the ≈øecond place the matter is to be prepared, for which purpo≈øe, in bodies troubled with Flegm, the decoction of Guaiacum, with Cretan Dittany, doth much avail without provoking ≈øweat. In the third place evacuation is to be made at ≈øeveral times. Among evacuating Medicines are commended Agaric, Aloes, with the juice of Savin, and the≈øe Pills: Take Aloes Succotrine three drams; the be≈øt Myrrh one ≈øcruple, extract of ≈øweet ≈ømelling Flag, Carduus, Saffron, of each three drams; Roots of Gentian and Dittany, of each five grains; make them up with Syrup of Laurel-berries, taking the quantity of one ≈øcrup ‚Ä¢ e at evening before ≈øupper. In the fourth place, by opening ob≈øtructions by tho≈øe things which provoke the Flowers, of which the≈øe are mo≈øt to be commended, the decoction of Ro≈øemary with Flowers of Cheiri, Pennyroyal-water twice di≈øtilled, and mingled with Cinnamon-water; Extract of Zedoary, Angelica, and Ca≈øtor, and the Earth which is found in Iron Mines prepared in the ≈øame manner as Steel, ≈øpirit of Tartar, the fat of an Eel, Colubrina with the di≈øtill'd water of Savin: And in the fifth place, by the di≈øcu≈ø≈øion of the dregs and relicks that remain, by ≈øudoroficks, or things that provoke ≈øweat, with a potion made of a Chalybeate decoction, with ≈øpirit of Tartar, &c.

The differences of this Di≈øea≈øe ari≈øe, partly from the ob≈øtruction of the Veins of the Womb, cau≈øed by a cold and thick blood, and thick ≈ølimy humours mixed with the blood, and coming either from ≈øome hot di≈øtemper of the Womb, which di≈ø≈øipates the ≈øharp and ≈øubtil humours, and leaves behind the gro≈øs and earthy parts, or from the cold Con≈øtitution of the Liver and Spleen; e≈øpecially if at the time of the men≈øtrual Flux (at what time the Flux of Blood is more violent) tho≈øe ≈øubtil humours happen to be di≈ø≈øipated, and then at the
time of the monthly Purgation, the Party affected feels a great pain in the loins, and parts adjoining; and if any thing come down, it is ≈ølymy, whiti≈øh, and blacki≈øh: The whole Body is po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed with a numne≈øs, the Colour pale, a ≈ølow Pul≈øe, and raw Urines. The Cure is the ≈øame with the former, great care being taken of a gro≈øs and ill diet.

There is another difference of this Di≈øea≈øe when it happens by Compre≈ø≈øion, which ari≈øes from external cau≈øes, as the Northern wind, and long ≈øtanding in cold water, which may be known from the relation of the ≈øick Per≈øon. The Blood in this ca≈øe is to be drawn to the lower parts by Frictions and Baths; or from internal cau≈øes, as fatne≈øs, or ≈øwelling of the Womb, or of the lower parts; in which ca≈øe Medicines mu≈øt be applied that a≈ø≈øwage the ≈øwelling. There is another difference which is in the hardne≈øs of the skin which happens either from the fir≈øt Nativity, and then the di≈øea≈øe is not ea≈øily taken away; or long after, from ≈øome cold and dry di≈øtemper: Concerning which look the former Chapters.

Another difference there is, when there happens a clo≈øing up of the skin, which is cau≈øed after Cicatri≈øing of an Ulcer, or by rea≈øon of ≈øome skin or Membrane growing to the Ve≈ø≈øels of the Womb, or by rea≈øon of frequent Abortion; after which the≈øe Veins to which the Secondines adhere, do grow together ≈øo clo≈øe that they cannot be afterwards opened.

Another difference of this Di≈øea≈øe there is, when it happens through want of Blood, which is not generated, either by rea≈øon of external cau≈øes, as Famine, over much evacuation, I≈ø≈øues, and ≈øuch like; or through internal cau≈øes, as a frigid Con≈øtitution of the principal parts, old Age, and Fevers; or when it is converted to other u≈øes, as before full growth, to the nouri≈øhment of
the Body: In Women with Child, to the nouri≈øhment of the Birth: In tho≈øe that give ≈øuck, to the increa≈øe of Milk: And in fat people, to the augmentation of the Fat: Or when it is con≈øumed either by External cau≈øes, as over much Exerci≈øe, Affrights, Terrors, Sadne≈øs, Baths, overmuch Sweating, which do con≈øume the ≈øerous quality of the Blood; or through Internal Cau≈øes, as are hot and dry Di≈øea≈øes, or over-great evacuations in other parts of the Body. Sometimes another difference of this Di≈øea≈øe proceeds from the dryne≈øs of the Blood, which happens to Women, who in the Winter time do too much heat their lower parts, by putting Coals under their Coats. For the cure thereof you mu≈øt u≈øe refrigerating and moi≈øtning Medicines.

div.head: Of the dropping of the Flowers, and the difficulty of their coming down.
div.p: THE dropping of the Flowers is, when they are coming down for many days together drop by drop.
This happens both from external cau≈øes, as over hard labour, &c.

And ≈øometimes from the dro≈ø≈øine≈øs of the blood, the pa≈ø≈øage not being wide enough. For the cure of this, it is convenient to open a Vein in the Arm with gentle purging, as in the former Chapter.

Sometimes from the weakne≈øs of the retentive faculty, there being at that time great plenty, thinne≈øs, and ≈øero≈øity of the blood. In this ca≈øe there is no pain; Medicines that bind and corroborate the Stomach here mu≈øt have place.

The difficulty of the Flowers is when they come down with pain and trouble, either through defect in the Veins, or in the Blood. The ≈øigns of this are gathered from the relation of the ≈øick per≈øon, who is then much troubled with pain in the Head, Stomach, and Loins, and lower parts of the body. And they do either
flow altogether, or drop by drop, as in the former di≈øea≈øe; It is a Di≈øea≈øe more incident to Maids than married Women, becau≈øe the Veins of the Womb are le≈øs open in them, than in tho≈øe who brought forth Children.

It happens ≈øometimes from a corruption of the blood, that is, from the dro≈ø≈øine≈øs and thickne≈øs thereof, and then the blood clots together; and there is a great pain long before the Flowers begin to come down. The Cure of this is performed by attenuating Medicines. Sometimes from the ≈øharpne≈øs and acrimony of the Blood, which proceeds from a mixture of ≈øharp humours with the Body, and then the genital parts do itch. It is cured by tho≈øe Medicines that temper the ≈øharpne≈øs of the Humour, as the four greater Seeds, Violets, and Flowers of Nenuphar. Sometimes from windy Vapours, and then the pain comes by intervals, and is ≈øuddenly exa≈øperated, rumbling up and down; and when the wind is forth, the pain cea≈øeth. The cure hereof is procured by evacuation of the matter, and di≈øpelling of the wind, as is before declared.

div.head: Of the di≈øcolouring of the Flowers.
div.p: THE di≈øcolouring of the Flowers is when their right colour, which ought to be red, declines either to palene≈øs, whitene≈øs, greenne≈øs, yellowne≈øs, or blewi≈øhne≈øs, through ≈øome defect, or vitiou≈øne≈øs of the blood.

The ≈øigns are apparent by the ≈øight of the blood; be≈øides that it is accompanied with an ill ≈ømell, many times al≈øo it is the cau≈øe of Fevers, trembling of the body, loathing of the meat, pain in the ≈øtomach, &c.

The differences of this di≈øea≈øe con≈øi≈øt fir≈øt in the vitiou≈øne≈øs of the blood, which is cau≈øed through ≈øome di≈øtemper either of the whole body, or ≈øome part thereof. Sometimes the blood is affected by rea≈øon of ≈øome ≈øtoppage thereof, and then the Flowers are ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed,
which cau≈øeth pains in the Brea≈øt, and ≈øtrong beating of the Brea≈øt; and if the woman begin to amend the Blood flows out with a ≈øtinking putrefaction, which continues 'till the eighth day; or it may be, becau≈øe the Blood is foul'd by the Womb, being full of excrements; and then you may perceive the ≈øigns of a foul Womb.

Sometimes the difference of this di≈øea≈øe con≈øi≈øts in the mixture of the Blood with other vitious humors. The Cure con≈øi≈øts in preparation and evacuation, but care mu≈øt be had, that becau≈øe the thick humors need attenuation, and that over attenuating things do melt the ≈øerous humor, that you therefore do not u≈øe over attenuating things, as Vinegar, &c.

Another difference is, when the Flowers decline to a whiti≈øh colour, which 'proceeds from abundance of Flegm, or from Putrefaction, and then Ulcers follow in the Womb, and barrenne≈øs follows; unle≈øs the womans Flowers do happen to flow for ≈øeven or eight days together, by which the woman is freed from the di≈øea≈øe; or el≈øe they break out to the parts above the groin without any tumor, and bur≈øt forth a little above the Hypochondrium, and then the woman ≈øeldom lives, or el≈øe there will appear after ≈øome few days a great ≈øwelling in the Groyn, without a head of a red colour, becau≈øe the Fle≈øh is there filled up with the Blood.
When it inclines to yellowne≈øs, or greenne≈øs, the di≈øtemper comes of Choler; when to a blackne≈øs and blewne≈øs, from Melancholy.

div.head: Of the inordinate Flux of the Flowers.
div.p:
THE di≈øorderly Flux of the Cour≈øes is either the coming of them down before their time, or el≈øe the ≈øtoppage of them for ≈øome time after the u≈øual
cour≈øe of Nature. They come down ≈øometimes before their time, partly by rea≈øon of internal Cau≈øes, and partly by rea≈øon of external Cau≈øes, as falls, blows, and ≈øuch like ca≈øualties that open the veins: Or from the expul≈øive faculty of the Womb too much provoked. Fir≈øt, by the plenty of blood, which is known by this, that the blood which is ≈øent to the womb from all part is fluid, and of its natural con≈øtitution; ≈øigns of a Plethora, or fulne≈øs of blood, are apparent in the Woman. It is Cured by blood letting if the blood abound by good diet, and frequent though gentle exerci≈øe. Secondly, it proceeds from the Acrimony and ≈øharpne≈øs of the blood which is known by the hot temper of the body, the blood it ≈øelf is more thin and yellowi≈øh. It mu≈øt be Cured by evacuating Medicines, as Rheubarb, and ≈øuch things as temper the blood, whereof we have already ≈øpoken.

It comes al≈øo when the retentive faculty of the womb grows lank, which may be known by the loo≈øene≈øs of the Ve≈ø≈øels of the Womb, be≈øides a moi≈øt and faint habit of the body: In the Cure, beware of things which are too A≈øtringent; baths, wherein the force and ≈øtrength of Iron may be effectual, may with ≈øafety be u≈øed. The ≈øub≈øi≈øtence and ≈øtay of the Cour≈øes beyond the accu≈øtomed time, proceeds from a fru≈øtration of the expul≈øive faculty; as when there is ≈ømall ≈øtore of blood, which is known by this, that the Woman is not troubled with the ≈øtay of the Cour≈øes; and e≈øpecially, if ≈øhe have over-exerci≈øed her ≈øelf, or u≈øed a ≈øpare diet before. Secondly, the thickne≈øs of the blood, which is known by the whitene≈øs and clammine≈øs thereof. In the performance of the Cure, you mu≈øt purge before too much blood be gathered together: Next, the Cour≈øes are to be attenuated, for the performance of which, Calamint and Mercurialis are to
be mo≈øt commended. In this Ca≈øe ≈øcarification of the heels is not ami≈øs.

There is another difference of this Di≈øea≈øe, which ari≈øes from the weakne≈øs of the expelling faculty, cau≈øed either by the frigid di≈øtemper of the Womb, of which we have ≈øpoken already; or by a kind of numne≈øs thereof, of which we ≈øhall ≈øpeak anon.

div.head: Of the over abundance of the Cour≈øes.
div.p: THE over much flux of the Cour≈øes is either a more abundant, or a more la≈øting Purgation of the Cour≈øes, through ≈øome defect, either in the blood, or the womb, or the veins of the womb.

The ≈øigns are evident, viz. want of Appetite, Crudities, a bad colour in the face, a ≈øwelling in the feet, and the re≈øt of the body, a waxing lean of the body; and in brief, a general ill habit of body.

The Cure (if it be of any continuance) is difficult; if it happen to an aged woman, there is none at all. It requires a revul≈øion, or drawing back of the blood, interception, and incra≈ø≈øation, or thickning thereof, and a clo≈øing up of the Ve≈ø≈øels by a≈øtringent Medicines. Yet ob≈øerve that they mu≈øt be ≈øtopt by degrees. To this effect, you may take this Powder.

Take of the ≈øeed of White Henbane, red Coral, of each half a dram, white Camphor half a ≈øcruple, and give the quantity of half a dram at a time; powder of Amber, Dragons-blood, Blood≈øtones, Red Coral, Lettice ≈øeed, of each one dram, Balau≈øt two ≈øcruples, Bole armoniack two drams, given in three ounces of Plantain-water, A≈ø≈øes milk heated with Steel. You may externally al≈øo apply a girdle made of the brui≈øed leaves of Baresfoot.

Of this Di≈øea≈øe there are many differences: Sometimes it happens from the blood which is derived from the bottom of the Womb, where for the mo≈øt part lies
the blacke≈øt and mo≈øt clotted blood; or from the neck of the Womb, which is more red and fluid. Another difference ari≈øeth from the plenty of blood, which appears by this, that the Ve≈ø≈øels are either broken or much opened, e≈øpecially in tho≈øe women who have had a ≈øtoppage in their Cour≈øes for a time, which pre≈øently break out again. The ≈øigns of this are evident; that is to ≈øay, a fulne≈øs of blood in the body; be≈øides that, the blood which comes forth ea≈øily curdles.

In the Cure, you mu≈øt have recour≈øe to blood-letting, which if you do for evacuation, it mu≈øt be done in the Hepatick Vein: If the woman be weak, in Salvatella of both hands. In the next place the u≈øe of Cupping-Gla≈ø≈øes is to be commended, being applied with ≈øcarification to the back, &c. Or, without ≈øcarification to the Brea≈øt, being u≈øed again when the woman is troubled with difficulty of breathing. In the third place, ligatures and frictions of the Arms are to be u≈øed.

Another difference of this di≈øea≈øe ari≈øes from a ≈øharp blood, which is known by the gnawing of the humor upon the Ve≈ø≈øels. In the Cure, you mu≈øt purge with ≈øyrup of Ro≈øes ≈øolutive, or with leaves of Sena; a pe≈ø≈øary of Sows dung and A≈ø≈øes dung, which is made up with Plantain water, and the mu≈øcilage of the ≈øeed of Quinces, is here of u≈øe if need require.

Another difference ari≈øes from a ≈øerous and watry blood; for either the Liver is weakned, or the Veins ≈øo debilitated, that it cannot attract the ≈øerous or wheyie humour in the blood: in this ca≈øe, the blood flows not forth in ≈øuch a quantity, nor is ea≈øily curdled: If a Cloth be dipped in it, and then dried in the ≈øhade, it pre≈øently di≈øcolours. In the Cure hereof you mu≈øt look to the rectifying of the weakne≈øs of the
Reins and Liver with convenient remedies, for which purpo≈øe the Livers of Foxes, Calves, Hens, &c. are very good.

Sometimes from a Rupture of the Veins, which proceeds either from a fulne≈øs of blood, or from Cau≈øes that do vehemently ≈øtir up the blood, e≈øpecially from hard labour; if it be needful, you mu≈øt let blood, and apply conglutinating Medicines.

Or from a gnawing of the Ve≈ø≈øels, which is known by this, that ≈øometimes there flows forth little blood, and that purulent, and full of the wheyie or ≈øerous humor. It ari≈øes from a ≈øharp and corrupt blood, and ≈øometimes from the u≈øe of ≈øharp Medicines. Among the a≈øtringent Medicines, the root of Filipendula is much to be commended, or a decoction of the ≈øame Root.

div.head: Of the Whites and Gonorrhea in Women.
div.p: THE Whites is an inordinate eruption of an excrementitious humour collected together through ≈øome vitiou≈øne≈øs of the blood. It affects Women chiefly, and ≈øometimes al≈øo Virgins, of which there are Examples: Yet it is more often in women, e≈øpecially if they be of a moi≈øt con≈øtitution, and live an idle and delicate life, eating ≈øuch things as are cold and moi≈øt. Old women al≈øo are affected herewith through the abundance of Flegm, and the weakne≈øs of the concoctive faculty.

It differs from the Gonorrhea, becau≈øe in that the ≈øeminal matter is white, and thicker; and flows by long intervals, and i≈ø≈øues forth in a le≈ø≈øer quantity from a nocturnal pollution; for that is joyned with venereal imaginations, and only happens in the time of ≈øleep. It differs from the di≈øcolouring of the Flowers; for they though not exactly, do always ob≈øerve their
times of Flowing. Be≈øides, they happen not to Women with Child, or ≈øuch who≈øe Cour≈øes are ≈øtopped. It differs from the putrid humour that i≈ø≈øues from the Ulcers of the Womb, becau≈øe that is joyned with the ≈øigns of an Ulcer, and the putrefaction is thicker and whiter; if it be mattery, it is coloured with blood, and i≈ø≈øues forth with pain.

The Cure of this mu≈øt be ha≈øtned, becau≈øe in a ≈øhort time it endangers the making of women barren, cau≈øing them to be lean, to fall into a Con≈øumption, Melancholy, the Drop≈øie, fall of the Womb, Swoonings, and Convul≈øions; which is the cau≈øe that though it be not hard to be cured in the beginning, yet it is afterwards very difficult; for by this means the whole body accu≈øtoms it ≈øelf to ≈øend forth its excrements this way, and the Womb being now weakned, gathers excrements apace.

Sometimes it proceeds from the whole body, and then you may perceive the ≈øigns of an ill humor through the whole body. In the Cure of this, you mu≈øt avoid blood-letting, for that the bad humor mu≈øt not be recalled to defile the blood; be≈øides, that the di≈øea≈øe is a ≈øufficient weakning and con≈øuming of the body. The humor is di≈øcu≈ø≈øed by the decoction of Guaiacum and China, and Lentisk-wood. For the drying up of the humor, the Root of Filipendula doth very much conduce. For a≈øtringent Medicines you may u≈øe chiefly the powder of dead men's bones, the a≈øhes of Capons-dung in rain water. The Patient mu≈øt avoid ≈øleeping upon her back, le≈øt the heat of the Lungs ≈øhould carry the humors toward the Womb: Frictions al≈øo of the upper parts, for the diver≈øion of the humor may be u≈øed.

Sometimes it is cau≈øed by the Womb it ≈øelf, and then there will appear ≈øigns of the affection of the
Womb, and the Flux is not ≈øo great. For the Cure of this, Suffumigations of Frankincen≈øe, Labdanum, Ma≈øtick, and Sanders are very requi≈øite.

div.head: Of the Green-Sickne≈øs.
div.p: THE Green-Sickne≈øs is a changing of the colour of the Face into a green and pale colour, proceeding from the rawne≈øs of the humors. The ≈øigns of this appear in the Face, to which may be added a great pain in the Head, difficulty of breathing, with a palpitation of the heart, a ≈ømall and thick beating of the Arteries in the Neck, Back, and Temples; ≈øometimes inordinate Fevers through the vitiou≈øne≈øs of the humors, loathing of Meat, Vomiting, di≈øtention of the Hypocondriack part, by rea≈øon of the reflux of the men≈øtrous blood to the greater Ve≈ø≈øels; a ≈øwelling of the whole body by rea≈øon of the abundance of humors, or of the Thighs and Legs above the heels, by rea≈øon of the abundance of ≈øerous humors.

The Cau≈øe is the crudity and rawne≈øs of the humor, and quantity withal, ari≈øing from the ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion of the Cour≈øes through the natural narrowne≈øs of the ve≈ø≈øels, or through an acquired narrowne≈øs of the ve≈ø≈øels by the eating of Oatmeal, Chalk, Earth, Nutmegs, and drinking of Vinegar; or from the ob≈øtruction of the other bowels. Hence ari≈øes an ill concoction in the bowels, and the humors are carried into the habit of the body, or become habitual thereunto.

The Cure is performed by the letting of blood, e≈øpecially in the heel; if the Di≈øea≈øe be of any continuance, by Purgation, preparation of the humour being fir≈øt con≈øidered; which is performed by the decoction of Guaiacum, with ‚Ä¢ retan Dittany; purging of the humor is performed with Agarick, Aloes Succotrin, with the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ice of Savin; for the unob≈øtructing of the
humor, prepared Steel, the root of Scorzonera, Bezoar≈øtone, in diet, Vinegar is utterly to be avoided.

The Cure of this Di≈øea≈øe is performed by opening Ob≈øtructions, by purging off vitious Humours, by correcting the intemperies of the Bowels, and by ≈øtrengthening them. Fir≈øt therefore, a gentle purging Medicine mu≈øt be given, that is agreeable to the Con≈øtitution, that the fir≈øt region may be emptied, and if the Belly be bound, a Gli≈øter mu≈øt be given fir≈øt of all, afterwards bleeding mu≈øt be ordered, unle≈øs the Di≈øea≈øe is very inveterate, and the Maid be inclined to a Cachexy. But a Vein in the Arm mu≈øt be opened, tho' the Cour≈øes are ≈øtopt; for at that time, if you bleed in the Foot, the ob≈øtructions of the Veins, and of the Womb would be increa≈øed. That quantity of Blood being taken away, that is nece≈ø≈øary, proper purges mu≈øt be u≈øed.

Take of the Pill Coch. major two ≈øcruples, of Ca≈øtor powdered two grains, of Peruvian Bal≈øom four drops, make four Pills, let her take them at five in the Morning, and ≈øleep after them if ≈øhe can. Let the≈øe Pills be repeated twice or thrice every Morning, or every other Morning, according to the ≈øtrength of the ≈øick, and their operation.
After the purging Pills let her take the following.

Take of the fileings of Steel eight grains, with a ≈øufficient quantity of extract of Wormwood, make two Pills to be taken in the Morning, and they mu≈øt be repeated at five in the Afternoon. She mu≈øt continue this Cour≈øe for a Month, drinking pre≈øently after the Pills a draught of Wormwood-wine.
If a Bolus be more plea≈øing,

Take of the con≈øerve of Roman Wormwood, and of the con≈øerve of the inner peell of Oranges, each one ounce; of candied Angelica, and Nutmegs candied,
and of Venice Treacle, each half an ounce, of Ginger candied two drams, with a ≈øufficient quantity of Syrup of Oranges make an Electuary, take of this Electuary one dram and an half, of the filings of Steel well powdered eight grains, with a ≈øufficient quantity of Syrup of Oranges, make a Bolus to be taken in the Morning, and at five in the Afternoon, drinking upon it a draught of Wormwood wine.

div.head: Of the ≈øuffocation of the Matrix.
div.p: THE ≈øigns of the Suffocation of the Womb, are a wearine≈øs of the whole body, with a weakne≈øs of the Thighs; a palene≈øs and ≈øadne≈øs of the Face; a nau≈øeou≈øne≈øs though ≈øeldom vomiting; oftentimes a loathing and di≈øtate of Meat, and that ≈øometimes with a grumbling and noi≈øe in the Belly, and ≈øometimes without.
