The ≈øigns of the pre≈øent Di≈øea≈øe are, that when the Vapours are carried up to the Heart, and do there ≈øtop the vital Spirits, a light ≈øwooning follows, the Pul≈øe changes and is little, the Body grows cold, all the ≈øpirits flying up into the Heart; the Vapour being thru≈øt up to the Head and Chaps, the Chaps are many times ≈øet fa≈øt, the Patient ≈øeeming to be ≈øtifled; the motion of the Brea≈øt and Diaphragm is di≈øturbed and hindred, ≈øo that the breath is almo≈øt ≈øtopt, the Patient living only by tran≈øpiration. Sometimes there is joined with it a kind of Uterine fury, with talking and anger: Sometimes it cau≈øes other madne≈øs; ≈øometimes the Woman falls into a dead ≈øleep, which makes her ≈øeem as though ≈øhe were dead.

It differs from the Epilep≈øie, becau≈øe in that the Convul≈øive motions are more general; nor is there any memory of tho≈øe things which happen about them after the Fit; the Pul≈øe is great, and the Mouth of the Party
affected fomes with a froth: It differs from the Apoplexy, becau≈øe in that the Fit comes ≈øuddenly without any notice; and the Patient is affected with a kind of ≈ønorting, and there is ≈øuch a Re≈øolution of the parts, that they feel not although they be pricked: It differs from a Syncope, in that there are no ≈øigns when the Fit will be, the Pul≈øe cea≈øes to the apprehen≈øion, and the Patient is troubled with cold ≈øweats. They differ from dead people by ≈øneezing, which may be provoked by putting ≈øomething for that purpo≈øe into the No≈øe.

The cau≈øe of this is a venemous, ≈øubtle, and thin Vapour, piercing in one moment through the whole body, and carried up from the matter in the Womb, corrupted after a peculiar manner, either by it ≈øelf or from external means, ≈øuch are perfumes, anger, fear, &c. and not only a≈øcending through the veins, but al≈øo through all the other breathing holes, and ≈øecret pa≈ø≈øages of the body.

The Cure is doubtful if it have po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed old Women for a time, for it begets weakne≈øs, con≈øumes the ≈øtrength, and ≈øhews abundance of humour; or if it po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth Child-bearing Women, either after a difficult Travel, or after an Abortion; or if it po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth Women with Child, becau≈øe it induces fear of Abortion; there is more hope, if the act of Re≈øpiration be not too much impeded, and if the Fits do not return too often.

The Cure regards fir≈øt the time of the Fit, being performed fir≈øt by means of interception, which may be done by binding the Belly under the Navel with a girdle made of the skin of a Hart, killed in the very act of Copulation. Secondly, by keeping the natural Spirits awaked and rouzed up by painful friction, by pulling the hairs of the Privities with violence and ≈øuffumigations made with Partridge feathers burnt, as al≈øo
Eel-skins, the application of A≈ø≈øa faetida and Oil of Tartar to the mouth. Thirdly, by way of revul≈øion of the humour, by Frictions and Gly≈øters di≈øpelling the winds, and the application of Cupping-gla≈ø≈øes with much flame, fir≈øt to the Thighs, and then to the Hips, putting ≈øweet things into the Privities; ≈øuch as are Oil of Sivet half a ≈øcruple, Oil of Nutmegs one ≈øcruple: Fourthly, by di≈øcu≈ø≈øion of the humour, which is performed inwardly by the Oil of white Amber, with the pouder of Walnut Flowers, extract of Ca≈øtor; externally by an Emplai≈øter of the fat of a black Heifer, Sclarea boiled in butter, adding to it a ≈øufficient quantity of Tachamahacca and Caranna: After the fit is pa≈øt, evacuation is to be regarded, fir≈øt with purgation, for which purpo≈øe it will not be ami≈øs to u≈øe the≈øe en≈øuing Pills: Take Siler mountain, Pennyroyal, Madder, the innermo≈øt part of Ca≈ø≈øia Pipe, Pomegranate Kernels, Piony roots, and Calamus, of each three drams; Mu≈øcus and Spike of India, of each half a dram; then make Pills thereof with the juice of Mugwort, of which ≈øhe may take every day, or every other day, before Supper. If the di≈øea≈øe proceed from the terms, let the Woman affected take an Ounce of Agarick poudered in Wine or honied water, or a dram of Agnus Ca≈øtus powder'd with an ounce of Honey of Ro≈øes: The Womb is al≈øo to be ≈øtrengthned by the internal and external application of ≈øuch things as re≈øi≈øt the malignity of the Di≈øea≈øe; among which are numbred, Faecula Brioniae, and Ca≈øtor: The difference of this Di≈øea≈øe con≈øi≈øts in this, that ≈øometimes it happens that it is occa≈øioned by the retention of the Seed, which is known by this, that the ≈øymptoms of the Di≈øea≈øe are more violent; and after the fit is pa≈øt, there flows out of the Womb a matter like to that of the ≈øeed. It is cur'd by evacuation of the ≈øeed, ≈øuch as are Rue, and Agnus Ca≈øtus,
and anointing with odoriferous ≈øalves, e≈øpecially if the woman be to live without the u≈øe of man.

If it come from the ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion of the terms, which is known by the Cour≈øes being mingled with a melancholy blood, take powdered Agaric, a dram of Pioney ≈øeeds, or the weight of a dram and a half of Triphera magna.

But take this for a ≈øecret, that for a married Woman in ca≈øe of the pre≈øent ≈øuffocation, there is nothing better than for the Man to anoint the top of his Yard with a little Oyl of Gilliflowers, and Oyl of ≈øweet Almonds together, and ≈øo to lye with her; for this a≈ø≈øuredly brings down the Matrix again.

This Di≈øea≈øe is very frequent, the Procatartick or external Cau≈øes of it, are either violent motions of the body, or, which is much oftner, vehement commotions of the Mind from ≈øome ≈øudden a≈ø≈øault, either of Anger or Grief, or the like Pa≈ø≈øions. Therefore as often as Women are troubled with this or that di≈øorder of Body, the rea≈øon whereof cannot be deduced from the common Axioms; for finding out Di≈øea≈øes, we mu≈øt diligently enquire whether they are not chiefly afflicted with that indi≈øpo≈øition which they complain of, when they have been di≈øturbed in their minds, and afflicted with grief; which if they confe≈øs, we may be fully ≈øatisfied that this di≈øorder proceeds from this Di≈øea≈øe we are now ≈øpeaking of; e≈øpecially if Urine as clear as Chry≈øtal evacuated copiou≈øly ≈øome certain times, makes the Diagno≈øtick more manife≈øt. But to the≈øe di≈øorders of the Mind, which are u≈øually the occa≈øions of this Di≈øea≈øe, is to be added emptine≈øs of the ≈øtomach, by rea≈øon of long fa≈øting, immoderate bleeding, and a Vomit or Purge that worked too much; and certainly this Di≈øea≈øe proceeds from a confu≈øion
of the Spirits, upon which account too many of them in a crowd, contrary to proportion, are hurried violently upon this or that part, occa≈øioning Convul≈øions and pain, when they ru≈øh upon parts indued with exqui≈øite ≈øen≈øe, perverting the functions of the Organs, both of that into which they thru≈øt them≈øelves, and al≈øo of that from whence they departed, both being much injured by this unequal di≈øtribution, which is quite contrary to the Oeconomy of Nature.

The Origen and Antecedent Cau≈øe of this confu≈øion, is a weak con≈øtitution of the Spirits, whether it is natural or adventitious; for which Rea≈øon they are ea≈øily di≈ø≈øipated upon any occa≈øion, and their Sy≈øtem ≈øoon broke: For as the outward Man is framed with parts obvious to ≈øen≈øe, ≈øo without doubt the inward Man con≈øi≈øts of a due Series, and as it were a Fabrick of the Spirits, to be viewed only by the eye of Rea≈øon; and as this is nearly joyned, and as it were united with the con≈øtitution of the Body, ≈øo much the more ea≈øily or more difficultly is its frame di≈øordered, by how much the Con≈øtitutive Principles that are allotted us by Nature, are more or le≈øs firm. That the ≈øaid Confu≈øion of the Spirits is the cau≈øe of Hy≈øteric Di≈øea≈øes, will appear by Mother-Fits, wherein the Spirits are crowded in the lower Belly, and ru≈øhing together violently towards the Jaws, occa≈øion Convul≈øions in every region thro' which they pa≈øs, blowing up the Belly like a great Ball, which is yet nothing but the rowling together or conglobation of the parts ≈øeized with the Convul≈øion, which cannot be ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed without great violence. The external parts in the the mean while, and the Fle≈øh being in a manner de≈øtitute of Spirits, by rea≈øon they are carried another way, are often ≈øo very cold, not only in this kind, but in all other kind of Hy≈øteric Di≈øea≈øes, that dead
Bodies are not colder, but the Pul≈øe are as good as tho≈øe of People that are well; nor is the Womans life in danger by this cold, unle≈øs it is occa≈øioned by ≈øome very large evacuation going before.

And the inordinate agitation of the Spirits di≈øturbing the blood, is the cau≈øe of the clear and copious Urine; for when the Oeconomy of the blood is interrupted, the Sick cannot long enough contain the ≈øerum that is imported, but lets it go, before it is impregnated with ≈øaline particles, whereby the Citron colour is to be imparted to it, whereof we have daily experiment in tho≈øe that drink much, e≈øpecially of thin and attenuating Liquors; for then their Urine is very clear; in which ca≈øe, the blood being over-power'd by that quantity of ≈øerum, and being wholly unable to retain it, puts it off quite clear, not yet died by the juice of the Body, by rea≈øon of its too ≈øhort ≈øtay.

As to the Cold, by which the external parts are ≈øo often chilled, it is very manife≈øt that that happens, becau≈øe the Spirits for≈øaking their ≈øtations too officiou≈øly, intrude them≈øelves into this or that part. Nor is it to be doubted, that weeping and laughing fits, which often ≈øei≈øe hy≈øterical women without any occa≈øion, are procured by the Animal Spirits forcing them≈øelves violently upon the Organs that perform the≈øe Animal functions.

And now I ≈øuppo≈øe it is manife≈øt, that this whole Di≈øea≈øe is occa≈øioned by the Animal Spirits being not rightly di≈øpo≈øed, and not by ≈øeed and men≈øtruous blood corrupted, and ≈øending up malignant Vapours to the parts affected, nor from I know not what depravation of the juices, and conge≈øtion of acrid humors as others think, but from tho≈øe Cau≈øes we have a≈ø≈øign ‚Ä¢ d; for that the fomes of the Di≈øea≈øe does not lurk in matter, will plainly appear by this one in≈øtance,
viz. A Woman that u≈øed to enjoy perfect health, being delicate, and of a thin habit of body, if ≈øhe chance to be weakned, and exhau≈øted by ≈øome error, or by ≈øome ≈øtrong Vomit or Purge, will certainly be afflicted with ≈øome one of tho≈øe Symptoms that accompany this Di≈øea≈øe, which would rather be removed, than occa≈øioned by ≈øuch Vomiting or Purging, if the fomes of the Di≈øea≈øe was contained in matter. The ≈øame may be ≈øaid of a great lo≈øs of blood, whether it is taken away by opening a vein, or flows immoderately in Labour; or of emptine≈øs, or too long ab≈øtinence from Fle≈øh; all which would rather prevent hy≈øteric Di≈øea≈øes, than occa≈øion them, if the fomes of them was involved in ≈øome matter; whereas on the contrary, nothing does ≈øo con≈øtantly occa≈øion this Di≈øea≈øe, as the≈øe evacuations‚ñ™ But tho' it is apparent enough, that the Original fomes of this Di≈øea≈øe is not lodged in the humors, yet it mu≈øt be confe≈ø≈øed that the confu≈øion of the Spirits produces putrid humors in the Body, by rea≈øon the function, as well of the≈øe parts which are di≈øtended by the violent impul≈øe of the Spirits, as of tho≈øe which are deprived of them, are wholly perverted; and mo≈øt of the≈øe being as it were ≈øeparatory Organs de≈øigned for the reception of the impurities of the blood, if their functions are any way hurt, it can not be but a great many feculencies will be heaped up, which had been elimmated, and ≈øo the ma≈øs of blood purified, if the Organs had performed their office, which they had certainly done, if a due Oeconomy of the Spirits had invigorated them. To this Cau≈øe is to be attributed great Cachexies, lo≈øs of appetite, a Chloro≈øis, and the White Fever in young Women, which is a ≈øpecies of hy≈øteric Di≈øea≈øes, and the ≈øource of many mi≈øeries.

From what has been ≈øaid, it is very manife≈øt that that is the chief indication in this Di≈øea≈øe, which directs the corroboration of the blood, that is the Fountain and Origin of the Spirits, which being done, the invigorated Spirits can pre≈øerve that tenure that is agreeable to the Oeconomy of the whole body, and the particular parts; and therefore when the confu≈øion of the Spirits has vitiated the humors by long continuance, it will be proper, fir≈øt to le≈ø≈øen tho≈øe humors ≈øo corrupted by bleeding, and purging, if the Patient has ≈øufficient ≈øtrength before we endeavour to corroberate the blood, and which indeed we can ≈øcarce do, whil≈øt a feculent heap of humors lies in the way. But fora≈ømuch as Pains, Vomiting, and Loo≈øene≈øs, are ≈øometimes ≈øo very ≈øevere that they will not bear a truce ≈øo long, until we have ≈øatisfied the fir≈øt intention of fortifying the blood; therefore ≈øometimes we mu≈øt begin the Cure by quieting the effects (the cau≈øe being let alone a little while) with ≈øome anodyne Medicine, and then we mu≈øt endeavour to rectifie the Spirits, who≈øe infirm con≈øtitution is the cau≈øe of this Di≈øea≈øe, by which we may again endeavour to Cure ≈øuch kind of Symptoms. And becau≈øe experience teaches, that there are many ≈øtinking things that will repell the inordination of the Spirits, and contain them in their places, which are therefore call'd hy≈øterics, we mu≈øt make u≈øe of them when we would an≈øwer ≈øuch intentions.

According to what has been ≈øaid, I order the Sick to be blooded in the arm, and that after bleeding, ≈øhe be purged three or four Mornings following. The Woman thinks her ≈øelf wor≈øe of tho≈øe days ≈øhe is blooded and purged; for the≈øe evacuations promote the confu≈øion of the Spirits, which I take care to forewarn her of, that ≈øhe may not de≈øpair, the Di≈øea≈øe of it ≈øelf
being apt to incline her ≈øo to do: But however tho≈øe ill humours heapt up by the long continuance of the Di≈øea≈øe, are in ≈øome ≈øort to be evacuated, before we can well an≈øwer the prime intention. After the≈øe evacuations, ≈øome ≈øteel Remedy mu≈øt be pre≈øcribed, to be taken about a Month, to comfort the blood, and ≈øo con≈øequently the Spirits, that proceed from it, and nothing will more certainly an≈øwer your intention in this ca≈øe than ≈øteel; for it rai≈øes a volatile ferment in the vapid and languid blood, whereby the weak Spirits are rou≈øed, that before were kept down by their own weight; and this is very manife≈øt, for as often as Chalybeats are given in the Green Sickne≈øs, the Pul≈øe are pre≈øently greater and quicker, and the outward parts grow warm, and the pale and dead Countenance is changed, and becomes fre≈øh and lively. But here we mu≈øt take notice, that bleeding and purging mu≈øt not always be u≈øed before Chalibeats, or when the Woman is weak, and almo≈øt worn out by the long continuance of the Di≈øea≈øe, they may and ought to be omitted, and you mu≈øt begin with ≈øteel, which mu≈øt be well minded.

I think ≈øteel is mo≈øt conveniently given in ≈øub≈øtance, and as I never ob≈øerved, nor heard, that ≈øo taken it ever injur'd any per≈øon, ≈øo I have been fully ≈øatisfied by frequent experience, that the bare ≈øub≈øtance performs the Cure ≈øooner, and better than any of the common Preparations of it; for bu≈øie Chymi≈øts make this, as well as other excellent Medicines wor≈øe rather than better, by their perver≈øe and over-officious diligence. I have al≈øo heard, and if it be true, it much ≈øtrengthens our a≈ø≈øertion, that the crude Mine, as it is digg'd out of the Earth, is more effectual in curing Di≈øea≈øes, than Iron that has pa≈øs'd the Fire, and bin purified by fu≈øion: So the Author affirms, but I have not yet try'd whether it be ≈øo or not. This I certainly know, that
there is no excellent and powerful Remedy, which has not received its chief Vertues from Nature: Upon which account, grateful Antiquity call'd excellent Medicines God's handicraft. Next to the ≈øub≈øtance of the ≈øteel, I chu≈øe the Syrrup of it, prepared with the fileings of Steel or Iron, infu≈øed in the cold in Rheni≈øh Wine, 'till the Wine is ≈øufficiently impregnated, and afterwards ≈øtrained, and boiled up to the con≈øi≈øtence of a Syrrup, with a ≈øufficient quantity of Sugar. Nor do I u≈øe any purging Medicine at ≈øet times, during the whole Chalybeat cour≈øe, for I think the Vertue of the Steel is de≈øtroy'd by a purge in hy≈øterical Di≈øea≈øes; and when the chief de≈øign is to reduce the Spirits to order, and to renew and confirm their Sy≈øtem.

If any one objects that fileings of Steel may hurt tho≈øe that take them, by ≈øticking in their Bowels, unle≈øs they are purged now and then; I an≈øwer fir≈øt, that I never found any ≈øuch thing in any one, and it is much more probable, that being involved in the ≈ølime, and with the Excrementious humours of the parts, they ≈øhould at length pa≈øs away with them, than when they are exagitated by purging Medicines, which occa≈øion unu≈øual compre≈ø≈øions, twi≈øting and contraction of the guts, whereby the particles of the ≈øteel, thru≈øt upon the coats of the Bowels, may penetrate deeper into them. When the patient is in a Steel cour≈øe, remedies commonly call'd Hy≈øterics are to be u≈øed, as it were by the by, to comfort the Blood and animal Spirits; in that manner and form, which is mo≈øt agreeable to the ≈øick. But if ≈øhe can take them in a ≈øolid form, they will more powerfully retain the Spirits in their office and place, than things that are liquid; for the very ≈øub≈øtance affects the Stomach longer with its ≈øavour, and works more forcibly upon the body, than either decoctions or infu≈øions. Being about to an≈øwer all the indications
I have touched upon above, I u≈øe to pre≈øcribe the≈øe few and common things, which commonly do what I de≈øire. Let eight ounces of blood be taken from the Arm, the next Morning let her enter upon the u≈øe of the Pills of Coch. Major and of Ca≈øtor, as they are mentioned in the Chapter of the Green-Sickne≈øs, and let them be repeated, as it is there ordered. Take of Galbanum di≈ø≈øolved in tincture of Ca≈øtor, and ≈øtrained three drams, Tachamacha two drams, make a Plai≈øter to be apply'd to the Navel.

Take of black Cherry-water, of Rue-water, and compound Briony-water, each three ounces, of Ca≈øtor tyed up in a Rag, and hanged in a gla≈øs half a dram, of fine Sugar a ≈øufficient quantity, make a Julep, whereof let her take four or five ≈øpoonfuls when ≈øhe is faint, dropping into the fir≈øt Do≈øe, if the Fit is violent, twenty drops of Spirit of Harts-horn.

After the Purging Pills are taken, let her u≈øe the other Pills made of fileings of Steel and extract of Wormwood, mentioned in the Chapter of the Green-≈øickne≈øs, according to the directions there ≈øet down; or ≈øhe may take the Bolus there mention'd, if ≈øhe likes a Bolus better than Pills.

Take of choice Myrrh and Galbanum, each one dram and an half, of Ca≈øtor fifteen grains, with a ≈øufficient quantity of Peruvian Bal≈øome, make twelve Pills of every dram; let her take three every Night, and drink upon them three or four ≈øpoonfuls of compound Briony-water thro' the whole Cour≈øe of this proce≈øs.
But if the Pills la≈øt pre≈øcribed move the Belly, which ≈øometimes happens in Bodies that are very ea≈øily purged, by rea≈øon of the Gum that is in them, the following are to be u≈øed.

Take of Ca≈øtor one dram, of volatile Salt, Amber, half a dram, with a ≈øufficient quantity of extract of Rue,
make 24 ≈ømall Pills, let her take three every Night.

But it is to be noted that Steel Medicines in what≈øoever form or Do≈øe they are taken, occa≈øion ≈øometimes in Women great di≈øorders both of Body and Mind, and that not only on the fir≈øt days, which is u≈øual almo≈øt in every body, but al≈øo almo≈øt all the time they are taken; in this ca≈øe the u≈øe of Steel mu≈øt not pre≈øently be interrupted at tho≈øe times, but Laudanum mu≈øt be given every night for ≈øome time in ≈øome hy≈øteric water, that they may the better bear it; but when the ≈øymptoms are mild, and it ≈øeems that the bu≈øine≈øs may be done without taking ≈øteel, I think it ≈øufficient to bleed, and to purge three or four times, and then to give the altering hy≈øteric Pills above-mentioned, Morning and Evening for ten days.
It is to be noted that ≈øome Women do ≈øo abhor hy≈øteric Medicines, that they are much injured thereby, therefore they mu≈øt not be given to ≈øuch.

If the blood is ≈øo very feeble, and the confu≈øion of the Spirits ≈øo great, that ≈øteel ordered to be us'd, according to the method pre≈øcribed, is not ≈øufficient to cure the di≈øea≈øe, the Patient mu≈øt drink ≈øome mineral waters impregnated with the Iron Mine, ≈øuch as are Tunbridge, and ≈øome others lately found out. But this is more e≈øpecially to be ob≈øerved in drinking of them, viz. That if any Sickne≈øs happens, that is to be refer'd to hy≈øteric ≈øymptoms, in this Ca≈øe the Patient mu≈øt forbear drinking them a day or two, 'till that ≈øymptom that hindered their pa≈ø≈øage is quite gone.

But if the Di≈øea≈øe by rea≈øon of its ob≈øtinacy will not yield to ≈øteel-waters, the Patient mu≈øt go to the Bath; and when ≈øhe has u≈øed the≈øe waters inwardly three Mornings following, the next day let her go into the Bath, and the day following let her drink them again; and ≈øo let her do by turns for two whole Months.
Venice Treacle alone, if it be u≈øed often, and a long while, is a great remedy in this Di≈øea≈øe.

Spani≈øh Wine medicated with Gentian, Angelica, Wormwood, Centaury, the yellow rind of Oranges, and other Corroboratives infus'd in it, does a great deal of good, ≈øome ≈øpoonfuls of it being taken thrice a day, if the woman be not of a thin and cholerick habit of Body.

The Peruvian-Bark al≈øo wonderfully comforts and invigorates the Blood and Spirits, a Scruple being taken Morning and Evening. But if any of the Remedies above-mention'd do not well agree, which often happens in cholerick and thin Constitutions, then a Milk Diet may be u≈øed; but nothing does ≈øo much ≈øtrengthen the Blood and Spirits, as riding much on Hor≈øeback every day for a long while. If the Di≈øea≈øe be ≈øuch, or ≈øo great a one, that it will not bear a truce 'till it may be cured with Medicines that corroborate the Blood and Spirits, we mu≈øt pre≈øently make u≈øe of hy≈øteric Remedies, as A≈ø≈øa-faetida, Galbanum, Ca≈øtor, Spirit of Sal-Armoniack, and whatever el≈øe has a filthy and ungrateful ≈ømell.

To conclude, if ≈øome intolerable pain accompanies this Di≈øea≈øe, or if their be violent Vomitings, or a Loo≈øne≈øs, then be≈øides hy≈øteric Medicines above-mentioned, Laudanum mu≈øt be u≈øed, which is only able to re≈øtrain the≈øe ≈øymptoms. But in quieting the≈øe pains which vomiting occa≈øions, we mu≈øt take great care that they are not mitigated, either by Laudanum, or any other Paregorick, before due evacuations have been made, unle≈øs they almo≈øt exceed all humane patience; but if the Sick has vomited a great while, you mu≈øt give Laudanum without delay, and ≈øuch a do≈øe as is not only equal to the violence and duration of the ≈øymptom, but ≈øuch an one as is ≈øufficient to vanqui≈øh it.

div.head: Of Barrenne≈øs.
div.p: BArrenne≈øs is an impotence to conceive, coming from defect either of the Genitals, or of the blood, or of the men≈øtruous blood.

Fir≈øt, through the defect of the Genitals, either by the clo≈øing up of the Orifice of the womb, which may be cut and opened by Art; or through the narrowne≈øs of the parts, for ≈øo they will not admit the Yard; or by rea≈øon of ≈øome Ulcers or Excre≈øcencies in the neck of the womb. Or by rea≈øon of ≈øome fault in the ≈øeed, either the woman being too young, or too old, or through ≈øome di≈øtemper in the Ve≈ø≈øels dedicated to generation, and then the woman perceives very little or no plea≈øure in the act of Copulation. The Cure of this is referred to the Chapter of the di≈øtempers of the womb.
Or when there is not that due proportion of ≈øeed which ought to be in both parties, which chiefly ari≈øes from the u≈øe of tho≈øe things that extingui≈øh barrenne≈øs, as Mint, Rue, Camphire.

Or from Inchantments; and then the man cannot lye with his wife; or though he ≈øhould, yet cannot emit the ≈øeed: Again≈øt which it is affirmed that the drinking a draught of cold water that drops from the mouth of a young Stone-hor≈øe as he drinks, and ≈øaved in a little ve≈ø≈øel, is very potent.

Or when the womb doth not draw the ≈øeed which is ejected, and that by rea≈øon of ≈øome cold and moi≈øt di≈øtemper; in which ca≈øe all ≈øorrow, anger, and much ≈øleep are to be avoided; as al≈øo the eating of Milk, fre≈øh Chee≈øe, and any thing that is made of dough. Neither is ≈øhe to eat Endive, Spinage, Beets, Lettice, Nuts, Cherries, Pur≈ølane, Onions, Garlick, or ≈øuch like; nor much broth, vinegar, and fat fle≈øh. In the
next place, the womb mu≈øt be clean≈øed from over-abundance of moi≈øture, with ≈øyrup of Wormwood, with the decoction of Harts-tongue, Fennel, Cumin, and Ani≈øeed.
After this take once every 14 days, a dram of ble≈ø≈øed Pills, fa≈øting five hours after them.

Take al≈øo of the≈øe following Pills. Take of Labdanum, Agaric, Wax, and Sheep ≈øuet tryed, of which you may make Pills to take two or three of them every morning, or u≈øe this confection: Take ≈øhaven Ivory, A≈øh keys, yellow and wild Rape-≈øeed, Siler mountain, with red and white Behen, of each one dram, Cinamon, Galingale, long Pepper, Cloves and Mace, Bal≈øam-wood, Ro≈øemary-flowers, Blatrae, Byzantiae, Marjoram, Penny-royal, of each four ≈øcruples, Baulm, Buglo≈øs, Citron Pils, of each two ≈øcruples, Pearls one ≈øcruple, Musk 2 grains, white ≈øugar twenty four ounces; ≈øeeth this with Malm≈øey, and make thereof a Confection.

Or becau≈øe of ≈øome Di≈øea≈øes in the parts; where note, that too much fatne≈øs of the Call doth clo≈øe the mouth of the womb: ≈øuch women mu≈øt not ≈øleep much, e≈øpecially in the day time; they mu≈øt u≈øe ≈øtrong Cly≈øters that are warm and dry, and purge often.

Or when the Womb doth not attract the ≈øeed when it is ca≈øt in; which proceeds from a moi≈øt intemperance, which is by the loo≈øene≈øs of the fibres of the Womb, ≈øo that the Womb cannot contract it ≈øelf; which is cured as in the moi≈øt di≈øtemper: Or by rea≈øon of the thickne≈øs of the Womb; for then the blood that increa≈øes the ≈øeed doth not ≈ølide down to that place. The cure hereof requires a thin diet, purging and ≈øweating; or by rea≈øon of the ≈ølipperine≈øs thereof, which happens by rea≈øon of the running of the whites in women: The cure whereof con≈øi≈øts in the ≈øtopping
of the whites, which hath been already treated of, or by rea≈øon of the gaping of the Orifice, which hath been occa≈øioned either by difficult birth, or by ≈øome abortion. The cure is performed by a≈øtringent Medicines, among which the chiefe≈øt are the fomentation of Lentisk and Myrtle; or by rea≈øon of ≈øome ≈øudden cough or ≈øneezing, immediately after copulation, by which the ≈øeed is ≈øhaken forth. Or when the Womb doth not alter the ≈øeed that is ca≈øt in, through an immoderate cold di≈øtemper.

Sometimes through heat, and then it would be requi≈øite to avoid hot air, and to keep the part about the womb cold; the eating of hot meats and ≈øpices mu≈øt be avoided. Purge after blood-letting in the Ba≈øilick vein of the right hand, with Electurium de Epythymo, and juyce of Ro≈øes, of each two drams and a half, whey four ounces, mix them well together, and take them in the morning, ≈øleeping on, and fa≈øting four hours upon. Purge al≈øo with Triphera Saracenica, and Rheubarb, with potions prepared and mixed with ≈øyrup of Ro≈øes, Violets, and Endive. Take Pi≈øtacia, Eringo's, of each half an ounce, of Saffron a dram, Lignum Aloes, Galangal, Avens, Mace, red and white Behen, Baulm-flowers, of each four ≈øcruple, ≈øhavings of Ivory, and Ca≈ø≈øia rinds, of each two ≈øcruples, ≈øyrup of Ginger confected twelve ounces, white Sugar ≈øix ounces; ≈øeeth the≈øe together with the ≈øyrup in 12 ounces of Baulm-water, untill it be all boyled away; when it is cold, put ≈øome more water to it, and ≈øtir them together; and at la≈øt of all, mix with it a ≈øcruple and a half of Musk and Amber: of this Con≈øerve let the woman take thrice a day; to wit, in the morning, an hour before ≈øupper, and an hour after dinner.

Or it proceeds from ob≈øtruction of the Flowers; in which ca≈øe, fir≈øt let blood in the Ba≈øilick vein, then
purge with Opoponax, and Hiera Compo≈øita, of each half a dram, to be made up into ≈øeven Pills, to be taken in the morning, ≈øleeping upon them an hour and a half, with a draught of ≈øugar'd water five hours after; or with a potion of ≈øyrup of vinegar compounded, ≈øyrup of Hemp agrimony, of each three quarters of an ounce; Feverfew, Mugwort, and Elecampane roots, of each an ounce, and mix them together: Then ≈øhe may put up into the Womb a pe≈ø≈øary of Musk, Amber, Aloes-Wood, and A≈øh keys, of each three grains, Saffron half a ≈øcruple, Hares rennet as much as ≈øuffices, which being made up like a good big Tent, ≈øhe mu≈øt keep a whole day in her Body.

div.head: Of the bringing up of Children, and of their Di≈øea≈øes.
Of the Di≈øea≈øes of the Head.
div.p: THE Di≈øea≈øes common to Children, are fir≈øt certain little ulcerous ri≈øings, chiefly in the Head; ≈øometimes in the whole Body; they ari≈øe from ≈øome vitious humour either collected in the Womb, or out of the Womb, by rea≈øon of the badne≈øs of the milk containing a ≈øerous, ≈øalt, and nitrous quality: If there be no ill to be ≈øu≈øpected, the humour may be driven forth by giving the Child ≈øome Syrup of Fumatory, or Harts-horn burnt: The Nur≈øe is to be purged, and the matter offending to be tempered with Syrup of Borage, or Fumary: If there be much corruption under the Cru≈øt of the Scab, the Head of the Child is to bo bathed with ≈øome ≈øoftning decoction, and then to be anointed with ≈øome drying Ointments.

Sometimes they are troubled with an inflamation of the Head, with which is joined a hollowne≈øs in the forepart of the Head; and in the Eyes; it may ari≈øe from the milk, if the Nur≈øe be ≈øubject to drink overmuch
≈øtrong drink; in the Cure, you mu≈øt beware of applying things which are too refrigerating.

They are al≈øo many times affected with a kind of Epilep≈øie, which proceeds ≈øometimes from extraordinary frights, from Milk that lies corrupted in the ≈øtomach, and ≈øometimes from Worms moving them≈øelves in the guts; and ≈øometimes it is the con≈øequent of other Di≈øea≈øes. The Cure is to be ob≈øerved, partly in the Fit, and partly after the Fit: The Smaragd-≈øtone, and the Hoof of a wild Elk put into the left Ear are very profitable, and take good effect; vomiting al≈øo, and this Emplai≈øter of white Amber, Frankincen≈øe, and Ma≈øtick, of each a dram and a half, Galbanum, Opopanax‚ñ™ of each a ≈øcruple, Mi≈øleto of an Oak two drams, Ambergreece ≈øix grains, Musk three grains, ≈øeed of Male Peonie half a dram, Labdanum, one dram and a half, a little Oil of Nutmeg, and ≈øprinkled with the du≈øt of Cubebs; the forepart of the head may be al≈øo anointed with Oil of white Amber. Fears and ≈øtarting in the Child's ≈øleep, are occa≈øioned from the putrid Vapours which are carried up with the animal Spirits, and ari≈øe from the Stomach; therefore they happen to Infants that ≈øuck greedily. In the Cure, care mu≈øt be taken that the Child do not fill it ≈øelf too unrea≈øonably, and provide that good and ≈øound Milk may be generated, and that the Children be not put to ≈øleep upon a full ≈øtomach: The ≈øtomach of the Child anointed near the orifice with Oil of Quinces, and Ma≈øtick, and Oil of Nutmegs. Before ≈øleep di≈ø≈øolve a little roll of Diamo≈øch in Milk, and give the Child; unle≈øs the Child be over-much troubled with heat, you may give it a little Treacle once in a week; over-much watching, or weakne≈øs, is occa≈øioned by ≈øharp Vapours which ari≈øe out of the ≈øtomach, by rea≈øon of the badne≈øs of the Milk; ≈øometimes it is occa≈øioned
by Feavers, and pain of ≈øome peculiar parts; there is nothing better than to anoint the ≈øoles of the Childs feet with Marrow, which hath no danger in it, rather than to give the Child ≈øtronger Opiates. A looking a≈øquint; in new born Children is cured by putting a Candle oppo≈øite to the place where the Child ca≈øts its Eyes.

Moi≈øtne≈øs of the Ears, by rea≈øon of the moi≈øtne≈øs of the Head, gathers quantity of humours together: The Cure of this mu≈øt not be over-ha≈øty; yet the Urine of Children di≈øtilled and dropt into the Ear, is a very approved Remedy.

div.head: Bigne≈øs and ≈øwelling of the Head in little Children.
div.p: SOmetimes in Children that are newly born, the Head grows to an extraordinary bigne≈øs which come to pa≈øs, either by rea≈øon of abundance of water contained in the ≈øame, which water is contained, either between the skin and the Pericraneum, or between the bone and the Pericranium, or between the bone and the Membranes called the Dura Mater, and the Pia Mater.

Or by rea≈øon of abundance of Vapours gathered together between the bones and the skin of the head, which cau≈øe the head to grow to ≈øuch an extraordinary bigne≈øs, that it cau≈øes oftentimes the death of the Child.

If water be gathered together between the bone of the head, and the Membranes of the Brain, it cau≈øes a giddine≈øs and Epilep≈øy to the Infant, without being able to take any re≈øt. For the Cure of the windy affection you may u≈øe fomentations, in ca≈øe the wind be contained only between the skin and the Pericranium; for which purpo≈øe, you may take of the leaves of Sage, Betony, Agrimony, ≈øweet ≈ømelling flag, and wild Margerom, of each a handful; Ani≈øeed and Fennel ≈øeed, of each two drams; Camomile flowers, Melilot, and red Ro≈øes, of each one handful; boil all the≈øe in common
water, adding to it a little Wine, and thereof make a Fomentation for the part affected, which may be a≈ø≈øi≈øted with a plai≈øter made of Oil of Ani≈øeeds, and bitter Almonds, of each one Ounce, Oil of Camomile an Ounce and a half, Laurel and Juniper Berries, of each two drams, Ani≈øeeds and Fennel-≈øeeds, of each one dram and a half, of the be≈øt Wine a pint; boyl them to the con≈øumption of the Wine, adding to the re≈øt half an ounce of Venice Turpentine, and as much Wax as is ≈øufficient: As for the watry di≈øtemper though it be difficult to Cure, yet you mu≈øt try this Fomentation to dige≈øt this Humour: Take Wormwood, Betony, creeping Time, Pennyroyal leaves, of each a handful, red Ro≈øe leaves, and leaves of Stoechas, a little handful, Cypre≈øs Nuts, Orange-flowers, and Florentine Orrice, of each two drams, boil them all in a Lye made of Vine-twigs and ≈øtalks; after which you may u≈øe this Plai≈øter. Take the powder of Bettony, Sage and Wormwood, of each two drams, Oil of Camomile and Ro≈øes, of each two Ounces, Unguenti Comiti≈ø≈øae one ounce, as much Wax as is ≈øufficient: But if the≈øe Remedies profit nothing, the only means left is to open the Head.

div.head: Of the Di≈øea≈øes of the Eyes, Ears, and No≈øes in Children.
div.p: MANY times Children are troubled with a light inflamation in their Eyes, with a certain gum, and thickne≈øs which hinders them from opening the eyelid: The mo≈øt pre≈øent remedies are, either for the Nur≈øe to wa≈øh the Eyes with a little of her Brea≈øt milk, or el≈øe with a little Plantain and Ro≈øe-water mixt together.

Sometimes the No≈øtrils are ≈øo ≈øtopt that they are not able to draw their Breath, but with much pain. For the Cure of which, the Nur≈øe mu≈øt moi≈øten a linnen Cloath in a little Ointment of Ro≈øes, or a little very good Pomatum, 'till the hard matter within be di≈ø≈øolved.

Many times there flows a moi≈øt humor from their heads, which happens to tho≈øe who have moi≈øt brains in the cure of this it mu≈øt be the care of the Nur≈øe to clean≈øe the ears, both within and without; afterwards let her drop into them a little oyl of bitter Almonds, and Honey of Ro≈øes mixt together.

div.head: Of certain Ulcers in Childrens mouths.
div.p: THere do many times grow a certain kind of Ulcers in Childrens mouths: For the cure of which the Nur≈øe in the fir≈øt place mu≈øt u≈øe a good and ≈øound diet, then mu≈øt the Ulcers them≈øelves be rub'd with a little Honey of Ro≈øes, and ≈øyrup of Violets, with a drop or two of Plantain-water; or you may wa≈øh them with half an ounce of Ro≈øe-water, or Plantain-water, in which put half a dram of Vitriol; if they be very red and inflamed, take Brambles, flowers of Pomgranates, Ro≈øes, Sanders, of each two drams, Allum half a dram; boyl them in water, afterwards ≈øtrain them to the quantity of three ounces, in which di≈ø≈øolve half an ounce of ≈øyrup of Mulberries.

If they be white, take Amber, Frankincen≈øe-wood, Cypre≈øs-Nuts, Pomegranate flowers, of each two drams, flowers of Ro≈øes and Myrtles, of each half a handful; boyl them in water to the con≈øumption of four ounces, wherein di≈ø≈øolve an ounce and a half of Honey of Ro≈øes.

div.head: Of certain other Tumours, called Paroulis and E≈øpoulis.
div.p:
PAroulis is a little ≈øwelling, red, and inflamed, and is ingendered commonly of a hot cholerick blood, or el≈øe from a ≈øalt flegm that falls down upon the gums, cau≈øing not only the gums, but the neck and chaps to be ≈øwelled. For the cure, you may anoint the gums with this oyntment: Take of fine Flower eleven drams, powder of Tragachanth one dram, burnt Allum one ≈øcruple, Ro≈øe-water one ounce; if there be any
inflammation, rub the gums with a mu≈øcilage made of the ≈øeed of Quinces, made with Ro≈øe-water, and Plantain-water, adding to it a little ≈øyrup of Jujubes. If the ≈øwelling be ob≈øtinate, bring it to a ≈øuppuration with Figs, Rai≈øins, Jujubes, Liquori≈øh, and French Barley, well boyled; when it is opened and launced, clean≈øe and dry it with hony of Ro≈øes ≈øyrup of Ro≈øes and Cherries.

The E≈øpoulis is a little excre≈øcence of Fle≈øh hapning between the teeth, but mo≈øt commonly the great teeth. Take the root of Buglo≈øs an ounce and a half, Plantain, Agrimony a handful, whole Barly a ≈ømall handful, red Ro≈øes half a handful, Pomgranate flowers 2 drams, 4 Dates, a dram and a half of Liquori≈øh; make a decoction and ≈øtrain it, and then add to it an ounce of ≈øyrup of Ro≈øes, and Pomgranates, to wa≈øh the place affected: you al≈øo may wa≈øh it with this Remedy. Take of the juice of Pomgranates and Quinces, of each half an ounce, juice of Barberies and Lettice of each two drams, a little of the decoction of Lentils, and red Ro≈øes.

div.head: Of the two ≈øtrings under the Tongue of a Child,
div.p: THere is one of the≈øe Strings or Ligaments, which appears, reaching from the bottom of the tongue, and extending it ≈øelf to the top of the tongue; this mu≈øt be cut off fir≈øt with a pair of Cizers, and the place rub'd with a little Mo≈øche Salt.

There is another Ligament which ri≈øes from the root, and extendeth it ≈øelf to the middle of the tongue, which is more hard and large, which hinders the tongue either from being ≈øtretched out, or to be moved in the mouth. The Cure hereof belongs wholly to the Chirurgeon.

div.head: Of the Cough in Children.
div.p: THE Cough in Children comes either from the di≈øtillation of ≈øome cold and ≈øharp humor di≈øtilling from the brain: If the humor be cold, the Child is al≈øo troubled with a vi≈øcous and ≈ølimy Flegm, which lies in the pa≈ø≈øages of re≈øpiration: If the humor flowing down be hot, the face of the Infant will be red; if it come of a cold humor, the Child mu≈øt be kept indifferently warm, giving it a little oyl of ≈øweet Almonds and Sugar-candy; it will not be ami≈øs al≈øo to wa≈øh the feet of the Child in Ale, wherein certain Cephalick herbs have been boiled, and after that to anoint the plants, or ≈øoles of his feet with Goo≈øes fat.

The brea≈øt of the Child may be al≈øo rubbed with oyl of ≈øweet Almonds, and fre≈øh-butter, and upon this put little linnen cloaths ≈øomething warm. If it be accompanied with any vi≈øcous matter, or flegm, you may give the Infant a little ≈øyrup of Maiden-hair, or ≈øyrup of Liquori≈øh, and Hy≈øop mingled together; or give the Infant this water to drink; Take of Rain-water, and Fountain-water, of each a pint, white Sugar one ounce, Honey an ounce, Vinegar two drams; boyl them altogether, and clarifie them, and let the Infant drink it.

div.head: Of breeding Teeth.
div.p:
IN breeding Teeth, the difficulty and pain that the Child endures, is ea≈øily perceived; and whether that be the thing which the Child is afflicted with, may be ea≈øily gue≈ø≈øed at by the time of breeding teeth, which is about the ≈øeventh month; be≈øide, the Infant is perceived to be often putting his fingers in his mouth, and the Nur≈øe perceives the Infant to gripe her brea≈øts hard, &c. the place where the teeth are about to break out looks white; there are al≈øo watchings, and the ≈øen≈øe of a very great pain. The ≈øwelling gums are to
be anointed with Hares brains boyled, or the fat of it. If they be inflamed, wa≈øh them with oyl of Ro≈øes, and white Wax, and the juyce of Night-≈øhade: if they be exulcerated anoint them with butter that hath no Salt in it, with a little Honey and powder of Frankincen≈øe.

div.head: Of the inflammation of the Navel-≈øtring in Infants.
div.p: SOmetimes after the binding of the Navel-≈øtring, it happens to exulcerate: for the cure u≈øe an emplai≈øter of Pompholyx, or anoint it with oyl of Ro≈øes, and a little Populeon.

div.head: Of the Worms.
div.p: OFtentimes Children are extreamly troubled with Worms; they are generated of a vi≈øcous and flegmy humor; are ≈øometimes round, and then Children are commonly troubled with a Feaver, and grow lean, their appetite fails them, they ≈øtart in their ≈øleep, they have a dry cough joyned with it, with a ≈øtinking breath, and an ill colour in their faces; the eyes hollow and dark with a kind of irregular Feaver, which comes three or four times a night, and they often rub their no≈øes; if they be little worms, they have always a de≈øire to go to ≈øtool, and their excrements are very purous. If the Infant be young, the Nur≈øe mu≈øt be ≈øure to keep a good diet, ab≈øtaining from all raw fruits, Pea≈øe and Beans, and all milky things, and any thing that ≈øhall be of a hard concoction: Next, you may lay a plai≈øter of the Ma≈øs of Pills Sine quibus, half a dram, pouder of Wormwood one dram, Myrrh and Aloes of each two ≈øcruples, meal of Lupines a dram and a half, the Gall of an Ox as much as ≈øufficeth; if the Infant be any thing grown, you may give him in a little broth a ≈ømall quantity of Harts-horn.

div.head: Of the Convul≈øion in Infants.
div.p:
THe Signs of Convul≈øion are the hanging backward of the head, in≈øomuch that the hinder part of the
head ≈øeemeth to touch the ≈øhoulders; ≈øometimes the head and the neck hang ≈øo far forward, that the Chin touches the Brea≈øt.

The Cure of this: If it come of too great abundance of humours, let the Air wherein the Child is nur≈øed be hot and dry, and exerci≈øe much; let the Nur≈øe not ≈øleep long, e≈øpecially after dinner; and let her diet be rather drying than any way moi≈øt. If the Child do not ≈øuck he mu≈øt avoid Meats that do trouble the head, and fill it up with Vapors, or ≈ølimy meats that may ≈øtop the pa≈ø≈øages of the Veins: Sweet things are very hurtful, but Honey and Water wherein a little Sage and Betony have been boiled, it will not be ami≈øs to give him: If purgation be needful, let the Nur≈øe rather than the Child purge, which may be performed with Ca≈ø≈øia or Manna. If the Child be any thing big, let his Belly be kept loo≈øe, by giving him a little water wherein Sena hath been ≈øteeped 24 hours, tempering it with a very ≈ømall quantity of the juice of Citron; or you may give him a little of the pouder of Diacarthamum in the pap of an Apple.

If the Convul≈øion comes of drine≈øs or emptine≈øs, or by rea≈øon of ≈øome great evacuation, flux of the Belly, vomiting, hunger, or the like, the Child mu≈øt be nur≈øed in an Air more moi≈øt than dry, and his diet mu≈øt be the ≈øame. The be≈øt and mo≈øt approved remedy is to apply a cautery in the hinder part of the Head to the nook of the Neck, between the ≈øecond and third Vertebra, which may be done to new born Children; Frictions al≈øo of the Legs, Back-bone and Thighs are very profitable; as al≈øo Cupping-Gla≈ø≈øes applied to the Thighs and Legs.

If the Convul≈øion come by rea≈øon of the Worms, you may give him this Cly≈øter. Take of ≈øimple Hydromel four ounces, new butter one ounce, powdered
Aloes half a dram, and make a Cly≈øter. Or you may give him two drams of Earthworms killed, dried and poudered, Sugar poudered one ounce, and let the Child take two drams of it every day in a ≈øpoonful of Lettice-water.
If any venemous Vapour be the cau≈øe hereof, let him take ≈øix grains of Treacle, or Mithridate in Mint-water.

div.head: Of the ≈øwelling of the Hypochondria in Infants.
div.p: WHICH cau≈øeth Children by rea≈øon of the narrowne≈øs of the Mouth of the Stomach to be troubled with a difficulty of breathing: It ari≈øeth from the greedine≈øs of the Infant, which either ≈øucks too great a quantity of Milk, or of other Meats. The inward Cure of this is performed by admini≈øtring the Powder of the root of Orrice or Paeonie.

div.head: Of Co≈øtivene≈øs in Children.
div.p: THIS proceeds from the unskilfulne≈øs of the Nur≈øe in the Dieting of the Child, or from a cold and dry Di≈øtemper of the Guts, or from the hot and dry Di≈øtemper of the Bowels; in this ca≈øe the Belly may be well loo≈øned with Ca≈ø≈øia, or with a liniment compo≈øed of new Oil of ≈øweet Almonds, Goo≈øe fat, May butter, Ointment of Mar≈øhmallows, of each two drams, Colocynth. gr. ≈øixteen, one ≈øcruple of Salt, Species Hierae one ≈øcruple, Diagridion four grains; make of this an ointment, and anoint the Navel.

Or it proceeds from a vi≈øcous Flegm, which wraps about and holds the dregs, which may be remedied by a ≈øuppo≈øitory of Mou≈øe Dung, and Goats ≈øuet, or by the u≈øe of an Emplai≈øter of Aloes, Bulls-gall, Myrrh, and May butter, to be laid upon the Navel.

div.head: Of loo≈øene≈øs in Children.
div.p:
LOo≈øene≈øs of the Belly happens either in the time of Teeth breeding, or out of the time; in the time of breeding Teeth, either by rea≈øon of the corruption
of the nutriment, or by rea≈øon of overmuch watching through the pain of the Teeth, or by rea≈øon of a Fever, and ≈øome unnatural heat: It mu≈øt not be ≈øuddenly ≈øtopt, if it be not over copious, and that the Infant can endure it; the Belly mu≈øt be afterwards clean≈øed with Ro≈øes ≈øolutive, and afterwards ≈øtopped; great ob≈øervation being had whether the cau≈øe come from a hot or cold Di≈øtemper.

div.head: Of Bur≈øtne≈øs in Children.
div.p: BUr≈øtne≈øs happens to Children, either by rea≈øon that the Peritonaeum is bur≈øt through crying, or falling, or ≈øplaying with the Thighs: For the Cure whereof the Child mu≈øt be kept quiet, and ≈øtill from crying; upon which, after the part affected is well bound up, you may give the Child inwardly of the e≈ø≈øence of the greater Comfrey one ≈øpoonful, with two drops of Bal≈øam of Sal Gemma. You may al≈øo foment the place with a fomentation made of the roots of the greater Comfrey, and O≈ømund Royal, the bark of Elm, and A≈øh, Knot-gra≈øs, each half an ounce, the leaves of Plantain, Mullein, Rupture wort, Hor≈øetail, Flowers of Camomile, red Ro≈øes, and Melilot, of each a handful and a half, Balau≈øt, Cypre≈øs Nuts and Acorns, of each two drams; put the≈øe into two bags, and boil them in equal parts of ≈øowre Wine and Smiths water, for a Fomentation to be u≈øed for a quarter of an hour; then you may lay on a Plai≈øter of the red drying Ointment eleven ounces, pouder of Ma≈øtick, Olibanum, and Sarcocol, Cypre≈øt Nuts, of each one dram, with a little Wax and Oil of Ma≈øtick to make a Plai≈øter, which mu≈øt be put upon the place affected, and bound down with a little pillow.

Sometimes this bur≈øtne≈øs proceeds from a watry humour abounding in the Abdomen, which de≈øcending into the Cods cau≈øeth them to ≈øwell; for which you
may u≈øe with good ≈øucce≈øs this Ointment: Take of Unguent. Comiti≈øs. and the red drying Ointment, of each two ounces, Pigeons dung half an ounce, live Sulphur three drams, powder of Lawrel Berries, and Mu≈øtard≈øeed, of each a dram, Oil of Dill, and Venice Turpentine of each three drams, Wax as much as ≈øufficeth: This is al≈øo an extraordinary remedy for the bur≈øtne≈øs proceeding from Wind.

div.head: Of the Inflammation of the Navel.
div.p: THE Inflammation of the Navel ari≈øeth when the blood gathers thither by rea≈øon of ≈øome external hurt; the danger is very great, if it ≈øhould Apo≈øtemate, and ≈øo the Guts fall down; and therefore ≈øuppuration mu≈øt be hindred as much as may be.

div.head: Of the jutting forth of the Navel.
div.p: THIS differs from the Inflamation, becau≈øe here the Navel doth not give way to the touch, neither is the colour of the Skin changed, neither is there any very great pain, or Pul≈øe, unle≈øs the Inte≈øtines are very much fallen; it proceeds from the ill binding thereof at fir≈øt, which is incurable; or when a greater portion than needs of the Navel ≈øtring is left. Secondly, from a laxation of the Peritonaeum, and then the tumour is equal, nor doth the Navel jut forth very far: In the Cure hereof, you mu≈øt let the Child ab≈øtain from all windy meats, and from much crying. Sometimes it is occa≈øioned by the rupture of the Peritonaeum; the ≈øwelling is hardly perceived when the Child lies upon his back, but increa≈øeth and ≈øwells forward when he walks, ≈øits, cries and bawls: In the Cure of this, the Mo≈øs that grows upon the wild Prune Tree, is very much commended; or you may make little ≈øwathbands of Leather, and anoint them with Oxycroceum.

div.head: Of the Stone in the Bladder.
div.p:
THIS is known by the coming forth of the Urine by drops and with pain, which is ≈øometimes unmixed,
≈øometimes containing a kind of ≈øerous humour, ≈øometimes died with a little blood: It is produced either by the Milk which is engendred of meats that do increa≈øe the Stone, or through a hot di≈øtemper of the Liver, which attracts the Chyle, and ≈øends it unaltered to the Bladder: For the Cure you mu≈øt u≈øe Baths, among which this is commended to anoint the Bladder withal; take Oyl of Scorpions, Oyl of bitter Almonds, Conies Grea≈øe, and Hens Grea≈øe, of each an ounce and a half, and of the juice of Pellitory of the Wall two ounces: Or take Sal Tartar one ounce, Par≈øly-water a Pint, mix them through a fine paper rubbed over with the Rinds of Oranges, and give a ≈ømall quantity thereof.

div.head: Of the not holding of the Urine.
div.p: THis ari≈øeth either from the Mu≈øcle, which ≈øhuts the orifice of the Bladder, which is ≈øo di≈øpo≈øed, that it is loo≈øed upon the lea≈øt exciting of the Urine, and grows ≈øo into a habit, that it many times accompanies them to their Graves; or from the ≈øtone in the Bladder, or from the weakne≈øs of the Sphincter proceeding from a cold and moi≈øt di≈øtemper; which is cured partly by the good diet of the Nur≈øe, and partly by convenient Medicines, among which a bath made of Sulphur, Nitre, and the leaves of Oak, is exceeding good.

div.head: Of the Intertrigo.
div.p: WHen the little skin in the Hips is ≈øeparated from the true skin; it ari≈øes fir≈øt from the ≈øharpne≈øs of the Urine, e≈øpecially in Children that are more corpulent, by rea≈øon of the dirt which frets the skin, being gathered together in the wrinkles. Bath the place, and then ≈øprinkle upon it either white Nihili, or anoint it with Oyl of Litharge.

div.head: Of Leanne≈øs.
div.p:
THis ari≈øes either from a ≈øubtle kind of Worms, which are generated in the mo≈øt mu≈øclely parts
of the Back and Arms, and con≈øume the Body; they break forth ≈øometimes like to black hairs; if you wa≈øh tho≈øe parts with a Bath mixed with Bread and Honey, they are taken away either with a Razor, or with a cru≈øt of bread. Secondly, it ari≈øes from the ≈ømall quantity of milk, which is oftentimes remedied by changing the Nur≈øe.

div.head: Of the difficulty which Children have to make water.
div.p: IF the Di≈øea≈øe proceed from ≈øharpne≈øs of the Urine, the Nur≈øe mu≈øt u≈øe ≈øuch a way of diet as is proper for the tempering and cooling of the blood; ≈øhe mu≈øt be purged, and let blood, u≈øing afterwards cooling and refrigerating broths. If it proceed from any gro≈øs humor ingendered in the Bladder, the Nur≈øe mu≈øt ab≈øtain from all meats that do breed gro≈øs humors, as milky meats, Pea≈øe and Beans, and ≈øuch like.

If the Child be troubled with gravel, which may be perceived by the whitene≈øs and rawne≈øs of the Urine, with a gravelly ≈øetling at the bottom, and the continual pain in making water: If the Child be any thing big, let a potion be given him of an ounce and a half of ≈øweet Almonds, an ounce of Pellitory water, and two drams of the juyce of Lemons; u≈øe as much of this at a time as is convenient. Or take of this powder, of the blood of a Hare ≈øix ounces, of the root of Saxifrage one ounce, burn them in an earthen pot; and if the Infant ≈øuck, give him a ≈øcruple of this powder in a little milk.

div.head: Of the Inflammation of the Almonds of the Ears.
div.p:
IF the Child be very ≈ømall, you mu≈øt wa≈øh the throat as near the root of the Tongue as may be with a linnen cloth, tied to a ≈øtick dipped in this Gargari≈øm; Take of new extracted Ca≈ø≈øia one dram, ≈øyrup of dry Ro≈øes one dram and a half, ≈øix ounces of the decoction of Coriander. Or you may anoint the Neck with Oyl of Violets, and Camomile, binding the Neck with a
little roller well anointed with the ≈øame; when the Child goes to bed, you may give him in a ≈øpoon a little ≈øyrup of dried Ro≈øes, of Pavot and Nenuphar mingled together, Oxycrate alone doth make an excellent Gargari≈øm.

If they come to a Suppuration, you mu≈øt u≈øe this Gargari≈øm: Take of the decoction of Barley, Plantain, Agrimony, Speedwell, Honey-≈øuckle, and herb Rob ≈øix ounces; in which di≈ø≈øolve Honey of Ro≈øes, and Sugar-Candy, of each half an ounce, to make a Gargari≈øm.

div.head: Of Vomiting.
div.p: IF it proceed from abundance of milk which the Child ≈øucks, you mu≈øt take care that the Child ≈øuck le≈øs and often.

If it come from any ill humor contained in the ≈øtomach, be≈øides that the Nur≈øe mu≈øt keep a very good diet, the Infant mu≈øt be purged with a ≈ømall expre≈ø≈øion of Rheubarb, giving it afterwards a little Mint-water, ≈øweetned with ≈øyrup of Quinces to comfort the ≈øtomach; putting afterwards upon his ≈øtomach this Plai≈øter: Take of the pulp of condited Quinces two ounces, red Ro≈øes, Wormwood, and red Saunders, of each two drams, Oyl of Quinces as much as ≈øufficeth; make a plai≈øter of this, and lay it upon the ≈øtomach of the Child.

div.head: Of the Hicquet.
div.p:
IF it come from an over much repletion, it will not be ami≈øs to make him Vomit, of what≈øoever age he be; or if it be nece≈ø≈øary that a greater force ≈øhould be u≈øed, you mu≈øt try to make him Vomit by putting down the Throat a feather dipt in oyl: If from the badne≈øs of the Nur≈øes mi ‚Ä¢ k, ≈øhe mu≈øt be changed for a better; if from the coldne≈øs of the ≈øtomach, you mu≈øt u≈øe remedies to comfort it, as little Tablets of Diarrhodon,
of which you mu≈øt di≈ø≈øolve a ≈øcruple in the Milk of the Nur≈øe; you mu≈øt al≈øo chafe the ≈øtomach of the Child with Oyl of Wormwood, Ma≈øtick, and Quinces.

div.head: Of the pain of the Belly in Children.
div.p: IF the di≈øea≈øe come from indige≈øtion, and moi≈øtne≈øs, the little Infant will Vomit, and be troubled with a Flux of the Belly, and the Belly will be hard. In which ca≈øe, you may give the Infant one ounce of ≈øweet Almonds drawn without fire, and mingled with a quantity of Sugar-candy, or anoint the Belly with this ointment: Take Oyl of Camomile, and Oyl of ≈øweet Almonds, of each an ounce and a half, mingle them, and therewith anoint the Belly: If wind be the cau≈øe, you may mingle a little Oyl of Rue in the fore≈øaid Oyntment.

div.head: Of the Small Pox in Children.
div.p: THE ≈øigns of this di≈øea≈øe are pains in the Head, accompanied with a Fever, redne≈øs about the Eyes, a dry Cough, and you ≈øhall mark in the skin up and down the body, certain little ≈øpots upon the Face, Back, Brea≈øt, and Thighs. The ≈ømall Pox is dangerous if they come forth with much pain, if they be greeni≈øh, blewi≈øh, or blacki≈øh.
For the cure of this; If the Infant ≈øuck, the Nur≈øe mu≈øt keep a good order of diet, ≈øhe may eat broth of Hens, with Endive, Cichory, Buglo≈øs, and Borage boiled therein.

Now to make the ≈ømall Pox come forth the more quickly; if the Child be little, the Nur≈øe mu≈øt drink this following Potion. Take of fat Figs one ounce, peeled Lentils half an ounce, Gum Lacca two drams, Gum Tragacanth, and Fennel-≈øeed, of each two drams and a half; make of this a decoction in Fountain-water, and ≈øtrain it to the quantity of two pints, ≈øweeten
this either with Sugar, or ≈øyrup of Maiden-hair; let her drink of this in the morning a good gla≈øs full.

Or, you may give the Child, if it be able to take it, this Julep to be u≈øed very often: Take of Cordial-waters two ounces and a half, ≈øyrup of Lemons one ounce, mingle it, and u≈øe it often; four or five hours after, give him of powder of Unicorns-horn, and Bezoar. Now to keep this venomous humor from attacking the eyes, temper a little Saffron in a ≈ømall quantity of Plantain and Ro≈øe-water, and rub the eye-lids, or you may anoint them with Tutie: For keeping them from the No≈øe; take Ro≈øe-water, and Betony-water, of each an ounce, Vinegar half an ounce, juyce of Pomegranates ≈øix ounces, in which ≈øteep two drams of Sanders, and two drams of the powder of Citron-peel; add to this ≈øix grains of Saffron, and make a Medicine for the Child to ≈ømell often to; the ≈øame Medicine will ≈øerve for the ears, by ≈øtopping them with a little Cotton.

To pre≈øerve the Mouth and Throat, and Tongue, take this Gargari≈øm; Take whole Barley one handful, Plantain leaves, leaves of Sorrel, Arnoglo≈øs, Agrimony, and Vervein, of each one handful; boyl this to the quantity of ≈øix ounces, di≈ø≈øolving in it ≈øyrup of dry Ro≈øes, and Pomgranates, of each half an ounce, Saffron half a ≈øcruple.

To pre≈øerve the Lungs, u≈øe ≈øyrup of Jujubes, Violets, and Nenuphar; when they are fully come out, to make them die the more quickly, rub the Face with Oyl of ≈øweet Almonds drawn without fire. Or u≈øe this Oyntment; Take old Lard, cut it in ≈ømall pieces, and melt it in a pot, then ≈øtrain it, then beat it, and mingle it with water for your u≈øe.

When the Pox is totally dead, take this Remedy to take away the marks. Take Half the weight of two
Crowns, clear Cream two ounces, mix them together, and with a Feather dipt therein anoint the Face of the Child two or three days; this cau≈øeth the skin to grow ≈ømooth, leaving not a pit in the Face.

div.head: A Full SUPPLY

argument.p: Of ≈øuch mo≈øt u≈øeful and admirable Secrets, which Mr. Nicholas Culpepper in his brief Treati≈øe, and other Engli≈øh Writers in the Art of Midwifery, have hitherto wilfully pa≈ø≈øed by, kept clo≈øe to them≈øelves, and wholly omitted; now at la≈øt made publick for the general good:

div.head: CHAP. I. In what manner the Generative, or Begetting Seed hath its beginning; and particularly of the four Degrees of Concoction.
div.p: THAT we may the better di≈øcern the whole cour≈øe and order of Generation, I have thought it convenient to demon≈øtrate how great a ≈øimilitude it bears with the production of Plants: but fir≈øt it is nece≈ø≈øary to take notice what Generative Seed is, and how extracted out of the three Concoctions.

We may ob≈øerve the natural Procreation of man to be altogether ≈øuch, as we perceive the generation and beginning of Plants or Herbs of every kind to be: For
as they every one of them from the Seed of his Kind, ca≈øt into the Womb of the Earth, do bud or increa≈øe, and do naturally grow to the perfect Form of its proper Nature: So Man al≈øo being a rea≈øonable Creature according to the quality of the Body, doth naturally draw his Original and Begining from the ≈øperm and ≈øeed of Man, projected and ca≈øt forth into the Womb of Woman, as into a Field: But that matter of Generation which we call ≈øperm or ≈øeed, by its original and nature, is only a ≈øuperfluous Humor, the re≈øidue and remainder, I ≈øay, of the nutriment and food, and the ≈øuperfluity of the third concoction in the Body, derived and conveyed along through the hidden and ≈øecret organs or in≈øtruments from the chiefe≈øt Members of the body unto the generative parts, and ≈øerveth for generation And it hath its beginning and breeding from the re≈øidues and remnants of all the meats belonging to the nouri≈øhment of Man, after they be altered and tran≈ømuted even to the third Concoction: Of the ≈øuperfluity of which concocted food collected and gathered together in its proper and due manner, it is evident that the ≈øame is ingendred, according to the con≈øtitution of the age and nature; for there is made a three-fold concoction of any meat, altered and converted into the nouri≈øhment of the living Creature, even to generation of ≈øeed, that concoction neverthele≈øs following, which is the pure≈øt of all Concoctions: For the Food being ≈øent down into the ≈øtomach, by chewing ≈øtreightway the pure Nutriment which is ordained to the other part (the dry Excrement being driven downward thorough the Guts to the Belly) through the ≈øucking Veins (named in Latin me≈øaraicae) carried as it were to one Gate flowing out of innumerable Channels, is brought to the Liver; where to the di≈øpo≈øition of the former concoction, made in the ≈øtomach, there is forthwith
made the ≈øecond concoction in the Liver of the food derived unto it, the ≈øuperfluous matter being ≈øeparated, that is to ≈øay, both kinds of choler, and the watri≈øh humour drawn and attracted by the emulgent ve≈ø≈øels (in Latin va≈øa emulgentia) that it being ≈øtrained through the kidnies, might de≈øcend down into the bladder; then the re≈øidue, refined and clean≈øed in the Liver by this concoction, that is to ≈øay blood, is conveyed over to the Heart, to receive its vital admini≈øtration and office. In the Heart again, is made the third Concoction of the food being received at one time; for there blood having taken unto it vital and lively ≈øpirit, being diffu≈øed and ≈øent abroad throughout the ≈øeveral members of the body, doth again expel and void out that which is ≈øuperfluous in it ≈øelf, by the ≈øecret pores and pa≈ø≈øages. At length here the Spirit changeth and turneth the blood conveyed through the ≈øpermatical or ≈øeed-ve≈ø≈øels (being branches of vena cava) there al≈øo further concocted into the nature of ≈øperm or ≈øeed, by the twined revolutions and back-turnings of the ≈ømalle≈øt ve≈ø≈øels for this purpo≈øe, and by the glandulous or kernel'd ≈øub≈øtance of the Te≈øticles, and the ≈øeed pa≈ø≈øages (which they call Para≈øtatae) available in that behalf: So the blood, exqui≈øitely wrought and laboured, and for the mo≈øt part converted into vital ≈øpirits, is ≈øtraight-way conveyed by the Artery named Aorta, and branches thereof to all the other Members of the whole body. But in the fourth place (that we may add one thing over and above our purpo≈øe) there is made an alteration of the food into the like ≈øub≈øtance of the thing nouri≈øhed, this juyce quickning and ≈øtrengthning life, which being the pure≈øt of all, remained la≈øtly with the vital ≈øpirit; that in like ≈øort being expelled, if any impure thing ≈øhall be remaining or engendred.

div.head: CHAP. II. The Generation of Man, compared with the production of Plants.
div.p:
THAT the rea≈øon of this Generation may be made the more plain and evident unto us, we will declare by a brief demon≈øtration, that there is the ≈øame begining of Plants and Herbs, and of other things which fall under the ≈øame con≈øideration; therefore as in the ≈øeeds of every kind, the grain it ≈øelf ca≈øt into the Earth, is the food, and as it were the fir≈øt ≈øubject of all the alteration following, whereby it buds and ≈øprings, is augmented and grows up into a nature like unto it; ≈øo meat being taken, affordeth in mans body the fir≈øt matter to a variable concoction. And as in Plants we may ob≈øerve a mo≈øt certain ≈øeparation of the pure from the impure, and of the remnant from the ≈øuperfluous matter; ≈øo here we perceive a natural ≈øeparation and ≈øeque≈øtration of that which is unprofitable, from that which is profitable, by their certain degrees: For fir≈øt the ≈øeed being committed to the Earth, by and by ≈øwelling with the moi≈øture of the ≈øame, ≈øtrippeth it ≈øelf from that little skin, in which it was inclo≈øed, and ≈øpringing upward, ca≈øteth forth the ≈øame being empty, as a dry Excrement, the grain in the mean time budding and ≈øprouting forth, that it may proceed forward toward the increa≈øe; afterward the increa≈øe and growth ≈øtretching even to the fruit di≈ørobed and bereaved of the Flower, the ≈øecond purging ca≈øteth down the flower ≈øprung up in the top of the bough, but pre≈øerveth the hope of the Fruit, being ≈øtripped of his flower, as that thing which remaineth pure and profitable by the ≈øecond purging. Afterwards the Fruit being grown to its ju≈øt quantity, the third alteration ca≈øteth down the leaves, as the ≈øuperfluity of this degree; but ordaineth the fruit, being now ≈øo often
clean≈øed and purged, for the utility of mans nouri≈øhment, maturity, and ripene≈øs being granted unto it. Put now, either the ≈øeed breaketh, the fruit lying hid in it, or el≈øe it ≈øendeth it out by putrefaction; and being ca≈øt into the ground it ha≈øteneth again into the property of its own nature, not tending towards it ≈øelf, which is remaining, but to the likene≈øs of its fir≈øt original, from whence it had its begining; ≈øo that in this it appeareth ab≈øolutely true, that Nature ingendereth things like unto it ≈øelf; for every thing doth naturally covet and de≈øire the form and likene≈øs of that form whence it is bred: Hence it comes to pa≈øs, that Apples grow not from Pears, nor Pears from any other kind of fruit, unle≈øs it be ≈øo brought about by the means of grafting and planting. And the ≈øame thing is to be acknowledged in the generation of Man and Woman, which is to be confe≈ø≈øed in the growing of Plants and Herbs; that becau≈øe we ≈øee bodies well di≈øtingui≈øhed by Members to be engendred of ≈øeed, we may al≈øo believe that the ≈øame ≈øeed is derived from the di≈øtinct and ≈øeveral parts of the body; wherefore let tho≈øe be advi≈øed what they ≈øay, who affirm the ≈øeed of generation to be ingendred of the Brain only, when as it is not ≈øo agreeable to the con≈øideration of the Concoctions, nor to the con≈øtitution of the bodies. True it is, that ≈øome, and that not a ≈ømall part, is derived from the Brain, but the chiefe≈øt part is collected together from the chiefe≈øt parts of the whole body: For if we ≈øay, that this ≈øhould be ingendred of one or two parts only; every one would find that this con≈øequence would follow by an infallible rea≈øon, namely, that tho≈øe ≈øame parts only ≈øhould be ingendred again: Therefore we may more rightly conclude, that be≈øides that beginning which it draweth from the Brain, it is ingendred from the whole body, and the mo≈øt e≈øpecial parts of the ≈øame,
the effect it ≈øelf manife≈øting the cau≈øe, mo≈øt e≈øpecially when we ≈øee di≈øtinct members, and perfectly fini≈øht, according to the due form of the body, and ≈øo truly, that the thing begotten doth an≈øwer and agree to the con≈øtitution of the thing begetting; of feeble ≈øeed, a feeble man being born; of ≈øtrong ≈øeed, a ≈øtrong and lu≈øty man: By which means it happeneth that we many times ≈øee the infirmities and ill favoured marks of the body in the Children, which are inherent in the Parents, and the≈øe we firmly believe to have pa≈ø≈øed into them by the corruption of the ≈øeed. And the≈øe things thus determined, may ≈øuffice to have been ≈øpoken concerning the beginning and ≈øub≈øtance of Ingendring Seed.

div.head: CHAP. III. What cour≈øe Parents ought to take that they may beget wi≈øe Children.
div.p:
IT may well be admired, what the rea≈øon ≈øhould be, that Nature being ≈øo wi≈øe and provident in all her actings, ≈øhould neverthele≈øs be ≈øo over≈øeen in a work of ≈øo ≈øpecial regard as Mankind, that for one whom ≈øhe produceth wi≈øe, ≈øolid and judicious, ≈øhe bringeth ≈øo many into the World of tho≈øe that are ≈øhallow, half witted, and void of prudence: But having ≈øeriou≈øly con≈øider'd with my ≈øelf, and ≈øearcht into the rea≈øon of natural cau≈øes of this ≈øo ≈øtrange a matter; I ea≈øily found the true rea≈øon to be this, namely, that Parents apply not them≈øelves to the act of generation, with that order and diligence that is required by nature, nor know the conditions which ought to be ob≈øerved, that their Children may prove wi≈øe and judicious. Now if by art we may procure a remedy for this, we ≈øhall have brought to the Common-wealth the greate≈øt benefit ≈øhe can receive. The main difficulty of this matter
chiefly con≈øi≈øteth herein, that we cannot di≈øcour≈øe hereof in terms ≈øo ≈øeemly and mode≈øt, as exact decency would require; but if for this rea≈øon I ≈øhould forbear to in≈øi≈øt upon any particular note or ob≈øervation, the whole bu≈øine≈øs would be of ≈ømall validity; fora≈ømuch as divers grave Authors are of opinion, that wi≈øe men ordinarily beget fooli≈øh Children, becau≈øe in the act of Copulation they ab≈øtain from certain diligences, which are of importance that the Son may partake of the Fathers Wi≈ødom.

For the more Methodical proceeding, I have thought good to divide the matter of this di≈øcour≈øe into four principal parts. The fir≈øt is to ≈øhew the natural qualities and temperature which Man and Woman ought to po≈ø≈øe≈øs, that they may u≈øe Generation. The ≈øecond, what diligence the Parents ought to imploy, that their Children may be male, and not Female. The third, how they may become wi≈øe and not fools. The fourth, how they are to be ordered after their birth for pre≈øervation of their wit. As to the fir≈øt point: Divers both ancient and modern Authors have delivered their opinions to this effect, that in a well ordered Common-wealth, there ought to be a≈ø≈øigned certain ≈øurveyors of Marriages, who ≈øhould have skill and judgment ≈øufficient to look into the qualities of the per≈øons that are to be married; and to allot to every woman a husband, and to every man a wife agreeable and proportionable to them in all re≈øpects: But whether ≈øuch a thing be of ab≈øolute nece≈ø≈øity in a State, or no, let it lye upon the care and con≈øideration of ≈øuch as take upon them to manage, and di≈øpo≈øe the affairs of Common-wealths. Hippocrates and Galen took much pains in pre≈øcribing certain Precepts about this matter, with ≈øeveral rules to know what ≈øort of Women were fruitful, and what not; what men were able for generation, and what di≈øable:
But touching all this, they deliver very little to the purpo≈øe, and that not with ≈øuch di≈øtinction as is requi≈øite for the bu≈øine≈øs in hand, therefore it will be nece≈ø≈øary to begin this di≈øcour≈øe from its principles, and briefly to give the ≈øame its due order and method that ≈øo we may plainly and clearly demon≈øtrate from what Union of Parents wi≈øe children are generated, and from what fools and faineants i≈ø≈øue. To which end is needful: Fir≈øt to be informed of a particular point of Philo≈øophy, upon the knowledge of which depends all that which is to be delivered touching this fir≈øt point; and that's this, that man is different from Woman in nothing el≈øe, as Galen al≈øo ob≈øerves, than in having his genital Members without his body whereas a woman hath all the very ≈øame parts within, ≈øo that if, when nature hath fini≈øhed her work in the formation of man, ≈øhe would convert him into a Woman, there needs nothing el≈øe to be done, ≈øaving only to turn the Organs of generation inward, and if, having formed a woman ≈øhe would transform her to a man, ≈øhe may effect it by doing the contrary: But whether or no the≈øe things have hapned, as ≈øome affirm they have, and of the certainty of Hermaphrodites being found in nature, may more commodiou≈øly be referred to a di≈øcour≈øe by it ≈øelf. Now what might be the cau≈øe that the genital Members are ingendred within, or without, and that the creature becometh Male or Female, is a thing plain and evident enough to demon≈øtrate, con≈øidering that heat extendeth and enlargeth all things, and cold retaineth and clo≈øeth them up; ≈øo that it is concluded by all that are knowing in Philo≈øophy and natural cau≈øes, that if the ≈øeed be cold and moi≈øt, a woman is begotten, not a man: And if the ≈øame be hot and dry, a man is begotten, not a Woman: Whence it is to be inferred, that there is no man to be termed cold in re≈øpect of a woman, nor woman hot in re≈øpect of a man.

This therefore is to be noted as a thing without all controver≈øie or exception, that the qualities which render a woman fruitful, are cold and moi≈øture, the womb holding the ≈øame proportion with mans ≈øeed, that the earth doth with Corn or any other grain; and we ≈øee, that if the earth want cold and moi≈øture, the ≈øeed will not pro≈øper; and that tho≈øe are the mo≈øt fertile ≈øoyls which partake mo≈øt of cold and moi≈øt: yet the≈øe two qualities ought to keep a certain mea≈øurablene≈øs, le≈øt that, either by exce≈øs, or deficiency, generation be ≈øpoyled; for as the Corn is vitiated by exce≈øs of rain, and overmuch cold; ≈øo in conception the ≈øeed may be choaked by over-abundance of the≈øe qualities; and on the other ≈øide, if tho≈øe parts in a woman ≈øhould be temperate as in a man, it were impo≈ø≈øible ≈øhe ≈øhould conceive, or be a woman: Nor could ≈øhe breed that flegmatick blood which ingendereth milk, by which, as Galen and Hypocrates affirm, the birth is nouri≈øhed while it remaineth in the mothers belly; neither could ≈øhe be beardle≈øs, or void of hair, if ≈øhe were overmuch inclining to hot and dry. Neverthele≈øs, all women are not cold and moi≈øt alike, there being of the≈øe qualities ≈øeveral degrees, ≈øome being cold and moi≈øt in the fir≈øt degree, ≈øome in the ≈øecond, ≈øome in the third, and in each of the≈øe they may conceive, if a man an≈øwer them in proportion of heat. As for the ≈øigns of the≈øe ≈øeveral degrees of coldne≈øs and moi≈øture in women, though hitherto they have not been taken notice of by any, yet it will be very requi≈øite in this place to con≈øider them according to the ≈øeveral effects, which each of the≈øe degrees produceth. Fir≈øt, by the quick apprehen≈øion and acutene≈øs of wit in women, for if they be very witty and acute, they are to be judged cold and moi≈øt in the fir≈øt degree only; if very ≈øhallow and ≈øimple, in the third degree, but if they partake of a middle nature
between the≈øe two extreams, it ≈øignifieth that they are in the ≈øecond degree. Secondly, their Conditions; they being either cur≈øt, or good natured, according to the≈øe three degrees. Thirdly, their voice; which is either ≈øhrill, or big according as they are more or le≈øs cold and moi≈øt. Fourthly, their ≈øub≈øtance in fle≈øh; leanne≈øs being a ≈øign of little coldne≈øs and moi≈øture; gro≈øne≈øs or over much corpulency, of the redundance of tho≈øe qualities: to be meanly fle≈øhed, betokeneth the ≈øecond degree. Fifthly, the colour of their face; which is either white, or ≈øwarthy, as the≈øe qualities are inten≈øe or remi≈øs; of the ≈øecond degree is compo≈øed a fre≈øh and lively colour. Sixthly, their hair; which is al≈øo either much, or little, according to the exuberance, or defect of cold and moi≈øt. Seventhly, a hand≈øom form and proportion of body is the re≈øult of the middlemo≈øt degree; deformity ari≈øing from either Extream.

Now from all the≈øe Signs it may be concluded, that tho≈øe women who are cold and moi≈øt in the ≈øecond degree, are of the perfecte≈øt temper, and in the be≈øt capacity, as to their own proper nature, of bringing forth Children.

div.head: CHAP. IV. The ≈øigns to know the ≈øeveral degrees of hot and dry in a Man.
div.p:
AS there are in Women three degrees of cold and moi≈øt, ≈øo likewi≈øe in Men there are as many of hot and dry; and the ≈øame ≈øigns which di≈øcover tho≈øe in women, ≈øpecifie the≈øe in men; only, the fir≈øt, or remi≈øs degree in women holdeth a proportion with the third, or inten≈øe degree in men; as namely, whereas among women tho≈øe have the bigge≈øt voices that are cold and moi≈øt in the fir≈øt degree; the like is to be concluded
of men that are hot and dry in the third, the defect in tho≈øe an≈øwering to the exce≈øs in the≈øe: now to under≈øtand the≈øe temperatures the more exactly, we mu≈øt take notice of a very ob≈øervable point mentioned by Galen, which is; that the temperature of all parts of the body, e≈øpecially the brain, follows the temperature of the Te≈øticles: and he affirmeth that they are of more importance than the Heart, alledging this rea≈øon; namely, that the Heart is the beginning of the life only, but the Te≈øticles are the beginning of living healthfully, and without di≈øtempers.

div.head: CHAP. V. What Women ought to marry with what men, that they may have Children.
div.p:
IN re≈øpect of married Women that prove Childle≈øs, Hypocrates advi≈øeth this experiment to be tried, to know whether the defect be on the Womans part, or on her Husbands, which is to make her ≈øuffumigations with Incen≈øe, or Storax, with a Garment clo≈øe wrapped about her, which may hang down on the ground, in ≈øuch ≈øort, that no vapor, or fume may i≈ø≈øue out, and if within a while after ≈øhe feel the ≈øavour of the Incen≈øe in her mouth, ≈øhe may conclude that the barrenne≈øs comes not through her own defect, but through her husbands; for as much as the fumes found the pa≈ø≈øages open, whereby it pierced up to the No≈øtrils: But although this proof perform that effect which Hippocrates ≈øpeaketh of, namely, the piercing up to the inner part of the mouth; yet this is no infallible argument of the Husbands barrenne≈øs, nor of the fruitfulne≈øs of the Wife: Since want of Children may ari≈øe through an unapt di≈øpo≈øition in them both, in re≈øpect of the corre≈øpondency of qualities, for it hath oftentimes hapned that a man who could not have Children by one
wife, hath had them by another; the like al≈øo hath befallen Women. What the corre≈øpondency ≈øhould be, which the man and wife ought to bear each to other, is expre≈ø≈øed by Hypocrates in the≈øe words. If the hot an≈øwer not the cold, and the dry the moi≈øt, with mea≈øure and quantity; that is, if there meet not in the Womb two Seeds, the one hot, the other cold, the one dry, the other moi≈øt, extended in equal degree, there can be no generation: For ≈øo marvellous a work as the formation of Man could not be perform'd, without a proportionable commixture of ≈øeeds, which could not be, if the mans ≈øeed and the womans were both of the ≈øame temperature.
