To exemplify what I have ≈øaid, it is to be concluded, that a woman who is wily, ill-condition'd, ≈øhrill-voiced, lean, ≈øwarthy-coloured, and deformed, (which are the ≈øigns of cold, and moi≈øt in the fir≈øt degree) may conceive by a man who is ignorant, good natured, ≈øweet voic'd, corpulent, having little hair, a well-coloured face, and a hand≈øome body, which are the ≈øigns of hot and dry in the fir≈øt degree; a woman cold and moi≈øt in the ≈øecond degree, in regard ≈øhe retaineth a mean in all tho≈øe ≈øigns above-mentioned is mo≈øt like to be fruitful, becau≈øe ≈øhe comes neare≈øt in proportion to men of each ≈øeveral temperature: But from the fir≈øt of the≈øe Unions or Conjoynings of man and woman, are mo≈øt likely to i≈ø≈øue the wi≈øe≈øt children, becau≈øe the dryne≈øs of the mother, correcteth and amendeth the defect of the father. Moreover, it is requi≈øite that women be dryed by a mature age, and not marry over young; for from thence it comes to pa≈øs mo≈øt commonly, that children prove ≈øhallow, and indued with little wit.

div.head: CHAP. VI. What cour≈øe is to be taken that Male Children be brought into the World, not Female.
div.p:
THo≈øe who ≈øee the comfort of having wi≈øe Children, mu≈øt indeavour that they be born Male; for the Female, through the cold and moi≈øtne≈øs of their Sex, cannot be endowed with ≈øo profound a judgment. We find indeed, that they talk with appearance of knowledge in ≈ølight and ea≈øie matters, but ≈øeldom reach any further than to a ≈ølight ≈øuperficial ≈ømattering in any deep Science. It is a thing very well worth ob≈øervation, that, whereas the right ≈øide of the reins, and the right te≈øticle, are naturally more hot and dry, and the left ≈øide of the reins with the left te≈øticle, more hot and moi≈øt, Nature ≈øeems to have intended that which at the beginning of the World is recorded in Hi≈øtory to have been very frequent; as namely, that a woman brought forth two Children at a birth, the one Male, the other Female, the right ≈øide which is hot and dry, being a≈ø≈øigned to the generation of Males‚ñ™ the left ≈øide which is cold and moi≈øt, to the generation of Females, and it ≈øeems to have been ≈øo ordained, to that end, that for every man there might be a wife: But after the Earth came to be well increa≈øed with people, it hapned as it appears, that this method and de≈øign of Nature was broken off, and now not only the double Child-bearing is very rare, but a far greater number of women are daily brought forth into the World than men: Whence it is to be gathered, that either Nature is grown weary, or el≈øe interrupted in her cour≈øe of working: However, ≈øince this defect of Nature is to be remedied with care and diligence, if men would imploy their ≈øerious con≈øiderations in a matter of ≈øuch importance; there are ≈øix things to be ob≈øerved
by tho≈øe that would obtain the accompli≈øhment of their de≈øire, in the de≈øign whereof this Chapter treats. The fir≈øt is, the eating tho≈øe ≈øorts of meats which are hot and dry, provided they have not tho≈øe qualities in too high an exce≈øs, le≈øt thereof be engenderd a man extreamly wily and malicious, and ≈øuch a one who≈øe actions may prove pernicious to the Common-wealth; but rather let tho≈øe viands be hot and dry in a moderate degree, ≈øuch as are Hens, Partridges, Turtles, Thru≈øhes, Goats, &c. and tho≈øe roa≈øted. The ≈øecond thing is the feeding ≈øo moderately, that the ≈øtomach may overcome and dige≈øt that meat which is eaten; for tho≈øe very ≈øorts of meat which are in their proper nature hot and dry, yet being eaten in ≈øo great a quantity, that the nature cannot dige≈øt them, they become cold and moi≈øt al≈øo, the immoderate drinking Wine is ab≈øolutely to be forbidden, there being no rawne≈øs which ≈øo much endamageth generation, as that of Wine, being ≈øo vaporous and ≈øubtle a Liquor. Whereupon a Law was anciently enacted in the Carthaginian Commonwealth, which prohibited the married couple to ta≈øte of Wine that day they were to perform the rights of the Marriage Bed. The third is, to u≈øe much exerci≈øe, which by fretting and con≈øuming the exce≈ø≈øive moi≈øture of the Seed, heateth and dryeth the ≈øame; whereas ea≈øe, and overmuch delicacy breedeth coldne≈øs and moi≈øture in the Seed. And hence it comes to pa≈øs, that rich and great per≈øons that live at ea≈øe and feed high, have for the mo≈øt part Daughters: And Hypocrates reporteth that the principal per≈øons of the ancient Scythians, who were very effeminate and womani≈øh, mo≈øt commonly either begot Females, or el≈øe they proved either Eunuches, or Hermaphrodites: and being ignorant of the natural cau≈øe of this defect, he ≈øaith (and derides them for it)
that they u≈øed to ≈øacrifice to their gods, imploring from them a remedy of that which was an effect of their mi≈ø-governance. The fourth diligence is, not to u≈øe the act of Generation untill the Seed be well concocted and ripened, it being convenient for ≈øeven or eight days before, to u≈øe tho≈øe meats which we have already pre≈øcribed, and ob≈øerving the ≈øame cour≈øe as Gardiners do with the Seeds which they would pre≈øerve; for they attend till they ripen, and clean≈øe, and wax dry, ≈øince if they ≈øhould pluck them from the ≈øtalk before they are deeply ≈øea≈øoned, and arrived to that point which is to be required, though they ≈øhould lye in the ground never ≈øo long, they would not grow at all. The fifth point, for a man to accompany with his Wife four or five days before her natural Cour≈øes, in regard the Child immediately ≈øtandeth in need of much food to nouri≈øh it. The ≈øixth and la≈øt point is to procure, that both the Seed of the Husband and Wife fall into the right ≈øide of the Womb, by which means it hapneth that Males are ingendred; the rea≈øon of which is, as Galen affirmeth, that the right ≈øide of the Womb holdeth affinity in temperature with the Liver, the right ≈øide of the Reins, and the right Te≈øticle, which we have already delivered to be more hot, as the left ≈øide is more cold, by which Females are ingendered: To the≈øe things there is another con≈øideration to be added, which Galen hath al≈øo ob≈øerved, namely, that the Seed of each Te≈øticle, are of a different nature, for whereas that of the right Te≈øticle cometh out more hot, more ≈øpeedily, and in a le≈ø≈øer quantity, that of the left cometh out more cold, more ≈ølowly, and in greater abundance.

div.head: CHAP. VII. What means are to be u≈øed for pre≈øerving the Childrens wit, after they are formed.
div.p:
MAN is compounded of a ≈øub≈øtance ≈øo ≈øubject to alteration and corruption, that at the ≈øame in≈øtant in which he begins to be formed, he al≈øo begins to fade and decline; whereupon Nature hath provided, that in mans body there ≈øhould be four natural faculties: Attractive, Retentive, Concoctive, and Expul≈øive; the fir≈øt, concocting and altering the aliments which we eat, return to repair the ≈øub≈øtance that was lo≈øt, each ≈øucceeding in his place; So that it little availeth to have ingendered a Child of the perfecte≈øt Seed, if we make no choice of the meats which afterwards we feed upon: For the Creation being fini≈øhed, there remaineth not for the creature any part of the ≈øub≈øtance whereof it was compo≈øed. True it is, that the fir≈øt Seed, if it be well concocted, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth ≈øuch vertue, that dige≈øting, and altering the meats, it maketh them (though bad and gro≈øs of them≈øelves) to turn to its own good temperature and ≈øub≈øtance; but yet we may ≈øo far forth u≈øe contrary meats, as the creature ≈øhall lo≈øe tho≈øe good qualities which it receiveth from the ≈øeed whereof it was made; therefore Plato ≈øaid, that one of the things which mo≈øt brought mans wit and his manners to ruine, was, his evil bringing up in diet: For which cau≈øe, he coun≈øelled that we ≈øhould give children delicate meats and drinks, and of good temperature, that, as they grow up, they may know to abandon evil, and embrace good; the rea≈øon whereof is very clear: For, ≈øince at the beginning the brain was made of delicate ≈øeed, and that this member is every day impairing and con≈øuming, and is to be repaired with meats which we eat; it followeth certainly,
that by u≈øing ≈øuch meats as are gro≈øs, and of evil temperature, the brains will become of the ≈øame nature: Therefore it will not ≈øuffice that the Child is born of good ≈øeed; but al≈øo that the meat which he eateth after he is born, be indued with the ≈øame qualities.

The ancient Greeks were very curious in this particular; Galen, and other Greek Phy≈øicians, pre≈øcribed to tho≈øe parents who were de≈øirous of begetting wi≈øe children, to eat much Goats milk boyled, for about ≈øeven or eight days before Copulation; this meat being of a moderate ≈øub≈øtance, the heat exceeding not the cold, nor the moi≈øt the dry. The Greeks al≈øo u≈øed to extract out of the milk, the Chee≈øe and Whey, as being the gro≈ø≈øer parts of the Milk, and left the butter; which being of a more ≈øpairy ≈øub≈øtance, they gave their Children, mingling it with Honey. They al≈øo gave them Cracknels of white bread, of very delicate water, with Honey, and a little Salt. But yet, in this way of regiment and ordering of the diet, there ari≈øeth one great Inconvenience; namely, that children u≈øing ≈øuch kind of delicate meats, will not enjoy ≈øtrength ≈øufficient to re≈øi≈øt the injuries of the Air, or other occa≈øions which u≈øe to breed Maladies: And ≈øo by endeavouring that our Children may become wi≈øe, we ≈øhall cau≈øe them to become unhealthful, and ≈øhort-liv'd; Therefore it is to be con≈øidered, how things may be ≈øo ordered, that the advancing of Childrens wit by their diet and education, may not prove incon≈øi≈øtent with the pre≈øervation of their health and ≈øtrength; which may be ea≈øily effected, if Parents will put in practice the≈øe Rules and Precepts which I ≈øhall pre≈øcribe. Hypocrates takes notice of eight things which make the fle≈øh plump and fat: The fir≈øt is, to be merry, and enjoy content and ea≈øe of heart; the ≈øecond, to ≈øleep
much; the third, to lie in a ≈øoft bed; the fourth, to fare well; the fifth, to be well furni≈øhed and apparelled; the ≈øixth, to ride much on hor≈øeback; the ≈øeventh, to have ones will, and not be cro≈ø≈øed in any thing; the eighth, to be much conver≈øant in all kind of Plays and pa≈øtimes, that yield contentment and delight. That this manner of life produceth the afore≈øaid effect, is mo≈øt true; but is likewi≈øe true, that it cau≈øeth the ≈øeed to be moi≈øt, and that the children engendred of that Seed, mu≈øt al≈øo abound with ≈øuperfluous moi≈øture, which both for the production of Wit, and the pre≈øervation of health, ought to be dried up; for as much as this quality ≈øtifleth the operations of the rational ≈øoul, and al≈øo occa≈øioneth ≈øickne≈øs and ≈øhort life: So that it appears, that a good wit, and a ≈øound body, ari≈øe from one and the ≈øame quality, namely, dryne≈øs; whence it is to be ob≈øerved, that the ≈øame rules which we are to lay down for the making Children wi≈øe, will al≈øo be effectual for the making of them healthy and long lived.

Fir≈øt, it behoveth for tho≈øe Children that are born of delicious Parents, who≈øe con≈øtitution mu≈øt therefore nece≈ø≈øarily con≈øi≈øt of more cold and moi≈øt than is convenient, to be wa≈øhed as ≈øoon as they are born with hot ≈øalt water, which, according to the opinion of all Phy≈øitians, ≈øoaketh and drieth up the fle≈øh, ≈øtrengthneth the Nerves, and by con≈øuming the ≈øuperfluous moi≈øture of the brain, increa≈øeth the wit, and freeth him from many dangerous Di≈øea≈øes; whereas a Bath of hot water that is fre≈øh, breeds (as Hypocrates affirmeth) five inconveniences; namely, the effeminating of the fle≈øh, weakne≈øs of the ≈øinews, dulne≈øs of the ≈øpirits, fluxes of the blood, and a nau≈øeating in the ≈øtomach: But tho≈øe that are born with exce≈ø≈øive dryne≈øs, are to be bathed in hot fre≈øh water, that the extremity of their temper may be corrected by a contrary quality. Now the rea≈øon
why hot ≈øalt water is available for tho≈øe that are over moi≈øt, is, becau≈øe it ≈øtoppeth the pores of the skin, and of two extreams, it is more conducing to health to have a skin hard and ≈øomewhat clo≈øe, than thin and open.

The ≈øecond thing requi≈øite to be performed when the Child is new born, is to make him acquainted with the winds, and with change of air, and not to keep him lockt up in a Chamber, which much enfeebleth the ≈øtrength, and wa≈øteth the ≈øpirits; nothing being ≈øo advantageous to a healthful kind of living, as to expo≈øe ones ≈øelf to all kind of winds and weathers, hot, moi≈øt, cold and dry; it is no wonder therefore that Shepherds of all men living enjoy the ≈øounde≈øt health, ≈øince they accu≈øtom them≈øelves to all the ≈øeveral qualities of the Air, and their nature is di≈ømayed at nothing; whereas on the contrary we find that tho≈øe men that give them≈øelves to live deliciou≈øly, and to beware le≈øt the Sun, the Wind, the Evening, or the Cold, offend them, are within a ≈ømall time di≈øpatched with a Po≈øt-Letter to another World. So far were the ancient Germans from nicety in this point, that they u≈øe to dip their Children as ≈øoon as born, in a cold River.

The third thing nece≈ø≈øary to be performed, is to ≈øeek out a young Nur≈øe of temperature hot and dry, with which two qualities the much cold and moi≈øt will be corrected, which the Infant brought from his Mothers Womb; ≈øhe ≈øhould be innur'd to hardne≈øs and want, to lye on the bare ground, to eat little, and to go poorly clad in wet, drought, and heat, ≈øuch a one will yield a firm milk, as being acquainted with the alterations of the air, and the Child being brought up by her, will come to enjoy a great firmne≈øs of body. The cour≈øe then which is to be ob≈øerved with the Nur≈øe, is to take her into the Hou≈øe about four or five Months before the Childs birth, and to give her the ≈øame ≈øorts
of meat to feed on, which the Mother u≈øeth to eat, that ≈øhe may have time to con≈øume the blood and bad humors, which ≈øhe hath gathered by the harmful meats ≈øhe u≈øed before, and al≈øo to the end that the Child may ≈øuck the like milk with that which relieved it in the Mothers belly, or at lea≈øt made of the ≈øame meats.

The fourth thing requi≈øite to be ob≈øerved, is not to accu≈øtom the Child to ≈øleep in a ≈øoft bed, or to keep it over-warm in apparel, or give it too much meat, which are things that fatten and enlarge the Fle≈øh; whereas the re≈øtraint of them dimini≈øheth and dries it up, which drine≈øs increa≈øeth wit, and much availeth toward long life, According to this Rule which I have pre≈øcribed, was He, who of all men living that ever the World had, was the wi≈øe≈øt brought up; for as ≈øoon as he was born, he began to be inur'd to cold and other alterations of the air; his fir≈øt bed was the Earth, his apparel coar≈øe; and a few days after, they went with him to Aegypt, a place very hot, and the meat they gave him, was that which I have already mentioned to have been u≈øed by the ancient Greeks. Whereupon it is that the Prophet E≈øay ≈øaith, He ≈øhall eat butter and honey, that he may know to e≈øchew evil, and chu≈øe the good: For though he was very God, yet being al≈øo perfect Man, he omitted not to make u≈øe of the ≈øame natural remedies as were u≈øed by the re≈øt of the ≈øons of men.

Thus we have ≈øhown what the qualities are, which the Brain ought to have, and what the ≈øub≈øtance; having proved according to the opinion of Heraclitus, that drine≈øs maketh the wi≈øe≈øt ≈øoul; and that by age from the day of our birth, 'till that of our death, we ≈øtill acquire more and more dryne≈øs, and by con≈øequence more knowledge. We have al≈øo proved, that the ≈øubtile and delicate parts of the Brain are corrected by what we eat; for tho≈øe that always feed upon Beef and Pork, mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øity have a Brain ≈øo gro≈øs and of ≈øuch evil
temperature, that the rea≈øonable ≈øoul cannot be ≈øo capable of e≈øchewing evil, or adhering to good.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Some farther Con≈øiderations than have before been mentioned concerning the gradual progre≈øs of the Births Formation in the Womb.
div.p: COncerning the Gradual Formation of the Infant in the Womb; of the growing up of the Fibrae within the fir≈øt ≈øeven days; of the Umbilical Veins and Arteries, of the Formation of the Liver, the Heart, the Brain, the Nerves, the Gri≈øtles, &c. a particular Di≈øcour≈øe hath been already made in this Book: It remains only that we touch upon ≈øome things, in reference to the ≈øame matter.

As the u≈øe of the two Membranules that enwrap the Birth (whereof the fir≈øt is called Ambiens, Avicius, Amnium, Aurela, Abcas, Abigas, Sela, Aligas, or the Armature of the Conception; the latter Alanthoides, Bilis, A≈øcari, Secca, Involucrum) which hath been formerly delivered, is a thing of great con≈øequence, to be known and well con≈øidered; ≈øo likewi≈øe is the con≈øideration of the Umbilical Veins and Arteries a matter no le≈øs important. The≈øe Veins meeting together a little beneath the Navel, and extended along that concavity where the Liver is to be formed, ≈øerve for the purging of the men≈øtruous blood, which is to be de≈øtributed through the members. The two Arteries are connected with ductile ligatures unto the great Artery: Through tho≈øe the heart of the Embryo receives ventilation, and draws ≈øpirit, and the purer part of the blood from the Womb.

Then after the fir≈øt ≈øix or ≈øeven days, the lineaments of all the members are de≈øcribed. Next, the Lineation being perfected within the ≈øpace of between four and
eight days after, a certain ≈øanguinous matter drawn through the Navel, pa≈ø≈øeth all along through the whole Birth, and being pre-di≈øpo≈øed toward the formation of the members, fills up at that time the lineatures. The following days from the ninth to the fifteenth, this ≈øanguineous juice is converted into Fle≈øh. At which time al≈øo the Members receive their colour, and that degree of hardne≈øs or ≈øoftne≈øs, which is peculiar to them; like as a Painter when he hath drawn the outward lines of any Picture, in the next place, he fills it up with various colours, according as the nature of each ≈øeveral part requires.

Otherwi≈øe thus,
Injectum ≈øemen ≈øex primis rite diebus,
E≈øt qua≈øi lac, reliqui≈øque novem fit ≈øanguis; at inde
Con≈øolidat duodena dies, bis nona deinceps
Effigiat, tempu≈øque ≈øequens producit ad ortum;

The fir≈øt ≈øix days to milk the fruitful ≈øeed,
Injected in the Womb, remaineth ≈øtill;
Then other nine of milk, red blood do breed,
Twelve days turn blood to fle≈øh by Nature's skill.
Twice nine firm part, the re≈øt ripe birth do make;
And thus foregoing time doth form man's ≈øhape.

To conclude this ≈øubject, the ancients were of opinion, that the heart (which in all animals po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth the middle ≈øeat, (like a King which hath the chief Seat of his Empire, in the mid≈øt of his Dominions) is both the fir≈øt principal member which is formed in mans body, and the la≈øt which dies: But later Phy≈øitians hold that the liver is fir≈øt formed, next the Heart, and la≈øtly the Brain.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Concerning the Notes of Virginity, and whether or no it may be Violated without the knowledge of man.
div.p: ABOUT the orifice of the ≈øinus pudoris, vulgarly mi≈øcalled the Neck of the Womb, is that pendulous production, by ≈øome termed the Hymen; by others (more rightly) clau≈øtrum Virginale, and by the French Bouton de Ro≈øe; for that it beareth a near re≈øemblance with the expanded bud of a Ro≈øe or Gilli-flower; Hence therefore originally ≈øprung that common expre≈ø≈øion of the Deflowring of Virgins.

Fora≈ømuch as the Integrity or Violation of this part is accounted the mo≈øt certain and infallible ≈øign of Virginity intire, or violated, ≈øome Learned Phy≈øitians that have written of this Subject, e≈øteem it a great vanity and folly, to think that there is any other Hymen.

Moreover, this word Flower, is u≈øed in divers acceptations, for be≈øides the proper ≈øignification it is commonly taken for the prime or chief part of any thing, and ≈øo youth is called the Flower of a Mans age; or for that which is hand≈øome or elegant; and ≈øo Rhetorical expre≈ø≈øions are called Flowers; or el≈øe for ≈øuch things as are not marred or ≈øpoiled by u≈øe; and according to this ≈øen≈øe a Woman deprived of her Virginity may be ≈øaid to have been Deflowred, or to have lo≈øt her Flower.

Now this Clau≈øtrum Virginale, or Flower con≈øi≈øteth of four Caruncles, or Fle≈øhy ≈øub≈øtances, called Myrtle-formed, in regard they re≈øemble Myrtle berries. The≈øe four caruncles are ≈øituated as it were in the four Angles of the ≈øaid Sinus Pudoris, and are connected together by certain Membranes or Ligatures, which are each of them ≈øituated in the inter≈øtices or ≈øpaces between each Caruncle, with which they are in a manner equally extended; which Membranes being once dilacerated, are an apparent ≈øign of devirgination; nor can it be denied, but that this dilaceration may be cau≈øed by other accidents, be≈øides the accompanying with a man; as by violent Coughing, Sneezing, or loud Vociferation; all which may occa≈øion a violent flowing down of humours, to the breaking of tho≈øe ligatures or membranes; but as for any Stories of a Hymen, as that it ≈øhould be a tran≈øver≈øe membrane, ≈øituated now in the lower extremity of the Sinus Pudoris, now in the mid≈øt of the concavity, that it is perforated all about in the manner of a Sieve, or in the middle only with one larger hole, or that the breaking of this Hymen ≈øhould be the only cau≈øe of Devirgination, are all to be rejected as vain and Frivolous,

div.head: CHAP. X. Whether there may be a mutation out of one Sex into another; and of Hermaphrodites.
div.p: BEfore any thing can be po≈øitively determined concerning this argument (≈øo much of uncertainty there is in it;) it will be convenient to recite what hath been delivered both as to the negative and the affirmative, by Authors that have maintained each contrary opinion, Severinus Pinaeus, who holds the Negative, writes to this effect, viz. That the genital parts of both Sexes, are ≈øo unlike each other in ≈øub≈øtance much more in compo≈øition, ≈øituation figure, action, and u≈øe, that ≈øcarce any thing can be found more unlike, and by how much the more all other parts of the body (excepting the Brea≈øts, which in women are more tumid, becau≈øe of their ≈øecondary u≈øe) have an exact re≈øemblance; ≈øo much the more unlike are the genital parts of the one Sex, compared with tho≈øe of the other; and if their figure be thus different, much more is their u≈øe. True it is, indeed, that both are appointed for generation, but in a different manner; for women contribute the matter, but men the form: The Venereal appetite al≈øo proceeds from different cau≈øes; for in men it proceeds from a de≈øire of emi≈ø≈øion, in women, from a de≈øire of repletion. In women al≈øo the chiefe≈øt of tho≈øe parts are concave, and apt to receive; but in men they are only porous, and in a manner ≈øolid.

The≈øe things con≈øidered, I cannot but wonder, ≈øaith he, how any one can imagine, that the Genital Members of Female Birth ≈øhould be changed into tho≈øe that belong to Males; ≈øince by tho≈øe parts only the difference
and di≈øtinction of Sexes is made: Nor can I well impute the cau≈øe of this vulgar error to any thing, but a mi≈øtake of ≈øome not over-expert Midwives, who have been deceived by the evil conformation of the parts, which may have happened in ≈øome Male-births, to have had ≈øo ≈ømall a protru≈øion, as not to have been di≈øcerned; as appeared by the example of a Child Chri≈øtned at Paris, by the name of Joan, as if it had been a Girl, when as it proved afterwards a Boy: And on the contrary, the over-far exten≈øion of the Clitoris in female Births, may have occa≈øioned the like mi≈øtake. But notwith≈øtanding what hath been thus ≈øaid in the Negative, there have not been wanting ≈øome learned Phy≈øitians, who have firmly a≈ø≈øerted the affirmative part; of which number Galen him≈øelf is one. A man, ≈øaith he, is different from a woman in nothing el≈øe except in the having his genital members without his body: And this is certain, that if Nature having formed a man, would convert him into a Woman, ≈øhe hath no other task to perform, but only to turn his genital members inward; and if a woman into a man, to do the contrary. And this, however held for a Fable, hath chanced many times in nature, as well while the Creature hath been in the Mothers Womb, as after the ≈øame hath been born: For divers times Nature hath made a Female Child, and ≈øhe hath ≈øo remained in her Mothers belly for the ≈øpace of one or two Months, and afterwards plenty of heat growing in the genital Members, upon ≈øome occa≈øion they have i≈ø≈øued forth, and the Child hath become a Male; but yet retaining ≈øome certain ge≈øtures unbefitting the Ma≈øculine Sex; as a ≈øhrill voice, womani≈øh actions, and the like. Contrariwi≈øe, Nature hath often made a Male, and cold growing on, and turning the genitals inward, it hath become a
Female; yet ≈øtill retaining a manlike fa≈øhion, both in voice and ge≈øture.

Now to give an impartial judgment of the≈øe two opinions, I cannot but hold that the latter of them carrieth a greater ≈øemblance of truth with it; for as to what Pinaeus affirms of the great difference of figure in the genital members of each, it will not be of ≈øo much force; if we con≈øider that the inver≈øion of them is that which chiefly occa≈øioneth this difference of form; the rea≈øon of which is evidently deduced from the contrary natures of heat and cold; heat enlarging and extending all things, and cold retaining and clo≈øing them up.

Now as to the bu≈øine≈øs of Hermaphrodites, or tho≈øe that enjoy both Sexes in one per≈øon, many there are that will not afford any belief, or, at the lea≈øt, doubt whether or no there are any ≈øuch things in nature; but although there cannot be ≈øo apparent a rea≈øon given for this as for the mutation of Sexes; yet in this we may ≈øuffer our ≈øelves to be guided by the ≈øame Criterium, as in the bu≈øine≈øs of Specters and Apparitions of Spirits; concerning which, although it hath puzled many learned men to find out, what ≈øhould be the true cau≈øes and rea≈øons, that ≈øuch things come to pa≈øs; yet it argues much indi≈øcretion not to give credit to them, both in regard Hi≈øtories have abounded with frequent examples of them in all ages; and al≈øo, con≈øidering the daily reports we have of ≈øuch things, both from the mouths and pens of ≈øerious and judicious men.

Perhaps it may be judged by ≈øome, to have been more decent that the≈øe things ≈øhould have been delivered in the Latin, than in the vulgar Tongue, that ≈øo the ≈øecrets of Nature might not have been pro≈øtituted to every unworthy Reader, that makes u≈øe of ≈øuch things,
only for a mockery, and a May-game, and to promote idle and la≈øcivious di≈øcour≈øe; yet fora≈ømuch as they are written for God's Glory, and the benefit and help of mankind, and intended only for the u≈øe of ≈øober, pious, and di≈øcreet Matrons; and that the want of skill and knowledge in the≈øe mainly important Secrets, hath been the occa≈øion of very many mi≈øtakes, to the great mi≈øery oftentimes of Women in travail, and prejudice of the poor Infant, the concealment of them had been much more inexcu≈øable, than the publi≈øhing can be.

div.p: TAke Mint, Ro≈øes, Marjoram, Saffron, Musk, as much as ≈øuffices of each; put them into a bag to be hung about the neck, ≈øo that it may reach to the ≈øtomach; this will keep the womb from falling low.

div.p: TAke Oyl of Ro≈øes, white Wax, juyce of Male-knot-gra≈øs of each 2 ounces, Bole-Armoniack, Crocus Martis, each ≈øix drams, of this make a plai≈øter: when the Flux comes down, let the woman contain her ≈øelf in her bed, and let this plai≈øter be ≈øpread upon her loyns. Lay a Goats-skin between the ≈øheet and the bed, becau≈øe of the heat of the hollow Vein; or el≈øe take Crocus Martis one dram, juyce of Knot gra≈øs four ounces, Ro≈øe-water and Vinegar, of each one ounce; mingle them all well together with the white of an egg, then dip a linnen cloth therein, and apply it cold to the loins.

div.head: An Emplai≈øter for a Woman that is fearful of containing the Birth.
div.p:
TAke of the root of Snake-weed, and Tormentil, each one ounce and a half, Joubertus a≈øtringent powder, Myrtle-berries, P≈øidia, Pomgranate-flowers, of each ≈øix drams; Dragons-blood, Spong‚ñ™ Bedeguar, of each half an ounce, Frankincen≈øe, Ma≈øtick, of each three drams; Cummin one dram; Nutmegs, Cloves,
of each half a dram, Common Pitch ≈øix ounces, Venice Turpentine, wa≈øhed in juyce of Shepherds-pur≈øe, Ship pitch three ounces, Wax as much as is ≈øufficient; make of the≈øe an Emplai≈øter to be applied to the reins.

div.head: Preparatory Oyntments to be u≈øed before the time of Delivery.
div.p: TAke Oyl of Lillies, and Cammomil, of each four ounces, new Hogs-≈øeam ≈øtrein'd, new fre≈øh Butter, of each an ounce and an half, Mu≈øcilage of the ≈øeed of Fenugreek extracted in Mugwort-water, two ounces of powder of round Birth-wort, and Saffron, of each two drams, Wax as much as ≈øuffices, make a mollifying Oyntment to anoint the Thighs, Hips, and Matrix Or el≈øe,

Take the roots of white Lillies cut ≈ømall, four ounces, leaves of Violets and Mallows chopt, of each one handful; oyl of Lillies one pint: boyl the≈øe together upon hot embers, in a ≈øilver di≈øh, always moving them 'till they grow ≈øoft, in the nature of a Catapla≈øm. Then ≈øtrein it, and to the ≈øtreined liquor add Goo≈øe-grea≈øe, Hogs-≈øeam, of each three ounces, Saffron one ounce, mingle them well, and make an Oyntment for the u≈øe above-≈øaid.

div.head: In ca≈øe of Vomiting.
div.p: APply to the Stomach a Stomachical Cerecloth ≈øprinkled with Galbanum powdered, powder of Cloves and Ma≈øtick, and then covered with fine linnen.
Or el≈øe give Aromaticum Ro≈øatum before meals, which is a mo≈øt excellent remedy.

A woman in the fir≈øt place finding her ≈øelf to be with Child for the three fir≈øt months, ought to keep from violent exerci≈øes, as al≈øo at the fir≈øt quarter, at Full of the Moon, and in the time when ≈øhe hath her
natural purgations; for at all the≈øe ≈øea≈øons there is a motion of the humours, and of the blood, which many times cau≈øeth a di≈øcharge of the Birth; neither ought a woman at ≈øuch times as the≈øe dance, ride, or go in Coaches, but upon urgent nece≈ø≈øity, and that very ≈øoftly.

In the fourth month the Child being alive moves and ≈øtirs, which cau≈øeth a ≈øqueami≈øhne≈øs in the ≈øtomach, where at that time 'tis good for the Woman to eat alone, that ≈øhe may neither ≈øee nor hear of any thing of hurtful diet, to which ≈øhe may have a longing de≈øire. Neither is it good at that time for her to walk in the field, or in gardens, for fear ≈øhe ≈øhould ≈øee any thing to long after, offen≈øive to her health.
The fifth and ≈øixth months are not ≈øo dangerous, yet 'tis good to have a care.

In the ≈øeventh month the Child comes to perfection, and oft-times endeavours to come forth; for which cau≈øe great and diligent care is to be taken of the Woman at that time. For though the Child born in that month may live, yet it will prove weak, and harder to bring up. The eighth month in indifferent. The Child which is born in that Month is not long liv'd, becau≈øe it is much weakned by its indeavours to get forth in the ≈øeventh, and has not yet recovered ≈øtrength.

div.head: Regulation of Diet.
div.p: FOR the fir≈øt eight months, it will be convenient for her to u≈øe ≈øuch meats and drinks, which neither moi≈øten, loo≈øen, nor bind overmuch, but moderately; and let them be of ea≈øie dige≈øtion, and good juyce.
As to Fle≈øh; Capons, Partridges, Larks, Pullets, and Mutton afford good nouri≈øhment.
As to Fi≈øh; the Gurnard, the Sole, the Smelt, and many other firm Fi≈øh may be eaten.

Her Bread ought to be white, well baked, and light. Marmalade is good after meals, and ≈øometimes before, neither are the be≈øt ≈øort of Pears forbidden. As for her drink, Claret is very good, as al≈øo ≈ømall Ale and Beer well brewed; ≈øtrong wines are very hurtful, e≈øpecially tho≈øe that are white.
She mu≈øt have a care to ab≈øtain from Spices, opening and windy meats; as al≈øo from raw herbs, and Salads, from Beans and Pea≈øe, and all baked meat.

In the ninth month ≈øhe mu≈øt ab≈øtain from all a≈øtringent things, as Pa≈øte of Quinces, Rice, and Pears, Marmalad, and the like; on the contrary, let her u≈øe mollifying and loo≈øening meats, as fle≈øh that is young and tender, Pottages made with Borage, Buglo≈øs, Lettice, Violets, March-mallows, and ≈øuch like.

div.head: Other Adverti≈øements relating to the ≈øeveral accidents which may happen.
div.p: FIr≈øt, if the Woman fear Abortion, and that ≈øhe carry her Child low near her Privities, let her do as follows.

Take the Treddles of three new laid Eggs, and beat them well together, then take of Scarlet Silk as much as ≈øuffices, and cut it very ≈ømall, and mix it with the egg, and make the ≈øaid mixture into Pills, take of the≈øe Pills in a little Claret-wine; do this three days together, and every month three times in the ≈øame manner.
You may al≈øo u≈øe this following Plai≈øter.

Take of Myr ‚Ä¢ les, Orange-flowers, of each one ounce, Acorn cups, ≈øtalks of Ro≈øes, each one ounce; Bole Armonick fine and true, Dragons-blood, of each three ounces. Turpentine two ounces; Oyl of Quinces or Myrtles as much as is ≈øufficient to make the
plai≈øter: which is to be applied to the reins, and upon the belly, and withall to be ≈øtretched out upon the thighs. It may lye on five or ≈øix days without changing.

However a woman ought not to tamper, nor u≈øe any thing, unle≈øs there be very great nece≈ø≈øity, which ≈øhe ≈øhall know thus; If at the full or new Moon, or el≈øe at the time when ≈øhe u≈øes to have her monthly purgation; if at that time her Purgations come down, then Abortion is to be feared, and remedies are to be applied.

But if the woman carry the Infant high, and that her belly ≈øwells, and extends ≈øo ≈øtrongly, that there may be ≈øome danger of fi≈ø≈øures and clefts in the skin, then let her u≈øe this following oyntment.

Take half a hundred of Sheeps trotters with bones and wooll; when the Moon is at the full, brui≈øe them, and beat them, then let them boyl in a good quantity of water, for half a days time, let them cool, and then take off the fat that ≈øwims, and with this mingle four ounces of Sperma Caeti, four ounces of Oyl of Almonds drawn without fire, and four ounces of white Wax; melt all the≈øe together over a ≈øoft fire, then put therein half a pint of Ro≈øe-water, then take it off the fire, and ≈øtir it till it grow cold; with this oyntment you ≈øhall fir≈øt anoint the part extended, and then lay ≈øome of it on the ≈øaid part where ever it be, ≈øpreading it upon ≈øoft leather, ≈øuch as Childrens gloves are made of.
About fifteen days or three weeks before ≈øhe lyes down, ≈øhe mu≈øt begin to u≈øe mollifying oyntments, anointing therewith the lower part of the belly, her thighs and genitals.

The Oyntment of Sheeps trotters will ≈øerve for fifteen days, but ≈øome eight days before ≈øhe lyes down,
let her u≈øe one which is more mollifying, ≈øuch as this which follows.

Take of roots of Lillies two ounces, Mar≈øh-mallow-roots two ounces, leaves of Mar≈øh-mallows, Mallows, and March-Violets, of each one handfull; of Hemp≈øeed, and ≈øeed of Fenugreek, of each one ounce; two Sheeps trotters with their Wooll on, cut and brui≈øed: boyl all the≈øe together in a great quantity of water, till all be boyled to a ma≈øh, then ≈øtrein them hot, then ≈øet the ≈øtreined liquor over a ≈øoft fire, let it con≈øume and evaporate, 'till there be nothing left but the fat, and ≈øomething of a vi≈øcous matter be≈øide. To this add eight ounces of oyl of Hemp≈øeed, drawn by expre≈ø≈øion like Oyl of Almonds, and eight ounces of Hogs-Seam; This Oyntment mollifies very much, and renders the pa≈ø≈øages very ≈ølippery and ea≈øie, to extend upon any occa≈øion.
While the party is with Child, if ≈øhe happen to be bound in body, let her u≈øe this following Cly≈øter.

Take one Sheeps trotter, Hemp≈øeed, and Fenugreek-≈øeed, of each one ounce; Melilot-flowers two handfuls, boyl the≈øe in Cows milk, then ≈øtrein it, and take ≈øix ounces thereof, and put thereto four ounces of Oyl of Hemp≈øeed, if ≈øhe be near the time of her Labour, but if not, Oyl of Ro≈øes, and if the excrements be very hard, you may add thereto one ounce of Catholicon.

At the time of Child-bearing, it is good to take the above-≈øaid Cly≈øter, if it may be done po≈ø≈øibly, for that, after the Woman is delivered, ≈øhe is to be four or five days without a ≈øtool, as well becau≈øe of the great evacuations which ≈øhe hath ≈øo lately had, as al≈øo that being to be kept continually hot in her bed, the excrements do thereupon harden, and afterwards putrifie,
and then generate putrid vapours, and many times a feaver.

There happens al≈øo another inconvenience from the ≈øaid excrements, being kept in the body, and not emptied before delivery; and that is this, that when the Patient endeavours to deliver her ≈øelf of the Infant, the excrements do al≈øo forthwith come out, which many ways give annoyance, as well to the Child, the Midwife, as to the other A≈ø≈øi≈øtants, by rea≈øon of the change of linnen, and the trouble≈øome ≈ømells.

Be≈øide the fore≈øaid inconveniencies, the Child will not come forth ≈øo ea≈øily, becau≈øe the Inte≈øtines being full, do compre≈øs the Matrix, and by con≈øequence cau≈øe the pa≈ø≈øages to be more clo≈øe and difficult. In the mean time, that is to ≈øay, when the woman is in pain, and that all the ≈øigns of Child-bearing do appear, then let her take about two ounces of Cinamon-water, this will fortifie her ≈øpirits, and ha≈øten the coming forth of the Infant.

If the water alone do not ≈øuffice, you may give it her the ≈øecond time, adding thereunto the weight of a half crown of counterfeit Borax made of Roach-Allum, ≈øuch as the Gold≈ømiths u≈øe; it is neither offen≈øive to the ta≈øte, nor any way dangerous, as ≈øome Phy≈øicians think, mi≈øtaking it for Chry≈øocoll of the Greeks; for it is a ≈øoveraign medicament both to cau≈øe the Child to come forth, and to expell the Secondines, if they come not forth in their due time.

If you cannot have the ≈øaid Borax,To help difficult Labour. then take two ≈øcruples, or forty grains of Date-≈øtones powdered very fine, and drink it in Cinamon-water; or for want of that, in a draught of good Hypocra≈øs.

The weight of a Crown of the powder of the
leaves of Cretan Dittany, drank in Cinamon-water, worketh the ≈øame effect.
Or el≈øe take of Venetian Borax, one dram, Saffron three grains; drink this in one ≈øpoonful of water of white Lillies: Or el≈øe, take this following powder.
Take Cretan Dittany half a dram, Savin, yellow Amber, of each two ≈øcruples, make it into powder, and drink it in water of Cinamon, Hy≈øop, or Rue.
Or el≈øe,

Take of the powder of leaves of Cretan Dittany half a dram, of Penny-royal half a ≈øcruple, a little Cinamon, Myrrh one ≈øcruple; mingle the≈øe powders well, and drink them in Hypocra≈øs. Or take this following water.

Take Water of Cinamon four ounces, of Hy≈øop and Thyme of each two ounces, of Ro≈øewater one dram, in the≈øe waters di≈ø≈øolve half an ounce of Confectio Alchermes, let them ≈øtand a whole night, then di≈øtill them in Balneo; the do≈øe to be taken at a time is two drams; you may add, if there be nece≈ø≈øity, a drop or two of Oil of Savin. Or, you may u≈øe this powder.

Take of Myrrh, of Cinamon, and Saffron, of each the weight of the third part of a Crown, mix them well together, and put them into a raw egg, and cau≈øe the party to ≈øup it up; and let her drink after it a draught of Hypocra≈øs. Or el≈øe take this potion.

Take of the juyce of Savin two ounces, Cinamon-powdered two drams, Saffron half a Scruple, water of Radi≈øhes four ounces, and a little Sugar; of this make a potion for the woman to drink in time of travail.

There be many other Remedies, but the≈øe are the mo≈øt certain, and ea≈øie to take, where the danger nor the pain is exce≈ø≈øive; but in ca≈øes of urgent nece≈ø≈øity, you may u≈øe the≈øe following remedies.

Take of Mugwort one handful, Butchers Broom and Fennel, of each one handful; of ≈øalt three drams,
of A≈ø≈øa foetida two drams, of bran one handful, of water and white-wine, of each eight pints: boil them to the con≈øumption of the third part. Or take this, which never failed.
Take of the root of Gentian powdered one or two drams, take this in white-wine or honey, it never hurts the Infant.

div.head: To accelerate and ha≈øten the labour before the time of Child bearing, u≈øe this following ointment.
div.p: Take of the mu≈øcilage of the ≈øeed of Fenugreek, and the root of Mar≈øhmallows, with water of Mugwort two ounces; oil of Lillies, and ≈øweet Almonds, and Hens-gera≈øe, of each one ounce and a half, of Saffron half a ≈øcruple; of Wax as much as ≈øuffices: Of this make an ointment to anoint the back, belly, and privy parts, for fourteen days together before the birth: Or el≈øe take this following Ointment.

Take oil of white Lillies, with hens grea≈øe, of each an ounce and a half, of Saffron half a ≈øcruple, of the≈øe make an Ointment with as much Wax as ≈øuffices, to anoint the Back, Navel, and privy Parts, for fourteen days together.

Note that all tho≈øe things which we have ≈øaid to be good, to be given at the time of delivery, mu≈øt never be given before; for that otherwi≈øe they will be of little u≈øe, they ≈øerving only to facilitate the Birth without endangering the Child or Mother.
The Woman ought al≈øo to walk about the Chamber as much as ≈øhe can, being held by other Women.

Neither let any per≈øon, whether Man or Woman, again≈øt whom ≈øhe may have any ill will, or who≈øe pre≈øence may breed any thing of ≈øhame in her, be at that time in the room, becau≈øe any ≈øuch accident as that retards Nature, but let them be ≈øuch as ≈øhe loves, ≈øociable, merry, and helpful towards her.
It is al≈øo nece≈ø≈øary for a Woman in Travel to ≈øneeze and cough, which are great means to force down the Infant to the lower parts.

And as to the Midwifes duty, ≈øhe ought to anoint the lower parts with oyl of Hemp-≈øeed, or Nuts, if the waters which ≈øhould precede the Birth do not come forth, or if they be come down a good while before the Birth, to the intent to make the ≈øaid parts ≈ølippery to ea≈øe the coming forth of the Child.
If the Child de≈øcend not ea≈øily, the Midwife may with her hand gently pre≈øs the top of the belly, to the intent to make the Child de≈øcend with more ha≈øt.

As ≈øoon as the Woman is delivered, and that the Secondines are likewi≈øe come away, it ≈øhall be convenient to wrap her in a warm ≈øheep-skin, which mu≈øt be flead near the Chamber, for that purpo≈øe; which mu≈øt be done with as much expedition, and as near a great fire as may be, that there may be nothing of coldne≈øs when the Woman is wrapt therein In this the Patient mu≈øt continue twelve hours. This will much help the Matrix in its natural purgation; when you take it away, you mu≈øt apply warm Cloths in the ≈øtead, and above all things take great care that no air do enter into the Matrix, which often-times is the cau≈øe of very great evils.

Or you may apply warm to the belly of the Patient, Tow dipt in the whites of Eggs, wherein the pouders of Cloves, Pepper, and Nutmegs ≈øhall be mingled, which mu≈øt be bound clo≈øe to the body with ≈øwathbands.
Great care is to be taken how you apply a≈øtringent things to the Womb pre≈øently after delivery, unle≈øs after perfect purgation of the Secondines; for fear of very great mi≈øchiefs.

Now if you u≈øe the ≈øaid ≈øheep skin, and that you
find the woman notwith≈øtanding tormented with very great pains, and that the ≈øaid skin doth not at all appea≈øe them; let her take an ounce and a half more or le≈øs according to the height of the di≈øtemper, of oil of ≈øweet Almonds drawn without fire the ≈øame day; and two hours after, let her take the weight of half a crown of this following powder either in white-Wine, or Capon broth.

Take of the root of great Comfrey dryed, two drams, kernels of Peaches, Nutmegs, each one dram, yellow Amber and Saffron, of each one ≈øcruple, Amber gree≈øe half a dram, make a powder of all this. For, be≈øides that it a≈ø≈øwages the Throws, it corroborates and fortifies the body, weakened by rea≈øon of tho≈øe great evacuations.

After you have taken away the ≈øheep-skin, if there be any excoriation in the privy parts, by rea≈øon either of the bigne≈øs of the Child, or the ≈øtreining of the woman, you mu≈øt anoint the ≈øaid parts with this following oyntment, which is infallible.

Take of Oil of St. John's wort well made, one ounce, Sperma Coeti half an ounce, bal≈øom of India two drams, white Wax two drams. This ointment doth con≈øolidate all the parts. But if together with this excoriation, any thing of the Secondines remain in the Womb, Oil of St. Johns-wort only will ≈øuffice, or, for want of that, oil of Nuts.
If the evacuations after the Secondines be too much, ≈øo that they cau≈øe too great a weakne≈øs, you mu≈øt apply to the Navel this following plai≈øter.
Take of Treacle one dram and a half, Bean-meal one dram Venice-Turpentine one dram, and thereof make an emplai≈øter to be ≈øpread upon thin Leather.

If all be well, and that only the lower parts be prejudiced,
after you have anointed them with Bal≈øom of the Indies, together with oil of St. Johns-wort, you mu≈øt foment the ≈øaid places with the following fomentation.

Take of Sage four little handfuls, wild Pomgranate flowers, Myrtle berries, Acorns, Cypre≈øs nuts, of each two ounces; let them be well brui≈øed together; red Ro≈øes four handfuls, Roche-allum one ounce; put all the≈øe into two little bags, and let them boil in Smiths water, or in water where iron hath been often quenched: when one bag is cold, apply another.
The Sheep-skin being taken away, if the patient be afraid of any wrinckles in the skin, which now is as much relaxed, as it was before extended; let her anoint the belly with this following ointment.

Take of Sperma Caeti, two ounces, oil of Myrtles, of Ma≈øtick, and St. John's-wort, of each one ounce, white wax an ounce and a half, Turpentine of Venice, wa≈øht in Vinegar of Ro≈øes, one ounce; of the≈øe make an ointment over a gentle Fire, with which you mu≈øt anoint the belly once a day, continuing ≈øo to do for ten or twelve days, laying when you have done upon the place ≈øo anointed, a linnen cloth dipt in the following ointment.

Take oil of ≈øweet Almonds, oil of Nuts, Sperma Coeti each four ounces; white Wax four ounces; melt the≈øe together, and dip therein a good large towel, big enough to wrap about the belly; when you do the≈øe things, great care is to be taken, that the patient do not take any cold.
If the patient have no mind to nur≈øe her Child, and de≈øires to dry up her milk, then do as follows, ≈øome ≈øix or ≈øeven hours after the Delivery.

Tak a linnen cloth cut round, about the bigne≈øs of the brea≈øts, making a little hole in the middle for the Teat to come through; then dip the clothes in the following
ointment, and lay them upon the brea≈øt, not taking them off again, 'till the end of ten or twelve days.

Take Venice Turpentine four ounces, wa≈øhed in one half part of Ro≈øe-water, and one half part of Vinegar, Populeon one ounce, mix them together, and apply them as is before ≈øaid. If the milk doth not dry up for all this, make the Catapla≈øm as follows.

Take Bean-meal four ounces, Bole-amoniack one ounce, juyce of Plantain three ounces, Vinegar of Ro≈øes, two ounces, Fountain water half a pint; let them boil 'till they come to the thickne≈øs of a Catapla≈øm, adding toward the end two ounces of Populeon, ≈øpread this on a linnen cloth, and apply them to the brea≈øts without wa≈øhing them, changing the Catapla≈øm twice a day.

The juice of Chervile boiled with Bean-meal, and a little Populeon, worketh the ≈øame effect. Becau≈øe the difficulty of Child bearing proceedeth from the lo≈øs of tho≈øe waters that break forth before the Child; therefore, to ≈øupply that defect, and to render the places ≈ølippery, let her u≈øe the≈øe following remedies.

Take Mar≈øh-mallows with the roots one handful, Mugwort, Savine, of each half a handful, Hemp≈øeed, and Fenugreek ≈øeed of each four ounces, Cummin ≈øeed one ounce and a half, boil all the≈øe in water; then take four ounces of this decoction, and add thereto oil of Hemp≈øeed two ounces, Mo≈øch. gr. 2. and inject it into the neck of the womb. Then take this following pouder.

Take of the bark of Ca≈ø≈øia, Dittany, of each two drams, Cinamon four ≈øcruples, Sugar the weight of the other ingredients. Make them into pouder, and let the Patient take one dram thereof in white-wine, or Mugwort water.

div.head: An Oyntment for the Midwifes hands.
div.p: TAke Oyl of Hemp≈øeed, one ounce and a half, Oyl of Ca≈øtor half an ounce, Gall Mo≈øchate half a ≈øcruple, Labdanum one ≈øcruple, make of this an Oyntment, with which, let the Midwife often anoint the neck of the womb.

div.head: After Delivery.
div.p: WHen the Infant is well clean≈øed by the Midwife, let her give unto it in the Winter nothing but a little Mithridate, but in the Summer let her mingle therewith a little con≈øerve of Ro≈øes and Buglo≈øs.

If the Mother have not yet taken any thing, let the Midwife give to her the juyce of a Capon pre≈ø≈øed out in a pre≈øs, with a little Saffron, and the yolk of an egg. Then let her take this following powder, again≈øt gripings of the belly, or after throws which indeed ≈øhe ought to take before any meat, pre≈øently after Delivery.
Take of the greater Comfrey dryed, one dram and a half, kernels of Peaches, Nutmegs, of each two drams, yellow Amber, one dram, Amber-gree≈øe two ≈øcruples; or this,

Take kernels of Peaches and Dates, of each one dram and a half, Nutmegs four ≈øcruple, Pulv. Elect. Diamargarit. Calid. two drams, Ani≈øeed condited, one dram; of the be≈øt Cinamon two ≈øcruples, Saffron half a ≈øcruple, Sugar as much as ≈øuffices, drink two drams of this powder in white-wine twice or thrice a day, if the pains be very great.

div.head: If the pains cea≈øe not with the≈øe remedies, u≈øe that which follows.
div.p:
TAke the whites of twelve eggs ro≈øted under the embers, Cummin-≈øeed and Hemp≈øeed, of each one ounce and a half, flowers of Camomile and Melilot,
of each two drams; boyl the≈øe in oyl of Dill, 'till they come to the form of an oyntment; apply it warm to the belly, ≈øtill changing it as it grows cold. Or thus:

Take the flowers of Dill, Ro≈øemary, Melilot, and Camomil, of each one handful; Fennel≈øeed, Ani≈øeed, and Cummin-≈øeed, of each two drams: boyl them in part wine, and part water, and make a Catapla≈øm for the whole belly.

div.head: To ≈øtreighten the Womb.
div.p: TAke of the leaves of Myrtle and Starwort, of each three handfuls, green Medlers, green Prunes, and the ≈øharpe≈øt wild Pears, of each one little handful and a half, the Stomacks of three Cocks newly taken out, di≈øtill all the≈øe together, then take Cotton and dip therein, and then put it into the womb, and let it continue there a good while.

div.head: To ≈øtreighten the Womb without the help of Swathe-bands.
div.p: TAke the white of an Egg, and meal as much as is ≈øufficient; make thereof a Catapla≈øm to cover the lower part of the belly; where it lies upon the belly, there mu≈øt be a hole made, and that hole mu≈øt be covered with mo≈øs.
You mu≈øt cover the plai≈øter al≈øo with powder of Frankincen≈øe.
This plai≈øter profits more in a little while, than a Swathe in many weeks.

div.head: A Fomentation to provoke the after-birth.
div.p:
TAke the Birth-worts, of each of them one ounce, or a handful; Carduus, Feverfew and Mugwort, each one handful; Dwarf Elder, half a handful, ground Ivy one handful, boyl them together in Wine, or Water, or Ale, e≈øpecially if there be any Fever, for then you mu≈øt by no means meddle with
Wine, adding to it one handfull of the leaves, or half a handful of the roots of Ma≈øter-wort.

div.head: For the ≈øame.
div.p: TAke Savine, one ≈øcruple, rind of Ca≈ø≈øia, half a ≈øcruple, Saffron ten grains, A≈ø≈øa-faetida two grains, juyce of Wall-Ivy, half an ounce, Snakeweed one ounce, Pulvis diagar ‚ñ™ five grains, Syrup of Mugwort half an ounce, mingle all the≈øe together, and make a potion to drink at once.
Or el≈øe take four drops of the di≈øtilled oyl of Savin in white-wine.

div.head: A Pe≈ø≈øary for the ≈øame.
div.p: TAke the leaves of red Coleworts, and brui≈øe them, and put them into a little piece of linnen cloth in the ≈øhape of a finger, then brui≈øe them again, that the juyce may come through, and dip the cloth in a mixture of oyl of Lillies, Camomil, and ≈øweet Almonds.

div.head: For the ≈øame.
div.p: TAke long and round Birthwort, A≈ø≈øa-Faetida, of each half an ounce, Myrrh one dram, Spike two drams, make them up with the decoction of Par≈øley, and Apple-tree leaves.

div.head: For the ≈øame.
div.p: TAke of Borax one dram, Cinamon one ≈øcruple, Saffron three grains; make a powder, and let the woman drink it in four ounces of water of Mugwort.

div.head: To expell the Child, and after-birth, in time of great nece≈ø≈øity.
div.p: TAke of the water of Mugwort, Agrimony, and Penny-royal, of each one ounce, Syrup of Mugwort one ounce and a half, powder of Ca≈øtor, round Birth-wort, Myrrh, A≈øarabacca, of each one ≈øcruple, mingle them together, make a potion.

Or el≈øe take Origanum, Calaminth, and Hy≈øop, of each two drams, roots of Orrice, A≈øarabacca, Savin, each one dram, Myrrh, Olibanum, Galbanum, Sagapenum, one ≈øcruple; di≈ø≈øolve them, and make a Pe≈ø≈øary.

div.head: To expell the after-birth, another.
div.p: TAke one ≈øtone of a Ca≈øtor, and di≈øtill it with ≈øtrong Vinegar; when you have ≈øo done, let the Patient take four ounces of this di≈øtilled liquor.

Or, you may take of the Oyl drawn out of the ≈øtone of a Ca≈øtor, with a ≈øoft fire, mingle it with a ≈øufficient quantity of this Oyl, a little of the waters of Penny-royal, and Dittany, and a little ≈øtrong Vinegar.

div.head: To expell the Birth, whether alive, or dead.
div.p: TAke the milk of a woman that nur≈øes a male child, and di≈ø≈øolve it with a little Saffron, that it may not be known; then boyl an egg rear, and take out the white, and in the place of that, put in the milk, and let the patient ≈øup it up; if it prevail not in a quarter of an hour, prepare another egg, and fill it with milk, as afore≈øaid.
Or take of the juyce of Buglo≈øs, four ounces ≈øweetned with Sugar.

div.head: Again≈øt pains of the heart.
div.p: TAke of the roots of Fennel, Buglo≈øs, and Cicory, each two ounces; boyl them in three pints of white-wine, to the con≈øumption of two parts, then add Fennel-water, and Cicory-water, each ≈øix ounces; then boyl them again till there remain but a pint and a half, take one ≈øpoonful morning and evening.

div.head: To dry up the Milk.
div.p: TAke Honey newly drawn out of the Hive, and di≈ø≈øolve it in water, and wa≈øh the brea≈øts therewith.

div.head: For the ≈øame.
div.p: TAke of the juyce of Mint and Shepherds-pur≈øe, of each half an ounce; mix them together and drink them a mornings, with the broth of a hen or chicken.

div.head: A Fomentation for the ≈øame.
div.p: TAke of the juyce of Par≈øley, and the ≈øtronge≈øt wild Turnep, equal parts; and moi≈øten therein a linnen cloth, and apply the ≈øaid Cloth to the Brea≈øts.

div.head: Another.
div.p: TAke Oyl of Violets three ounces, juyce of Mint and Par≈øley three ounces, white Vinegar one ounce, Ro≈øe-water two ounces: boyl all the≈øe over a gentle fire, to the con≈øumption of the juyces; then add a little wax, and make an oyntment. Or,
Take of the tops of Elder, Sage, and Mint, one little handful; boyl them in common water, and make thereof a Catapla≈øm to be applied to the brea≈øts.
If you would increa≈øe the milk, foment the brea≈øts with the decoction of Fennel,To encrea≈øe Milk. or el≈øe give her the decoction of Mint, and lay the Mint boyled upon her brea≈øts.
Or, if the≈øe things prevail not, u≈øe this following Powder.

Take of Ani≈øe, Fennel, Cummin-≈øeed, two drams, Ginger half an ounce, Carui, of both ≈øorts of Pepper, Coral, each one dram, Cinamon, three drams, ≈øeed of Daucus one dram, Siler montan. half an ounce, Cardamom, Long pepper, each three drams, Se≈øelos half an ounce, ≈øeed of Se≈øamum one ounce, white Poppy half an ounce, mingle them, and make a powder thereof, and take one dram at plea≈øure, in broth made of red Coleworts.
Or, you may u≈øe this following oyntment.

Take of Venice-Turpentine, oyl of Ro≈øes, Vinegar
of Ro≈øes equal parts, add to this a little new wax, and therewith anoint the brea≈øts.
But if the Milk do curdle and harden in the brea≈øts.

Fir≈øt chafe the brea≈øts well with raw honey, then take of new wax two ounces, new oyl of nuts and vinegar two or three ≈øpoonfuls, melt them together, and dip that in little round linnen clothes, with holes in the middle to lay upon the brea≈øts.
Now if there be any tumour or hardne≈øs cau≈øed by the coagulation of the milk, then

Take of the leaves of Par≈øley, Hemlock, Uinca pervinca, Box and Chervile, and let them boyl in the ≈øtronge≈øt Vinegar, and then ≈øtrain them; then take oyl of Ro≈øes, Lillies, and ≈øweet Almonds each one ounce, of the fore≈øaid Vinegar four ounces, mingle them in a marble mortar for an oyntment, adding one ≈øcruple of Camphire di≈ø≈øolved in part of the oyl and toward the latter end of your ≈øtirring it, add the white refrigerating Ceratum of Galen, Unguent of Ro≈øes of Me≈ø≈øu one ounce and a half, mingle them all well together, and apply them to the hard ≈øwelling part, it a≈ø≈øwages the tumour, and cau≈øes the milk to flow through the Teats.
If the Tumor be painful and enflamed, you mu≈øt not u≈øe the Camphire, (for it encrea≈øes the pain) till that the pain be a≈ø≈øwaged.

div.head: An Oyntment again≈øt the curdling of the Milk in the Brea≈øt.
div.p: TAke of the roots of Mar≈øh-mallows half a pound, boyl them well in Vinegar, and ≈øtrain them thro' a hair ≈øieve, add to this Bean-meal one ounce, powder of Rue, and dried Mint, one dram; Oyl of Ma≈øtick as much as ≈øuffices.

div.head: Again≈øt Fi≈ø≈øures in the Brea≈øts.
div.p: TAke Gum-Arabick mo≈øt finely powdered, one ounce, Ro≈øe water and Aqua-vitae a ≈øufficient quantity, prepare them together, till they come to a ju≈øt thickne≈øs, make thereof an oyntment, and apply it to the ≈øaid Fi≈ø≈øures.
Or el≈øe, anoint the ≈øaid Fi≈ø≈øures with Ointment of Ro≈øes, then apply the in≈øide of the leaf of Ground-Ivy, changing often; this cures within ≈øix or eight days.

div.head: Another of the ≈øame.
div.p: TAke Lytharge of Silver, Myrrh, Ginger, and oyl-Olive, as much as ≈øuffices; mix them to the thickne≈øs of an oyntment; before you apply this, moi≈øten the Fi≈ø≈øures them≈øelves with ≈øpittle, but no part of the brea≈øt be≈øide.

div.head: Pain in the Brea≈øts after Delivery.
div.p: TAke new Wax two ounces, oyl of Nuts half an ounce, oyl of Rape-≈øeeed, or Turnep ≈øeed half an ounce; fir≈øt melt the Wax, then add the Oyls; dip therein the clothes cut fit to the brea≈øts; if there be any pain after delivery, the application of the≈øe cloaths, will with great ≈øucce≈øs a≈ø≈øwage the ≈øame.

div.head: An Opiate to be given to Childern newly born.
div.p: TAke Mithridate of Alexandria three drams, Con≈øerve of Buglo≈øs and Ro≈øes, of each one dram; mingle them well together, and keep them in a gla≈øs Ve≈ø≈øel well ≈øtopt; an hour, or half an hour after the Child is born, before it hath ≈øuckt, give to it of the fore≈øaid opiate, to the quantity of a Filberd; let it not ≈øuck till five hours after; continue thus doing for a month, giving the Child this opiate once in a week; and then it will be ≈øufficient, that the Child ab≈øtain but an hours ≈øpace from the Teat.

It will not be ami≈øs to anoint the Navel of the Child
with an ointment made of Ambergreece, and Suet, equal parts, with a little oil of ≈øweet-Almonds. This will pre≈øerve the child from Epilep≈øies and Convul≈øions.

div.head: Again≈øt Barrenne≈øs.
div.p: TAKE of Pine-nuts, fir≈øt well wa≈øht in Ro≈øewater, ≈øix ounces; ≈øweet Almonds, wa≈øhed in like manner, and brui≈øed, each two ounces, Citron pill, condited root of Satyrion, Erythranion, one ounce, Pulp of Sebe≈øten, Prunes of Dama≈øcus fat, boiled in Sugared water, each one ounce and a half; Coriander prepared three drams; Pulveris Diambre one dram Penidium one ounce and a half, the inner rind of Cinamon, half an ounce, true Amber of an A≈øh-colour, one dram, Mo≈øo. one Scruple, refined Sugar boiled in Ro≈øe-water, one pound and a half; take all the≈øe things and beat them, and powder them well, and make thereof a Pa≈øte ≈øo dried at a gentle fire. Let the woman take this at plea≈øure after dinner, and three hours before at plea≈øure, ab≈øtaining from liquid meats. The man al≈øo may eat of this pa≈øte; but let him not u≈øe copulation at the time of the Womans Purgations, nor when ≈øhe bathes her ≈øelf, but pre≈øently after. Tho≈øe mornings that he ab≈øtains, let him take one ≈øpoonful of the water of Cocks-blood, with three or four ≈øpoonfuls of the be≈øt Broth.

div.head: For the ≈øame.
div.p: A Syrup. Take Syrup of Hempagrimony, Simple, Oxymel, Syrup de rad. each one ounce and a half, waters of Nipp, Betony, and Mugwort of each three ounces, make thereof a ≈øyrup perfectly boiled, ≈øtrein it, and let it he aromatized with Cinamon, for three do≈øes, morning and evening.

A Potion. Take Agarick infu≈øed in Honey of Ro≈øes, and a little white-Wine for a whole night, one ounce; Diacatholicon, half an ounce, Diaphenicon, Elect. Ind.
major, each one dram and a half; Syrup of Ro≈øes Solutive, with Agorick one ounce, with a decoction of red Chiches; make a Potion thereof, and give it after the Syrup is all taken, for ten days, and ten days before the coming of the monthly purgations.
Three days after the operation of the ≈øaid potion, let blood in Vena Saphena, of the right foot, and take away three ounces of blood at evening.

An Opiate. Take of the great Triphera without Opium, two ounces, Methridate three ounces, mix the≈øe well together, and let her take thereof the quantity of a Walnut after ≈øhe is let blood, drinking upon the ≈øaid Bolus, a ≈øpoonful of Aromatick Wine, white or Claret; let the Patient take this when ≈øhe is clean from her Purgations only in the morning, while ≈øhe hath them upon her only at night, and then let her al≈øo make u≈øe of this Pe≈ø≈øary.

Take of Spike, Myrrh, and Agarick, and Colocynth each three drams, Benedict. one ounce and a half, mix them well together with the juyce of French Mercury, and wrapt in fine red ≈øilk, make thereof little Pe≈ø≈øaries, and put one of them into the Womb in the day, and another at night: But, from the time that ≈øhe is let blood until her Purgations, let her u≈øe but one in the day; but from the time that they begin, until the time that they end, let her u≈øe two, as is before ≈øaid.
Let her withal take this following Cly≈øter two or three days before her purgations.

Take Feverfew one handful, Penny-royal, Calamint, and Savine, of each half a handful, ≈øeed of Juniper one ounce, flowers of Melilot, and tops of Dill, of each one handful, make a decoction of nine ounces of water, add thereto oil of Lillies four ounces, two whites of eggs, and one dram of common ≈øalt.

La≈øtly, one day before her monthly purgations,
let her take three Pills of tho≈øe which are called Pillulae Rufi, then after ≈øhe is clean from her Purgations, let her lye with her Husband.

div.head: For the ≈øame.
div.p: AN Injection. Take Cypre≈øs one ounce, Myrrh half an ounce Pulp of Colocynth one dram, Bdellium one ≈øcruple, water a pint; boil them altogether to the con≈øumption of the third part, then ≈øtrein them, make an injection of four ounces of the ≈øtreined liquor into the Womb, three days before the Bath, and let the Patient keep it as long as ≈øhe can.

A Fumigation. Take juyce of Bi≈øtort, Schoenanth, Cypre≈øs nuts, red Storax, and Ma≈øtick, one ounce, Hares-dung; mix them, and pound them well together, and make a Fumigation; let the patient receive it ≈øitting on a ≈øtool with a hole in it.
Then let her u≈øe this following Bath.

Take Ba≈øil, Calamint, Betony, Melilot, Ro≈øes, each two handfuls. Thyme, Elder Germander, Mugwort, Savin, Balm, of each two handfuls, Feverfew, leaves of Laurel, and Lavender, each one handful, brui≈øe them together, and when the water boyls, throw them in; when they have boiled ≈øufficiently, let her take the waters off, and bath therein.

A Plai≈øter, Take of the ma≈øs of Emplai≈øter of Ma≈øtick, one ounce; of Plai≈øter for the Womb, two ounces, mingle them together, and extend them upon a round piece of red cloth; in the middle whereof, put one Trochi≈øch de galla Mo≈øchat. and ≈øix grains of Amber-greece; the la≈øt day of her bathing, when ≈øhe goes to bed, let her apply that plai≈øter to the region of her Matrix.
That Night, after due concoction, let her lye with her Husband,

div.head: To increa≈øe Lu≈øt, and to help Conception.
div.p: TAKE of the juyce of the Herb Mercury, and clarified Honey, of each one ounce; of meal of Nigella, two ounces; make thereof a ma≈øs, and let the Patient take two or three every night.

div.head: An Opiat for the ≈øame.
div.p: TAKE Con≈øerve of Eringo-roots, and Satyrion, each three ounces, green Ginger condited, Citron rind one ounce and a half, ≈øweet Almonds, Pi≈øtaches, Pine-Apples, Filberds, Che≈ønuts, Dates, the Pulp of Cocus's of each one ounce; of the reins and loins of the bea≈øt called a Skink, of the pizzle of a Bull, of the ≈øtones of a Hare, or Boar, of each half an ounce; ≈øeed of Par≈ønip, Rockquet, and Nettles, each three drams, white Pepper, Galang. and cinamon, each half a dram; all the≈øe things being well provided, and beaten mix them together with Wine, ≈øweetned and boiled to a thickne≈øs, and make an Opiate; add thereto of the powder of Glow-worms killed in the ≈øteam of Vinegar, one ≈øcruple.

div.head: For the ≈øame.
div.p: TAKE Pine-Apples, new Filberds peel'd, of each one ounce and a half, brains of Cock-≈øparrows two drams, new Satyrion, ro≈øted under the a≈øhes in wet tow, three drams; Stones of a Ram roa≈øted, half an ounce, Indian Nuts, one dram, pound them all with the broth of young Pigeons, then mingle therewith ≈øix ounces of refined Sugar, and boil it to a thickne≈øs, and add thereto the following pouders.

Take ≈øeed of Bombax clean≈øed, the be≈øt Cinamon, each two ≈øcruples, ≈øeed of Rocket, Onions, Nettles, and Par≈ønips, each half a dram, the reins of Skinks, Long Pepper, Galang. White Ginger, of each two ≈øcruples, ≈øhavings of the pizzle of a Hart four ≈øcruples; make a Confection, and take the quantity of a Walnut
after the fir≈øt ≈øleep, and two hours before you eat.

div.head: An application to be made upon the Privities pre≈øently after Delivery.
div.p: TAKE the whites of two Eggs, and oil of St. John's wort, of each one ounce and a half, oil of Myrtles one ounce; dip therein flat ≈øtoups of Hemp, and apply them to the lips of the Privities; do this three or four times a day, but take heed that it touch not the neck of the Matrix, becau≈øe it hinders its purgation.

div.head: The next day foment the≈øe parts with this following Fomentation.
div.p: TAKE of Wine and water half a pint, of Madder, Ro≈øe-mary, and St. John's-wort of each two little handfuls, let them boil for a Fomentation, which is to be applied hot, with the Hempen ≈øtoups afore≈øaid. This is to be done the ≈øecond day.

The third day, take wine a pint, water half a pint, Myrrh two drams, Cinamon two drams and a half, Allum two drams and a half; of the ≈øtones of Grapes two drams, the rind of Granates one dram, flowers of red Ro≈øes, one little handful and a half; make of this a decoction to foment the Womb until the ninth day twice a day.

Take oil of St. John's wort one ounce and a half, Sperma Coeti three drams, with a little wax; make of this an ointment to u≈øe at the beginning, with the afore≈øaid Fomentation to the lips of the Privities.
When you have taken away the ≈øheeps-skin, as is before ≈øaid, you may not only do as is there ≈øet down, but al≈øo u≈øe this following method.

Fir≈øt, take Sperma Coeti two ounces, oil of ≈øweet Almonds, Camomile, and St. John's wort, of each an ounce and a half, Goats ≈øuet one ounce, oil of Myrtles half an ounce, Saffron half a ≈øcruple, with this ointment being lukewarm, let the belly be well anointed once every day, then lay over the whole belly this following Cerecloth.

Take of new wax four ounces, Sperma Coeti one ounce and a half, Turpentine wa≈øht in Ro≈øewater two ounces and a half, oil of Almonds and St. John's-wort, of each one ounce, Saffron half a ≈øcruple. Let them melt and boyl together; when all the ingredients are well mixed, take them from the fire, and put into it the hempen cloth, and when it is cool, make it ≈ømooth, and apply it; let it be bound on with ≈øwathes, and do this for eight or nine days together.
The Woman being thus duly and rightly purged, and being free from any Fever, or other bad ≈øymptoms, ≈øhe may make u≈øe of the≈øe following Baths.

She ≈øhall go into the Bath three mornings together, the fir≈øt being luke-warm, ≈øtaying therein but a very little. The ≈øecond a little hotter, with ≈øomething longer continuance therein. But in the third let her ≈øtay as long as ≈øhe can.

div.head: The Bath in Summer.
div.p: TAKE a very clean Tub, wherein wine hath for ≈øometime been; put therein a quantity of the be≈øt Wine, and fill it with River-water, and the ≈øecond day after you have filled it, put therein Marjoram, Mug-wort, Agrimony, Penny-royal, of each two handfuls, then let them boil, and as they boil, now and then quench a hot piece of Iron therein, then add flowers of red Ro≈øes, two ounces and a half, Camomile, Dill, and Melilot, of each one ounce and a half, ≈øtrein them all, and ≈øo make the fir≈øt Bath, out of which let her come out as ≈øoon as ≈øhe feels any pain.
When ≈øhe comes out, let her take as follows.

Of the rind of Pome-citron, and Con≈øerve of Buglo≈øs, of each two ≈øcruples, let her take this going into her bed; then let her ≈øweat, and the ≈øweat being wiped off, let her eat ≈øome good and whol≈øome meat.

Take the water of the fir≈øt bath, and add thereto Bean-meal, and Oat-meal, of each two pound and a
half, meal of Tares one pound and a half, of Lupines one pound, Roach-allum, and Salt, of each four ounces, Cloves and Nutmegs, of each one dram; let them be aromatized with Benjamin and Storax, then put them all together in a bag, and let them boil in the fore≈øaid water.
When ≈øhe comes forth, let her take the afore≈øaid Bolus.

div.head: The third part.
div.p: FILL the Tub emptied of the Wine with River water, then add thereto a quantity of white-wine; then take of Ro≈øemary, Mint, Marjoram, Mugwort, Savin, Ground Ivy, of each two handfuls, Scarlet grains, four ounces, flowers of Ro≈øemary, Camomile, Mint, of each two ounces; Bean-meal, Oat-meal, of each one handful and a half, meal of Lupines and Tares, of each one pound; Cloves, Nutmegs, and Cinamon, of each half an ounce; brui≈øe all the≈øe things together, and let them boil in a little bag, adding thereto a pint and a half of Aqua vitae, and let burning Iron be often quenched therein. This is the third Bath, wherein ≈øhe is to ≈øtay as long as ≈øhe can.
When ≈øhe comes forth, let her take the ≈øame Bolus, as before.

div.head: After ≈øhe hath bathed, let her foment for one or two days the lower parts of her Belly.
div.p: TAKE of red Ro≈øes two handful and a half, Shoenanth half a handful, Myrtle-berries two drams and a half, Allum one dram and a half, Ma≈øtick three drams; let them be brui≈øed, and then boil together in ≈øower red wine: Add al≈øo two drams of Nutmegs; with this being taken lukewarm, let fomentation be made for eight days together.
The fomentation ended, let her receive this following Fume, in a Chair with a hole in it.

Take Lignum Aloes raw, half an ounce, Nutmegs, and Cypre≈øs nuts, of each two drams and a half; yellow
Amber one dram and a half, make all the≈øe into powder, and let her ≈øit over the Fume.

div.head: A Fomentation for the Womb the ≈øecond day after the Bath.
div.p: TAKE Galbanum and Cypre≈øs-nuts, of each half an ounce, rind of Granates two ounces, red Ro≈øes dryed, one ounce, Marjoram a handful Schoenanth one handful; Allum a dram and a half, Thyme half a handful; let them be boiled in ≈øharp wine for a Fomentation.

div.head: To cau≈øe the ≈øwelling of the Belly to fall.
div.p: SOme women have their bellies as much ≈øwelled after Delivery as it was before; when any ≈øuch thing happens, do as followeth.

Take half a pound of Figgs, Barley-meal and Beanmeal, of each four ounces, powder of Brick two ounces, Cypre≈øs nuts one ounce; let them boil all together in Smith's water, 'till it come to a thickne≈øs, then ≈øpread it upon a linnen cloth, and apply it warm to the Belly; re-iterate this often, and the belly will fall to its wonted ≈øhape. Or el≈øe,

Take meal of Beans, Rice, and Almonds, of each two ounces, powder of Brick one ounce and a half, Bole-Armoniac two ounces and a half, Dragons blood one ounce and a half; of Cypre≈øs-nuts ten drams, Scarlet grains, three ounces, Galls half an ounce, oil of Myrtles ≈øix ounces, wild Prunes, Ro≈øewater each a pint and a half; boil them to the thickne≈øs of a Pulte≈øs, and apply them as afore≈øaid to the belly.

div.head: Pain after Delivery.
div.p: TAke heed, that when you find the Patient in pain after Child-bearing, e≈øpecially on the right ≈øide, that the redne≈øs, or high colour of the Urine do not deceive you, whereby you may be induced to give refrigerating medicines, finding the whole body to be hot for ≈øuch urine proceeds from the greatne≈øs of the pain and commotion in the body, and the hot lying in bed.

Therefore if you find the Patient to be full of pain in
her belly, and ≈øides, and likewi≈øe perceive a retention of humours that ≈øhould be voided more fluently.
Take of Sweet-≈ømelling Flag, one ounce and a half, Zedoaory half an ounce, Mace eight ≈øcruples, Cinamon four ≈øcruples; make thereof a powder, and give her one dram at a time in powder.

Now though there be a Fever which ≈øeems burning, yet refrain not at all to give this powder; for it doth not for all that augment the Fever, but cau≈øes the Womb which was ≈øo lately and violently moved, to return to its former e≈øtate, and the pain of the Matrix being cea≈øed, the Fever will cea≈øe of it ≈øelf. Or el≈øe, take ≈øweet-≈ømelling-Flag one dram, Dittany half a dram; make thereof a powder.
Or, take root of Dittany one dram, Seed of Hartwort, and leaves of Rue, one ≈øcruple and a half, make them into powder, and give it as is before ≈øaid.

div.head: Again≈øt the ≈øwelling of the belly, after Delivery.
div.p: TAke Origanum, Night-≈øhade, Ma≈øtick, of each one ≈øcruple, Sagapenum as much as ≈øuffices; make of this ≈øeven Pills, let her take them all at once, and let her drink upon them four ounces of the water of the flowers of white Lillies.

div.head: Again≈øt wrinckles in the skin after Child bearing.
div.p: TAke oyl of ≈øweet-Almonds two ounces, Capons-grea≈øe half an ounce, liquid Storax half a dram, Mu≈øcilage of Tragacanth, extracted with Ro≈øe-water, two drams, Wax as much as ≈øuffices, make thereof a Cerecloath, and apply it to the belly.
Oyl of ≈øweet-Almonds, with the marrow of a Hart, is good al≈øo for this purpo≈øe.

div.head: This following oyntment may be u≈øed before a Woman lyes down.
div.p:
TAke the marrow of the fore foot of a weather in the full of the Moon, ≈øet it on the fire, and let it melt in Ro≈øe-water by degrees; you may conveniently
add to this Hens-grea≈øe, or oyl of Lillies.

div.head: Another.
div.p: TAke the Seam of a Goat, a Kid, and a Weather, of each three ounces; wa≈øh them diligently in Ro≈øe-water, adding Sperma Caeti, Ro≈øe-water as much as is ≈øufficient, and as you beat them, and mix them together, add powder of Ma≈øtick with the white of an egg, and ≈øo make an oyntment.

div.head: A Pomatum for the ≈øame.
div.p: TAke Oyl of ≈øweet-Almonds eight ounces, Sperma Coeti, Capons-grea≈øe, marrow of a Hart, and the bone of a Weather, four ounces; melt them all together between two di≈øhes, in water of Lillies, then in Ro≈øe-water.

div.head: An Oyntment for the ≈øame.
div.p: TAke of the Mu≈øcilage of the Seed of Fenugreek, and Hemp≈øeed, extracted in water of Lillies, one ounce, oyl of ≈øweet Almonds and Lillies, of each half an ounce, the blood of a Hog fryed, the fat of a Capon, and a wild Duck, of each ≈øix drams, with a little new wax; make thereof an oyntment, and keep it in a gla≈øs covered with wax.

div.head: Another.
div.p: TAke white Wax four ounces, melt it, and add thereto the marrow of fifty feet of black weathers, gathered in the full of the moon; when they are melted, add thereto oyl of ≈øweet Almonds, ≈øix ounces, wa≈øh them in water of Gourds and Lillies, 'till it grow cold, then wa≈øh it again in Ro≈øe-water; if it be too thick, you may add a little oyl of Olive.

Or, you may take oyl of ≈øweet-Almonds, and oyl of Olives of each five ounces, Clove-water four ounces, Musk three grains; a little Benjamin; mingle them, and brui≈øe them well together, and let them dige≈øt for twenty days together: Then dip your cloaths or skins therein, and keep them clean wrapt up in clean linnen.

div.head: THE COMPLETE MIDWIFE. Her Practice Enlarged.

argument.p: The ≈øerious and mo≈øt choice Secrets of Madam Louy≈øe Bourgioes, Midwife to the Queen of France; which ≈øhe left to her Daughter as a Guide for her: And al≈øo for the Practice of all di≈øcreet Midwives, to prevent all dangerous Mi≈øtakes in a work of ≈øo high Concernment; nece≈ø≈øary to be known by all Child-bearing Women, and others.

div.p:
IN the Year 1630. a young Lady whom I was wont to bring to bed, pa≈ø≈øing by my hou≈øe, came in to me, and told me, that ≈øhe was four Months gone, and that ≈øhe perceived the Infant to ≈øtir; about a Month after, ≈øhe came to ≈øee me, and told me that ≈øhe was in much pain, for that ≈øhe had not perceived the Infant to ≈øtir in two days, and that therefore ≈øhe believed that it was dead, by rea≈øon of a certain very great Fright which ≈øhe had had; for at the time that ≈øhe was frighted, ≈øhe perceived the Child to move, but after that never; and her belly began by little and little to wax le≈øs; and about three weeks after ≈øhe had that reflux of milk that Women u≈øe to have that lie in; when this was gone, ≈øhe had no grievance; yet ≈øeeing her often, and knowing her to be big with Child, ≈øhe asked me my advice, to know what ≈øhe ≈øhould do. Whereupon I asked her, if any ill vapours ro≈øe up into
her mouth? ≈øhe told me no. If ≈øhe had not lo≈øt her appetite? ≈øhe an≈øwered, that ≈øhe never had a better in her life; her heart was light, her body in good temper, ≈øo that there was nothing that troubled her but an apprehen≈øion ≈øhe had, that the Child was dead: whereupon I made her try all means to make the Infant ≈øtir; but ≈øhe notwith≈øtanding felt nothing, only ≈øhe perceived that ≈øomething did heave a little upon the operation of the Remedies, which was nothing but the Matrix, which being now di≈øtempered and grown cold, did as it were an≈øwer the hot Remedies, te≈øtifying thereby ≈øome good which it received thereby.
