I advi≈øed her to be patient, and to wait Nature's lei≈øure, which is provident enough of it ≈øelf; telling her that I had ≈øeen an infant which had lain a long time in the womb without budging, which for all that was not dead, although you could not perceive in the woman any thing, but the ≈øigns of a dead Child. I had oftentimes brought the Lady to bed, and ≈øhe ≈øtill had very good Deliveries, and very ≈øound Children, of a good colour, ≈øo that I believing her to be of a ≈øound con≈øtitution, thought that if the Infant were dead, Nature, which was very ≈øtrong in her, would expel it in time convenient, and that ≈øhe ≈øhould not be forced, not having given any te≈øtimony of defect; re≈øolving al≈øo, when her Reckoning was out, if then Nature ≈øhewed it ≈øelf weak, that we would con≈øult her Friends and Phy≈øicians. Many of her Friends told me, that they doubted that ≈øhe was deceived in thinking her ≈øelf to be with Child; to which I an≈øwered, that they might be confident that it was ≈øo. In brief, ≈øhe was brought to bed, ≈øixteen weeks after the fright which ≈øhe had. Now here ari≈øeth a great doubt, whether the Child died at the hour of her being ≈øcared, by rea≈øon that it did not move in all that time? A rea≈øon that the Child was not dead,
may be, becau≈øe that the Gentlewoman had not her milk till within three weeks after; and yet I cannot but think that it died at the ≈øame time; for certainly, by that fright the vital ≈øpirits were ravi≈øhed from it, and the blood of the Arteries retired to the heart of the Mother, not being di≈øtributed to the Infant, but at the good plea≈øure of Nature; the cour≈øe of which being ≈øtopped, it retired to its fir≈øt ≈øource, through which the Child ≈øuffering a ≈øuffocation, gave a violent motion; and now, after the fright, was come to her ≈øelf, and that Nature would have returned to fini≈øh her work, ≈øhe was not deceived, becau≈øe the vital faculties of the Infant were extinct; and, notwith≈øtanding all this, the Mother not cea≈øing to re≈øtrain the men≈øtrual blood as ≈øhe was accu≈øtomed; that finding it ≈øelf ≈øtopped, and ≈øtill increa≈øing without that u≈øe made of it that was wont, it made a reflux to the Brea≈øts, which flowed down again in five or ≈øix days; for the Infant coming to decrea≈øe in the womb, now way was made for them, which came not down for all that, but in the Delivery and after; which was in this manner: At the end of the ≈øixteenth week after the fright, ≈øhe had pains in the night, ≈øhe thinking to endure them well enough 'till morning, in the morning cau≈øed me to be ≈øent for. I came to her, finding with her a Phy≈øician, and ≈øundry others of her acquaintance. The Phy≈øician that expected me, had ordered a Cly≈øter to give it her if I thought it to the purpo≈øe; I found her pale, cold, and yet in a ≈øweat, with ≈øo little pul≈øe, that I e≈øteemed her dead; I touched her, and found ≈øhe had been in Travail, which had been too long neglected, I called pre≈øently for a plain ≈øilver di≈øh, into which I ≈øqueez'd the juice of half a Citron, and ≈øet it upon a Chafing di≈øh of coals; being warmed, I cau≈øed her to take it; this re≈øtored Nature a little, and ≈øtirred up her
pains, and then I a≈ø≈øi≈øted her; notwith≈øtanding ≈øome of the waters ran down: After her fir≈øt throw, the legs and thighs of the Child came forth: Now finding the Infant to be dead, and ≈øeeing that ≈øhe was troubled with no more throws, I was afraid of drawing it forth, for fear it might be rotten: I did give her a Cly≈øter without moving her, the force of which bringing the Child away, ≈øhe was delivered of a dead Infant, all over of a leaden colour, without any ill vapour; the Secondine ≈øound and fair as you ≈øhall ≈øee, her purgations as clear as could be, and ≈øhe had as good and as happy a Lying in, as any woman in the World; all which time ≈øhe had not the appearance of any Milk at all. Hence we may admire the effects of Nature, which are wonderful! But in ≈øuch ca≈øes Women mu≈øt be ≈øure in due time and place; for if a Woman do re≈øi≈øt her pains, and doth not put her ≈øelf in a right po≈øture, ≈øhe runs a great hazard of her Life.

div.head: A ≈øecond Ob≈øervation of a Woman that had been in Travail nine days.
div.p:
BEing called to the Labour of a Woman that had been in Travail nine or ten days, of whom there was little hope; I went, and there found the Woman almo≈øt dead, her eyes open and fixed, her no≈øe ≈øhrunk in, her breath ≈ømelling like a Charnel-hou≈øe; and ≈øhe took nothing down into her ≈øtomach, that ≈øhe did not in≈øtantly vomit up again; ≈øhe had drunk up above two pints of water in an hour, and by her bed, there was a whole ≈øea of tho≈øe things that ≈øhe had vomited up. They gave her cold water, and the yolk of an Egg ≈øometimes, though it came up again at the ≈øame in≈øtant. She felt no pain of the Infant, but finding her Womb was open and her waters beginning to come down: I found that ≈øhe had been in Travail; only Nature was oppre≈ø≈øed, and had not had any good a≈ø≈øi≈øtance,
≈øo that the Infant was retired back again, which ≈øtifled the Mother, and provoked her vomiting. Upon which, I gave my advice, and though I thought my ≈øelf come a little too late, yet I re≈øolved to do what lay in the power of my Art; and therefore I re≈øolved to give her a good ≈øtrong Cly≈øter to awaken Nature, and to bring the Infant lower, which did according to our hopes; afterwards to drink a ≈ømall quantity of Rhubarb-water which ≈øtayed with her; a little after, I gave her the Yolk of an Egg, which ≈øtayed with her al≈øo, cau≈øing her to drink nothing but Rhubarb-water; and at every hour's end, I gave her the Yolk of an Egg, which did al≈øo ≈øtay with her; by this time, Nature began to ≈øtrengthen it ≈øelf, and the pains of the Infant came again; and in le≈øs than two hours, after the Cly≈øter and other nouri≈øhment given, when I ≈øaw her pretty well, and that Nature ≈øtrove to expel the Infant, I gave her half a dram of Confection of Alkermes in a little Wine; and a little while after I cau≈øed her to take another Cly≈øter, into which I put a little Hiera, and a little Benedictum, which fini≈øhed the work; for ≈øhe was then delivered of a very lu≈øty Child, which lived about two days: I came thither about noon, and ≈øhe was brought to bed before nine at night. I wrote this thus particularly, to let you know that oft-times for want of knowing where the mi≈øchief lies, the Remedies are mi≈øapplied; and indeed a Woman Travailling in the ninth Month, ought chiefly to be ≈øuccoured with Cly≈øters.

div.head: Of a Woman here in Town that bare her Children eleven months, and could not be Delivered.
div.p:
BEing called to a Woman in this Town, that thought her ≈øelf three months and a half gone, which is one of the Terms of time, wherein commonly the Moles and Fal≈øe-births are delivered; having
then ≈øome lo≈øs of blood and pain, I was ≈øent for, and judged it to have been ≈øome imperfect Conception, and therefore I u≈øed all means to a≈ø≈øi≈øt her; yet could ≈øhe not expel it, for all the≈øe long pains: Whereupon finding ≈øome ≈øtrange apprehen≈øions in her, I wondered; for, in all the time of my Practice, I never knew ≈øuch a thing as that dangerous in my life. But I afterwards found this apprehen≈øion to come from a certain accident that had happened to a Si≈øter of hers, who being with Child, carried it very well to the end of the ninth month; at the end of which ≈øhe began to be in pain, as if ≈øhe would have cried out: the pains were great and long, which they were not at all a≈øtoni≈øhed at, by rea≈øon that it was her fir≈øt Child, yet were not the≈øe pains accompanied with any ≈øigns of Labour, as, the opening the exterior orifice of the Womb: And they continued thus for the ≈øpace of two days and two nights. Many medicines were u≈øed to facilitate the birth, but to no purpo≈øe; and now ≈øhe felt not the Child ≈øtir any more. And now it was concluded, that ≈øhe had mi≈øtaken her time; and now being at re≈øt for four or five days, and growing weary of the City, ≈øhe went into the Country, and being returned without taking notice that ≈øhe had received any harm, ≈øhe was taken with the ≈øame pains as before, which continued a day and a night, and then cea≈øed as before. This was adjudged to be certain pains of the Colick; after this, ≈øhe endured one month longer in her former e≈øtate, which was now the eleventh month compleat; at the end of which ≈øhe felt ≈øome little pain like throws, which pre≈øently affected her heart; upon which ≈øhe was laid upon her bed, and they brought her Wine; but at the very in≈øtant ≈øhe died, without having any time to call for a≈ø≈øi≈øtance: Seeing her dead, they perceived upon the right ≈øide of her belly a very black
mark about the breadth of a Dollar; being opened, they found the Child all putrified. Hence we mu≈øt ob≈øerve, that in Women that are big with Child, who have frequent pain, and nothing coming forth, the Matrix that ≈øhould open, rather ≈øhuting it ≈øelf clo≈øer, whether it be at the time or no, you mu≈øt make for them cly≈øters that expel wind, which are to be reiterated as occa≈øion requires; which Rule if it had been ob≈øerved in this Woman, ≈øhe, nor the Fruit of her Womb, had not peri≈øhed in that manner.

div.head: Of the common opinion, that a Woman ≈øeven months gone, ought to walk very much; and of the Accidents that happen thereby.
div.p:
IT is a common error among Midwives, which is not to be pa≈ø≈øed by, that a Woman with Child, when ≈øhe hath gone ≈øeven Months of her time, is to walk much: Upon a conceit that exerci≈øe is very proper for her; for that, they ≈øay, doth loo≈øen the Child from the reins, and facilitates the Birth. I confe≈øs, as to facilitating of the Birth, it may ≈øomething avail; only I mu≈øt add this al≈øo, that it is better to draw away the Child than to break it; and moreover it is better to be ≈øomething longer in Travail, than to incurr two or three evils which ordinarily happen; the fir≈øt is, that the Child in the end of the ≈øeventh month, doth make certain endeavours to free it ≈øelf from the belly of the Mother; and without doubt his fir≈øt endeavour is to turn him≈øelf in the belly of the Mother; for the Infant turns him≈øelf a good while before the time of Labour; and therefore, I ≈øay, Exerci≈øe is very dangerous: The fir≈øt rea≈øon is, becau≈øe by pu≈øhing downward the belly is dilated, and e≈øpecially in ≈øuch as carry their Children low; and be≈øides, oft times the head drags down all the body of the Womb, and
loo≈øens the ligaments in ≈øuch a ≈øort, that after Delivery it can hardly be put into its place again. Be≈øides, the Children having their heads between the bones of the Mother, by much walking of the Mother, they come to be brui≈øed, ≈øo that the Infants do many times dye, and no man is able to give a cau≈øe why; for the branches of veins which are for the nouri≈øhment of the brain open in an in≈øtant, letting out the blood which is contained in them; and when the corruption is ingendered, there follows immediately Feavers, and corruption of the Infant: At other times, Women coming to ≈øit upon a hard ≈øeat, do brui≈øe the head of the Infant, which cau≈øes like accidents; and in all the≈øe accidents, none but the Midwife is to blame, unle≈øs the belly it ≈øelf be ≈øpoyled. This, they ≈øay, is the fault of the Nur≈øe, who did not apply remedies fit to re≈øtore the fault. I mu≈øt confe≈øs that remedies do much avail to the recovery of the afore≈øaid malady, and do much avail to the healing of that di≈øea≈øe; but, to re≈øtore it to ≈øuch an e≈øtate as it was in before, I ≈øay it is a thing impo≈ø≈øible for medicines to perform: For the skin which is once ≈øeparated, cannot be clo≈øed again without a ≈øcar. I would now not only blame tho≈øe that a≈ø≈øi≈øt them, but, by putting the actions of people before them, ≈øhew them where lies the fault, and what rea≈øon I have ≈øo to do: I mu≈øt confe≈øs that fal≈øe accu≈øations have made the mo≈øt able Midwives timorous; for they lye liable to ≈øo many cau≈øes of detraction, that all that are either but indifferent good, or el≈øe not good, are all accu≈øed alike, if any thing fall out ami≈øs with the Patient, as if they were the ab≈øolute cau≈øes of the evil, or that it lay ab≈øolutely in their power to hinder it. It happens al≈øo many times, that a Midwife worthy of that name, doth deliver a woman from death, and yet in the place of much prai≈øe, ≈øhe incurs
many times much blame; ≈øo that they are oftentimes con≈øtrained (to avoid the ≈øcandal) to adverti≈øe them of their ill procedures, and to give place to tho≈øe that know not how to do things with that ≈øweetne≈øs and judgment. The fault is no where but in the ignorance, ≈øcandal, and ingratitude of Women toward tho≈øe of this Calling. Be≈øides, there are a company of young Women, that becau≈øe they have had one Child, do give them≈øelves a great deal of liberty to talk of the≈øe things. Cries one, I like not the≈øe Midwives that handle me; I will change mine, cries another, for that trick al≈øo; ≈øo that many out of a kind of fear have a greater de≈øire and will to be complacent than to do well; and ≈øo ≈øitting with their hands before them, entertain their Patients with di≈øcour≈øe; who for all that feeling their pains, are con≈øtrained to thru≈øt forward, upon which the head of the Infant coming fir≈øt, for the mo≈øt part the womb ≈øerves for a Head-band, which comes forth before it; whereas, might the Midwife be permitted to touch the Patient, they might put back the Womb, and prevent many accidents that happen in Lyings-in, which happen ≈øometimes to be a total relaxation of the Matrix; of which when the Women complain to their complacent and flattering Midwives, they reply; why, Mi≈øtre≈øs, you know I did not touch you; and be≈øides, I am not in fault if you have been touched: This is the fruit of their reproaches. You will ≈øay, there are abundance of Countrey-women that the Midwife never touch at all, and they do not know ≈øcarcely, whether a Woman lye in, or no, unle≈øs they ≈øee the Infant appear. But they are not free from the Di≈øea≈øe whereof I ≈øpeak; for I have ≈øeen ≈øo great a company of them, that I have been afraid to behold them. This comes, ≈øay the Midwives, becau≈øe they touched them not, and
that it is occa≈øioned, either becau≈øe the Infant is too big, or they ≈øay, it is a bur≈øtne≈øs, or the coming down of the great gut; the mo≈øt ≈øubtile put up a Clew of Thred, the others a Ball of wax, which ea≈øeth a little while, but comes out again every hour.

div.head: Of a Child which they thought ≈øick of the Epilep≈øie, occa≈øioned by the ≈øickne≈øs of the Mother, and of the cau≈øe.
div.p: ONE day there came to me a Gentle-woman, to de≈øire me, that I would give her ≈øomething for her Daughter that was ≈øick of the Mother: When her Mother related what ≈øhe ailed, I de≈øired to ≈øee her. I ≈øaw her, and ≈øhe had in one hour two ≈øeveral fits, which was an affrightment, attended with very much yawning, after which ≈øhe remained in a very great weakne≈øs; all which time the mouth of the Child was drawn more to one ≈øide than the other; the eyes when ≈øhe was out of the fit were open, and fixed in one place; I inquired of the Mother, at what age her daughter came to be fir≈øt troubled with it; who an≈øwer'd, that ≈øhe had been in this Town ≈øomthing more than a year; and that before that time ≈øhe was never troubled with any ≈øuch thing: I gave her the be≈øt Coun≈øel that I could; and fir≈øt of all I bid her to carry her again to the place where ≈øhe was fir≈øt nur≈øed: u≈øing ≈øome few remedies that were convenient; which pro≈øpered ≈øo well, that, after ≈øhe came thither, ≈øhe had but one fit, though ≈øhe had them ≈øo frequently before. Of this no other cau≈øe can be given, but that the air of the place where ≈øhe lived for that year being thicker then that where ≈øhe was nur≈øed, cau≈øed in her a ≈øtirring of the humours, with which the mother was continually afflicted, ≈øhe being di≈øpo≈øed naturally to that kind of di≈øea≈øe.

div.head: Of a young Woman, who being ≈øtruck upon the belly by her Husband with his foot, was in great pain, and could not be brought to bed without the help of a Chirurgeon.
div.p: I Will here relate a thing which I have ≈øeen in a young Woman; that, if the like accident ≈øhould happen, the ≈øame Remedies may be applied. There came a Woman to me, to declare to me a di≈øea≈øe with which ≈øhe was troubled, de≈øiring me to do my utmo≈øt; for that hitherto, ≈øhe could not lye in without the help of a Chirurgeon, who had already killed two of her Children. I, knowing what an ill Husband ≈øhe had, and that he had given her a blow upon the belly with his foot, and had broken the Peritonaeum; which was the rea≈øon, that part of her guts hung down upon the ≈øhare-bone like the bag of a Bag-pipe; to which place, being big, the Womb jutted out, ≈øo that when the time came, the Infant had not liberty to turn it ≈øelf; ≈øo that the Midwife ≈øeeing ≈øhe could not have the Child without lo≈øing the Woman, was fain to make u≈øe of Chirurgeon. I con≈øidered her di≈øea≈øe, and ordered her to carry a ≈øwatheband, ≈øuch a one as Women with Child carry to ≈øupport their bellies, only made a little more hollow; and I cau≈øed her to wear it as they that are bur≈øt do wear half-flops, lying ≈ømooth with cu≈øhionets within, and never to ri≈øe without this, whether big, or no; which ≈øhe did, and ≈øtill does, and bears as fine Children, and lyes in as well, as any other Woman.

div.head: Of two Deliveries of one Woman.
div.p:
THere was a Woman, who being come to a ≈øufficient age, became big: ≈øhe cau≈øeth two of the be≈øt Midwives of the Countrey to a≈ø≈øi≈øt her in her Lying in; the hour being come, they did as Art commanded them, which was, The Child coming well into the world; to keep her in a good ≈øituation, to cau≈øe her to eat things which were only for the purpo≈øe, to keep
her moderately warm, and then to bring her pains to a good i≈ø≈øue. I excu≈øed the pa≈ø≈øion and impatience of friends, but I would not do any thing again≈øt my duty for complacency; a fault that is ≈øoon committed, but not ≈øo ea≈øily repented of; This Woman was pretty long, as mo≈øt Women are of their fir≈øt Children; in which time her husband, altogether impatient, and ≈øeeing her to doubt the report of the Midwives, Therefore, ≈øaid he, here is a Chirurgeon hard by, who may be ≈øent for to re≈øolve the doubt of the Midwives; he ≈øent for him ju≈øt about the hour that the Woman was to be brought to bed: The Chirurgeon when he came, ≈øaw that the Child was ready to come forth. The Midwives who had given way to the Chirurgeon, thinking to take their place again as ≈øoon as he had touched her, to make his report, were deceived; for he ≈øeeing the bu≈øine≈øs ready to be done, told her Husband that it was nece≈ø≈øary for him to operate, but that he would proceed with ≈øo much indu≈øtry, that he would not only bring forth a ≈øound and a lu≈øty child, but moreover that he would render his wife al≈øo into a ≈øafe condition. The Midwives when they would have ≈øpoken, were put to ≈øilence. The Gentlewoman was pre≈øently delivered, and he ≈øtayed but a little while to receive his reward: Thus the Midwives that had attended long, and all the while of the Travail, were di≈øpi≈øed, and put off; and the Chirurgeon extolled and prai≈øed, and well rewarded with ≈øeveral mo≈øt obliging and courteous invitations. About a year after, he was entertained upon the former ≈øcore like a Prince; the hour of her Labour came again; and the Gentleman was gone to vi≈øit ≈øome of his friends, having ≈øuch a confidence in the Chirurgeon, that he ≈øet his mind at re≈øt for any danger. The Labour of this child was not like the Labour of the other child; for it came with the feet foremo≈øt; and when the whole body was come
forth, the head could not be got forth. He had brought with him no in≈øtruments, thinking that this Delivery would have been like the other; but ≈øeeing him≈øelf at a ≈øtand, he ≈øent to a Chirurgeon not far off for an I≈øtrument: in the mean time, he ≈øent into the kitchen for a Ladle, with a hook at the end thereof, to draw forth the child. He drew it ≈øo well, that he drew away the life of the child: and without ≈øeeking any further for any body to ≈øaddle his hor≈øe, or bidding any body farewell, he fled his wayes. This may be an in≈øtruction to tho≈øe that are ≈øo ready to entertain Mountebanks, and Empericks; than whom, there are no men more prodigal of the life of another for money.

div.head: Of a Woman, that becau≈øe ≈øhe would not be ruled in her Lying in, died.
div.p:
I Was one day called to the Labour of a woman, which had good Deliveries of her Sons and Daughters, at their due time, although her Deliveries of Boys were always more difficult than tho≈øe of her Daughters; being come to her, I found her walking in the Chamber with her leggs bare, in a ≈øea≈øon that was not over-hot. I cau≈øed her to be put into her bed to warm her again, but ≈øhe would by no means endure it; although I prayed her, ≈øhe was angry with me, and told me, This was not the rule, to be con≈øtrained. The Mi≈øtre≈øs and the Nur≈øe combined again≈øt me; the night approached; the waters being come down, I feared the ill ≈øucce≈øs of this bu≈øine≈øs, that her di≈øea≈øe would be irrecoverable by rea≈øon of her ≈øelf-will'dne≈øs. I de≈øired her husband to u≈øe his endeavour, but he could do no more with her than I: about midnight, I prayed her to go to bed again, and to warm her ≈øelf, and unle≈øs ≈øhe would do ≈øo, I could do nothing. She told me, I under≈øtood nothing in re≈øpect of a certain Surgeon, who, when ≈øhe had ≈øuch a kind of Labour before, only toucht her with his finger, and delivered her; and that ≈øhe
would have him. I was content, and ≈øo ≈øhe ≈øent for him. He came very confidently, but his work was not at ≈øo ea≈øie a pa≈øs as formerly: he put a good large Table-Napkin before him, tru≈ø≈øing it up to his elbows, ≈øaying he was as able to deliver her as before. She would no more ≈øee me after his arrival: the Surgeon to whom I repre≈øented (after his arrival) all that I had under≈øtood and ≈øeen, and the fear which I had of her, told me that all would be well. At day break, a neighbour of mine calling me away, I de≈øired her Husband to let me go; but he was unwilling, unle≈øs I would promi≈øe to come again, which I did; and as ≈øoon as the door was open, one of the ≈øervants told me, another Midwife was ≈øent for. Her Husband de≈øired me again, that ≈øince the Chyrurgeon failed of his skill, I would u≈øe my skill; but it was too late, for the Chyrurgeon left them, and the Woman died. See here how ill a thing it is to be opinionated, for I could ea≈øily have delivered her, if ≈øhe would have been ruled by me.

div.head: Of certain Women that bear Children, and lie in before their time: And others, at their full time, who grow big, and full of humours, which cau≈øeth the death of the Child, pre≈øently after their Delivery; their Children being nouri≈øhed in their bellies, like fi≈øh only with water.
div.p:
I Knew a Gentlewoman who had Laid-in three times, but yet none of her Children lived: I de≈øired her to take a Phy≈øician that might give advice both to her and me, and to order her ≈øome remedies, and a government of diet to keep her from ≈øuffering the like accidents for time to come. We cho≈øe a Phy≈øician, who pre≈øcribed certain Tablets or Trochi≈øques, to take from the time ≈øhe began to grow big, until the time of her Delivery, twice a week; as al≈øo to take the water of Indian Bul-ru≈øh, and of Sar≈øaparilla, to mix in her drink, or broth, as often as ≈øhe would, having a
due regard to the heat of her blood: She ob≈øerved every tittle of his directions, which made her to bear a Son, alive, ≈øound, and healthful. She continued the≈øe Remedies four years together, but the next time ≈øhe grew big with Child, ≈øhe thought that Nature of ‚Ä¢ t ≈øelf would be ≈øufficient: I coun≈øelled her to the contrary, but ≈øhe hearkned not; ≈øo that when her time came, ≈øhe was brought to bed of a dead Child. I ≈øhall give you the Receipt of the Tablets, and of the water, for the benefit of Women that are ≈øubject to an ill Delivery, by rea≈øon of the great quantity of water, which hindereth the Child from turning in the Womb: The Water is made in this manner.

Take two pints, or two pints and a half of water; put therein half an ounce of the root of Indian Bul-ru≈øh, and an ounce of Sar≈øaparilla; put this in the drink, and let it infu≈øe one night; mix it with the drink, or el≈øe drink it pure.
The Tablets are made after this fa≈øhion
Take Mace, Saunders, Rhubarb, Pearl, and Coral, Sena, of each 25 grains, with one ounce and half of Sugar; let every Tablet weigh ≈øix drams.

div.head: The ob≈øervation of a Woman, who was thought unable to bear any more Children; yet contrary to expectation, was delivered of one; and the rea≈øon thereof.
div.p:
THere are certain Women who have the neck of the Womb long and hardned, by a cold humor that falls down thereon, and renders them uncapable of conceiving. One I have heard of, who was afflicted with this Di≈øea≈øe, and voided a great deal of putrified blood; by a certain fumigation that I taught her, ≈øhe was cured. I can ≈øay this of a certainty, that after this Woman had voided this putrefaction, ≈øhe came to ≈øee me with a very lu≈øty Child, and was big of another; for being di≈øcharged of the burden of putrified blood, ≈øhe found her ≈øelf marvellou≈øly free for
Conception; for the Matrix that began to be ulcerated, was now fortified, and ≈øtrengthned again, and the natural heat began to take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion there again.

div.head: A good ob≈øervation in the choice of Nur≈øes.
div.p:
THere be two ≈øort of Nur≈øes which I have found: The one is of ≈øuch Women as are of an ill humor, or juice; which humors ≈øettle all in the milk, for that is the place where the≈øe fluxes di≈øcharge them≈øelves. The≈øe Women are in a better condition being Nur≈øes, than when they are not Nur≈øes; and being not Nur≈øes are ≈øubject to pains, ≈øometimes in the arms, and ≈øometimes in the ≈øhoulders, ≈øometimes in one of their legs or thighs; or el≈øe they are ≈øubject to the watring of the eyes, or ≈øwelling in the corner of the eye or no≈øe. The≈øe are good Nur≈øes, as long as Children are fat; but the fat is ≈øoft, and the Infants dull and ≈øotti≈øh, giving no great ≈øigns of vivacity; coming to bear teeth, they are very ≈øickly, and do ordinarily die, by rea≈øon of the flux, that pu≈øheth out too great company of teeth at once. The Children that e≈øcape this, are more ill juic'd in their infancy, than are their Fathers and Mothers in their old Age. If the flux that afflicts them be ≈øalt, the milk is of a blacki≈øh and blewi≈øh colour, if it be of Choler, it is more dangerous than the other, for that is more dangerous and venomous to the Children. There is another ≈øort of Nur≈øes more dangerous than the≈øe I have now ≈øpoken of; who pre≈øently after they have Lain in (that is, three, or four, or five, or ≈øix months) are taken with their Purgations, a thing which never happens to good Nur≈øes: for this is the cour≈øe of Nature, that all the blood which is retained, is dedicated to the nouri≈øhment of the Infant. This is cau≈øed by a moderate heat which is in their blood; and, to ≈øay true, as ≈øoon as ever this happens, the Infant mu≈øt be taken away, for they are more apt to conceive, than to nur≈øe; and if they continue Nur≈øes,
they do but ruine the Children. This is but too much experimented, and I ≈øpeak this to ≈øave the lives of a great many Children, when ≈øeeing them ≈øuck I have di≈øcovered their want of milk; ≈øo that I may ≈øay, there dies a third part of the Children, for want of taking care in this particular, which yet ≈øeem fat, and in good ca≈øe.

This is the cau≈øe of great Cholicks and windine≈ø≈øes in Children, which kills them in a moment; for the lea≈øt Feaver that takes them, carries them away. Be≈øides this, there are ≈øome who≈øe milk is ≈øo little, but withal ≈øo thick, that it ≈øticks upon the tongue, palate, and throat, which cau≈øes, as it were, a white canker, which is more and more heated by rea≈øon of their forcible drawing in vain; and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth all the throat, whereby they are hindred from ≈øucking. The≈øe Nur≈øes will milk after this, a drop or two out of their brea≈øts, crying, Look ye, the Child cares not for ≈øucking. I never knew more abu≈øe in any thing, than in Nur≈øes: for let them make what excu≈øe they will, it is nothing but nece≈ø≈øity that reduceth them to be ≈øuch. Although the greate≈øt part do ≈øay, that it is to get acquaintance; yet when they have a Child, whether they have milk or no, yet they de≈øire not to part with it, no more than they do to drown them≈øelves; whereby the Parents are often deceived. And therefore the Mothers ought to have a great care, and to make it their bu≈øine≈øs to ≈øurprize the Nur≈øes at their own hou≈øes, that if there be any mi≈øcarriage, they may find it out. And indeed it is very rea≈øonable, that the cau≈øe of the≈øe poor creatures that cannot complain, ≈øhould not be neglected; and the≈øe She-murderers be made known, that they may not go unpuni≈øhed.

div.head: Of a Woman which I laid two ≈øeveral times, and of the difference of her bearing of two Children, proceeding from ≈øeveral cau≈øes.
div.p: I Was called to lay a Woman, who ≈øaid ≈øhe was gone her full time; ≈øhe had the ≈øame pains that women are wont to have in the time of Travail, but her waters came not down. At one forcible Throw ≈øhe ca≈øt forth a great membrane like a Hogs-bladder, all united within and without, only that it had divers branches of veins, as you ≈øhall ≈øee in a bladder; which I pre≈øently cut, and found therein a little Infant, well ≈øhaped, ≈øwiming in black waters: it had gone its full time, and was ≈øo lean, that it re≈øembled a meer Picture; it had the Navel-≈øtring holding fa≈øt to the bladder, where it is to be ≈øuppo≈øed tho≈øe ≈ømall branches of the veins do end. Here, as I gue≈øs, as long as it found any blood, it lay langui≈øhing; but, that beginning to fail, it died, and pre≈øently voided tho≈øe excrements that were contained in the inte≈øtines, which being mingled in the waters, made them black: And as for the Woman her ≈øelf, ≈øhe was the fulle≈øt of humours that ever I ≈øaw in my life. Another time I brought the ≈øame Woman to bed, who was delivered of a Child that came the ordinary way into the World, with the head foremo≈øt; now I perceiving her in Labour, found nothing at fir≈øt but a certain ≈øoftne≈øs, as if the waters were coming down: Afterwards I perceived a certain bag with hair; athwart which I ≈øaw certain great knobs or heads. The Infant being come forth was not yet formed; the face and the head were like vizards more than any face; it had the form of a no≈øe, but it was ≈øoft like wooll: The head was full of water, and tho≈øe knobs which appeared, were nothing but the futures of the head, which the too great abundance of water had disjoyn'd: in the hands it had nothing but hair in≈øtead of bones, and the toes were of the ≈øame: The woman her ≈øelf was ≈øaid to be extream cholerick, and moi≈øt.

div.head: In≈øtructions of a famous and dying Midwife to her Daughter, touching the practice of this Art.
div.p: DAughter, if the excellencies of what is to be known in this World are to be found not in one, but in ≈øeveral Countries; certainly they are mo≈øt able to in≈øtruct who have had the greate≈øt experience, and longe≈øt travel in the World; which is the rea≈øon, that in this ≈ømall Treati≈øe I have not tyed up my ≈øelf to the rules ≈øolely of my own Nation, but have ≈øearched the ≈øtudies al≈øo of other Nations, that thou maye≈øt be bettered, not only by my experience, but by the Labour of others.

In the fir≈øt place therefore, I exhort thee to be diligent, and to leave nothing un≈øearched that may tend to the advantage of thy practice. And to this end, be always learning to the la≈øt day of thy life; which that thou maye≈øt not cea≈øe to do, be always humble; for tho≈øe that are proud and ob≈øtinate, never gain upon the hearts of tho≈øe that are knowing in ≈øecrets. Be ≈øure thou never make trial of any new Remedy or Receipt, either upon poor or rich, if thou be'≈øt not a≈ø≈øured of the quality and operation thereof; and that it can do no hurt, whether it be applied outwardly, or taken inwardly. Hide none of tho≈øe good Receipts which thou knowe≈øt, either from Midwives, or Phy≈øicians; for otherwi≈øe they will e≈øteem them as little as tho≈øe of Mountebanks, as if thou had≈øt but one cure, like them, for all Di≈øea≈øes, and yet did≈øt brag as they do of doing wonders, yet ≈øtill conceal their Receipts. Thou mu≈øt ≈øpeak freely of that which thou knowe≈øt, and give a rea≈øon for what thou ≈øaye≈øt. Be not negligent, but ≈øo increa≈øe thy Talent, that people may ≈øay, you are better than ever your Mother was: I mu≈øt tell thee, thou ha≈øt taken a matter of great importance into thy hand; and that in this Art there are two ways ea≈øie to take; the one to ≈øave thy credit, and the other to lo≈øe
it. Above all things, you mu≈øt beware (for any trea≈øure in the world) of adhering to one vice, ≈øuch as they are guilty of who give Remedies to cau≈øe Abortion; for tho≈øe that do ill, and tho≈øe that ≈øeek a damnable remedy, are wicked in a high degree. But it is a higher degree of wickedne≈øs for tho≈øe that are no way ingaged in the bu≈øine≈øs, for lucres ≈øake to kill both the body and ≈øoul of an Infant. This I do not ≈øpeak that thou ≈øhoulde≈øt refu≈øe to give Remedies upon ju≈øt occa≈øions: but to take heed how you be cheated by ≈øubtle per≈øons, who ≈øhall tell you fine ≈øtories of the di≈øea≈øes of their Wives, or Daughters, which they may ≈øay are very hone≈øt, hoping to get from you ≈øome Receipts to effect their wicked de≈øigns, ≈øend them to the Phy≈øicians, for you may give them a lawful excu≈øe, in ≈øaying that ≈øuch matters do not belong to your charge. Never keep the cawl called Amnios, which covers the head and ≈øhoulders of the Child, for Sorcerers to make u≈øe of.

If you are ≈øent for to any hou≈øe, inform your ≈øelf of what condition they are, and whether they be rich, or whether they be the poore≈øt creatures in the world, ≈øerve them with like pains and affection, and if you find them to be very poor, take nothing; for to them a little is a great deal: vi≈øit them al≈øo afterwards with diligence, that for the ≈ømall time wherein they keep their bed, you may be a≈ø≈øi≈øting to them in ≈øtrengthning and recovering of their healths. I charge thee, Daughter, that in all thy life thou never receive a Woman into thy hou≈øe to lie in; for that is but a kind of Panderi≈øm cloathed in ≈øome pretence of Charity; neither doth thy profe≈ø≈øion oblige thee to do it. If it chance to be a woman that is not wholly betaken to whoredom, that there is ≈øome hopes of recovering her from that lo≈øt condition; if then ≈øhe de≈øire you out of a belief of your ≈øufficiency, or ≈øecrecy, you may then go
to her in an hone≈øt place. You mu≈øt comfort her, if ≈øhe be afflicted, and put her in the right way, exhorting her never to commit the like again; but to receive ≈øuch per≈øons into your hou≈øe, is but a means to encourage evil: As the receivers of ≈øtollen goods are a means to encourage Thieves; even ≈øo, the Midwives that bring ≈øuch a ≈øtench to their hou≈øe, do a≈ø≈øi≈øt and abet the evil which they do, whil≈øt they know where to di≈øcharge them≈øelves of the like burthen again. At the fir≈øt when I took upon me this Calling, I took two into my hou≈øe, the one of Quality, the other of an ordinary condition; I ≈øaw them ≈øometimes in ≈øuch fits of de≈øpair, that I could hardly bring them out of them again. Tho≈øe from whom the evil came; upon who≈øe account I had received them, came now and then to ≈øee them, becau≈øe they brought them maintenance; I was continually fain to keep watch with them, for fear they ≈øhould do any evil in the hou≈øe: And I mu≈øt needs ≈øay, I had better have kept a herd of Swine. Such unre≈øts as the≈øe ought not to enter into the brea≈øt of a Midwife; for, her mind ought to be free and at peace. Be≈øides that, a cu≈øtom of laying Women of an ill life, ≈øpoyls the reputation of a Woman, and oft times endangers the health al≈øo. To confirm which, I knew an hone≈øt under≈øtanding Midwife, that laid a Courtezan that ≈øeemed to ail nothing at all; but ≈øhe, having an inveterated Pox, gave it to the old Midwife upon her right hand, upon which there came a red Bubo; for all which, being unwilling to leave off her Calling, ≈øhe ≈øpoyled after that above thirty Hou≈øholds; for the Husbands got the Pox from their Wives, and the Children from their Mothers

Now let me tell thee, Daughter, that thou oughte≈øt not to take it ill to ≈øee the condition of Midwives de≈øpi≈øed; neither let this hinder thy Studies in the perfections of this Art, which are not to be comprehended by tho≈øe
that de≈øpi≈øe it. Neither be di≈ømayed if thou ≈øee≈øt people in this condition, that do not de≈øerve to be; for this doth not at all dimini≈øh the honour of tho≈øe that are good: for it comes from hence to pa≈øs, becau≈øe they that receive them for mony, do as Stablers do, put the good and bad Hor≈øes together; the good Hor≈øes are in no danger to be hurt by the Jades, but the Jades are in hazard of being kickt and ≈øpoyled by the good Hor≈øes.

Never think of any think el≈øe but of doing well, and ≈øerving tho≈øe that ≈øhall call thee according to their own liking, if that which they de≈øire be not prejudicial to them, but if that which they de≈øire; be to their hurt, be ≈øure that thou di≈øcharge thy ≈øelf of them, and e≈øpecially excu≈øe thy ≈øelf to the a≈ø≈øi≈øtants, that thou may≈øt per≈øwade them to rea≈øon. A ≈øweet di≈øpo≈øition in a Midwife is much more commendable than a rigorous: the pain of Child-bearing is a very hard labour, which thou mu≈øt con≈øider, and accordingly conform thy ≈øelf to the humour of the Patient, knowing thy ≈øelf to be called to comfort and a≈ø≈øi≈øt her.

Mark well, entring into a hou≈øe, in what condition the Patient is; if the evil be at hand, you mu≈øt encourage her, and prepare your ≈øelf with tho≈øe things that are nece≈ø≈øary; and fir≈øt you mu≈øt ≈øee that the Bed be well made for the woman that is to be brought to bed, and then to put on her a little ≈ømock, and wa≈øte-coat, and other linnen nece≈ø≈øary: And if ≈øhe be ≈øo opinionated, as that ≈øhe will not; tell her how much you do it for the better; and how great a pain it will be afterwards; content her though, for you mu≈øt make of a bad Market no more then you can. You ought to give order for things to be had from the Apothecaries with her con≈øent; or if ≈øhe be young, with the con≈øent of her friends. You mu≈øt take order al≈øo that ≈øome good broth be made for her to take, in the time of her Travail, if it ≈øhould chance to be long; and al≈øo two hours after her being
brought to bed. Above all things I charge thee, that what ever bu≈øine≈øs thou mai≈øt have there, that thou go not about them too ha≈øtily. For there is nothing ≈øo nau≈øeous to be ≈øeen, as the improvident actions of over-bu≈øie women. Never be di≈ømayed if every thing go not well; for, fear di≈øorders the ≈øen≈øes; and a per≈øon that keeps her wits together, without ≈øuffering them to be ≈øcattered by fear, is capable of giving a≈ø≈øi≈øtance in weighty affairs, and e≈øpecially where things are done with lei≈øure; for in ≈øuch ca≈øes Nature helps marvellou≈øly, when we are mo≈øt at a ≈øtand. There is a great nece≈ø≈øity of prudence, e≈øpecially in the age wherein we live. There is now no need of Coloquintida to render any thing good in it ≈øelf, bitter and di≈øagreeable to the ta≈øte. There are few Women now a days that do give that re≈øpect, or have that kindne≈øs for them as in former ages; for then, when their Midwife died, they ≈øhewed a great deal of ≈øorrow, and prayed God that now they might have no more Children: which though it were not well done, yet it ≈øhewed their affection. Now adays, Women u≈øe them as meer Hirelings.

There is a great deal of artifice to be u≈øed in the plea≈øing of our Women, e≈øpecially the young ones, who many times do make election of Men to bring them to bed. I blu≈øh to ≈øpeak of them, for I take it to be a great piece of impudence to have any recour≈øe unto them, unle≈øs it be in a ca≈øe of very great danger. I do approve it, I have approved it, and know that it ought to be done, ≈øo that it be concealed from the Woman all her life long; nor that ≈øhe ≈øee the Surgeon any more: for it is very inconvenient to Husbands, that (unle≈øs in ca≈øes of very great danger) ≈øuch things concerning their own Wives ≈øhould be communicated to any other men but them≈øelves.

To this purpo≈øe ≈øhall I tell thee Daughter, that being called to the Labour of a Friend, where were none but
2 or 3 of her acquaintance, they asked me what I thought of the Labour: to which I an≈øwered, that the Child did not come well, but that I would do the work with the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of God, without danger to the Child, or to the Mother. They de≈øired me that I would let a Surgeon ≈øee her: for their ≈øatisfaction, I con≈øented to it; provided that ≈øhe might not ≈øee him; for I was fearful, le≈øt ≈øhe ≈øhould die with apprehen≈øion and ≈øhame; I per≈øwaded her to ≈ølide down toward the feet of the bed, and darkned the Room on that ≈øide where he was to come; at the feet he touched her, and ≈øhe was brought to bed without any other a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, ≈øave that of God and Nature. Since the≈øe injuries have bin put in fa≈øhion, there have bin ob≈øerved greater hazards and dangers in lying in than before, which might be remedied by per≈øons capable of their profe≈ø≈øion, if they might be let alone. But this Detraction is ≈øo much in reque≈øt, that among ≈øome kind of people, there is much ado to make them believe the truth, and e≈øpecially where they cannot get great advantage by ≈øo doing, and truly, Honourable per≈øons which I have had the honour to ≈øerve, make other women ≈øeem mon≈øtrous to me.
